Thys the land, loke wel therto, That ye shal departe at two, Atwyx√´ both√´, thogh that neuere, Whyl they lyu√´, may dysseuere. ‚ÄòAnd to thys tweyn√´, ansuerynge Ys thys swerd double-kervynge; Wher-with ye shal your wyt applye, Sowle & body to Iustefye, Whan ye sen yt be to do; As thus tak hed, I men√´ so: The Body, ffro hys synnes grete, Duely punysshe in cold & hete, Yive hym peyne, and ek penaunce, Consydred euery cyrcumstaunce: Travaylle, whan he ys to rage, Sende hym out on pylgrymage; Charge hym with fastyng & wakyng; So that alway answerynge The penaunce be to the trespace, Off equyte that yt not passe: Thus ye shal do, yiff ye be wyse. ‚ÄòBut in a-nother maner wyse Punysshen the spyryt ye shal also; As thus: taketh good hed ther-to: In dyuers caas ye mot consydre, And peysen euery thyng to-gydre: Yiff he be proud or obstynat, Dysobeyynge or ellaat, Hys trespace to amende, And ne lyst nat to entende To be redressed by meeknesse, And, thorgh pryde or Frowardnesse, Wyl tak√´ no correcc√Øon. Than may yow (in conclusyon) Tornen (to maken hym afferd,) The tother party off the swerd, Wych ys sharp, & whet ful kene, To wonde, & hurte, & parte atwene, And ful mortally to byte: Spareth nat ther-with to smyte, Lyk as ye may, by your power. ‚ÄòWherfor doth iustly your dever To smyte & hurte, for punysshyng, By the sharpe strook of cursyng; ffor wounde nor hurte ys noon so fel Nor noon so mortal nor cruel Nor mor peryllous to be drad; ffor Remedy may noone be had, Nouther salue, That soor to sownde But by hym that gaff the wounde, Or by A-nother (in certeyn) That ys a-bove, mor souereyn, Wych hath an hand, power, & myght, Hym to recure, (of verray ryght,) Serche the soor with-Inne & oute. Wherfore he sholde gretly doute, That so ys hurt, as I ha told, Wherso be he yong or old. Exaumple off the pereyl off cursyng. And to purpos in especyal: Yt fyl that oon offycyal In-to a gardyn onys wente, To gadre cheryes off entente, The fayrest that he koud√´ se, And clamb ful hih vp on A tre. But shortly, in hys comyng doun, Yt ffyl thus, (in conclusyon,) That a braunche hys surplys hente, And the cloth a-sonder Rente, Wher-of in hert he wex ful wroth; And, or he any ferther goth, Thus he seyde vn-to the tre, ‚ÄúNow,‚Äù quod he, ‚Äúcursyd mote thow be!‚Äù And wente hym forth, fer nor ner, Tyl vn-to the next√´ yer, To gadre cheryssh he kam a-geyn, And found the tre drye & bareyn. Off wych thyng he wex al sad, And in hys hert√´ no thyng glad, Whan he remembrede how that he Hadde a-forn cursyd that Tre. Wher-of he repenteth sore, And, with-outen any more He seyde, (or he ferther wente,) ‚ÄúI the assoylle, in myn entente. God wot, I ment√´ no thyng so, So gret√´ vengaunce to ha do: I ha mysdon; for-gyue yt me, ffor the dyffaute was nat in the. My-sylff, I may the Rentyng whyte, I knowe yt wel, & the aquyte.‚Äù And after the absolucyon Yt bar cheryes gret Foyson, Laden with frut fynaly, ffor tweyne, yt bar almost twenty; And heet hys full√´ with glad cher, Affter, euere, fro yer to yer; And neuere forgate, in hys lyvyng, The sentenc√´ off hys cursyng; ffor swych thyng, so as semeth me, Shulde nat lightly forgetyn be. ‚Äòffor they be foolys, in certeyn, That Reklesly of cursyng seyn, How that a man that cursyd be, That afferme of skorn, that he Hath hetyn hys sawle of whyt√´ bred. Off curs they take so lytel heed, Havyng no Reward, Thorgh ther synne, How the soule that ys with-Inne Ys off gostly frut, certeyn, Wonder drye, and ek bareyn, By the swerd of curs confoundyd, And so mortally ywoundyd, That yt may profyt neuer a dele To ber√´ frut (who lok√´ wel,) Of vertu, (I yow ensure,) ffor that yt lakketh moysture Off grace, wherby, (who kan espye,) Al vertu√´s fructefye. ‚Äòffor wych, folk shold√´ taken hede, The swerd of cursynge for to drede. I men√´ as thus specyally, Whan ther ys caus√´ iustly why, And he that doth yt, hath power To execute yt fer & ner, By ordynarye auctoryte. But yet to-forn (yt semeth me) He sholde consydren (in hys syth) Whan that he smyte, he smyte of ryht, And that hys caus√´ be not√°ble Or he procede to be vengable. ffor, I telle yow sykerly, No man ne smyteth duelly, With the sharp√´ for to kerue, But he to-forn ful wel obserue That he ferst with the platte assay, In goodly wys√´, what he may, Al that ys mys, for to redresse: ffor by the platte, I ther expresse Off thys swerd, and specefye, Prudent a-wys in prelacye, With good & trewe avys√´ment. ‚ÄòAnd fyrst, that he, in good entent, By trew√´ Ammonycyon And fructuous predicacyon, Or he smyte by violence, To let√´ pass√´ the sentence, The evele to smyten in sparynge, And spare hem also in smytynge. Thys was of Ihesu the doctryne, In whom lyth al the medycyne Off deth, whan men be woundyd so. ‚ÄòAnd taketh alway heed her-to, To vse the platt√´, nyh & ferre, Whan ye se your sogettys erre, Alder-fyrst; I men√´ thus, With doctryn√´ vertuous Tech√´, preche, & so begynne ffor to make hem leve ther synne. Yiff ye may folkys so recure That be woundyd, I yow ensure, Ther grevous woundys to allegge, Bet ys the platt√´ than the egge. ffor ech√´ leche that wel kan werche, Namly lechys of the cherche, That han manhys sowle in cure With plat they shold√´ fyrst recure, Rather than with the sharp√´ wounde, By ther charge, as they ar bounde. ‚ÄòNow haue ye herde & ye lyst se How ye shal vsen all√´ thre, The plat, the sharpe, & eke the poynt, I haue yow told, fro poynt to poynt; And rehersyd ek also In divers caas how ye shal do; Somtyme Iug√´ by vengaunce, Somme punyssh√´ by penaunce, Entrete somm√´ with ffayrnesse, Somme chastys√´ with sharpnesse, And for that skyle, the swerd, ywys, Ys y-callyd Versatylis; Wych ys to seyn, (oute of doute,) A thyng that men mowe torne abowte, Now the platte, (who kan take hede,) And the sharpe, whan yt ys nede. ‚ÄòAnd for thys skyles, off resoun Yt ys yput in your bandoun, Ay to be redy, (as yt ys skyle,) ffor to tourne yt at your wyl. Ther-to ye han power & myght, As the caas wyl suffre off ryht, Off verray trouthe & equyte. ‚ÄòAnd for that skyl√´, sothly ye, That in yow ther be no blame, Therfor ye trewly ber the name Cherubin, fful of scyence And off dyvyn√´ sapyence, ffor mysterye that ys ther-In. ‚Äòffor yiff ye wer nat Cherubin, Thys to seyne, in your werkyng Yiff ye ne haue nat ful konnyng, Ye myghte do ful gret outrage, Ryght gret harme, & gret damage; In stede off the platte & pleyn, Tournen the sharp√´ egge in veyn Correcte a caus√´ grene & newe, Deme, or ye the trouth√´ knewe, Off hast, with-out√´ good a-vys, Wych ys contrayre to your offys. ffor in the hand (yif yt be souht,) Off a fool that kan ryght nowht, A swerd ne shold√´ nat be take, Ryghtful doomys for to make; And in the hand off men yrous, To take a swerd ys peryllous. ffor thys swerd (yiff ye tak√´ hede,) Was bryht brennyng as the glede On euery part & euery syde, With flawme perpetuelly tabyde, To yow ytake, (take hed ther-to,) Off Grace Dieu nat longe ago. And cause why, of the brennyng, Yiff ye lyst to have knowelichyng, Was, that ye sholde, lyk your degre Ben ay in love & charyte; ffor loue brennyng in your desyr Ys shewyd by the bryght√´ fyr; And so to speke, in wordys fewe, Ye sholde alway your syluen shewe Wyth cherysshyng ffyr of plesaunce; ffor, yt wer a great meschaunce Yff Ire, in stede of charyte, Brent your hertys, (as semeth me.) Swych rag√´ ffyr (shortly to telle,) Was kyndlyd ffyrst, and kam from helle, And to your swerd, I dar Recorde, Noon swych fyr may nat accorde. ‚ÄòNow haue I told (ye sen yt wel,) Touchyng thys swerd euerydel; Why ye yt bere, & skyl√´ why. ffor ye be porterys verrayly Off the rewme of Paradys, Lych cherubin, prudent & wys. And the keyes ye han also To shette the gatys, & vndo; With-out√´ yow ther entreth noon, Nor may in at the gaatys gon, With-Inne to haue hys mansyoun. ‚ÄòSeyn Peter (of entencyoun) Hath mad yow (yiff ye vnderstonde,) Hys vnderlegatys, ther to stonde, To kepe the passage & entre; And at the gat√´ for to se Trussellys, ffardellys, in that place. Or any marchaunt in may passe, He mvste vntrusse hem & vnbynde, That no thyng be lefft be-hynde. How sore aforn that they yt close, ye muste hem make yt to vnclose By trew√´ reuelacyon And enter confessyon. ‚ÄòWherfor tak kep, & beth ryht wys, And seth to-forn, by good a-vys, The swerd, the key√´s ek also, How ye ha take hem both√´ two; And lat noon pass√´, (loketh wel,) But he vnclos√´ hys fardel. And also that ye wel provyde To cerche hem wel on euery syde, Thys synful folk, with pakkys large. Beth besy ay, hem to dyscharge; And weyeth wysly in balaunce, Consydryng euery circumstaunce, By good delyberacyon Demynge, in your dyscrecyon, Your verray name, & what ye hihte. And consydreth in your syhte, To dyscerne, in euery place, Affter the gylt & the trespace, To charg√´ synnerys, & constreyne, Mekly for to suffre peyne, And enioyne hem ther penaunce. ‚ÄòAnd whan ye sen ther r√©pentaunce Ye may to swych, erly & late, Opne du√´ly the gate Off Paradys, of verray ryht, By iust√´ tytle, thorgh your myght. ‚ÄòLo, her the sygnyfycacion, And trew√´ demonstracion Off swerd & key√´s, bothe yfere, Shortly, (yiff ye lyst to lere,) I ouerpasse & late yt gon, By-caus√´ folkys many on Han her-to-forn (who lok√´ wel,) Declaryd the mater euerydel, And what they tokne in ther wrytyng: Consydreth thys in euery thyng; Looke that ye yow nat excuse Your offyce trewly for to vse, So as ye ouht√´ dyscretly.‚Äô [The Pilgrim.] And whan that Resoun fynally Hadde told hyr tale, I herde al wel, And consydred euerydel, Talent I hadde, & gret desyr To haue that swerd√´, bryht as ffyr, And the key√´s eke y-ffere, Off entent (as ye shal here,) That I myghte ben an huissher, Or at the gate a porter, The passage to kepe of ryht Ther-on tawayt√´ day & nyht: This fantasye fyl in my thouht; But, God wot, I wyst√´ nouht, Nor knewe ful lytel (at the leste), What was the ffyn of my requeste, Nor took but lytel heed ther-to. And offt√´ tyme yt falleth so, That A man hath wyl ta thyng Wych neuere ys brouht to noon endyng, As men may offt√´ syth√´s se. ffor yiff the sonys of zebedee Hadde madd ther askyng ryhtfully They hadde ben herd ful hastyly: Off ther askyng, (as ye may lere,) And off al that they gan requere, Yt was ytornyd other wyse Than they, afor√´n, gan devyse: In the gospel ye may yt se And evene lyk yt ffyl of me, Whan I to Moyses gan gon, Besechyng hym that he, A-noon Wold√´ graunte, lyk myn askyng, The swerd and keyes to my kepyng, Off hem frely to haue vsage, ffor to kepen the passage. But whan that he had herd me wel, He fulfyllede neuereadel Lych the purpos of myn askyng, Nor thentent off my thynkyng: The swerd he took me in myn hond, But (as ye shal vnderstond,) Commyttyd so to my depoos That yt was alway styll√´ cloos In the skawberk, as I ha sayd, Wheroff I was nat wel apayyd. The key√´s also, stronge & wel Bounde & closyd vnder seel; And al was don off hih prudence, That I sholde hau√´ no lycence To vsen hem at lyberte, But yiff I hadde auctoryte ffrom hem that hadden al the charge. ffor yiff I vsede hem at large Mor than my power was or ys, As I was tauht, I dyde amys. Wher-off I was, ay mor & more Abaysshed, & astonyd sore, And specyally (to speke in pleyn,) That I to-forn hadd√´ nat seyn Som other folk ybound√´ so, In cas semblable as I was tho; Thynkyng (in myn entencyoun) That I wold√´ to Resoun Holden my way, off hyre tenquere, And the caus√´ iustly lere Off al thys thyng, for mor certeyn; And thus she Answerde me ageyn: Resoun Answerd: ‚ÄòMy ffayr√´ ffrend,‚Äô a-noon quod she, ‚ÄòLych as I consydre & se, Thy wyt ys blont & dul som del, That thow mayst nat se ryht wel; And thogh thow haue at skol√´ be, Thow hast nat ther (as semeth me,) Lernyd gret wyt, nor bore a-way; And specyaly (I dar wel say,) Thow hast nat lernyd, for al thy wyt, predicamentum ad aliquid. ffor thys predicament, sothly, Hath hys beholdyng (fynaly) Vnto som other maner thyng Than to hym sylff, as in werkyng Makyng (in conclus√Øon,) Hys ground & hys fundacyon Vp-on A-nother grounde, in soth: Thys predicament alway so doth. ffor what he hath (tak heed, my brother,) Nat off hym-sylff, but off a-nother He taketh yt, to be mor strong, And to no whiht ne doth no wrong. ‚ÄòAnd bere a-way thys in thy thouht, That yt were ytold for nouht, But he hys power (to speke in pleyn,) Tooke off A-nother (in certeyn); ffor off hym sylff yt may not be. Exaumple I wyl now lern√´ the That with thyn eyn√´ mor clerly Thow mayst be-holde yt openly. ‚ÄòWhan God Almyghty (yiff yt be souht,) Al thys world hadde maad off nouht, (As clerkys wel rehers√´ kan,) To-forn or he had makyd man, (Tak hed & lok√´ prudently,) He was ycallyd but God only, Yiff Genesis ne ly√´ nouht. But A-noon as man was wrouht, (Tak hed & mark√´ wel thys word,) Than was he callyd God & Lord, In tookne, (who that kan obserue,) He made a seruaunt hym to serue, Tho was he Lord, havynge lordshepe. And yet (who that taketh kepe,) Hys lordshepe was nat mor at al As ben thys lordys temporal, Gretter off domynacyon Whan they han in subieccyon Peplys at her lust to-beye: ffolk ar wont than to seye, That ther seruauntys & meyne Yiveth them power & powstee; So that (in conclus√Øon,) Ther myght & domynacyon, Off ther sogettys fyrst doth sprynge, And ys engendryd in werkyng. ffor yiff ther sogettys wer put away, Ther lordshepe (I dar wel say,) Sholde faylle, & ther power; And sogettys, wych they haven her To serven hem, and to obeye, Sholde ek fayll, I dar wel seye; ffor lordshepe pleynly ther wer noon, Yiff ther seruauntys wer agon. The name off servaunt ek also, Yiff that lordshepe wer ago, Muste ek faylle, as thow mayst se; ffor nouther party may nat be With-outen other (yt ys no drede). ‚ÄòBy wych exaumple (who taketh hede,) Lordshepe ys sayd especyally Off seruauntys; & ek trwly Seruauntys also namyd be Off lordshepe, in ther degre. And thus ys sayd, (haue thys ther-wyth,) Predicamentum ad aliquid. ffor eche off other hath gynnyng, And ys on other dependyng. Whan the Ton ys, than ys the tother; ffor yt ne may nat be noon other; Whan the Ton faylleth, ek also They muste ffayll√´ both√´ two. Vnderstond wel thys lesson, How thou art in subieccyon; Consydre how thow art ysett Vnder a-nother, and soget To hym, and mvstest hym obeye Wych hath also (I dar well saye) Vpon the(e) Iurediccyon, Power & domynacyon, As thy souereyn, what-euere he be. ‚ÄòBut o thyng deceyveth the: Thow hast no sogetys as hath he; ffor wych thyng (consydre & se,) Thow fayllest & art put a-bak. And in swych caas, thow hast gret lak To haue the swerd, bryht and cler, Commyttyd vn-to thy power, Out of the skawberk, yt to vse. Yt wer but veyn for the to muse Ther-vp-on, or gruchche ageyn. ‚ÄòThe key√´s also in certeyn, Thow mayst nat han hem, nor possede But vnder seel, (yt ys no dred.) The swerd also, (yt ys no dovte,) Yiff that yt wer drawen oute, Thow sholdest ther-with do ryht nouht. ffor yiff the trouth√´ be wel souht, Thow hast yt nouht in thy demeyne No thyng for to part at-weyne, Nouther to keru√´ nor to smyte. And shortly, (yiff I shal endyte,) Bet wer to the, Touchyng swych werk, To kepe yt cloos in the skauberk Than folyly thy-sylff to bolde, Out off the skauberk yt to holde; ffor ffolkys wold√´ deme off ryht, Ther-off whan they hadde a syht, Yt wer no wysdom, but foly, And a maner Surquedy, Whan they be-held√´ euerydel, The keyes nat closyd vnder seel, Syth thow (with-outen any glose,) Mayst nouther shett√´ nor vnclose, Yt longeth nat to thyn offys. ‚Äòffor wych, lern√´ to be wys, And se how they wer taken cloos, And vnder seel in thy depoos, Knet & bound√´ faste & strong, That thow with hem ne do no wrong. Thy power ferther doth nat strecche, Wher-off thow sholdest no thyng rechche, Yiff thow wer wys, as semeth me. ‚ÄòAnd Tak also good heed, & se, Off al that I to-forn ha sayd: Thow sholdest be ryht wel a-payd Off thy power, & nat ne stryve, Thogh thow neuere in al thy lyve Haddest no lordshepe mor at al. And for to speke in specyal, Yt ouhte ynowh to the suffyse, As I shal to the devyse, Thy-sylff for to gouerne a-ryht, Dyschargyd off euery other whyht. Than artow prudent, dout√´les; And for thys skyl√´, Moyses,‚Äî ‚ÄòWych in hys tyme was wys & old,‚Äî Took hem to the, as I ha told, To fyn only (to speke in pleyn) That he, as lord & souereyn, May, whan hym lyst, as thow shalt lere, Whan that tyme doth yt requere, The key√´s closyd vnder sel, He may to the vnbynd√´ wel; The swerd also, by tytle of lawe, Mak√´ that thow shalt yt drawe Out off the skauberk, fer nor ner, Lych as thow hast off hym power, Sogett alway to hys sentence And as the caas graunteth lycence. Hys power he may commytte To the, ffro wych thow mayst nat flytte. ffor as I shal to the devyse, Yiff thow dydyst other wyse Thow sholdest offende ful gretly, Pereyl off deth except only, Wych ys a cause evydent That thow mayst wel (& nat be shent,) The swerd ydrawe, (tak hed her-to,) And the keyes vnbynde also. ffor nede & gret necessyte Lycence grauntyd vnto the Plentevously, & ek vsage, Consydryd with the surplusage, Pre-supposyd ther be no whyht To whom the offyce sholde of ryht Appertene off duete. I men√´ thus,‚Äîtak hede & se; Marke yt wel in thyn entent,‚Äî That he be nat ther present Wych halt the swerd (now vnderstond,) Bare & nakyd in hys hond, And the keyes vnbounde also, Off ryht, as he ouht√´ do, Thys he that haueth pleyn power, (Who kan looke with eyen cler,) And haueth Iurediccyon Above, & domynacion, And ys the ryght ful relatyff, To whom, with-out√´ noyse or stryff, Thow art soget, & vnder put To hym allone: & trewly, but Thow hym obeye, thow art Coupable; ffor yiff thow, in cas semblable, Haddest sogettys vnder the, Thow myhtest wel (lyk thy degre,) Don as he doth in all√´ thyng, And fulfyll√´ in werkyng. Thanne folwede yt a-noon forth-wyth, Thy power wer Ad aliquid; But thow hast noon, (as semeth me,) Wheroff thow ouhtest glad to be, And in thyn hert√´ ful Ioyous.‚Äô The pylgrym argueth: ‚ÄòMa dame,‚Äô quod I, ‚Äòmost vertuous, (Yiff ye lyst to her√´ me,) I have seyn, & alday se, Som folkys (in conclusyon) That hadden in subiecc√Øon) Sogetys noon, nor gouernance, And yet they dyde hem sylff avaunce, And wer ther-off no thyng afferd, Nakyd for to bere the swerd. To whom also yt ys wel founde That the key√´s wer nat bounde, But redy euere (beth wel certeyn,) Tvnshetten & to shette ageyn Lokkys echon (yt ys wel wyst,) And entrede whan that euere hem lyst. At all√´ tyme they be redy, Shette and vnshette hardyly. The cause to me vn-knowen ys; And yet I dar afferm√´ thys, They ha no mor power than I; ffor wych they han, al sodeynly, Astonyd myn oppynyoun. ffor yiff ther be Relacyoun Yfound√´ there, I dar wel say That yt ys ystole a-way.‚Äô Resoun Answereth. Resoun answerde ageyn to me: ‚ÄòTake heed and vnderstond,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòThe Formere off the high hevene, And maker off the Sterres Sevene Hath so ordeyned all√´ thynges, That they shal, in her meuynges, Holden ther cours swyfft or soffte, Lyk as the bodyes hih a-loffte, Lyst ordeyn√´, (who kan knowe,) So that erthly thyng√´s lowe Receyv√´ dysposicyons Off hem, & ek impressiouns, To be gouernyd (in sentence) Affter the hevenly influence, Dyversly, ech in hys kynde, Who the causys kan out fynde Off ther dyuers mocyouns Thorgh naturel Inclynaciouns. Yet for al thys, yt lettyth nouht, But that the Lord, wych al hath wrouht, Hath lordshep√´ sovereyne, What hym lyketh to ordeyne, As the Lord most pryncypal With-outen any mene at al: In heuene, Erthe, or in the se, So as hym lyst, yt must√´ be. Off hevenly bodyes cyrculer, He stant no thyng in ther daunger; But he may do, thys myghty kyng, What-euere hym lyst, in hys werkyng, hih a-loffte, & her don lowe, Thogh the hevene no-thyng knowe The Influence of hys power, Wych ys so myghty & ent√©r, That no whyht may yt comprehende ‚ÄòHow fer hys power doth extende, Was neuere yet noon so gret clerk. ‚ÄòAnd thogh the heuene, touchyng his wark Hadde any maner knowelychyng To comprehendyn hys werkyng, Yt shold√´ nat so hardy be To gruchche ageyn hys deyete. But I speke in wordys pleyn, Humblely with Davyd seyn Touchyng hys myght wych doth excelle, ‚ÄòLat the heuene hys glorie telle, Hys laude, hys honour, & preysyng, And yive worshepe to hys werkyng. And also (in hys best entent) Lat also the fyrmament Hys handwerk devoutly preyse, And day-by-day hys honour Reyse In laude & prys ful many fold.‚Äô ‚ÄòBut caus√´ why that I ha told Thys thyng to the thus, by-&-by, I shal reherse the cause her why. The hih√´ hornyd, most holy, Callyd in erth√´ comounly Off God the chos√´ cheff vyker, And hys plac√´ kepeth her, And doth yt pleynly occupye,‚Äî The wych, no man wyl denye;‚Äî Yet thogh thys vyker, aboue echon Haue power off yore agon, Aboven euerych other whyht, And wolde the cours (of verray ryht) Off hys myghty excellence Wher doun shad by influence To other lowere of degre Commytted from hys souereyn se, Whom he ordeyneth her & yonder By commyssyon to be vnder Hys high power by Ordynaunce For to haven Governaunce (Who that kan the trouth√´ seke) ‚ÄòTo bere the swerd, and key√´s eke, So that by her dyscrecion And prudent mediacyon All thynge vnder ther myghte Wer gouernyd wel by Ryht, Wych to hem dooth apertene Vnder entent pur & clene, Affter the bond off ther offys. ‚ÄòBut nat for-thy, yet for al thys, Ther ys no caus√´ but that he Wych that hath the souereynte, The cheff vyker above echon, Off verray ryght, & other noon, Ys curat (in conclus√Øoun, With-oute al mediac√Øoun,) Ouer crystys folkys alle. Yt may noon other-wys√´ falle, Off verray ryght, I the ensure. Al-be that he, vnder hys cure Haue set by hy commyssyon, Somme folkys of relygyon, Hys offys to excersyce Vnder hym in sondry wyse; Hem establysshed, with power large, ffor to helpe hym ber hys charge; In hys name, or elles nouht ffor what they do, or what ys wrouht, ffro hym the power ys descendyd, The wrong by hym mot be amendyd, Yiff ther be any in ther werkyng. ‚ÄòAnd therfore, touchyng thys thyng, (To seyn shortly, & nat tarye,) They be nat but ordynarye, Commyttyd, ther offys for to do, Thogh thow sest hem both√´ two Ber swerd And key√´s in ther hond Naked & vnclosyd; yet vnderstond, They ha nat stole hem, fer nor ner, ffor they hadd√´ pleyn power Off the vyker pryncypal, ‚ÄòWych aboue gouerneth al, That gaff to hem ther power with Predicamentum ad aliquid. They tooke yt (who consydereth al) Off hys gyffte in especyal; And whan hym lyst, (yt ys no nay) He may ageyn take yt away, Whan that he seth tyme & place. ffor thyng that grauntyd ys off grace May be Restreyned efft ageyn In many caas, be wel certeyn. And thogh thow haue no swyche power, Thow sholdest, with al thyn herte enter, To Ihesu Cryst, in thyn entent, Thanke of that he hath the sent; fferther nat medle than thyn offys; ffor I holde, he ys nat wys, That in medlyng ys mor large Than the boundys of hys charge.‚Äô Off the Sacrament off the Awhter: And whan thys lady, Dame Reson, Touchyng myn oppynyon, Hadde declaryd vnto me, Ryht forth-with I dyd√´ se, (As I be-held tho douteles,) That the hornyd Moyses Shope hym Ryght as any lyne To make redy & go dyne, And hys mete ek redy make. And tho, good heed I gan take How hys mete (pleynly to deme,) Was other than yt dyd√´ seme; And off √≥ thyng, as I took heed, Ther was no thyng but wyn & bred, The wych wer nat to hys entent; ffor tho he hadd√´ gret talent To etyn fflesshe, in hys delyt, And blood ek in hys appetyt, ffor to dyfface the old√´ lawe, And the Ryytys ther-off with-drawe; Wych lawe (as I vnderstood,) Bad men they sholde ete no blood. But Moyses‚Äîin hys entent, Contrayre to that comandement, To helpyn hym Among hem alle,‚Äî Grace Dieu be-gan to calle; And she kam forth A-noon ryht. And ther I sawh a wonder syht, Mor merveyllous than euere aforn I hadde seyn syth I was born. ffor ther I sawh, (as I took heed,) In-to Rawh fflessh√´, tornyd bred; Grace Dieu ordeynede yt so. And wyn (I took good heed ther-to,) Was tornyd ek in-to Red blood. The wych (so as I vnderstood,) Sempte of a lambe, as thouht√´ me. And, as A man curteys & fre, Hys offycerys he gan calle, And bad they shold√´ komen alle Vn-to dyner; & ek hem tolde The maner hooly how they sholde Han myght & power enterly ffor to maken al redy The dyner al so wel as he, At du√´ tyme, in ther degre. And as they weryn at dyner, To hem he gaff pleynly power To maken (in conclus√Øon) That merveyllous mutacion, Bred in-to flesshe, wyn in-to blood. And off that foode (I vnder-stood) He Gaff to etyn to hem alle (Wych to-forn he dyd√´ calle,) Thys new√´ met√´ most vnkouth, Mynystrng yt in-to ther mouth. With hem, hym-sylff he heet also, And of the blood he drank ther-to. I sawh yt with myn Eyen cler. But swych a merveyllous dyner Ne was neuere a-forn yseyn, Nor neuere (that I herd√´ seyn,) Ne was no swych mutacyon, Nor off so wonderful Renoun. But whan I hadde be-holden al, I tornede me A-noon with-al To-ward that lady dame Resoun, Makynge to hyr thys questyoun: The pylgrym: ‚ÄòMa dame,‚Äô quod I, ‚ÄòI yow preye That ye to me lyst to seye: What semeth yow, telle on pleynly.‚Äô Resoun koude nat answere. ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthat wyl not I, ffor ther-of I kan no thyng; Yt passeth myn vnderstandyng, My wyt also, & ek my mynde. To sen, myn Eyen ben to blynde; I se no mor ther-off then thow; And I am so astonyd now, Mor than euere I was a-fore, Syth tym√´ that I was bore. ffor yiff that she (I dar wel say) Hadde ymakyd off an Ay A bryd with ffethres for the flyht, Or that she hadd√´, thorgh hyr myght, Off a lytel barly greyn Makyd an Er large & pleyn, Thys ylkede Ornede Moyses, I wolde han be stylle & in pes, And ther-off han take noon heed. But [s]he hath mad Rauwh fflessh of bred, Wherof I am falle in rage. And also of that beuerage, That [s]he hath tornyd wyn to blood, My sylff beholdyng, ther I stood, Ageyn the custom of nature. And trew[√´]ly, I the ensure, That I shal no lenger dwelle, But to Nature the trouth√´ telle, And sendyn hyre to be A-wreke To Grace Dieu, with hyr to speke, With cher boystous, wordys nat ffayre, Vnto whom she ys contrayre. ffor she hath, (yiff I shal not lye,) Off pryde only, & surquedye, Lyft the custom & vsage, And off nature the passage Transcendyd pleynly, & the boundys; And in dede, ek yt founde ys That she hath, of force & myght, Broke hyr franchyse & hyr ryht.‚Äô The Pylgrym: And whan Resoun hadde told me thys, Sche A-noon retournyd ys In-to hyr tour vp hih ageyn. And thanne A-noon, vp-on the pleyn I sawh a lady off gret age, The wych gan holden hyr passage Towardys Grac√´ Dieu in soth, And off hyr port I-rous & wroth, And hyr handys ek of pryde Sturdyly she sette a syde. Hyr Eyen ek (I took good hede,) Brennyng bryht as any glede; Wonder large off hyr feature, Trowynge that she was Nature: And so she was, thys lady old, ffor Resoun hadde vn-to me told Hyr maner and condycioun. And, to myn inspecc√Øoun, Sche was redy for to stryve, ffor Anger dyde hyr hert√´ Ryve Atweyne, in purpos for to chyde; Hyr handys set vnder hyr syde. And vn-to Grac√´ Dieu A-noon Thys old√´ lady ys forth gon; And Rudly fyrst she gan abrayde, And vn-to Grac√´ Dieu she sayde: ‚ÄòDame,‚Äô quod she Right of Entent ‚ÄòAs yee stonden her present, Wher-so that yee be leeff or loth, With youre gou√©rnaunce I am wroth, That ye be bold, in any wyse ffor to medle of my fraunchyse. And I am kome, as ye may se, To dyffende my lyberte. Vn-to yow yt ys nat due My ordynauncys to remeue. Record I take off all√´ wyse, Yt outhe ynowgh to yow suffyse The party that ye han ytake, And no maystry√´s for to make In the boundys that I kepe. ‚Äòffor, thogh ye han the lordshepe Off the heuene & euery spere, And off the sterrys bryht & clere, And off the planetys hih a-loffte, Somme swyfft & somm√´ soffte Holdyng ther cours & ther mevyng, And as ye lyst in all√´ thyng They stonden all in your demeyne, Ther cours, as ye lyst, ordeyne. Ouer hem ye han the souereynte; And yiff I wold√´ medle me Towchyng ther cours, or how they goth, With me ye wold√´ be ful wroth, And my presumpc√Øon despyse. And I, ryht in the sylu√´ wyse, Yiff ye medlede wrongfully Touchyng the boundys of my party, Ther to cleyme off me lordshepe, My fredam I wold√´ kepe. Rather than suffren any wrong, I wold√´ deye, thogh ye be strong; ‚ÄòTrusteth thys ryght wel at al. ‚ÄòAnd declare to yow I shal, Now that ye & I be met, The trew√´ boundys that be set Atwyxe vs tweyne, syth go ful long, That noon to other do no wrong; Wych to yow I shal devyse, And declar√´ the fraunchyse Off outher part, yiff ye lyst lere, That noon ne medle, fer nor nere, To have lordshepe off othrys ryht, Nouther by forc√´ nor by myght. ‚ÄòAnd yiff ye lyst to lerne yt sone, The cercle off the cold√´ moone, Atwyxen yow & me for evere The boundys trewly doth dysseuere, And yiveth to euerych hys party; Yiff ye lyst look Ryghtfully As I shal declare now: The hiher part longeth to yow, Wher ys your lordshepe & your myght, And ye may ther (off verray ryght) Maken thyng√´s fresshe of hewe, And whan ye lyst, transforme hem newe; Your power ys so vertuous; ffor thogh ye mad√´ dame Venus A best with hornys sharpe & hard, I wolde ther-to ha no Reward. And thogh that ye, (yt ys no fayl,) Off Mercury√´ made a snayl I wold√´ me nat putte in pres To gruchche, but kepe me stylle in pes; ffor ther I cleyme no maner ryht. ‚ÄòBut her by-nethe, ys al my myght; Off ellementys I am maystresse, Lady also & pryncesse Off wyndys and inpressyouns, And mak√´ transmutacyouns, Many wonder varyance. ‚Äòffor I ha the gouernaunce Off fyr, of heyr, (as ye may se,) Off erthe, and off the larg√´ se, Off ther accord & ther debate; I leue no thyng in on estat, But mak√´ eche thyng, by declyn, ffor to draw√´ to hys ffyn. I make alday thyng√´s newe The olde, refresshyng off her hewe. The erthe I cloth√´, yer by yer, And refresshe hym off hys cher Wyth many colour of delyte, Blewh & gren√´, Red & whyt, At prym√´ temps, with many a flour. And al the soyl, thorgh my fauour Ys clad of newe; medwe & pleyn And hill√´s hih, ek spyce & greyn I mak√´ to enspyre soote, And do the bawme, out of the Rote In-to the crop a-ryse & sprynge. ‚ÄòAnd in-to tr√´es ek I brynge Ther lusty blosmys whyte & rede; And in ther braunchys ek I sprede A-brood myn fressh√´ vestymentys, And with myn vnkouth paramentys I cloth√´ ham wyth buddys glade, Wych, with wynter, dede I made, Thorgh constreynt of hys coldys kene, Tornyng to russet al the grene With fretyng of hys bytter cold. ‚ÄòBut al that wynter maketh old, And with hyr stormys doth desteyne, I make yt fresshe & yong ageyn; The bromys with ther golden floure, That wynter mad√´ (with hys shour) Nakyd and bare, dedly of hewe, With levys I kan cloth hem newe; And off the feld the lyllyes ffayre, And off herbys many a payre, That wynter slowh with hys constreynt, ‚ÄòAnd made hem of ther colour ffeynt, ffor no cost, me lyst not spare, But ther Rychesse I do repare,‚Äî Whan hete off cold hath the victorye,‚Äî That Salomon in al hys glorye Was nat clad (I dar wel sey) Halff so freschly as ben they; Nor hys rob√´s wer nat lyche Off colour to the busshes Ryche, Wych be clad in my lyffree, ffro yer to yer, as ye may se. ‚ÄòAnd who that taketh hed ther-to, Al thyng that men se me do, I do by leyser, by and by: I am nat Rakel nor hasty; I hate, in myn oppynyouns, Al sodeyn mutacyouns; My werkys be the bettre wrouht, Be caus√´ that I hast√´ nouht: I take rec√≥rd of dame Reson. ‚ÄòAnd also ek in no seson I slep√´ nouther day nor nyht; ffor, of custom & of ryht, I hate al maner ydelnesse, Ouer al wher I am maystresse. I am nat slowh, thorgh-out the yer, To do my werk & my dever Affter my power & konnyng; And I make, with my werkyng, Man & womman to speke a-ryht Euery language, thorgh my myght; ffovlys to flen, I teche also, And euery best√´ for to go; ffysshes to swymmen in the see, ‚ÄòAnd I make ek (as ye may se,) Serpentys on the grovnd to krepe; And all√´ greyn√´s ek I kepe, Make hem groven in ther guyse, And al ther sesouns I devyse. And yiff I shal the trouthe expresse, I am lady & maystresse Off al the Erth√´, who lyst knowe. ‚ÄòBut ye wolden holden lowe My power, (yt ys no doute,) Yiff ye myghte yt brynge a-boute, fful wrongfully, ageyn al ryht, And apallen ek my myght At your fre choys; thys the ffyn; Tourne vnkynd√´ly my wyn In-to blcod, folk for to drynke; The wych√´ doth me sore a-thynke, And fret myn hert√´ so with rage That ye do me swych outrage, So nyh vn-to myn herte yt sytte: And yt passeth ek my wyt, Your governaunce in thys matere. ‚ÄòTouchyng bred, ye shal wel lere, (To speken in especyal,) I am not so wroth with-al, Nor gruchche (in myn oppynyoun) Off thylk√´ mutac√Øoun, Be cause that I (who taketh hed,) Medlede neuere to mak√´ bred, Croste nor krom√´, al my lyve. But I dar afferme her blyve, Thogh I neuere mad√´ looff, The mater that yt ys made off Kometh fro my corn & greyne; And I delyuered hem, certeyn, Vn-to Crafft, wych I assure Ys soget vn-to Nature. Thogh she yt made by hyr engyn, The mater ffyrst was pleynly myn, And kam fro me, yt ys no drede. ‚ÄòBut that ye han thus turnyd bred In-to Rawh fflesshe at your dyner, In preiudyce off my power, To forbarre me of my ryht,‚Äî Wher hadde ye power outher myght To werk√´ so ageyn my lore? I may suffren yt no more. I ha forboor yow many day, And suffryd ek (yt ys no nay,) Wrongys that ye ha do to me. I not by whos auctoryte, That ye, by your gouernauncys, My custommys & myn ordynauncys‚Äî Ageyn Resoun and al skyl‚Äî Ye han ytournyd at your wyl. I haue hem wel in R√©membraunce, With euery maner cyrcumstaunce. ‚Äòffyrst, contrayre to myn entent, The busshe affyre, & nat brent, How ye yt made ful longe ago. And I remembre wel also Off Aaron & of Moyses, How that ye, ageyn my pes, Ther yerdys, both√´ old & drye, Ye maden, thorgh your maystrye, The Toon a serpent (ys yt nat so?) In presence of Kyng Pharaoo; The tother, ye made wexe al grene With frut & levys, (thus I mene,) Budde and blosme, with many flour, To myn vnworshepe & dyshonour, Ageyns nature, at the leste. And ye tournede, at the feste Off on callyd Architeclyn, Water also in-to good wyn. And also many A-nother thyng, Thorgh your wonderful werkyng Ye han ywrouht ageynys kynde. ‚ÄòAnd o thyng cometh now to mynde, Wherwyth ye dyde myn hert√´ tene, ‚ÄòThat ye made a mayd√´ clene To bere a chyld, by your art, And of man hadde neuere part. To me ye dide to gret A wrong; And I ha suffryd al to long That ye, a-mong thys werkys alle, Lyst me nat to consayl calle. Wher-of, whan I dide aduerte, I hadde gret sorwen yn myn herte; Thogh I made no noyse at al, I gruchchede in especyal A-geyn your werkys wonder stronge: A man may suffren al to longe, As I ha don, or that he speke; And abyde or he be wreke; Slepe to long, or he a-wake; Suffren, or he vengaunce take; And I ha ben to longe in pes, And in maner Rekk√´les To suffre wrong, & took noon hede Off al that ye ha done in dede. ‚ÄòAnd now ye ben ykome ageyn, Off entent to make in veyn New√´ thyng√´s men may se, Only to excyt√´ me Ageyns yow, both nyh & ferre, To be wroth, & gynne a werre, And to be with yow at debat. And, ne wer the gret estat That ye be off, trusteth me wel, I wolde spar√´ neueradel Yow to werreye & oppresse, That ye ha swych hardynesse ffor to chaungen myn vs√°ges, And lyst nat, thorgh your gret outr√°ges, Off equyte, to myn avayl, ffor to calle me to counsayl, Wher-off I am riht wele apayd.‚Äô And whan Natur√´ hadde al sayd, Grac√´ dieu ful sobyrly, (That herde hyr tal√´ by and by,) Nat hastyly, but by mesure, Thus Answerd√´ to Nature: Grace Dieu answerde: ‚ÄòYe ben,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòto cruel, To hasty also, and to fel Ageyns me, in your language. ffor ye speke by gret outrage Proudly to me, & ha no feere, Lych sothly as thog ye were In party dronken of your wynes Wych that groweth on your vynes. Ye resemble by your mood And by your port, as ye wer wood. And for ouht that I kan se, Ye be sottyd (thus semeth me) Off newe, & I wot nat how. ‚ÄòRemembreth what ye spake ryht now, And how ye sayde to me pleynly, ‚ÄòThat ye wer nat to hasty In your werkys, fer nor ner; But that ye wrouht al be leyser, And in your werkys dyde tarye.‚Äô And I se now the contrarye In your persone folyly. ffor ye to me, ful nyc√´ly, Al that euere ye dide expresse, Was ysayd off hastynesse, With-outen any gret avys, Lyk as thogh ye wer nat wys; Your wordys nat in ordre set, Rancour, your Resoun hath so let. And, trewly, nadd√´ be That I concevede, & dyde se Your sodeyn Ire & your Rancour, And also for myn owne honour, I hadde yow voyded A-noon ryht, And booden yow gon out of syht. But folkys wych that ben Irous, Hasty & malync√≥lyous, ‚ÄòOther folk, that wys√´ bene, Mot forbern hem in her tene, Be-cause they kan hem nat gouerne; And ek for they kan nat dyscerne A thyng clerly in ther entent. ffor ther trouble, entendement Ys with Ire yblynded so, That they wot nat what they do. To sen a trouthe, they nat entende, ffor they kan nat comprehende, Thorgh ther obstynat blyndnesse, No thyng but off wylfulnesse: It stondeth thus, I dar assure. ‚ÄòBut tel me now, dam√´ Nature, Touchyng that ye, her in thys place, Rebuk√´ me off my trespace, And vndernemen and repreve, And outragously your-sylven greue Off offencys I scholde ha do; And affermen ek also, Your fraunchys√´ to avaylle Off boundys & off botaylle: I men√´ thus, of boundys set, By mesour tryed out & met A-twyxe the ryht of yow & me, And seyn, ‚ÄòA-geyn your lyberte That I dyd√´ gret offence To entre, & hadde no lycence, In-to your gardyn al to sone, Vnder the cercle off the moone, Wych to yow allone ys fre.‚Äô I pray yow, answere ageyn to me, (Say the trouthe, so God the saue!) Off whom holde ye that ye haue, Your lordsh√©pe & euery del? Ye Resemble (who lok√´ wel,) Vn-to the wyld√´ swyn savage, Wych that renneth in hys rage In the woodys large & grene, And ne kan no ferther sene ‚ÄòBut to the frut that he hath founde, And the Acornys on the grounde, ffor to fille hys hongry mawe. ffor he, in hys swynys lawe, Off hys rudnesse bestyal, Ne kan no ferther se at al Toward the hevene, nor the tre Wher he receyveth hys plente, That bar the frut for hys repast, Al that ys from hys mynd√´ past; ffor to the acorn al only, And to hys ffood√´ fynally Ys set hys herte & al hys thouht; ffor he in soth ne recchet nouht Off alle the surplus neueradel. ‚ÄòAnd trew[√´]ly ye may ryht wel Vn-to thys swyn resembled be, Wych kan not be-holde or se, Nor of malys, nor dysdeyn, Lyst nat knowen in certeyn Off whom ye han al your power With-Inne your boundys, fer or ner. With-out√´ me ye ha no thyng; Nor al your crafft nor your werkyng, With-out√´ me may nat avaylle. Yovr werkys alle I sowbpowaylle, And hem supporte, yif ye ha mynde. ‚ÄòVndoth your Ey√´n dyrk & blynde, The Eyen of yovr entend√´ment; And, by good avys√´ment, The lyddys off your Eye vncloseth! Knoweth wel (and nat supposeth) I am lady, hool & entere; And ye be but my chamberere: Thys shal ye fynde al openly Yiff ye looke avys√´ly. Leve your wordys hih aloffte, And lerneth for to spek√´ soffte, And Renounceth al your rage; ffor ye sholde me don homage ‚Äò(Off Iustyce and equyte), ffor th√°t ye holde, ye holde of me. ffor long agon, a gret partye, I gaff to yow (of curteysye) To occupye your sylff alway, Off entent that, nyht nor day, That ye sholde nat ydel be, And that ye sholde, a-geyn to me Yelde accountys off euery thyng Touchyng the fyn of your werkyng, As a chamberere (in sothnesse) Sholde vnto hire mayst[e]resse. And therfore, yiff ye wer wys, Ye shold√´ nat in your avys Speke of boundys in no degre Set be-twyx√´ yow & me. The boundys c√≥nstreyne your party; But, for al that, I go frely Wher that me lyst, at lyberte: They bound√´ yow, & no thyng me; Close yow out, that ye nat passe; But I go fre in euery place; In heuene, in erthe, & in the se I bound√´ yow, & ye not me. Wer yt offend√´ yow or greue, I take of yow no maner leue, To go & medle wher I shal: Ye ha no thyng to do with al. ‚ÄòI do ryht nouht in my werkyng But as yt ys ryht wel syttyng Off equyte & ryhtwysnesse. ffor she that ys a mayst[e]resse Muste haue a seruaunt hyr to-beye: I trowe ye kan yt not with-seye. And ye ouht to know ek wel That ye ha power neueradel With-out√´ me, on no party. I wyl shew√´ good skyle why, Vp-on the wordys that ye ha sayd, So ye wyl nat ben euele apayd. Ye seyde, ‚Äòthe mevyng of the hevene And the planetys all√´ seuene Longen to me pleynly in al; And how ther cours celestyal, I haue yt hol in gouernaunce; And how that I, at my plesaunce Tourne the hevene Round abowte. ‚ÄòThanne I axe of yow thys doute: Yiff I now made a new√´ pley, ffor to take the sonne away Doun fro the heuene a-noon ryht, That no man of hym hadde a syht Thys hundryd yer, in no manere, Nor that hys bryht√´ bemys clere Ne wer nat seyn: answere here-to, What maner thyng√´s myghte ye do? Or wheroff sholde ye ha socour, To brynge forth outher herbe or flour? Or fostre your sedys, blosme, or greyn? Or with new√´ grene a-gayn Clothen the busshes in ther maner As ye ar wont fro yer to yer, By yerly reuoluc√Øouns? ‚ÄòAnd touchyng generac√Øouns, What power ha ye ouht to do, Yiff the sonn√´ wer ago? Al sholde faylle, yt ys no nay. And syth√´ go ful many a day, The paynym Arystotyles, Wrot & expressede douteles, That was so noble & prudent, Preveth ful wel by argument, By trouth also, & good Reson, That al generacyon Ys susteyned by the sonne. Whan the sky√´s dyrke & donne Ben devoyded a-way clene, With hys bemys bryht & shene, That on erthe wer no bryhtnesse, I take your clerk vn-to wytnesse, ‚ÄòArystotyle, in thys debaat, ffor to ben myn aduocaat A-geyns yow in thys matere. ffor your power al yfere Wer lost & gon (shortly to fyne,) Yiff no sonne ne dyd√´ shyne. ffor your power wer al shent, Yiff the Round√´ fyrmament, The plan√©tys, & ech spere, And the bryht√´ sterrys clere, Yiff I hem maade to cesse echon, Than wer your power clene agon, A-batyd, & set a-syde. Wher-vp-on, lat be your pryde, And gruchchet nat ageyn[e]s me, Syth I ha the sovereynte, Lordshepe, & domynac√Øoun. ‚ÄòAnd yt wer abusyoun‚Äî Lych as wryteth Ysaye, And in hys book doth specefye, A gret despyt (both fer & ner)‚Äî Yiff a-geyn the carpenter The Ex wer bold, by surquedye, ffor to holden chauntpartye. Yt wer a thyng ageyn[e]s kynde, In Holy Wryt as ye shal fynde, And a thyng off gret dysdeyne, And yiff the pot sholde also seyn To the potter that hym wrouhte, And hys forme a-bout√´ brouhte, Yiff he pleynede off hys makyng, Touchyng hys fason and werkyng, Yt wer a thyng nat covenable. ‚ÄòAnd evene lyk in cas semblable Ye argue ageyn[e]s me, Wych in effect nat ellys be (ffor al your sotel argument) But myn handwerk & instrument, Wych I ha mad to helpen me, Nat off no necessyte, ‚ÄòThat I off yow (yiff ye take hede,) Sholde haue any maner nede Among my gret√´ werkys alle, But only whan me lyst yow calle. ‚ÄòAnd many a thyng I haue ek wrouht, To wych I ne callede yow nouht. Yt nedede nat the caas so stood: And I shal chaung√´ wyn to blood With-oute your counsayl or your red, And in-to Rawh flessh, ek whyt bred, And brown also, whan that me lyst, Thogh off yow yt be nat wyst. ‚ÄòThe cause ys, in conclus√Øoun, Off thys ylke mutac√Øoun, At myn own√´ lust yt dresse; And ellys ne wer I no maystresse, But yiff I hadd√´ lyberte To don al thyng that lyketh me With-out√´ labour at myn ese, Wych shold√´ yow nat dysplese, Thogh I do thyng (tak hed her-to,) Wych your-sylff ne may nat do; Therof ye sholden ha dysport, And in your hert√´ gret coumfort, As of the bussh, wych to the syht Sempte as yt hadde brent ful bryht, And brent nat, as I ha sayd; Wher-of ye sholde be wel apayd, And thank me of entenc√Øoun Only for the savac√Øoun, Rather than chyde, or lowd√´ crye Off rancour & mal√©ncolye, Off hast to be so Rekk√´les. ‚ÄòAnd off the yerd of Moyses And off Aaron, wher-on ye pleyne; And off that Mayd√´ souereyne, Mayde & moder in clennesse, Off chastyte the cheff pryncesse, Wych bar a chylde in verray dede, And kept alway hyr maydenhede; ‚ÄòAnd off the water tornyd to wyn At the fest off Archityclyn: Al thys I wrouht√´, thorgh my myht, With-oute preiudyce of your ryht; Wher-off ye sholde ha gret gladnesse, And nat gruchche for hevynesse Touchyng al thys, in no manere. ffor alway a good chaumberere Shold√´ be ryht glad in herte Whan she seye, or dyde aduerte The fayr√´ werkys (in sothnesse) Off hyr lady or maystresse, Pryncypally (who lok√´ wel,) Whan that she leseth neueradel Off hyr ffraunchyse in no degre. ffor euere mot preferryd be The comoun good in general. Goodys that ben √©specyal, The comoun good, in soth I calle That doth profyte to folkys alle, Especyally in al vertu.‚Äô And whan thys lady, Grac√´ dieu, Had al sayd, I yow ensure, A-noon thys lady, dame Nature, Whan she had herd hyr tale a long, Knowyng that she h√°dde do wrong, And hyr compleynte (to specefye,) Was ygroundyd on folye, fful humblely in hyr degre She ffyl a-noon vp-on hyr kne. Nature cryede mercy. The fyrst√´ word that she gan seye, Nature, off mercy gan hyr preye, And with humble cher & fface She confessede hyr trespace; And to hyr sayde most mek√´ly, ‚ÄòMa dame,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòful folyly I have gov√©rnyd me to yow, And ful vngoodly spok√´ now, Wher-off I repent√´ sore. And certys, I ne shal no more Offend√´ yow in no manere, Nouther in spech√´ nor in chere; So that, of mercy & pyte, Ye wyl as now forgyve yt me, That I ha don al outterly; And that ye wyl, so gracyously, Off alle that euere me asterte, No thyng reservyn in your herte, Only off your benygn√´ grace, But clene forget√´ my trespace.‚Äô Grace Dieu answereth: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod Grac√´ dieu ryht tho, ‚ÄòI wyl gladly that yt be so; But taketh hed of that I seye, In peyne of lesyng of your eye, That ye neuere, in al your lyff, Be nat hardy for to stryve A-geyn my workys in no wyse; Nor that ye no thyng despyse What-euere I do, for al your wyt; ffor I ne wyl nat suffren yt, But werke alway (as yt ys skyl) With-out√´ yow, affter my wyl.‚Äô And whan thys parlement was do, As ye han herd, atwen hem two, And Moyses ek dyned hadde With hys seruantys good & badde, He made A-noon (thys, the cheff,) ffor to depart√´ the releff: Hys Awmener yt hadde in charge, And bad to yive yt forth ful large To pylgrymes, wych day be day Travayllede forth vp-on her way; Off the wych, as thouht√´ me Ther was gret noumbre & plente. But, or that he gaff any thyng Off the releff in partyng Vn-to any maner whyht, Out off a chaumbre, a-noon ryht, I sawh two ladyes kome yfere, Wych, of port & of manere And off wommanly plesaunce, Hadden ful gret suffysaunce; And curteysly amyd the pres, Atwen the peple and Moyses, They putten hem, thys ylk√´ two. And she that wente a-forn ryht tho, (As yt sempte vn-to my wyt), Held in hyr hand a lytel wryt Vnclosyd vn-to my reward, As ye shall heryn affterward, Yiff ye lyst a whyl√´ dwelle. But off the tother I shal fyrst telle, Wych in hyr hond, (as I be-helde The sam√´ tyme) an hamer helde. And in hyr other hand with-al, She held a yerde, sclender & smal, To skouren chyldern, & chastyse. And also,‚Äîas I shal devyse, Vn-to my syht a thyng vnkouth,‚Äî She held a bysme in hyr mouth Atwyxe hyr teth, (yt ys no fayl,) Wher-off I hadd√´ gret mervayl. Yet she yt helde so cvrteysly That no man wold√´ deme ther-by That she was neuere the lass√´ wys. But yiff a-nother (to my devys,) Hadde holde yt so as dyd√´ she, Men wolde ha sayd, she hadd√´ be Out of hyr wyt, or ellys falle In-to rage. And fyrst of alle Thys lady wysly dyde abrayde To pylgrymes, & thus she sayde: (The bysme lette hyr neueradel But that she myght spek√´ wel:) ‚ÄòSyrs,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòI wot ryht wel That ye consydren euerydel My gouernaunce & myn aray. But I wot wel, (yt ys no nay,) Ye nat aduerten in substaunce Touchynge al my gouernaunce. I trowe ye kan nat al espye What thyng yt doth sygnefye. But, kometh ner to me echon, And I shal declare A-noon To yow the maner by & by, And yt expon√´ feythfully, Off the trouthe my sylff taquyte. ‚ÄòI am the ffayre, louyd but lyte; Off my port, demur And sad, Debonayre, & gretly drad Off fel√´ folkys that me se. And trew[e]ly I am ek she Now-a-day√´s lytel preysyd, And yet ful worthy to be reysed Off prys, to folkys that be dygne; Rygerous & ful benygne To all√´ that be vertuous; Happy also, and ryht Ewrous, The gracyouse, of smal plesaunce, I am callyd Dame Penaunce. The cheff wardeyn (who lyst se,) Off thylk√´ yl√´ most secre; The wych (who espy√´ kan,) Ys yhyd with-Inne a man. I make yt clene (I yow ensure,) Off all√´ fylthe & al ordure, Or ther-yn entre any whyht. Therfore I bere, off verray ryht, Thys bysme; Thys hamer, ek ther-to, And thys lytel yerde also, On al felth√´s to be wreke. With thys hamer I brose & breke, Lyk to my condycyoun ‚ÄòWith anguissh and contric√Øoun, Hertys that be obstynat With synn√´s olde, ek indurat, And fulfyllyd with vnclennesse, I do alway my bysynesse To make hem souple, nesshe, and tendre, And off her gret√´ bollyng, sclender; Also for to wake and wepe, Sorwe & pleyne with syh√´s depe, ffor ther synn√´s waymentynge. And as a Chyld√´ with betynge By exaumple (as ye se offte,) Maketh his hard√´ appyl soffte With offt√´ smytyng off hys ffyst, Tyl yt be tendre as hym lyst, And that the lycour ysseth oute, Ryght so fare I, yt ys no doute: I smyt√´ hertys vp & doun, And make hem, by contryc√Øoun, Wyth salt√´ terys (thys the cas,) To sorwe, crye, & seyn, allas That they euere dyde Amys! Ye shal yt fynde, & thus yt ys, Off ther tresp√°cys they repente, And seyn, in al ther beste entente, ‚ÄòA, Lord God! now, off thy grace, How shal I han off my trespace Alleg√´ment, with-out√´ the, But thow graunte, off thy pyte, That I may, al outterly, Off my Gylt√´s ha mercy, So that I do no mor Amys? Now, good√´ Lord, thow graunt√´ thys!‚Äô Thus I maken hem cryen offte. ‚ÄòAnd with thys hamer I mad√´ soffte Seyn Petrys herte, & yt to-brak, That yt wente al vn-to wrak, Wych ffyrst was hard as any ston. But I made yt nesshe A-noon Whan he hys mayster fyrst forsook. ‚ÄòBut whan that I the hamer took, I smet hym so with r√©pentaunce, And made hym nessh√´ with penaunce, That the Iews, off hys wepyng Yssede out in c√≥mpleynyng Of verray sorwe & bytternesse, He felt ther-off so gret dystresse In hys greuous hertly peyne. ‚ÄòAnd also Mary Mawgdeleyne, With thys hamer I smot so That hyr herte I rooff a-two, Wych was ful hard with synn√´s old. But with strokys manyfold I made hyr tendre, (yt ys no doute,) That the terys yssede oute, Out off hyr brest, so gret plente, That men myghte the lycour se By hyr chekys renne a-down Off verray sorwe, so gret foysown, That, in hyr bytter sorw√´s kene, She was wasshe with-al so clene, And so inly purefy√´d, That ther was no felthe espyed Off synne with-Inne hyr tendre herte. ffor, whan the bytter terys smerte Off hyr wepyng wer Ronn√´ down Thorgh sorwe & gret contryc√Øoun, I took vn-to hem so gret kepe, That I hem gadrede on an hepe, That ordure lefft√´ noon be-hynde. And I to-gydre dyde ham bynde‚Äî Al that euere they wrouhte a-wrong,‚Äî And make ther-off a ly√´ strong, That ther-with-al (I yow ensure,) I wasshe a-way al ordure. ffor who so lyst consydre & se, So gret a synn√´ may non be, But that the lye off r√©pentyng Doth yt a-way in wasshyng, And maketh yt clene euerydel, ‚ÄòYiff yt ther-in be wassh√´ wel. And for thys skyle, in my wasshyng, I am vn-to the myghty kyng Callyd sothly the ‚Äòlavendere,‚Äô And also ek hys ‚Äòchaumberere,‚Äô In thys offyces both√´ two, ‚ÄòNow vnderstondeth ek also, That thys hamer I ber with me ffor thys skyle, as ye shal se, Yt fareth, by a synful man, (Who so vnderstond√´ kan,) As by A Pot (in sothfastnesse) That ys ful of vnclennesse, Verray stynkyng & horryble, And to smell√´ ful odyble, Wych may nat wel devoyded be, ffor-as-myche (as ye wel se) The fylthe ys hardyd so with-Inne, That yt wyl not lyhtly twynne,‚Äî Off old gadryng ful indurat, And in maner obstynat,‚Äî To be made clene in any wyse. But than anoon I kan devyse Myn hamer myghtly tavale, And breke the pot in pecys smale; And on the felth√´ to be wreke; On smal√´ sherdys I it breke. ‚ÄòAnd fyrst off all√´ I begynne To drawe the felth√´ hyd with-Inne Out, to make yt shede a-brood, Wych with-Inne so long a-bood, And al the ordure ek with-al. And yiff I broke yt nat so smal On pecys vp-on euery syde, The fylthe with-Inn√´ wolde abyde, And mor & mor ay wexyn hard. ‚ÄòNow vnderstond, & hath reward To thys doctryne & thys lesson Touchyng verray contrycioun, Ye that desyre of herte & thought ‚ÄòTo lerne yt, & for-gete yt nouht. Thynketh, ye folkys that be wyse, That yt doth nat ynowh suffyse A man, in Groos (as ye shal lere,) To gadre hys synn√´s all yffere; But, lyk the pot, he most hem breke, And no thyng in the asshes reke. I mene as thus: conceyveth al, Thogh that a pot be brok√´ smal On sherdys & on pecys ek, Yet al yt ys nat worth a lek, But euery sherd be cerchyd wel Touchynge hys ordure euerydel, And yscrapyd clene a-way, Ye mot hem breke in gret affray, That felth√´ noon ther-in abyde; ffor wych ye most√´ wel provyde With sobbynge & with syh√´s depe And salt√´ terys that ye wepe, And other peynys sharpe & smerte; Thynkynge thus with-Inne your herte; ‚ÄòThow dyst offende on swych a day, Where yt Sonday or Monday; Than dystow thylk√´ gret√´ synne; And swych an hour thow dyst begynne, Havyng off God no dred nor fere. Thys was gret; that was grettere. And thus thow dyst, thylk√´ tyme, Wher yt at Eve, wher yt at pryme, And to don evel, were offt√´ blythe, And that thow dyst so offt√´ sythe. And rekne by & by yffere The cyrcumstauncys & the manere; Torne & cast ek, vp so doun, Wher that thy Temptac√Øoun Was gret or smal; acounte al thys, And thynk√´ whan thow dyst amys, Yiff a-forn thy great offence Thow madest any r√©systence, And wher thow wrastlyst any thyng ‚ÄòTo with-stonden in werkyng Thy temptacioun, gret or smal; Or wher thow (in especyal) In thy wrastlyng dist purchace Thy temptacioun to enchace; Or wher that thow, for shame or drede, Lettyst for to do the dede; Or wher thow settest drede asyde, And on the ded√´ dist abyde Tyl thow haddest do thy lust, And after that lefftyst the rust To kankren in thy consc√Øence, In aggreggyng of thyn offence: Al thys mote be of du√´ ryht Consydred wel off euery whyht. ‚ÄòAnd thys the maner (who loke wel,) To breke in pecys euerydel The vessell off thy gret offence With-Inne thy own√´ conscience: Smyt yt with the hamer sore, Tyl yt on pecys mor & more Be mad by pleyn contric√Øon, By swych consyderac√Øon That ther abyd√´ fylth√´ noon. ‚ÄòAnd thus I werke alway in on, With thys hamer that I holde, Al vnclennesse to vnfolde; I breke al doun, & spar√´ nouht Off no thyng that ys done or thouht, Tyl that trewe purgac√Øoun Be makyd by contric√Øoun. ‚ÄòBut yet a lytel word, I praye That I mot vn-to yow seye, Off thys old√´ pot texpresse, Wych ay ys ful of vnclennesse, Off whos ordure, gadyrd off old, With-Inne yt sylff, as I ha told, Engendryd ys a werm (in soth,) Wych ful gret√´ damage doth By long processe, yiff yt abyde. ‚Äòffor thys worm, hym-sylff doth hyde With-Inne thys pot ful couertly, That no man may wel espy Off hys engendryng, fer nor ner; Nor of hys norysshyng the maner. Thys, the werm of consc√Øence, Wych hath hys teht by vyolence Hardere (who that look√´ wel,) Than outher Iron outher stel; Wonder cruel, ay fretynge, And ryht perillous in percynge, So fer forth (yt ys no drede,) But he be slayn in verray dede, Thys mortal werm wyl neuere fyne, Vp-on hys mayster for to myne, And gnawe vp-on hym day & nyht, Tyl he ha slay hym thorgh hys myght, Thorgh hys dredful vyolence. ‚ÄòBut for to mak√´ r√©sistence, Ageyn thys werm, hym to with-stand, I ber thys hamer in myn hand, And smyte a-pon hym ay so sore, And spare hym nat, but mor & more I ley vpon hym, to be wroke. And thys ys whan the pot ys broke On pecys smal√´, vp & doun, By verray trewe contric√Øoun. ffor yiff yt wer nat broke aright, Myn hamer shold√´ ha no myght: Thys the Fyn, shortly to seye, To slen hym nor to make hym deye. Wherfor ye most√´ suffre wel That I breke hym euerydel On pecys smale, the werm to presse, Tavoyde away al vnclennesse. And on thys werm, (yiff ye lyst se,) Thus I shal avengyd be; Make hym lowly to obeye, That he of verray forc√´ deye To-for yow in your own√´ syht. ‚ÄòAnd thus, yiff ye take hede a-ryht, Thys the sygnyfycac√Øoun And verray exposic√Øoun Off thys hamer that ye her se; The wych ys namyd, ek off me, (Trewly, in conclusyoun,) Nat ellys but contryc√Øoun. ‚ÄòSwynge vp-on, yiff ye lyst lere, Off the bysme ye shall here, Wych, myd my teth, day by day, With-Inne my mouth I bere alway, As I to-forn ha told yow here; And how I am the Chaumberere Off hym that ys most myghty kyng. And thys bysme ys wel syttyng To hyre that ys a chaumberere. But yt may happ√´, the manere Ys vn-to yow a thyng vnkouth, That I yt holde thus in my mouth. But yiff I mad√´ mencyoun Off the Exposyc√Øoun, Ye know√´ wel, (yt ys no doute,) That who that euere shal casten oute Any felthe or vnclennesse, Out off a plac√´, he most dresse The bysme wysly to and fro, That he nat be-syd√´ go; But that he hau√´ ay in mynde, That felth√´ noon be leffte be-hynde, Lyst, in the purgac√Øoun, Men myghten han suspecyoun That any maner vnclennesse,‚Äî Thorgh slouth√´ or foryetylnesse,‚Äî Wer lefft be-syden, her or ther, In any Angle or Corner, ffor the bysme was nat redy To swep√´ clen√´ by & by. ffor, by swych occas√Øoun, Ther myghte, of felth√´ gret foisoun Be couert, as yt happeth offte, On hepys reysyd hih a-loffte In som Angle, Est or West, The wych thyng wer nat honest. ‚ÄòAnd to purpos off thys matere, In holy wryt, (as ye shal here,) I have y-rad ful yore Agon Off dyvers gatys mo than on, And sondry namys, (who taketh hede) They hadd√´ sothly as I rede, Gaate off the welle, men dyde on calle; And a-nother, A-mong alle, As the byble kan yow telle, Namyd was the gate of helle. And A-nother I kan nevene, Callyd was the Gate off hevene; And a-nother gate ther was, That was callyd the gate off bras, And also ek, to last√´ long, Ther was a gate of Iren strong. But A-mong hem euerychon Ne√´mye speketh of on, And callyd ys in scripture The gate off felthe & ordure, To voyden (In conclus√Øoun) Alle the fylth√´s of the Toun; Out by that gat√´, day be day, Alle the donge to lede away, That no maner corupcyoun Nengendre nat with-Inne the Toun. And bet yt ys, as thynketh me, That thylk√´ place defoulyd be, Than al the cyte wer encoumbryd Wyth ffylth√´s, wych may nat be noumbryd Wych euery day encresse off newe, And mor & mor ay do renewe. ‚ÄòBut wher that I am chaumberere, And abyde, (as ye shal lere,) ffor to do my besynesse, And Grac√´ Dieu ys ek maystresse, That ther be .vj. Gatys large, Wych to kepe, ys a gret charge, As I shal to yow descryue. ‚ÄòAnd off thys syx√´, ther be fyve By wych al maner vnclennesse, ffylthe, ordure, and wrechchydnesse Entreth in, erly & late. Off wych fyve, the fyrst√´ gate Ys callyd the gate off smellyng, The tother the gate off heryng, The tother of Touch, the fourthe of tast, The ffyffthe (wych I rekne last,) Callyd ys the gate off syht.
