And ys yset fyrst off echon. ‚ÄòAnd that ye shold√´ be al on, Thexaumple techeth yow ful wel, (Yiff ye consydren euerydel,) How ye bothen, in O lyne Stonde, & may yt not declyne. Lyneally, yt ys noon other, As brother verrayly to brother, Nature wyl that yt so be, Hih and lowh, off o degre, Both√´ tweyne ymade lyche; The por√´ man & ek the ryche, At the gynnyng, as ye shal lere, Al forgyd wern of O matere, Touchyng ther ffyrste orygynal, And both√´ tweyn√´ be mortal; The Ton, the tother, in certeyne They be but werm√´s both√´ tweyne, And they ne kan hem sylffe nat kepe, But that they shall to erth√´ krepe; When that deth doth hem assaylle. ‚Äòffor what ys worth, or may avaylle, A feloun herte or hardynesse, Daunger, despyt or sturdynesse, Nat may socoure vp-on no syde, Ther deynous port, ther gret√´ pryde, Yt may hem done noon avauntage, ffor al shal passe By o passage, And by on hole off gret streihtnesse; Powerte & ek rychesse, Al goth O way, bothe gret & smal; Excepc√Øoun ys noon at al, To helpyn in thys streiht√´ nede. ‚ÄòWherfor euery man take hede, Thorgh pryde to be nat rekk√´les, Thys rych√´ Iowel callyd pes, To kepe yt wel, & lese yt nouht. ‚ÄòAnd euery man, in herte & thouht ‚ÄòDo hys dyllygent lab√≥ur, To ha pes with hys neih√´bour, As roote off al perfeccioun, Vp to parforme the patroun Off vnyte & sothfast pes, Tendure & lasten end√´les; So as yt ouht, off iust resoun, As tookne off the tabellyoun, With wych, in pes and vnyte, Al testamentys shold√´ be Sygned & markyd comounly, And ek confermyd openly. ‚ÄòAnd tovchyng her thys wryt present, Callyd of Cryst the testament, With tookne off tabellioun, I mark√´ off entencyoun To last in pes & vnyte.‚Äô And whan thys lady Charyte Hadde Radd and yoven off Entent The pes off Cristes Testament To all√´ folkys that were there, Chargynge hem, off herte entere, Affter the fform√´ euerydel, Al ther lyve to kepe yt wel,‚Äî Anoon a-geyn, as ye shal se, Thys fayr√´ lady Charyte Hyr tal√´ ganne al openly, Sayynge thus benygn√´ly. Charyte speketh hyr ageyn. ‚ÄòSyrs,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòye haue herd al By thys lettre (in specyal) Wych I ha rad in your presence Openly in audyence, How Cryst Ihesu, off hys goodnesse, And off hys gret√´ kynd√´nesse, Out off thys world whan he sholde gon, Gaff hys pes, to yow echon, ‚ÄòWith many gyfftys off gret prys, Wych ye shal kepe, yiff ye be wys, As I ha told in ech estat; ffor pes devoydeth al debat, Wher yt abydeth parfytly. ‚ÄòBut I shal telle the caus√´ why That I me putt√´ fyrst in pres Atwyx√´ yow & Moyses, And the table wher as he stood. ffor me-thouht yt was nat good That noon off yow, in no degre, Sholde a-proche with-out√´ me To claym√´ part (thys, the cheff) At hys table, off the releff But I my-sylff wer ther present. ‚ÄòAnd ek the sayd√´ testament, That I ha told off in substaunce, And yiff ye haue in remembraunce Dame Penaunnce yow told√´ so, Yiff ye took good hed ther-to, With-outen hyr√´, thys the ende Ye be nat hable for to wende To the table off Moyses. And but ye haue ek parfyt pes With yow echon, & also me Wych am ynamyd Charyte, Ye be vnworthy & vnhable To ha the releff off hys table. ffor yt were a presumpc√Øoun, And a gret transgress√Øoun, To neyhen ner, or to be bold, Or to clayme (as I ha told) Off that releff most specyal, Wher-off ech part ys on & al,‚Äî Ther ys ther-in no dyfference;‚Äî And therfor, lat be noon offence In yow, vp-on no maner syde, But that aforn ye yow provyde, As I the charge haue on yow leyde.‚Äô And whan Charyte hadde al sayde, And mad a ful conclusioun Off hyr speche & hyr sarmoun, Pylgrymes hem putt√´ fast in pres To-ward the table off Moyses; Conveyed ech in ther degre With parfyt pes and Charyte, And with verray r√©pentaunce, Confess√Øoun, & ek penaunce. Pylgrym√´s alle off good entente, To Moyses they hem presente, As they myghte hem redy make, And, the releff off hym take fful devoutly off assent. And Grac√´ Dieu was ay present Whan they, with gret deuocyoun, Took yt in ther entencyoun, And with a clen√´ conscience. But I sawh ther in presence, Somme pressen to the table That wer vnworthy & vnhable; Wych held hem-sylff fer out asyde, And fro Charyte gan hem hyde, And fledde also fro dame Penaunce; And yet hem-sylff they gan A-vaunce, Off bold√´nesse al sham√´les, ffor to receyve off Moyses The releff, wher as he stood. The wych√´ thouht√´ nat but good; ffor he, off clene affecc√Øoun, Gaff yt with-oute excepc√Øoun (Off the plente that he hadde,) To pylgrym√´s good & badde, ffor he noon hede ne dyd√´ take. But they retournede foul and blake, I men√´, swych that of boldnesse Tok√´ yt nat in clennesse, As they ouht ha done off ryht; Swych wer foul & blake of syht Lych√´ to a colyers sak. ffor in hem-sylff was all the lak That they semede so odyble, Stynkynge also, & horryble, Hungry, thorgh ther gret offence, & nedy in ther consc√Øence; And, for lak off good entent, Wer also ful indygent, And voyde ek off al gostly foode. ‚ÄòBut sothly, thylk√´ that wer goode, And goostly tooke ther ffedyng, They wer fulfylled in all thyng Off that releff most in substaunce, And ther-in hadde al suffysaunce, Replevysshyd in herte & thouht, Off other thyng them nedede nouht. The goode pylgrym√´s thouht√´ so, That they wer Redy for to go (Thorgh suffysaunce off that repast) ffro the table whan they wer past, And, to-forn all√´, as they koude, ffor verray Ioye they seyd√´ loude, That they wolde noon other thyng, Hem to sustene in ther lyvyng, And to deffende hem fro damage As they wente on pylgrymage As pylgrym√´s good and sadde. But mervayl of O thyng I hadde With-Inne my sylff, & gret√´ doute That swych A meyne & a route As was ther, to putte a preff, Was fulfyllyd off the releff, The wych was (as thouht√´ me,) So verray smal in quantyte. Wher-off I gan wondre sore, And merveyll√´ mor & more, And thoght√´, thogh ther hadd√´ be Ten so myche in quantyte Off releff lefft at the tahle, Me sempt√´ that I hadde be hable At O dyner, my-sylff ryht wel, To have hete yt euerydel, And yet nat had (to my plesaunce) Halff A repast of suffysaunce. And yet, the pylgrymes euerychon Sayde & affermede, On by on, That they fonde swych fulsomnesse, And so plentuous largesse As they yt tooke by good leyser At that merveyllous dyner, That to euerych (in ther guyse) A lytel dyde ynowh suffyse. And euerych (in especial) Was ther fulfyllyd with ryht smal Ther-with, myghty mad, & stronge. Wher-vp-on I gan ful longe, And thouhte (A-mong hem euerychon) Myn vnderstondyng was agon ffor lak off wyt in gret dystresse, And forcloudyd with dyrknesse. Reson was hyd, so sempt√´ me, That I kowde hyr nowher se; In al that place, I sawh nat tho, No whyht I myht√´ speke vn-to, Save Grac√´ Dieu, wych ther abood, And to-for the Table stood Off Moyses; & off entente, Vn-to hyre a-noon I wente. The pylgrym askede. ‚ÄòMa dame,‚Äô quod I, ‚ÄòI ha gret nede That ye wolde, off goodlyhede, And off your gret excellence, Shewen to me som evydence How yt myght√´ shewyd be, That so lytel quantyte Off thys releff (in any wyse) Myghte of resoun ynowh suffyse To so manye as ben here? ffor, ma dame, (& ye lyst lere,) Swych ten in quantyte Wolde nat suffysen vn-to me At O dyner, to my delyt, To fulfylle myn appetyt.‚Äô Grace Dieu answerde, ‚ÄòI leue ryht wel,‚Äô quod Grac√´ Dieu, ‚ÄòTouchyng thys merveillous vertu, Thow hast gret ned√´ for to lere; But herkene now, & ley to here, I shal the tech√´ verrayly The pryvyte√´s, by & by, Bothe by evydence & preff. ‚ÄòThys ylk√´ vertuous releff, Som whyle (who yt vnderstood) ys ynamyd flesshe & blood, And som tym√´ (tak good heed,) Yt ys ycallyd wyn & bred, Goostely mete & goostely foode; To pylgrym√´s that be goode, fflessh & blood yt ys no doute; Bred & wyn shewyd with-oute, Al be yt so (yt ys no dred,) That yt to-forn was wyn and bred, As thow knowest wel certeyn; But Moyses (no thyng in veyn) Vp-on hys table (as yt stood) Hath tournyd yt to fflessh & blood. Thys ys trewe, & verray soth; Wher-off nature was ryht wroth; Anger made hyr hert√´ ryve, And ther-vp-on gan with me stryve: She knewe no ferther (thys, the ffyn) But that yt was ay bred & wyn. ‚ÄòThow shalt wel know√´ how that she Sawh nat the gret√´ pryvyte, ffor lakkyng off dyscrecyoun, Off thys ylke mutacyoun, But I the charg√´ ther I stonde, That flessh & blood thow vnderstonde, And so beleue yt verrayly, And lat nat meue the outwardly, Thogh that yt shew√´ outward so ‚ÄòIn touch & syht√´ both√´ two, Also in tast & in smellynge Lych bred & wyn Rescmb[e]lynge, Outward, as by √°pparence; Trust√´ shortly in sentence, Thy fowr√´ wyttys (lerne of me) ffynally deceyved be; Off verray foly they be blent, That they ha noon Entend√´ment, The trouth√´ trewly to conceyve; Swych dyrknesse hem doth deceyve, That the offyce of hem echon Ys from hem four√´ clen√´ agon, ffor lak, pleynly, of knowelychyng. ‚ÄòBut the fyffthe wyt off heryng‚Äî Wych mor clerly in sentence Haueth full intelligence‚Äî He techyth the wyttys euerychon Evydently what they shal don,‚Äî The tast, the touch, & ek the syht, Smellyng also (off verray ryht,) Whan they ha lost ther knowelychyng, The ffyffthe, that callyd ys Heryng, Aparceved hath so wel, That he knoweth euerydel In thys matere what shal be don. And thys was fyguryd longe a-gon,‚Äî Red the Byble, yiff ye kan,‚Äî In Ysaak, that old√´ man, Whan Esau (to hys entente,) In-to the feld on huntyng wente, And hys labour spente in veyn. ffor longe or that he kam ageyn, Iacob verrayly in dede, Cladd√´ in Es√°wys wede, With her vp-on hys hondys layd (As hys moder hadde hym sayd,) To Ysaak held√´ hys passage, And to hym brouht√´ the potage In ryht gret hast, (as he was tauht,) And sayde, he hadde hys pray ykauht In venery, amyd the feld. ‚ÄòBut, Ysaak no thyng be-held, ffor he was dyrkyd off hys syht, And gretly feblyd off hys myght, ffor Touch & smellyng wer agon; And Ysaak wende eu√©re in on, That Esau hadd√´ be present. But Rebecca, off entent, Sent√´ Iacob in hys name; ffor in hyr herte she hadde a game, Esau, to sett√´ abak. ‚ÄòBut thys old√´ man Ysaak‚Äî The patryark of gret vertu,‚Äî Took Iacob for Esau, In touch, in tast, & in smellyng, In syghte also; but hys heryng Was hym be-lefft, hool & entere. And thus he sayde, as ye shal here: ‚ÄòThe voys of Iacob semeth me; Off Esau, the handys be; I here Iacob speken wel; But the handys that I fel, The handys ben off Esau.‚Äô ‚ÄòConsydreth now how the vertu Off Touch, & tast, smellyng, & syht Hadd√´ pleynly lost hys myght; The force off heryng stylle a-bood; With Isaak, ryht so yt stood. By wych exaumple, tak good heed ffor profyt off thyn own√´ speed, Off thys fygure that I ha told; Lefft vp thyn eyen & be-hold: Avaunce the nat, nor mak no bost, ffor thy .iiij. wyttys thow hast lost. Ther myght, ther force, ar fro the weyved; Yiff thow truste hem, thow art deceyved; ffor Tast nor touch in no degre, Nor n√≥ thyng that thow kanst se, Nor thy smellyng (tak good hed,) Ne shewe to the but wyn & bred; By ther engyn, hih nor lowe, Thow ne shalt noon other knowe. ‚ÄòThy ffour√´ wyttys set a-syde, And lat heryng be thy guyde; ffor, thys .iiij. in sothfastnesse Kan nor may ber no wytnesse. Wher-for thow mustest, for the beste, Abyde on heryng, and ther reste; ffully truste to hys sentence; Yiff feyth to hym, & ful credence; ffor heryng shal, with-out√´ slouthe, Teche to the, the pleyn√´ trouthe, Ryght as yt ys, ne doute yt nouht. ‚ÄòAnd conceyue wel in thy thouht, Thys releff (yiff thow kanst take hede,) Ys pleynly nother wyn nor bred, But the flessh (yiff feyth to me,) That heng vp-on the rood√´ tre, And, by force & verray strengthe, On the croos was drawe alengthe, fful streyhtly nayled on the rood; And thys ys ek the verray blood, On goode ffryday that he shadde, Whan Iew√´s to the deth hym ladde, Wher-off he was steyned reed. Thow mayst also call yt bred, Thys same releff, (with-out√´ stryff,) The verray sothfast bred off lyff. Wych susteneth (I the ensure,) Al the world with hys pasture, And yiveth to hem in substaunce Verrayly ther sustenaunce. And ek also (thys myn vsage, Ther-off to han thys language, Looke thow take good heed ther-to,) I calle yt bred, & name yt so; Wych, for manhys savac√Øoun, ffro the heuene kam a-doun, To ffed√´ man her verrayly. ‚ÄòYt ys the bred, ek, trewly Wher-with Aungelys fedde ybe In that hevenly souereyn se. Thys bred, pylgrym√´s euerychon, On pylgrymag√´, (wher they gon,) Or wher-so-euere that they were, In ther sherpe they shold yt bere. ‚ÄòAnd thogh that thow (as sempt√´ the,) Sey yt but lyte of quantyte, I charg√´ the, her a-noon ryht, Trust in no wys√´ to thy syht, Nor to thyn Eyen, wych ar blynde; But haue alway wel thy mynde To thyn heryng; & ther only Tak thy doctryne fynally; ffor, by heryng thow shalt lere A thyng that I shal the tellyn here: ‚ÄòMy frend, take good hed, & se. Thow herdest lat√´ Charyte Maken to the a good sarmoun, But (as in conclus√Øoun,) Thys lady (yiff thow took good hed,) Spak but lytel off thys bred In hyr sarmoun (thus stood the caas); And pleynly, thys the caus√´ was; ffor she hyr-sylff the menys souhte, That she the greyn from hevene brouhte, And made yt in the erth√´ lowe Her be-neth√´ to be sowe; But that erthe, (be wel certeyn,) Wher as sow√´ was thys greyn, Was nat labouryd (trust me wel,) Mor yheryd neueradel; Vnderstonde yt, yiff thow konne. ffor, by het√´ off the sonne, That shyneth fro the heuene A-loffte With hys attempre bemys soffte, And the hevenly dewh most clene, With hys syluer dropys shene, (The wych√´ doth no thyng in veyn,) ‚ÄòMade to growen vp thys greyn, Tyl yt was rype & ful off corn. ‚ÄòThan Charyte yt hath vp shorn, And in a plac√´ wonder straunge She made yt leyn vp in hyr graunge, Tyl the thressherys (with gret hete) Hadde thys greyn ythrysshe & bete; And after fannyd yt so clene That ther was no chaff ysene, And the strawh yleyd a-syde; ffor ther ne myght√´ nat a-byde Husk nor chaff, but puryd greyn, Nor, no thyng that was in veyn, Al mad nakyd off entent, Out off hys olde vest√´ment. ‚ÄòAnd whan yt was so ffer ywrouht, Thys greyn was to the mell√´ brouht, And ground√´ ther with ful gret peyne A-twyxe the hard√´ stonys tweyne. And yiff I shal the soth√´ telle, The s√´yl-yerdys off the melle, Wych tourned√´ abouten offte, Wer clad in cloth that was not soffte. ‚ÄòTys melle ek (yiff thow canst espye,) Wyth fals√´ wynd√´s off envye, (Wher as yt stood vp-on the grounde,) Tournede euere about√´ Round; And the Grynstonys (that I off spak) Mad ful hard√´ for the wrak, Wer stonys off derys√Øouns; Off skorn, & fals illus√Øouns, The wych two (who kan aduerte) Perceden ful nyh the herte. ‚ÄòAnd whan no thyng was lefft at al, But that yt was yground√´ smal, Charyte gan neyhen ner, And wolde be-come a pasteler, Lych a baker, (yt ys no drede,) Off that flour to make her bred. And hyr Ovene was of old ‚ÄòVerray hote, (& no-thyng cold,) Wher-as she caste hyr for to bake. ‚ÄòAnd whan she gan hyr past to make, Al tournede nat vn-to hyr pay, Wher-off she hadd√´ no desmay, Off thylk√´ past wych that she wrouhte. & A-noon she hyr be-thouhte (Among, in al her besynesse,) Off on that was a gret maystresse, So sotyle off dyscrecyoun Was nouther founde in borgh nor toun; ffor what men thouhte, or wolde haue don, She koude yt brynge about a-noon: Lernyd she hadde, in hyr contre, At scolys ther she hadd√´ be. Thogh al hyr konnyng wer nat wyst, She koude haue mad, yiff that hyr lyst, Al the world so large & Round, And al the compas off the ground, ffor tashet & closyd al With-Inne a sotyl boyst, but smal; And off An Ey with-Inne the shelle, She koude also (I dar wel telle,) Ha put an Ox√´ strong & large; ffor yt was, no maner charge To hyr gret magnyfycence; And hyr name was Sapience. ‚ÄòAnd, for hyr gret sotyllyte, Thys lady, callyd Charyte, Prayede hyr, off goodlyhed, ffor to help√´ make thys bred Off the fflour wych that she brouhte; And also lowly hyr be-souhte To tempre the past so sotylly, That yt myght√´ fynally, Off Resemblaunce be but smal; And that yt myghte suffyse at al (By vertu, verrayly in dede) Al thys worlde to fostre & fede, That ech, off lowh & hih degre, ‚ÄòMay, off lytel, ha plente. ‚ÄòAnd for thys caus√´ ryht a-noon Dame Charyte ys forth gon Vn-to thys lady Sapience; And with humble Reuerence, As she sat in hyr Royal Se, Lowly, thys lady Charyte Prayede hyr good heed to take, To help√´ that thys bred wer bake. And she goodly, and that a-noon, fforth with Sapience ys gon; And, as she koud√´ best deuyse, Temprede yt in swych a wyse, Made yt gret with-oute mesure, To yive al folkys ther pasture, Suffycy√©nt to feden al, Thogh to thy syht yt was but smal Outward, as in r√©semblaunce, Yet, by souereyn suffysaunce, Closyd in a lytel space, Ther was so gret plente of grace To al the world, in h√°bondaunce, Ther-in to fynd√´ suffysaunce. ‚ÄòTak heed, & be nat neclygent Off a-nother experyment That ther was wrouht; tak ek good hede, In the makyng off thys bred, Yt was ywrouht so sotylly That in euery smal party, Severyd and ybroke asounder, And departyd her & yonder, Grettest & smal, Rekne echon Wer lych off vertu, & al on; Off O power & O manere As whan yt was hool and entere. The wych√´ thyng (I the ensure,) Yplesede nat to dame Nature; ffor she was wroth therfor with me, And ther-on wolde ha vengyd be. She knew ther-off no thyng at al, ‚Äòffor yt was hydde in especyal ffrom hyr knowyng euerydel. And also ek, ye wyt√´ wel, Offt√´ syth√´ Ryot & age Putt√´ folkys in dot√°ge, That they may not trouth√´ se. And for she doutede hyr off me To be blamyd in certeyn, Yiff so were she kome a-geyn, Or put a-bak fro hyr entent, Ther-fore she hath hyr clerk now sent, Arystotyles the wyse, In dyffence off hyr fraunchyse, To thys lady Sapyence. ‚ÄòAnd whan he kam to hyr presence, As hym thouht√´ fyrst was due, Goodly he gan hyr to salue; Affter, demeur & sad off chere, To hyre he sayde in thys manere: Arystotyles dyde hys massage in thys manere: ‚ÄòMa dame,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòin-to thys place, Vnder s√∫pport off your grace, Nature hath me hyder sent, To declare yow (off entent) Your dyffaut√´s, by & by; And to shewe the caus√´ why Off my komyng, ys thys, that ye Han to-brook (as semeth me) Off nature the ordynaunce, And don to hyr√´ gret grevaunce, Wych pleseth me neueradel, Al be yt so, I love yow wel. ‚ÄòYe knowe (off your dyscrecyoun, Off trouthe ek, yt ys no Resoun, Who so cleerly looke & wel,) That an hous or a vess√©l Sholde be lasse, & her ygynne, ‚ÄòThan that thyng wych ys with-Inne. And yiff I made to your entent, By √°pparence off Argument, As thus, that I wold√´ preve, (ffor to mak√´ folk be-leve,) That a paleys huge & large, Or A menstre off gret charge, That yt wer but A Turneys smal. Clerkys wolde (in especyal) Seyn yt wer but mekerye, Or A maner sophystrye, Shewyd, as yt wer for game; And ye your sylff ha do the same. (Yiff ye lyst to be avysed,) In thys bred wych ys desguysed; ffor the foode & the pasture, That ys withinne (as ye assure,) Gyveth ful repast spyrytual To al the world in general, So ffer the vertu doth extende; And yet, that thyng to comprehende, Al the erth√´, in no wyse, Nor the hevene, mowh nat suffyse, That thyng ye (in especyal) Han closyd in a cloystre smal, Who kan mesure yt, or compasse, And shet yt in a lytel space? And swych .xiiij.? (on see or land) I myghte wel holden in myn hand! I trowe your sylff kan nat sey nay; And for no fauour I ne may Suffre no lenger (in certeyn,) But that I must√´ yow with-seyn, And declare, wher as ye ffaylle, (And yt ys no grete merveylle, Who-so lyst goode heed to take) Thogh natur√´ dyde awake, ‚ÄòAnd ther-vpon gaff yow an hete, Yow to with-stonde & conterplete, Touchyng hyr ryht in specyal. ‚ÄòAnd thys greueth me most at al, That my Maxime √°pryved, Ye in dede han yt reprevyd; And (to speke in wordys pleyn,) Neuere in my lyff herde I seyn‚Äî In-no scolys, her nor there,‚Äî But that ‚Äúon al‚Äù (what euere yt were,) Mot be gretter than hys party. But ye han makyd wrongfully, (I wot nat by what maner scole,) The part Egal to the hoole, With-outen any difference! Wych I holde a gret offence Ageyn nature, in verray soth. And no wonder thogh she be wroth, And laboure for Amend√´ment. And for thys skyle she hath me sent To your presence, only to here What ye wyl seyn in thys matere.‚Äô Sapyence answerde. A-noon thys lady Sapience. (Whan she hadde herd√´ in sentence The wordys of Arystotyles) She stynte a whyle, & was in pes. But at the last√´ she abreyde, And vn-to hym ryht thus she seyde: ‚ÄòMy frend,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòI do wel se Off trowth√´ that thow lovest me, And dost me calle, off herte entere, ‚ÄúThyn oun√´ souereyn lady dere;‚Äù In wych thow hast ylost no thyng But yfounde ful grete Fortheryng. Wherfor thow shuldest, lyke the wyse, ‚ÄòPrudeently thy-sylff avyse, Thynke aforn, & ek beholde, How that whylom I dydd√´ holde Two scolys off ful gret Renoun; And bothen (in conclus√Øoun,) Wer vnder my gouernaunce. And the, in konnyng to avaunce, I tauht√´ many thyng√´s newe‚Äî Record thy sylff yiff thow be trewe.‚Äî And (to speke in wordys fewe,) Grete merveill√´s did√´ shewe. And in on off thys scolys tweyne, My scoler most√´ souereyn, ffyrst of echon (I the ensure,) Was hyr-sylff, dam√´ Nature. ‚ÄòAnd as thy-sylff ful wel yt knewe, I tauhte hyr many thyng√´s newe; ffyrst, by Crafft off hyr werkynge To make the fressh√´ flourys sprynge, Buddys, greyns, & flourettys, The flour delys, the violettys, The rosys also, fresshe off hewe, And many other craftys newe, As men may se (who taketh hede,) Wych to reherse, yt ys no nede, I tauhte hyr al, & thyng√´s mo. ‚ÄòAnd in my other scole also, Wych, thy sylff lyst to sue, I tauht√´ folkys to argue Pro & contra, yong & olde, And wych wey they sholden holde To preven out the sothfastnesse Off every thyng, fro the falsnesse; Betwyxen good & evel dyscerne. And I maade ek (who kan concerne) Lawes off Cyvile and Cano?; And ther, (in myn Entencion) ‚ÄòMyn eldest douhter, moste Entere, Ther I sett√´, folk to lere, Wych that callyd ys ‚ÄúSyence,‚Äù Sotylle, and off gret excellence; And ther she helde hyr parlementys, And formede many argumentys, As she that was deuoyde off slouthe. ffor loue off whom (thys the trouthe,) Thow kam to skole; & for hyr sake Nyht & day thow dydest wake, Tyl, for thyn owne Avauntage Ye wer coniunat by maryage, Wherby I mad√´ the so wys, That thow be-kam myn aprentys. And thanne, off gret affeccyoun, I mad√´ reuelac√Øoun To the, Amongys my werkynges Off naturys secr√´ thynges; To knowe the cler√´ fro the derke; Nat that thy syluen sholdest werke No thyng that longeth to hyr art, But that thow sholdest (for thy part) The causes knowen by & by, And ther-on demene fynally The trouth√´ pleynly, & no more. ‚ÄòAnd for that skyl√´ gon ful yore, In guerdon of thy gret labour, I callede the my ‚Äúparamour.‚Äù And syth thow hast, vnder my cure, Dwellyd so long√´ with Nature, And seyn so many fayr√´ thynges, And so many vnkouth werkynges With-Inne my scole, of gret fauour, Thogh thow seye in me Errour, Thow sholdest, off thy Curtesy, ffor-bere me more pacyently, Yiff thow lovedest, and wer kynde. ‚ÄòAnd thow sholdest haue in mynde, And remembren (off good Resoun,) How onys a myghty champyoun, That koude the crafft off fyhtyng wel, Tauhte hys konnyng euerydel To a poore man hym besyde, And lyst ther-off no thyng to hyde; And for hys mede he took no thyng, Off curteysye, for hys konnyng. ‚ÄòBut affterward, the case stood so That they shold√´ both√´ two,‚Äî At Requeste off dukys tweyne, A certeryn quarll to dareyne,‚Äî Mete in a feld: & so they mette; And as they gan vp-on to sette, Euerych other to assaylle, He that was wysest in bataylle, Off wysdam & dyscrecyoun,‚Äî I mene the maister Champyoun, That was avysee, & mor wys‚Äî Sayde A-noon to hys prentys, ‚ÄúYt ys no ryht, wher-for I pleyne, On, to fyht√´ ageyns tweyne. Ye be tweyne, I am but On.‚Äù And Thaprentys thanne Anoon, As he bakward cast hys look, The tother Rauhte hym swych a strook That he fyl ded, & al was done: And thanne the mayster sayde Anoon, ‚ÄúMy prentys hath nat lernyd al, ffor I kepte in especyal A poynt, tyl that I hadd√´ nede.‚Äù ‚ÄòAnd thus, yiff thow kanst taken hede,‚Äô (Quod this Lady Sapience) ‚ÄòI taughte neuere al my Science To the, as I rehers√´ shal. What, wenystow to knowen al? ‚ÄòFor vn-to the, nat ne syt ffor to knowen al my wyt; Thow dyst yt neuere yet dysserue. Som-what to me I wyll reserue, To be mor strong in bataylle, Lyst thow woldest me assaylle With thy sotyl sophystrye, To don to me a vyllonye With argumentys off fallaas, Sout out in som maner caas, By fraude or by decepcyoun ffor lakkyng off dyscrecyoun. ‚ÄòBut tel me now A-noon, I preye, And the Trouth√´ nat geyn-seye, Yiff I gaff a purs to the, Ryght fayr & ryche vp-on to se, And wentyst forth with-al A-noon; And sodeynly, whan thow wer gon, Par caas thow founde ther-in as blyue Off gold thre pecys, outher fyve Outher .vj., whan thow hast souht, Tel on, as yt lyth in thy thouht, Wer yt deceyt or sophystrye, Or myghtestow off gent(e)rye Seyn I hadde deceyved the? Answere ageyn; tel on! lat se!‚Äô Arystotylles Answerde: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòme lyst nat lye, Yt were no maner sophystrye, But A tookne off gentyllesse; And also (pleynly to expresse,) A sygne (as I kan devyse,) Off honour, love, & gret fraunchyse.‚Äô Sapyence speketh: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she to hym ryht tho, ‚ÄòThys bred I haue ymadd ryht so, So sotyl ek, yt ys no doute, But I ha not shewyd with-oute ‚ÄòThe grete Tresour wych verrayly Ys shet with-Inn√´ secr√´ly, Por√´ folkys for to fede, Ay, whan they ther-off ha nede; And specyally to hem that be ffrendys vn-to charyte, Wych in ther passage, nyht & day Holden ay the ryht√´ way. All√´ swych (yt ys no dred) Shal be sustenyd with thys bred, And haue ther ful repast with-Inne, Swych as be nat infect with synne. And Over-mor, (yiff thow take hed,) Yiff the valu off thys bred Were yshewyd al with-oute, Men shold√´ nat (yt ys no doute,) Haue no maner hardynesse ffor taproche, in sothfastnesse; But rather, for verray feere, Go, seke her bred ellys where, To ther sustentac√Øoun. ‚ÄòBut her ys no decepcyoun, But curteisye & gret bounte, Honour & lyberalyte; ffor, to speke in wordys fewe, But yiff I dyde with-out√´ shewe A gret√´ thyng by √°pparence, The wych√´, as in existence, Were nat with-Inne, (who lyst se,) But verray smal off quantyte, Thou myyghtest than[√´] me repreve, And by argumentys preve Ageyn me (in conclusyoun) A maner off decepcyoun, And blam√´ me in many wyse. ‚ÄòAnd yet to the I shal devyse Another Answere, wych to the Shal suffyse, yiff thow lyst se. I Holde yt no deceyt at al, Thogh to the Eye it shew√´ smal, ‚ÄòAnd with-Inne be gret & large. Wher-vp-on, her I the charge That thow be-leue yt stedefastly, And put no doute, but ferm√´ly Truste ay so, off herte & thouht; And lok√´ thow denye yt nought, But her-on feythfully abyde. ffor yiff that I (on any syde) Hadde yt mad in other wyse, Than thow a-forn hast herd devyse, I hadd√´, thorgh my neclygence, Ther-in don ful gret offence. ‚ÄòBut tel me now A-noon, I preye, And spar√´ nat, platly to seye As thow semest in thys matere, Wych hast repreuyd me so here, Off myche thyng, nat yore agon, Trowest thow answere A-noon, That nat a-cordeth with resoun. A vessel, hows, or mans√Øoun May be lasse (& her I gynne) Than the thyng that ys with-Inne. ‚ÄòBut ffyrst I axe, to voyde al stryff, Sawh thow euere, in al thy lyff, Off manhys herte the quantyte? Answere A-geyn; tel on, lat se!‚Äô Arystotyles Answereth: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod he, & that ful blyth, ‚ÄòI haue yt seyn ful offt√´ syth.‚Äô Sapyence axeth: ‚ÄòThanne,‚Äô quod she, with-out√´ slouthe, ‚ÄòDeclare to me the verray trowthe; Syth thow halst thy sylff so wys, How gret ys yt, to thyn avys.‚Äô Arystotyles answereth: ‚ÄòSothly,‚Äô quod he, ‚ÄòI dar expresse, As touchyng the gretnesse, Yt ys but smal vn-to the sihte; ffor ther-with-al, vnneth√´ myghte, An hungry kyte (& do no wast,) ‚ÄòTher-off han a ful repast, To staunche hys hunger (for gret nede,) At the ffulle hym-sylff to ffede.‚Äô Sapyence axeth: Quod Sapyence to hym ageyn, ‚ÄòThan axe I the (no thyng in veyn,) Yiff thow knowe auht, answere to me, The inward gret capacyte Off an herte, wych ys so smal; And yiff yt myghte (to reknen al,) Be fully fed in any wyse; Or what thyng myghte to yt suffyse To appese hys gret delyt, Or staunche hys gredy appetyt.‚Äô Arystotyles answerd: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod Aristotiles, ‚ÄòI dar afferm√´ dout√´les, Ther ys no thyng that I kan se, That may Gyv√´ ful sawl√´ (Who that wysely kan aduerte,) ffor to staunche a gredy herte, Nat alle the world, yt to fulfyl, Thogh yt were hooly at hys wyl.‚Äô Sapience argueth: Thanne her-vp-on quod Sapience, ‚ÄòYt behoueth in sentence, That the fulfyllyng in substaunce To the fulle haue suffysaunce; Or ellys yt mot nedys be That the wlgar auctoryte, Wych for thy party thow hast leyd, Prevyd by argument & seyd, In al the world, thow toldest me, Ther may no plac√´ voyd√´ be; And yiff that woyde wer any thyng, Yt sholde folwe, off thy seyyng, That yt muste fulfylled be; ‚ÄòOr ellys off necessyte Yt muste algatys voyde a-byde: Thy sentence me lyst nat hyde.‚Äô Arystotyles Answerde: ‚ÄòTouchyng,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòthat I ha sayd, So ye be nat evele apayd, I wyl afferme the same yit, I wend√´ trewly to my wyt. ffor to speke in wordys pleyn, That O gret Good most souereyn Sholde (but yiff my wyt be dul,) Make a thyng ffor to be ful.‚Äô Sapyence speketh: ‚Äòffor-soth,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthow seyst ryht wel, And ther-in erryst neueradel. But yt behoueth (yf thow kanst se,) That yt mot nedyes gretter be Than al the world ys off gretnesse; And than mot folwen in sothnesse, (Vnderstond, & herkne me,) That yiff that thyng sholde closyd be With-Inne the world, (yt ys no drede,) On som party yt muste excede, (I dar ryht wel the trouth expresse,) Or overgon yt for gretnesse.‚Äô Arystotyles: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod he, ‚ÄòI may nat wel In thys with-sey yow neueradel.‚Äô Sapyence argueth: ‚ÄòThan her-vp-on,‚Äô a-noon quod she, ‚ÄòIn any wyse how myght yt be, That thys world, so gret in al, With[in] an herte that ys so smal Myghte be put, or closyd be? ffor thann√´, off necessyte Mot nedys folwen, & off Resoun, The hous or thabitac√Øoun Mot be lasse (a preff to wynne,) Than the thyng yput with-Inne. Wher vp[on], conclude I may ‚ÄòThat al thy wordys (yt ys no nay,) Be repreu√°ble founde in dede, And verray fals, yiff thow take hede. ‚ÄòAlso to the I shal devyse A preff in a-nother wyse, By open demonstracyouns. Hastow nat ben in thilk√´ touns, Rome, and Athenys ek also, And soiourn√®d in both√´ two, fful many a yer in both√´ leyn, The maner & the gretnesse seyn, And be-holde ther gouernaunce? Now yiff thow haue in R√©membraunce By cler report off outher toun, Tel me thyn Oppynyoun, What space of land they do contene, And yiff thy wyth may eke sustene, I charg√´ the that thow me telle What noumbre off clerkys ther-in duelle, Off ther estate and ther degres, And the gretnesse of ther cytes.‚Äô Arystotyles answerede: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòto sey the sothe, They be gret and larg√´ bothe, Round off compas, & ryht wyde, And many scolerys ther a-byde, And many a-nother craffty man, As I ful wel Remembre kan.‚Äô Sapience Axeth: Quod Sapience, ‚Äòthan pray I the, O thyng that thow tell√´ me; Touchyng ther makyng and byldynges. Yiff thow hast al thys gret√´ thynges Reportyd wel, on euery syde, Wher hastow put hem to abyde?‚Äô Aristotiles answerde: Quod he, ‚Äòwith support off your grace, I kan telle noon other place, ‚Äò(ffor to speke in wordys pleyne,) Wher I ha put tho townys tweyne, So renomyd & flourynge in glorye, Saue only in my mem√≥rye!‚Äô Sapyence: ‚ÄòNow sothly,‚Äô quod Sapience, Thow hast shewyd thy sentence To me ful pleynly & ryht wel; And declaryd yt euerydel In wordys wyse, & nat rude. And her-vp-on thow shalt conclude, (Yiff prudently thow lyst take heed,) Yiff thy mem√≥rye be in thyn hed, Thow seyst yt ys in lass√´ space (Who so lyst a-ryht compasse,) Than ys thyn hed, on outher syde, Wher thy Mem√≥rye doth a-byde. ‚ÄòAlso ek, in wordys fewe, A-nother exaumple I wyl shewe, Wych I to the rehers√´ shal Off thyn Ey√´ by the bal: Yiff thow ther-to kanst loke a-ryht, Yt ys but smal vn-to the syht, And conteneth lytle space; And yet the gretnesse off thy face A-bydeth there, (yiff thow list lere) Swych as yt ys, hool & entere In Roundnesse off that lytle bour. ‚ÄòTak hed also off A merour, Or ellys off a lytel glas. To purpos in the sam√´ cas, Wher thow mayst ek thy fac√´ se Off what gretnesse that yt be! ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow wylt in bettre wyse, Vn-to the, that I devyse To assoyl thyn Argument ffynally to myn entent, That seyst I sholde ha falshed the, And repryved thy Maxim√´, Whan I seyde, yiff thow take heed, ‚ÄòThat euery party off thys bred Off vertu, in especyal, I make as gret as I do al, Thogh yt be broke on many a part. ‚ÄòAnd tak Exaumple (for al thyn art) Off A merour, fyrst hool at al: Thogh yt be brooke on pecys smal, In ech√´ part and quantyte Thow mayst as wel thy fac√´ se As toforne, (yiff thou lyst lere) Whan yt was fyrst hool and entere Aristotiles Axeth: ‚ÄòNow, myne own√´ lady dere, I pray yow, (towchyng thys matere,) Wych be so sotyl in konnyng, Telleth me, touchyng thys thyng, Vnderstonde ye ‚Äúlocaliter,‚Äù Or ellys ‚Äúvirtualiter?‚Äù Lat thys thyng√´s ben yset, To-gydre bounden & yknet; In boundys closyd so strongly That I ther-on may feythfully Gyve answere, as yt ys skylle, Or close my mouth, & so be stylle.‚Äô Sapience Answereth: ‚ÄòI vnderstond√´ nat,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äò‚ÄúLocaliter,‚Äù as thow shalt se; Thys to seyn√´, with thy grace. He occupieth ther no place. Somme vnderstond√´ certeynly That he ys ther vertuously; Somme seyn ‚Äúymaginatiue,‚Äù And somme ‚Äúrepresentatiue,‚Äù On ther oppynyouns, as they dwelle. And this exaumplys I the telle, To yive the ful avys√´ment How thow mayst, in thyn entent, Conceyve, that halst thy sylff so wys, And to yive the, good avys, How a cloystre off smal mesure ‚ÄòMay comprehend√´ gret pasture; And, as gret√´ thyng√´s set In smal√´ bondys may be knet. ‚ÄòAnd evene so, yiff thow take hed, Vnder lyknesse off thys breed. The grettest good most soverey? Ys ther closyd in certeyn; Nat only ‚Äúymaginatiue,‚Äù Nouther ‚ÄúRepresentatiue,‚Äù (Vnderstond now wel my lore,) Nor ‚ÄúVirtualiter‚Äù with-out√´ more; But ther yt ys put sothfastly, (Yiff thow lyst lerne ffeythfully,) Bothen ‚ÄúCorporaliter‚Äù And also ek ‚ÄúRealiter;‚Äù Bothe ‚ÄúPresencialiter‚Äù And also ek ‚ÄúVeraciter;‚Äù With-oute al symulacioun, Deceyt, or any Ficcioun‚Äî And off thys puttyng, the caus√´ why I haue declaryd in party. ‚Äòffyrst, yiff thow consydrest al, ffor an hert√´ that ys smal, I ha the bred mad smal also, (Yiff thow take good hed her-to.) And for hys gret capacyte, The good that hath most sovereynte, I haue ther-in put (certeyn) The good that ys most souereyn: Gret vnto gret, smal vn-to smal, Wych ys Answeryng in al, And corespondent by mesure. ffor affter that (I the ensure,) That an herte be gret or smal, Ryht so, in especyal, Answeryng, by mesure, Ryght so ys mad√´ the pasture; A smal hert√´ (tak good hede,) ffyndeth also smal the bred. ‚ÄòConsydre & se the maner howh: ‚ÄòYiff he desyre to haue ynowh, He shal ther ffynd√´ (Trust√´ me) Suffysaunc√´ to hys sawl√´, Hym to fulfyllen at hys Ese, And hys desyrys to appese. And, as I rehers√´ shal, Her ys noon offence at al, Nouther vn-to yong nor old. ‚ÄòAnd for thys cause that I ha told, The hous ys lasse, with-out√´ wene, Than thylk√´ thyng yt doth contene; And lasse (for short conclus√Øoun,) Ys the habytacyoun Than the good (I dar wel telle) Wych with-Inne the hows doth dwelle. ‚ÄòAnd I suppose (tak also hed,) That vn-to the, by lyklyhed I hadd√´ don, in my werkynge, Som thyng wych wer nat syttynge, Off wych thow wer nat plesyd wel. And ek (to Reknen euerydel,) That I ha told the in substaunce, Thogh yt wer nat to thy plesaunce, I ouhte off Reson, nor off skyl, Answeryng no-thyng but at my wyl, Off ryht nouht, (as semeth me,) Nor take no maner hed to the Off no-thyng that thow hast me souht. ‚ÄòAnd, par cas, yiff I hadde wrouht Some vnkouth thyng that wer not√°ble By Aventure, or profyt√°ble Mor than any other whyht, Wych wer merveillous to syht, I ouht√´ nat, as thynketh me, Off no wyht apechyd be; Consydred how (in sothfastnesse) That I am namyd a ‚Äúmaystresse,‚Äù Wych ouhte suffysen vn-to the: ‚ÄòThow gest as now no mor of me: Tak thys now in especyal. ‚ÄòAs for Answere to the, fynal, Lo, her ys al, in wordys pleyn:‚Äî Go now, & retourne home ageyn To Nature (in conclus√Øoun), To mak to hyre relac√Øoun, As she that ys (shortly to fyne,) A symple scoler clepd off myne; And also (yiff thow lyst to lere,) But off Grace my chaumberere. ‚ÄòAnd syker, I wyll that yt be wyst, I wyl do what-euere me lyst, Wherso yt ples√´ outher greve, And take off hyre no maner leve; And don what euere lyketh me, Only for loue off Charyte; What euere hyre lyst, that shal be do: My wyl ys that yt shal be so. ffor what-so that hyr lyst devyse, In al my best√´ ffeythfull wyse I shal consente (& tarye nouht,) To al that euere she wyl ha wrouht, In specyal & in general.‚Äô And whan that he hadde herknyd al, Thys Aristotile gan abraide, And humblely to hyre he seyde: Aristotle meked hym selffe. ‚ÄòSothly,‚Äô quod he, ‚ÄòI se ryht wel Yt may avaylle neueradel (ffor ouht that I kan espye,) With yow to holden chaumpartye, Or Argue al the long√´ day: Yt ys best that I go my way. Do what yow lyst, ffer or ner, Your myght ys grete, and your power; What-so ye lyst, ye may well do?.‚Äô ‚ÄòAnd thus thys mayster ys a-gon, And dyd√´ ek hys bysy cure, ffor to tellen to Nature Off hys exployts and off hys sped. And a-noon, as she took heed, She gan to gruchen in hyr thouht; But whan she sawh yt wayllede nouht, Mor to maken r√©sistence, She suffrede al in pac√Øence.‚Äô Whan Grac√´ Dieu off hyr bounte, Thys tal√´ hadde ytold to me, To-forn as ye han herd devysed, With gret desyr I was supprysed In my thouht & my cor√°ge, And hungrede for myn √°vauntage, In hope tave had the bettre sped ffor to haue Etyn off that bred. The Pylgrym prayede. ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod he, & gan hym meke, ‚ÄúHumblely I yow be-seke, Me to graunte, to myn encres, Off the Releff off Moyses, My voyded hert√´ to fulfylle, Wych so longe (a-geyn my wylle, As ye wel knowe,) hath voyd√´ be, And neuere ne hadde hys ful sawlee. ffor, to thys tyme neuere yit I nat conceyvede in my wyt Wher-with yt myghte fulfylled be; ffor wych, I pray yow, graunteth me.‚Äù Grace Dieu Answerde ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthy requeste, I holde yt ys nat dyshoneste; ffor thys bred ys necessarye To all√´ folk wych lyst nat tarye In ther vyage, thus semeth me. ffor, or thow come to that cyte Whyder thow castest for to gon, By many wey√´s mo than on, Thow shalt be troublyd (yt ys no dred) ‚ÄòYiff thow haue nat off thys bred, Al thy sorwes for tapese, Thow art lyk to haue dysesse, And in thy wey√´ gret offence; ffor wych thow shalt ha lycence To take thys bred, & ek conge. ‚ÄòBut fyrst, off ryht & equyte, Toward thys bred or that thow drawe, (As yt ys wryten in my lawe;) Thow must ha fyrst, pocess√Øoun Off a sherpe & a bordoun, As thow to-forn Requeryst me In lowly wyse to graunte hem the. ‚ÄòAnd I answerd√´ the ageyn, And the be-hihte ek (in certeyn,) That in myn hows ther was plente Off both√´ tweyne: thus told I the. And tolde the, on the tother syde, That I sholde for the provyde, To shew√´ the, in my depoos, Thynges that wer with-Inn√´ cloos, Wych I ha shewyd but to fewe; But vn-to the I shal hem shewe. And somme off hem secrely I ha the shewyd in party, And am ay redy (as I tolde) Thy couenaunt√´s for to holde With-outen al collus√Øoun. ‚ÄòAnd towchyng shyrpe & bordoun, Thow shalt hem haue (as I be-hihte) Deluyered in thyn own√´ sighte. And after that, (yt ys no drede,) Thow shalt nowe put ther-in thy bred With-Inne thy shryppe, as yt ys ryht; And affter that, thow shalt ha myght, fforth vp-on thy way, by grace, As A pylgrym for to passe. The pylgryme answerid: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod he, with gret meknesse, ‚ÄúI thanke vn-to your worthynesse; ffor my desyr & my wysshynges Resten fully in thys thynges. I wolde, with-out√´ wordys mo, Have hem fayn, & ben ago.‚Äù Thanne thys lady, off hyr grace, Ladd√´ me in-to a place In wyche (who kan report√´ wel) Was ful many a ffayr Iowel, Vp-on wyche myn Eye I leyde; And Euene thus to me she seyde: Grace dieu spake: ‚ÄòLefft vp thyn Eye, be-hold & se, And tak good heed now vn-to me! ‚Äòffyrst, thys skryppe & thys bordoun Haven thys condycyoun, That thow in soth may them nat se, But yiff so falle, thyn eyen be Set ther as thyn Erys stonde. And therfor thow shalt vnderstonde, Yiff thow hem seye A-noon now ryht With thyn Eyen cler & bryht, Wher as they be, now trust√´ wel They sholde the ples√´ neueradel. Wherfor I shal (yiff that I may) Bothe thyn Eyen take away, And hem out off her plac√´ fette; And in thyn Erys I shal hem sette, That thow mayst, at lyberte, Skryppe & bordoun bettre se.‚Äô the pylgryme marvelethe: ‚ÄúMadame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúwhat lyst ye seyn? Me thynketh that ye speke in veyn: Ye speke off thyng that me wer loth, And make myn hert√´ wonder wroth, And yive to me occas√Øoun To leu√´ skryppe & ek bordoun, ‚ÄúAnd to for-sak√´ both√´ tweyne. And syker (yiff I shal nat feyne,) I hadde leuere to do so, Than to endure so gret√´ wo, ffor taper√´ monstruous, Or shewe me-sylff so odius; Or that ye sholde (I yow ensure,) So me transforme or dysfygure.‚Äù grace dieu spake: ‚ÄòVnderstond,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòa lyte In thys mater, my sylff taquyte, Off wych I shal the tell√´ more. ‚ÄòYt ys not yet ygon ful yore (Yiff thow remembre, & lyst tak hed,) Whan thow doutest the off thys bred, And haddest merveil (ek parde,) By what Resoun yt myght√´ be, Whan thyn hert√´ stood in doute That so mych√´ folk aboute Hadde in thys bred ful suffysaunce, And ful repast to ther plesaunce, That al thy wyttys, in no wyse Koud√´ tech√´ the the guyse Of thys vnkouth√´ pryvyte; And, ne hadde thy Erys be, (Yiff thow Remembre th√® ryht wel,) Thow haddest knowen neueradel. ‚ÄòFor yiff yt be a-ryht conceyved, Alle thy wyttys wer deceyved, And lyede pleynly vn-to the, What they felte or dyd√´ se, Saue the trouth (& thus yt stood) With thyn Eryng stylle a-bood. ‚ÄòWherfore I muste (of verray ryht,) Translate thyn Eyen & thy syht, Thyder wher thyn Erys stonde. And (as thow shalt wel vnderstonde,) Thyn Erys muste haue Ey√´n clere Taparceyv√´, in thys matere, And to conceyven euery thyng. ‚Äòffor, trust√´ me wel, that Eryng Wel dysposyd, voyde of slowthe, Kan the tell√´ best the trouthe, In thyng√´s wych that ben dotous, Wonderful & merveyllous. ‚Äòffor wych thyng, I wyll nat lette, Ther thyn Eyen for to sette, With hem to sharp√´ mor thy wyt; ffor thow seyst nat clerly yit, As thow ouhtest in thyn mynde. Thow trustest vp-on four√´ blynde. On whom trowynge, (trust√´ me,) Thow art ful blynde, & mayst nat se. ‚ÄòBut yt be-houeth, that clerly Thow mustest sen, & openly, Or thow haue pocess√Øoun Outher of skryppe or off bordoun. ffor thow shalt hem nat possede, Nor bern hem out (yt ys no drede,) Out off myn hous, in no manere, (Sherpe or bordoun bothe yfere) Tyl thow knowe (with-out√´ slowthe) Verrayly the pleyn√´ trouthe Off al that hath be told to the Touchynge thys bred; now truste to me, And wene nat,‚Äîin no maner wyse, As I shal to the devyse,‚Äî That I no-thyng off volunte Seye thys wordys to tempt√´ the A-skawnce: I wold√´ A-geyns ryht With-drawe that I ha the be-hyht: To the, my promys I wyl kepe; ffor neuere, vakyng nor a-slepe, (As I ryht wel rehers√´ kan,) I deceyved neuere man Off thyng that longede vn-to me. ‚ÄòAnd ther-fore dout√´ no-thyng the, That I wyl to no strang√´ fourme, The diffacen, nor dysfourme; ffor platly (in conclus√Øoun) ‚ÄòYt lyth in thyn ellecc√Øoun, And in thy fre choys yt shal be, ffor to chesyn, as for me To settyn thyn eyen her or there. ‚ÄòAnd for my party, thow shalt lere Yiff thow in me haue swych√´ tryst, ffor to Remeue hem wher me lyst, As for onys to assaye, Yiff I ther-wyth nat the dysmaye, But do yt for thyn √°vauntage, The ther nat pleyne on no damage.‚Äô The pilgrim axithe: ‚ÄúWher-off serueth (touchyng thys thyng) Clernesse off myn vnderstondyng, Wych clerkys calle (in sentement) Intellect or entend√´ment, Wych hath Eyen (I dar seyn so,) As manye (or an hundryd mo) As hadde Argus of yore agoon, Yit in hys Erys hadde he noon, In bookys olde ye may well se. ‚ÄúI hope yt stant nat so with me, That good avys shal me so faylle, Nor no Rudness√´ so masaylle. Me thynketh pleynly (as I tolde) But that myn vnderstondyng sholde Techyn me the trouth al pleyn, And ther-to hau√´ no dysdeyne, Me tenfourme of al thys thyng, With-outen any remowyng Off the Ey√´n in myn hed Into myn Eryn (who kan tak hed); Wych wer in soth An vnkouth syht, And gret merveyl to euery whyht.‚Äù Grace Dieu Answerde Quod grace dieu, ‚Äòtak hed, & se, Thyn vnderstondyng (trust√´ me) Wolde in soth ha no dysdeyne To tech√´ the the trouth√´ pleyn. But thow mayst trust√´ me ryht wel: ‚ÄòHe vnderstondeth neueradel Off thys matere that we off talke, He goth be-syde, & maketh a balke,‚Äî To sen clerly thexcellence, The valu and the magnyfycence Off that we holde our parlement, He ys so feble & indygent ffor lak off knowyng (in sothnesse), He ys [so] fallen in dyrk√´nesse, That he knoweth her-of ryht nouht, Truste me well, (yiff yt be souht,) The verray trouthe, (so god me saue). ‚ÄòAnd ther thow seyst, he sholde ek haue An hundryd ey√´n, & yet mo, Thow shalt wel wyte yt ys nat so, Nor that yt ys a thyng credyble, Nor off hys lookys wych be possyble, Wych he hath by successyouns; I sey nat off thentencyouns Wych thow hast in many wyse; ffor than (shortly to devyse) In swych caas thow seydest wel, And elles platly thow shalt fel Thow wentyst foule out off the weye. ‚Äòffor he hath only but on Eye, That Symply seth & vnderstondeth, And thyng√´s wych he vnderstondeth Lyk to hys syht, as they doth deme, He byt, & kan no ferther deme. Swych thyng as longeth to hym off ryht, ffor to be demyd by the syht, He receyveth to hys presence; And thann√´ thyn Intelligence, Also ffer as he doth se, He Gyveth hys doom in that degre: On thyng nat seyn, he kan nat muse; But al swych thyng he doth refuse, And sent yt forth (pleynly to seyn), Outward, ther as yt kam a-geyn. ffor lak, he kan no ferther se, ‚ÄòThorgh hys ffoltysshe vanyte.‚Äô The pilgrym axithe: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúful gladly I wolde wyten certeynly, Clerly to be put out off doute, What ys he that wych sendeth oute, And what ys he (ek in certeyn) That Reporteth hem A-geyn Tydynges erly & ek late; And yiff ther be ek any gate A-twen the brynger and hym that sent; I wold√´ fayn in myn Entent Off yow haue Informacyoun, And clerly dyffynycyoun.‚Äù Grace Dieu Answerthe ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod sche, ‚Äòby thyn askyng Thow shalt neuere knowe no thyng As I be-leu√´, in substaunce. ‚ÄòThow herdyst whylom, how dame penaunce Made a declarac√Øoun Off vj. gatys, in hyr sarmoun. And fyve off hem, she sayd√´ blyue, That they wer the wyttys fyue; By wych gatys she dyde assure, That al fylth√´s & al ordure Entrede in, in sondry wyse, (As thow herdyst hyre devyse,) Whan they wer open, & nat cloos. The wych gatys, to my purpos I wyl now take in specyal With-out√´ preiudice at al. ‚Äòffor thys gatys, I calle ‚Äúporterys,‚Äù ‚ÄúBryngerys-in & massagerys‚Äù Off ech√´ thyng, & sayd with-oute, But yiff yt falle with-out√´ doute, Certeyn Secretys, wych that be Hyd & ydon in pryvyte. Thys gatys I calle the ‚Äúpassages, Wherby in passen the massages.‚Äù ‚ÄòThys to seyne (vnderstond me wel; ‚ÄòConceyve my speche euerydel:) Eye ys the gate, lookyng porter; Nose, the dore & massager Who kan parceyve ys smellyng; And semblably in euery thyng, Euene lyk yt doth be-falle Off thyn other wyttys alle, Thanne whan that lokyng is porter Off the Eye, & massager. ‚ÄòAnd I wyl here by & by Speke off the Ey√´ specyally, And lete the tother passe & gon. ‚ÄòNow herkne, & thow shalt here A-noon As I sayde rathe vn-to the, Lokyng, with wych men do se, Vn-to the Eye ys porter (As thow well wost) & massager; And whan that he seth thyng√´s newe, ffresshe & lusty of ther hewe, ffayr or foul, wher-so yt be, He bydeth nat in no degre, Nouther slepeth nor resteth nouht, But, as swyfft as any thouht,‚Äî Thorgh hys bysy dyllygence, A-noon, (as he hath licence Off the wyttys callyd comwne,‚Äî Thanne hys offyce to contune,) He maketh a demonstracioun, Report & ful relacyoun, ffyrst off all, to fantasye. ‚ÄòThanne ffantasye doth hyr hye To Go forth to Entend√´ment, To yive a trew√´ Iugement Off report that he hath brouht, Iustly to deme, & err√´ nouht, Be yt off thyng√´s newe or old. ‚ÄòNow telle I the, as I ha told Amongys al thy doomys stronge; Yiff the thyng vn-to hym longe, Thanne he (in conclus√Øoun) ‚ÄòWyl yt demyn off Resoun. And ther-vp-on ek d√©termyne, And in hast hys doomys fyne, Whan he hath cerchyd yt & sought. ‚Äò& yiff to hym yt longeth novht, By hem that brouhte yt (in certeyn), In haste he sent yt forth ageyn; The Messagerys (Erly and late) Conveye yt by the sam√´ gate By wych yt kam: lo, her ys al. ‚ÄòAnd mor to the I tell√´ shal; (Reporte me wel at all√´ tymes;) The skryppe that longeth to pylgrymes, (I mene, off pylgrymes in specyal, Swyche as be good√´ founde at al,) Whan they hem skryppen euerychon, They fyrst vn-to the gat√´ gon Off the Ere, & off Eryng; And ther, with-oute mor taryyng, Hem sylff redy for to make, ffyrst, the porter they awake Yiff that he slepe; and than A-noon, By thylk√´ gat√´, in they gon. ‚ÄòOff other gatys (I ensure) They do no fors, nor ha no cure; ffor heryng ther ys cheff porter; And he goth forth as massager, ffyrst to wyttys that be comwne; And, or that they ther-on comwne, They make a demonstracyoun Cler, & ful relac√Øoun, To fantasye, wher as she Syt. ‚ÄòAnd no lenger she abyt, But to the gret√´ Iuge she goth (Wherso that he be glad or wroth); She sheweth platly hyr entent Vn-to thys Iuge, Entend√´ment. And whan that he hath musyd longe Theron, in hys doomys stronge, And he, for lak off knowelychyng, ‚Äòffeleth ther-in no maner thyng, Thanne off Folye, he chek maat, Awhapyd and dysconsolat, Sent yt ageyn (yt stondeth so) By thylk√´ gate that yt kam fro; ffor he (shortly, in sentement) Koude gyue noon other Iug√´ment, ffor al hys wyttys wer a-gon, Saue that Eryng (among echon) Kam a-noon to hys refuge, ffor to deme & be a Iuge, As yt longede off verray ryht. ‚Äòffor smellyng, Tastyng, touch, & Syht, They wer deceyved, euerychon; And for to knowe the trouthe a-noon, And a trew√´ doom to make, A man must√´ the Ey√´n take, And to the Erys hem translate, Wych off Eryng ys the gate; And ther, whan they be set aryht, They shal be cleryd so off syht To dem√´ trouthe, and no-thyng erre, Bryht as any sonne or sterre.‚Äô The pylgrym answereth: ‚ÄúWhat euer,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúthat ye han sayd, Ther-off I am ryht wel a-payd. I ha consydred euerydel That ye to-forn ha seyd ryht wel; ffor wych, ma dame, (as ye best se,) I wyl√´ that myn Eyen be With-Inne myn Erys set a-noon, Or ye any ferther gon. ffor I ha conceyved in my thouht, That to me, ful lyte or nouht My pylgrymag√´ sholde avaylle, Yiff so that I dyd√´ ffaylle To haue a Skrypp√´ or Burdo?.‚Äù And tho to myn Entenc√Øo? (Lyche as to yow I told√´ Late ) Myn Eyen two she gan translate In-to myn Eryn, ther they stood. And for she sawh that yt was good, An huchche she gan a-noon vn-shette; And out a-noon ther-off she fette (Lyk to myn oppynyoun) Bothe a skryppe & a bordoun. Off wych thyng√´s, a-noon I Gan to merveille ful gretly, With myn Erys (as she me tolde) Whan that I gan hem be-holde: The skrypp√´ mad & shap√´ clene, By A gyrdel heng off grene, The wych was (as I vnderstood) Spreynt with dropys off red blood, Wheroff I was abaisshed sore. And over that, I sawh yet more: Vpon the sam√´ gyrdle stronge, Off syluer, smal√´ bellys honge, Twelue in noumbre, & no mo, Wel enamellyd; & also Ech off hem (I yow ensure) Hadd√´ a dyuers Scrypture, The lettrys large & curyous; And in the ffyrste was wryten thus: ‚ÄúGod the ffader,‚Äù fful wel ywrouht, That heuene and erth√´ made off nouht, And made ek man to hys lyknesse, Off hys grace & hys goodnesse. And ferthermor (yiff I shal telle) Was wryten in the next√´ belle: ‚ÄúGod the Sone, off wysdam most.‚Äù In the thrydde, ‚ÄúGod the Holygost.‚Äù And they wer mad so wel, echon, Semynge to me they were al on; And with-Inne I dyd√´ se A claper that seruede hem all thre. In the fourthe was wryte & graue, How goddys son√´, man to saue, Cryst ihesu, descended doun ffrom that hevenly mansyoun In-to the Erthe, & be-kam man; And (as I rehers√´ kan,) Off the holy gost conceyved, Porely in thys world receyved, Born off A mayd√´ pur & ffre, Ay flouryng in vyrgynyte, Wych all√´ wemmen dyde excelle. And wryten in the fyffth√´ belle, Graue in ordre, by & by, Was hys gret√´ tormentry, And ek how he was crucyfyed, And how that he for man hath dyed, And suffryd ful gret pass√Øoun, To maken hys redempcyoun, With many woundys ful terryble, And rebukys ful penyble, Mankynde only for to save; Take fro the croos, put in hys graue, Affter al hys peyne & wo. And in the .vj. was wryte also, (Wrouht, yt myghte nat be amendyd,) How he to hell√´ ys descendyd, Hys frendys ther to fette a-way, Wych hadde be there so many a day To bryng√´ hem to paradys. And in the .vij. (by gret avys) Was wryte hys resurecc√Øoun; In the viij., hys Ascencioun Vp to the hih√´ heuene ageyn, With hys fader (in certeyn) To sytten there on the ryht syde, With hym perpetuelly tabyde, Ther to demen quyk & dede, Euery man affter hys dede. Also (yiff ye lyst to wyte,) In the nynth√´ ther was wryte (Graue off hym that dyde yt werche,) Crystys spous√´, hooly cherche, With al hys dyuers paramentys, And all the .vij. sacramentys. And in the Tenth√´, men myhte se The Oonyng and the vnyte Off seyntys, the comunyoun, Ordeyned for manhys refeccyoun, And off synn√´s Indulgence By baptesme & by penytence. And in the .xj. (be wel certeyn,) Was the Rysyng vp A-geyn Off all man-kynde, bothe hih & lowe, Whan gabryel hys horn shal blowe, To calle all ffolkys off entent To kom√´ to the Iug√´ment. Body & sowle (as ye shal lere) Both√´ knet Ageyn yfere, Shal ther come to audience, ffor to heryn the sentence; And thyder haven ther Repayr To-for the Iuge hih in the hayr, Goode & badde: thus stant the caas. And in the .xij., grauen ther was Only, off good√´, the guerdoun, And off wykked, punycyoun, Swych as dyd√´ no penaunce, Nor ne hadde no r√©pentaunce To make amendys, I yow ensure. Loo, her, hooly the scrypture Off the syluer bellys clere, And off the namel ek yfere. Now shall I tellen the ffacioun And the maner off the bordoun, Wych was (yiff ye lyst to lere) Wrouht & mad in thys manere: Yt was ymad bothe strong & lyht, Long also, & evene vpryht; Off dry√´ wode (yiff yt be souht) Wyche neuere ne roteth nouht, Nor neuere perissheth, (in certeyn,) Nouther for ffyr, nor ffor no reyn. Yt was ywrouht & mad so wel; And a-boue, a Round poomel Off a merrour, that shon ful bryht, And gaff envyroun a gret lyht, In the wych, men myght√´ se ffer ffrom hem al the contre Rounde aboute hem Envyroun. ffor ther ne was no regyoun So ffer from yt, by no dystaunce, (To Reknen euery cyrcumstaunce) But men myghte sen yt euerydel, And beholde yt ffayre & wel. And in that myrour dyde I se The maner hool off the cyte To the wych I was so bent ffor to gon, in myn entent. ffor wych (in myn oppynyoun) I preysede gretly the Bordoun, And louyd also wel the bet. & lower doun ek ther was set A-nother poomel, wych off makyng Was lasse & Round, (to my seemyng,) Maad off a charboncle ston, The wych as any sonn√´ shoon, Thorgh al the contre shadde hys lyht (Yt was so Oryent and so bryht) An hug√´ compas round a-boute. And whan she hadde ytaken oute Thys two Iowellys ffayr & ryche, I trow√´ nowher wer noon lyche, Grace dieu (fayre mot hyr falle!) In goodly wys√´ gan me calle. Grace dieu speketh: Thys lady goodly spak to me, ‚ÄòKom ner, my sone; tak hed & se; Loo her (yiff I shal nat feyne) Thylk√´ Rych√´ Gyfftys tweyne Wych I be-hihte whylom to the; And thow shalt nat deceyved be. ‚ÄòLoo her A skryppe & a Bordoun, ‚ÄòThe wych (off hool entencyoun) I gyve to the, now kep hem wel! Considre the maner everydel, How they be ryht necessarye To forthre the, (thow shalt nat tarye,) To help√´ the in thy vyage, And to spede thy pylgrymage. Thow shalt off hem have ay gret nede, Yiff thow lyst thy Iourne spede, Nedful to pylgrym√´s alle; And ‚Äúfeyth,‚Äù thy Skrypp√´ thow shalt calle; Wyth-out√´ wych, may nat be Brouht about√´ no Iournee Nor vy√°ge that may a-vaylle. ffor, thy bred & thy vytaylle, Ther-in thow shalt alway concerve, And all√´ tymes thow shalt observe Thys skrypp√´ wel in thy bandoun, In euery cyte & euery Toun, In al thy most√´ feythful wyse, And also for to auctoryse. ‚ÄòTouchyng thys Skrypp√´ callyd ‚Äúffeyth,‚Äù Herkne what thapostel seyth In a pystel that he endyteth, And to the Romayns pleynly wryteth: ‚ÄúThe ryht-ful man, with-out√´ stryff, By thys skrypp√´ lat hys lyff;‚Äù Thys to seyne, that ffeyth off ryht Yiveth lyff to euery maner whyht; As Abachuch that hooly man, In hys wrytyng rehers√´ kan, The secounde chapytle off hys book, Who so lyst lyfft vp hys look. ‚ÄòAnd thys skryppe (with-out√´ wene,) Off hys colour mot be grene; Wych colour (who so look a-ryht) Doth gret comfort to the syht; ‚ÄòSharpeth the Eye, (yt ys no dred,) And so doth ffeyth, (who taketh hed;) Yt maketh pylgrymes glad & lyht, With hem abydyng day & nyht; And in ther weye (I dar reporte,) Gretly doth hem Reconforte. ffor good pylgrym√´s euerychon, On pylgrymag√´ wher they gon, Only ffeyth doth hem sustene, By exaumple, as the grene, The gentyl colour glad & lyht, Yiveth clernesse to the syht. ‚ÄòWhan the gren√´ al with-oute Ys spreynt with dropys Round aboute Off red blood (who kan entende), Than the syht yt doth amende fful gretly, I dar wel seyn; ffor ther ys drop√´ noon certeyn, But yt ys worth, & off mor prys To pylgrym√´s that be wys, Than outher perle or margaryte. And (as I dar ryht wel endyte,) Yt is mor Ryche & precyous, Mor off valu & vertuous, The bloody dropys, whan they be spreynt Vp-on the gren√´, & ymeynt, To make a man mor strong & lyht, And tafforc√´ with hys syht, Than any other Rych√´ ston ffor to rekne hem euerichon, ‚ÄòThe grene ys good in specyal Whan the rede ys meynt with-al Off blood; for pleynly the Rednesse Wych that was shad in clennesse Off gloryous martyrs longe agon, That spente her blood, & lefft√´ noon, But suffrede al the vyolence, And the mortal ek sentence Off Tyrauntys Tyranye, ‚ÄòAnd sparede nat platly to dye, (Ther legende so wryt & seyth) ffor to dyffend√´ crystys ffeyth; ffor wych, vp-on thys skryppe off grene, The bloody dropys ther ysene, Shewyn (in conclus√Øoun) Ther martyrdam, ther pass√Øoun, Off ther own√´ volunte, Only to yiven vn-to the Verrayly an exaumplayre (Wherso-euere thow repayre) To suffre deth for crystys sake, Rather than thow shust forsake Thy skryppe in any maner wyse, Off wych thow hast herd me devyse. ‚Äòffor seyntys wych that suffrede so, I wot ryht wel that they be go To paradys, & Entryd in; ffor the swerd off cherubin, Wych whilom at the gat√´ stood, Ys so blontyd with her blood, That yt ys (I dar wel seyn) In the skawberk vp ageyn. ‚ÄòBut now-a-day√´s it stant so, Hooly seyntys ben all a-go, That wer so myghty & so strong, And dradd√´ nat to suffre a wrong ffor the ffeyth, yt to dyffende, Her lyff, her blood, ther-on to spende; Redy they wern, & that a-noon; But now, annethe ther ys nat on That wyl hym putte in Iupartye, Crystys feyth to magnefye, Nor mak√´ myghty r√©systence Ageyn Tyrauntys by dyffence. ‚ÄòYet somme boste & spek√´ grete Whan they be fumous, ful off heete, And han yheete & dronke at large, Her bely stuffyd as a barge: Than they, for our feythys sake, ‚ÄòWyl crystys croos vp-on hem take; And, as champyouns, thanne they seyth That they wyl fyht√´ for our ffeyth. But whan yt kometh vn-to nede, Al that th√©y spak touchyng dede, Yt ys for nouht, I dar wel seyn; And thus ther bost ys but in veyn; By ther wordys they wyl nat dwelle. ‚ÄòBut by old tyme, I shal the telle, Whan I the skryppe gan fyrst devyse, Yt was al in a-nother wyse, With-out√´ bellys, symplely; Than suffysede, stedefastly To lou√´ god, our cr√©atour, And hym to serue with gret honour. ‚ÄòBut affter roos vp heresyes, Oppynyouns & fantasyes, The ffeyth√´ falsly for to greue; And ther gan euery man to leue On god affter hys own√´ lust, And sett√´ pleynly Al ther trust Affter ther own√´ ffantasye; Off wych (yiff I shal nat lye) Somme wer callyd ‚ÄúArryens,‚Äù And somme also ‚Äúpellagyens,‚Äù With ther oppynyouns newe; And other sectys ful vntrewe, The feyth off cryst for to werreye, And lyst nat to the cherche obeye, Thorgh ther false oppynyouns, Concludyng by collus√Øouns Off falshed shewyng many sygne, Ageyn thy skrypp√´ to malygne, Ther-vp-on to be a-wreke; Off whom me lyst no mor to speke. ‚ÄòBut my speche I wyl restreyne; ffor wych cause, folk dyde hyr peyne, And prelatys off the cherche, Ageyn ther malys for to werche, Makyng in especyal ‚ÄòSenys & counsaylles general, Off prouydence & gret avys, ffor to wythstond√´ ther malys, And ther errours to putte a-way, That contynuede many a day, To reform√´ the bewte Off the cherche by vnyte, I mene, by vnyte in substaunce Off our ffeyth and our creaunce, In ther hool Entencyoun; To mak√´ Restytucyoun, By ther dyllygent labour, Off that was broke by ther Errour, That with-Inn√´ nor with-oute Yt sholde no mor be put in doute. ‚ÄòAnd for that skyle, & no thyng ellys, They souhten out the .xii. bellys That I off spak, & I the telle: They sett√´ lettrys in ech belle, And articles off our creaunce, By thapostolys Ordynaunce; The wych wer mad (with-out√´ stryff) In hooly cherch√´ prymytyff. ‚ÄòAnd in the Skryppe (tak hed to me) Off wych√´ now I tell√´ the (Off entent ful pur & clene), The bellys, mad off syluer shene, They hengen hem, as thow mayst se, Wych thow howest (off du√´te) Offt√´ syth√´s here hem Rynge, Off entente only to brynge Ther sown vn-to thy r√©membraunce, And how thow shalt, in thy creaunce, Leve in god ay stedefastly. ‚ÄòAnd for that skyle, contynuelly In thyn Erys the tawake, Thy bellys shal a chymbyng make, Day be day (in sothfastnesse) To tech√´ th√® the stedefastnesse Off the feyth, thy-sylff to Saue. ‚ÄòAnd the nedeth nat to haue Noon other horlege, day nor nyht, ffor to smyte thyn hourys ryht, Yiff thow ther strokys trewly tellys, .xij. hourys and .xij. bellys; And ek also graue in the lettre .xij. Artycles, to go the bettre, Wych shal echon yfound√´ be Wyth-Inne thy skryppe, to tech√´ the, And tenforme the wel ynowh. ‚ÄòBut thow hast be somwhat slowh, In thyn herte to taken hede, Ther scryptur√´ for to Rede; I men√´ thus, thy sylff to saue, The Scrypture in the bellys graue; Yet, by ther chymyng (in substaunce), Thow sholdest ay ha r√©membraunce Vp-on thy skrypp√´ callyd ‚Äúffeyth,‚Äù ‚ÄòAnd thynk ek what Thapostel seyth: To the Romeyns he endyteth, Pleynly seyth, and thus he wryteth: ‚ÄúThat thys bellys, in ther chymynge, And by noyse off ther sownynge, Parfytly they brynge in feyth To the Erys; and thus he seyth: ‚ÄúWher thyn Eyen be set most clere, The verray trew√´ sown to here, Abydyng√´, nat transyt√≥rye, To excyten thy Mem√≥rye, Thy pylgrymag√´ to Acheve, How thow shalt ffyrst, in god be-leue; Wych doth nat ynowh suffyse, Wyth-out√´ that I shal devyse. ‚Äòffor yt be-houeth ek herto, That thow mustest beleue also Stedefastly (yt ys no dred), That thys wyn & ek thys bred Be chaungyd in-to flesshe & blood. ‚ÄòAnd her-with-al yt ys ek good, Be-leue O god in Trynyte, Thre personys in vnyte. And, thy ffeyth mor strong to make, Thow shalt a good exaumple take Off thylk√´ syluer bellys thre, To wych, in Tookne off Vnyte, A claper serueth in chymyng, Wych declareth in sownyng, ‚ÄúTher ys but o god, & no mo.‚Äù ‚ÄòAnd tak Alway good hed her-to, ffro thys, that thy ffeyth nat varye, Who-euere sowne the contrarye. And truste wel how the partycles And the Remnaunt off Artycles Of all the tother, (who kan entende) Euerychon, her-on depende. ‚ÄòNow take thy Skryppe, & go thy way, And thynk her-on ryht wel alway; And forget nat (yong nor old,) No thyng that I ha the told, Wryt in thyn herte as in a book.‚Äô [The Pilgrim.] And off hyr hand the Skryppe I took; But she, only off hyr goodnesse, The skryppe about√´ me gan dresse,‚Äî Thys Grac√´ dieu, ful manerly,‚Äî And Tapoynte yt ffetysly, Ouer my shuldere she yt caste, And be-gan to bookele yt faste, In travers wyse, yt tenbrasse, She gan the gerdel to compasse; Made the pendant, that was long, To be knet & fastnyd strong, That the Tong√´ thorgh gan perce. And than to me she gan reherse A scrypture off ysaye Remembryd in hys prophesye, The .ii. chapytle ye may se, Grac√´ dieu seyng to me: Grace dieu: ‚Äòffyrst, thow shalt haue ffor Sykernesse A gyrdel off Ryghtwysnesse, To restreyne al lecherye. And, for to mak√´ also dye Al fflesshly lustys euerychon, I shal the gyrde (& that a-noon,) Wyth thys skryppe, wych thow shalt bere The to dyffende (that no thyng deere) On pylgrymage, wherso thow go.‚Äô And thanne she took a wryt also Out off hyr huchche, & rauht yt me. ‚ÄòIn thys wryt, thow mayst,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòBe-hold√´ the descrypc√Øoun, The maner hool, and the fasoun Off the skryppe that I the took; And offt√´ cast ther-on thy look ffro day to day, the bet to spede; And offt√´ sythe that thow yt rede, The cop√´ pleynly, & scripture, The wych ys mad (I the ensure) In latyn only, off entent To yive to th√® entend√´ment, And to clerkys that kan lettrure, And vnderstonde hem in Scrypture, That they may, both hih & lowe, The maner off thy Skrypp√´ knowe, To folwe the ffeyth off crystys secte; To hem thys latyn I dyrecte. [The Pilgrim.] Wyth thys skryppe whan I was bounde, Glad I was, & ful Jocounde; And than I gan a-noon enquere, Prayede she wolde vn-to me lere. (Lyst that ther wer any lak) Off the gyrdel that she off spak, That I myghte vnderstonde aryht The thyng that she hadde me behyht. Grace dieu: Quod Grace dieu, ‚Äòtouchyng al thys, Off thy gyrdel & my promys, Thow sholdest (off good entencioun) ffyrst yaxyd A Bordoun, The to susten√´ nyht & day, And supporte the on thy way Wherso that thow go or walke. And affter, I caste me to talke With the, and pleynly ek expresse Off the gyrdel off ryhtwysnesse. ‚ÄòBut ffyrst tak hed off the Bordoun, How yt ys good in ech sesoun, ffor he nat falleth comounly That leneth ther on stedefastly. ffor wych thow shalt (as yt ys ryht,) With al thy fforce & al thy myght, Ther-on reste, what so be-falle. And trewly thow shalt nat falle, What perillous passage that thow go, As longe as thow takest hed ther-to, And, tavoyde away dyspeyr, Wherso thow gost in foul or ffayr, Or what fortun√´ the be-falle. ‚ÄúGood hope‚Äù alway thow shalt yt calle: Thys the name off thy Bordoun, Off trust & trewe affecc√Øoun, Wych ys callyd Esperaunce, Affter the speche vsyd in fraunce, And the maner off that langu√°ge. ‚ÄòAnd looke alway, in thy pass√°ge, That thow holde the wel ther-by, And ther-on rest√´ feythfully In peryllous pathys wher thow wende. And by the pomellys at the Ende, Holde the strongly, I the rede, ffor they shal, in al thy nede Susten√´ the, thow fall√´ nouht, ‚ÄòThe hiher pomel (yiff yt be souht) Ys ihesu cryst: haue hym in mynde; And in scrypture (as thow shalt fynde.) He ys the morour cler & bryht, With-out√´ spot, (bothe day & nyht,) In the wyche, a man, by grace, May beholde hys own√´ fface, In wych merour (as I tolde) Al the world ouht√´ be-holde. In wych also men may fynde All√´ thynges wrouht be kynde. Reste vp-on hym with herte and thouht, And go surly, & dred the nouht; And to hys help√´ alway calle, And trust√´ wel thow shalt nat falle. ‚ÄòThe tother pomel lowere doun, Wych (with-oute comparisoun, Yiff I shal the trouth√´ telle) Ys the Mayde that doth excelle Al other off bewte & bounte; ffor she, in hyr vyrgynyte, Bar a chyld in thys world here, Mayde & moder bothe yfere, The Charbouncle most cler off lyht, Chasynge away dyrknesse off nyht, And al thys world doth √©nlwmyne; The ffressh√´ bemys so clerly shyne. Al that go mys in ther pass√°ge, Or erryn in ther pylgrym√°ge; Or ffolk that gon out off her way, (As wel be nyht√´ as be day, I dar afferme yt in certeyn) She maketh hem to resorte ageyn Vn-to the ryht√´ weye a-noon: ffor to pylgrym√´s euerychon She ys the trew√´ Gyderesse; And ther socour in al dyrknesse; And yiff they slydre, or fall√´ doun, Thys Emperesse off most renoun, Only off mercy, doth hem releue, That no thyng ne may hem greue In ther passag√´ nyh nor ferre, For she ys the lood√´ sterre, With her bryht√´ bemys clere, To al pylgrymes in thys lyff here, That han to hyre affectyoun. ‚ÄòAnd for that skyle, in thys bordoun, In thys pomel (yiff thow kanst knowe) She ys yset her doun alowe By an Arche ymad off newe: No charbouncle so bryht off hewe, Nor noon other precyous ston, Rekne the .xij. euerychon. ‚ÄòAnd in thys bordoun, look√´ wel How she ys set for a pomel, Pylgrymes to saue, they be nat lorn, Wher-as ther was but On to-forn. ‚ÄòBut thys pomel most bryht & shene, Pylgrym√´s only to sustene, Ys set in ful goodely wyse; ffor ellys myght√´ nat suffyse The tother, but she wer ther also, Hem to supporte, wher-so they go. ffor she ys mene, (& that ful offte,) To the pomel hih a-loffte: Thys to seyne, thys heuenely quene, To hyr sone ys euere a mene; Coumfort most princypal & cheff Tal pylgrymes in ther myscheff, Hem to supporte, who taketh hede. ‚ÄòAnd therfore whan thou hauest nede, Trust on hyre, & neuere varye, ffor she ys most necessarye To holde hem vp in ther passage, Wher they ben old or yong off age. Leue on hyre, what so befalle, & in thy way thow shalt nat falle, Yiff that thow in eche sesoun Haue in hyre affecc√Øoun, Thow mayst nat stomble nouther slydre Whan thys pomellys ben to-gydre; She ys the pomel set mor lowe, By whose helpe, (as thow shalt knowe, And as I shal the trewly teche,) To the hiher thow shalt wel reche; Both√´ wrouht off Stonys clere: And yiff thow loue on bothe yfere, Thow mayst trust, thorgh ther myght, Thow shalt nat falle, but gon vp ryht. ‚ÄòWherfor, for thy sauacyoun, Hold the wel by thys Bordoun Wych ys mad ful stronge, to laste; And therfor, therby hold th√© faste; Trust on yt & nat ne feyne; ffor thys pomellys both√´ tweyne Ben so noble and ffayr off syht, So glad, so coumfortable & bryht, And lyk thy skryppe (I the ensure,) Thow shalt ffor ech haue a scrypture Yiff thow kanst hem vnderstond: Lo, haue hem here now in thyn hond; And consydre & loke hem wel: The ffyrst toucheth the pomel, Yset a-lofft√´ most cheffly; And the tother, wryt ther-by, (Shortly, for thow shalt nat tarye) Longeth to the Secoundarye. [The Pilgrim.] Affter, (shortly to expresse) Grac√´ dieu, off hir goodnesse, Off the skryppe and the bordoun Putte me in pocess√Øoun; And I thouhte a-noon ryht tho That I was redy for to go Vp-on my way, but trew(√´)ly I ne was no thyng redy, Lyk as I wende; ffor vn-to me Ther as I stood, ryht thus sayde she. Grace dieu sayd ‚ÄòThe tyme ys good and couen√°ble (As I ha sayd), and accept√°ble, That I my promys and my graunt, Holde vn-to th√©, & my couenaunt, As I be-hihte: tak hed her-to. And thow requeryst yt also, To be gyrt (for sykernesse) With a gyrdel off ryhtwysnesse, ‚ÄòThy reynys strongly for to streyne, fflesshly lustys to refreyne. ‚ÄòNo man hath power (trust√´ me) ffor to gon at liberte, But he be gyrt ryht myghtyly. Therfor, (off purpos feythfully), The tassure in wele and wo, I wyl the gyrde, or that thow go, So that thow (in thyn entente) Off fre wyl lyst to assente, To be thus gyrt; and ellys nouht, Now sey, as lyth ryht in thy thouht.‚Äô The pilgrime: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I in lowly wyse, ‚ÄúAl that euere ye deuyse, I wyl ther-off no thyng refuse, Nor ther-vp-on no lenger muse; But off thys thyng, with al my myght I yow requere off verray ryht.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚Äòffyrst, to make thy syluen strong, To be myghty a-geyn al wrong, Yt be-houeth, in thy diffence, ffor to mak√´ resistence, That thow hau√´ strong armure. And ffyrst, (thy syluen to assure,) Next thy body shal be set A purpoynt or a doublet, On wych thow shalt fful myghtyly Be gyrt and streyned ryht strongly ‚ÄòWith a gyrdel off Ryhtwysnesse, Ther-on thyn armure for to dresse.‚Äô The pylgrym. ‚ÄúCertys,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúyiff ye lyst se, Yt wer contrarye vn-to me To gon armyd in my vy√°ge; Yt wold√´ lette my pylgrym√°ge, And don to me ful gret grevaunce; ffor I hadde neuere yet vsaunce Nor in custom, trust√´ me, Al my lyue, armyd to be: I knewe ther-off nothyng the guyse. To me yt doth ynouh suffyse, To be gyrt (in sothfastnesse) With a gyrdel off ryhtwysnesse.‚Äù But than thys lady off gret uertu, Wych ys callyd Grace Dieu, In-ta chaumbre ful secre Entrede; and than she callyd me. Grace Dieu: ‚ÄúKom ner,‚Äù quod she, ‚Äúand ha no drede; Look vp an hih, & tak good heede. Vpon thys perche, the harneys se, Wher-with that thow wylt armyd be, Pertynent to thy vy√°ge And nedful to thy pylgrimage.‚Äù Ther saw I helmys and haberiouns Plate and maylle, for champyouns Gorgetys ageyn al vyolence, And Iakkys stuffyd, off diffence; Targetys and sheldys, large & longe, And pavys also that wer stronge, ffor folk to mak√´ r√©sistence, Tall√´ that wolde hem don offence. The pylgrym Than quod I, ‚Äúas in bataylle, What enmy shal me assaylle Or a-geyn me make affray, To distourble me in my way?‚Äù Grace dieu ‚ÄòWenystow thy sylff tassure, ffor to gon with-oute armure To Ierusaleem, & nat fynde Brygauntys to-forn And ek be-hynde, Daungerys grete, & encoumbraunces, Empechementys & meshauncys? Thevys and mardrerys ay lyggynge Vp-on the weye, euere espyynge, Thow shalt ffynde, so gret plente, That thow off hem shalt wery be, Ther assautys to endure. Wherfore the nedeth strong armure, Myghtyly hem to with-stonde. And for thy profyt, y wyl ffounde, With harneys to arrayen the, That thow shalt nat afferyd be.‚Äô The pylgrym ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúsyth ye wyl so, Armyd algatys that I go, Shew me what armure I shal were, And what wepenys I shal bere; And how I shal me armen wel, And the maner euerydel.‚Äù Thanne, off merveyllous fasoun, She took to me a Gambisoun, A maner harneys that I knewe nouht: And behynde, ther-on was wrouht A ful strong styh off fyn√´ stel, ffor to receyu√´ strookys wel Off the hamer, whan euere yt smyte, That yt shal hurt√´ but a lyte. Than quod Grace Dieu to me: ‚ÄòThys Gambesoun wych thow dost se, Ys so wrouht, (who taketh hede,) ffor ta-woyde a man fro drede; That, from cartage in-to Inde, Men myght√´ nat a bettre fynde; ffor (as thow shalt wel vnderstonde,) Thogh a man hadde foot nor hond, And were vn-to a stak√´ bounde, Hys foomen about√´ rounde, Yiff he hadde on thys garn√´ment, And clad ther-in (off good entent), He myghte nat ouerkomen be, But fynally, in surete, With gret worshepe & gret glorie, Off hys Enmyes han vyctorye. ‚ÄòAnd yet thys garnement, (I dar swere, Who that euere doth yt were,) Hath most Ioye & plesaunce In thyng that ys to folk penaunce, ffor hys proffyt & avauntage,‚Äî Som folk holde yt gret damage;‚Äî ffor pacience (in conclus√Øoun) Haueth thys condic√Øoun, (ffor to descryve and spek in pleyn Off pacience the trew√´ greyn,) I men√´, to hys √°vauntage ffructefyeth with fforage: Tempest fulfylleth hys garnerys, And pestylenc√´ hys celerys; Hys sofftest bedd√´, (in sothnesse,) Ys ymakyd off hardnesse.
