But thow ne shalt no thyng do so, But let thy Swerd (tak hed her-to) (The Swerd, I mene, of Ryghtwysnesse, ffor any maner holynesse,) Cloos with-Inne (wher so thow be,) The skawberk off humylyte. ‚Äòffor what deme off dyscrec√Øoun A-vaylleth any perfeccioun‚Äî Abstynaunce, outher penaunce, Or any vertu, in substaunce‚Äî But yiff they ygroundyd be On lownesse and humylyte, Ground and rote off eche good werk. And put thy Swerd in the skawberk Off meknesse & lavlyhede. ‚ÄòAnd affter that, tak good heede ‚Äò(As a man no thyng afferd) The to gyrd√´ with thys swerd, Thys noble swyrd off ryghtwysnesse In the skawberk off meknesse. ‚ÄòAnd thy gyrdel ek shal be‚Äî With wych thow shalt ygyrden the‚Äî The gyrdel off ‚Äòperseueraunce‚Äô; The Bokle callyd ek ‚Äòconstaunce‚Äô; That whan the tong ys onys Inne, They shal neuere parte A-twynne, But perpetuelly endure To kepe the cloos in thyn Armure, That they departe nat assonder. And yiff they dyde, yt wer gret wonder; ffor perseueraunce (I dar seye) Ys the verray parfyt keye And lok also (I dar assure) Off perfeccioun off armure. ‚ÄòAnd therfore alway do thy peyne ffor to fastne wel thys tweyne, The gyrdel off perseueraunce With the Bookle off constaunce; And than thy Swerd, longe tabyde, Ys wel gyrt vn-to thy syde: Ha thys wel in mynde, I charge. ‚ÄòNow wyl I spekyn off thy Targe, The wych in soth (who kan entende,) Schal thyn Armure wel A-mende, And kepe yt, (lyk as yt ys wrouht,) In vertu that yt A-peyr√´ nouht. The wych vp-on thy brest to-fore, Off custom euere shal be bore, As cheff thyng for thy dyffence: The name off wych shal be ‚Äòprudence‚Äô; A Targe most worthy off Renoun. ffor, whilom, Kyng Salamoun Bar ay thys targe in hys entent, ffor to do ryhtful Iug√´ment, Rychere to hym (Erly & late) Than off gold to .ij. hondryd plate, ‚ÄòAnd mor off valu (as yt ys told) Than al the sheldys mad off gold, Wych in hys temple (out off doute) He mad√´ hang√´ round a-boute. ‚Äòffor, by thys targ√´ off prudence, He hadd√´ so gret excellence Of worshepe, & so gret honour, As he that was off wysdom flour. Whil he was gouernyd by prudence, Endurede hys magnyfycence; And whan that prudence was a-go, Hys worshype wente a-way also. Hys sheldys off gold, ek euerychon, A dyeu whan prudence was a-gon. ffor prudence, the shyld I calle, Off fyue hundryd the best off alle, ffor to rekne hym, on by on; And, to kepe a man ffrom hys fon, Ys noon so myghty off vertu, Nor equyualent off valu. ‚ÄòWherfor, whil thow art at large, Looke thow haue vp-on, thys targe, Wherso thow entre in batayll, Whan thyn Emnyes the assaylle, To force thy quarel & a-mende, Ber vp, & wel thy-sylff dyffende At alle assautys fer & ner, In maner off a bok√´ler. ffor gonnys, dartys, & quarel, Shrowd√´ the ther-vnder wel; Be no coward, But wysly bolde. ‚ÄòAnd now I haue the pleynly tolde Off thyn armure, (yiff thow tak hede,) Wher-off thow shalt haue ay most nede, With-outen many wordys mo: Now be avysed what thow wylt do.‚Äô The pylgrym. ‚ÄúCertys,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúther ys no more; ‚ÄúBut I am astonyd sore Off o thyng wych cometh to mynde, Wych that ye ha lefft be-hynde: Thys to seyne, off al armure Ye han me makyd strong & sure, Saue my leggys & ffeet also: Ye haue no thyng yseyn ther-to, Nor ryht nouht for hem ordeyned; The wych ouht√´ be compleyned; ffor folk off hih dyscrec√Øons Speke fyrst off Savac√Øons, Off greevys, & kusshewys ek also, Whan that men shal haue a-doo; But ye (by short conclus√Øoun) Make ther-off no mencyoun. ‚ÄúBut, for to tell√´ yow my thouht, ffor my party, I rechch√´ nouht; ffor, in spede off my vyage, Yt were to me noon √°vauntage, Yiff I shold√´ gon at large, ffor to bere so gret a charge.‚Äù Grace dieu axete ‚ÄòSawh thow euere (so god the blesse!) In forest or in wyldernesse (Tel on, yiff yt cometh to mynde) Huntyng for hert outher for ynde, Chasyng for Rayndeer or for Roo, Huntyng for buk outher for do?‚Äô The pylgrym answereth ‚ÄúTrewly,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúto speke in pleyn, Somtyme, huntyng haue I seyn.‚Äù Grace dieu ‚ÄòThanne,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòI the comaunde, Answere vn-to thys demaunde: Bestys that ben in wyldernesse, Whan huntys don ther besynesse To chacen hem, and kachche her pray, What ys that thyng that best may Helpen bestys in ther defence, ffor teschewe the vyolence ‚ÄòOff houndys in swych sodeyn iape, ffrely fro the deth to skape?‚Äô The pylgrym ‚ÄúTrew[e]ly, vn-to my Syht, To hem, best help ys the flyht.‚Äù Grace dieu ‚ÄòThanne, yiff they hadde vp-on Armure, On ther leggys, (hem sylff tassure) Outher off plat√´, maylle, or stel, ffro byt off houndys to kepe hem wel, Answere ageyn, shortly to me, Sholde they be swyfft, away to fle?‚Äô The pylgrym ‚ÄúCertys,‚Äù quod I, ‚ÄúI wot ryht wel, Yt sholde hem furthre neueradel So to ben armyd, (as I gesse,) But rather hyndren ther Swyfftnesse.‚Äù Grace dieu ‚ÄòNow her-vp-on tak hed to me, Conceyue what I shal tell√´ the: In thy passage, ther thow shalt pace, Yt ys holde a perylous place; And I the putte in ful surnesse, Ther lyth A mortal hunteresse, In a-wayt to hyndre the, Wyth gret noumbre off hyr meyne, Gretly to drede, & daungerous; The name off whom ys dame Venus, And hyr sone callyd Cupide, The blynd√´ lord, waytynge asyde With hys Arwes fyled kene, To th√© ful dredful to sustene. ‚ÄòAnd thys lady doth euere espye, With huntys in hyr companye, Most perillous to hurte & wounde, Al pylgrym√´s to confounde. ffor ther ys hunt√´ nor foster That chaceth ay the wyld√´ deer, Nor other bestys that byth Sav√°ge, That may be lykned to the rage ‚ÄòOff dame Venus: wherfor tak hede How gretly she ys to drede. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow kanst the trouthe espye, Venus ys sayd off venerye; ffor she ys the hunteresse Wych euere doth hyr bysynesse To take pylgrim√´s by som treyne, And tenbracen in hyr cheyne, And with hyr ffyry brond also ffor to don hem peyne & wo, And ther passag√´ for tassaylle. ‚ÄòAnd fynally, in thys bataylle Ther geyneth power noon, nor myht, Nor other rescus but the fflyht, ffor flyht ys only best diffence; And ffor to mak√´ r√©sistence A-geyn hyr dredful mortal werre, The ffyht with hyre ys best a-ferre. ‚Äòffor yiff A man be rekk√´les ffor to putte hym sylff in pres, ffarwel dyffence off al Armure! Ther folwe shal dyscoumfyture On the party that doth a-byde; ffor Venus & hyr sone cupyde, In ther conquest han vyctorye, And in ther werrys, ffals veyn glorye, Whan folkys at dyffenc√´ stonde To fyht√´ with hem hand off honde; ‚ÄòAnd for thys skyle, thow sholdest be lyht ffor to take th√© to the flyht; Whan thow hast nede, (take yt in mynde,) Legharneys ys lefft be-hynde, That thow mayst, at lyberte, Hyr dartys and hyr brondys fle. ‚ÄòWhan thow hyr seyst, mak no dyffence, Nor noon other r√©sistence, But eschew√´ place & syht, And alway tak the to the flyht. Tourne thy bak, & she wyl go; And yiff thow flest, she fleth also. ‚ÄòA-geyn whos malys and envye, fflyht ys the best√´ remedye Off al other (yiff yt be souht); Other harneys the nedeth nouht Vp-on thy leggys (trust√´ me,) ffor no maner necessyte, With Venus to holde chaumpartye.‚Äô And whan I sawh, & gan espye, And vnderstood hyr wonder wel Touchynge tharmur√´ euerydel Wych she hadd√´ for me brouht, I gan assaye, and taryede nouht Me tarm√´ fro poynt to poynt; But me lykede nat my purpoynt: I fond ther-in so gret a lak, Yt heng so heuy on my bak, I wold√´ fayn haue lett yt be; But lyst that she were wroth with me, I suffrede; &, in c√≥nclusioun, Ther-on dyde the haberioun Wych she me tok, ful bryht & clere. And affter that, the double Gorger,‚Äî To hyr byddynge I took swych hede;‚Äî And thanne the helm vp-on myn hed, Mad ful strong, and forgyd wel; Next, my glovys, ffynere than stel, And gyrte me with my swerd ryht tho. And alderlast, I took also My targe, that callyd was ‚Äòprudence,‚Äô And hengyd yt on in my dyffence Round a-boute my nekke a-noon. And platly, whan I hadde al don Lyk as she bade, with myn harneys, I felte ther-off so gret a peys, That I myght√´ nat endure The greuous wheyhte off myn armure, That for dystress√´ I a brayde, And to grac√´ dieu I sayde: The pylgrym ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúne greff yow nouht Thogh I dyscure to yow my thouht; And lat yt yow no thyng dysplese, Thogh I declare myn gret vnhese, And disclose yow my mescheff; Thys armure doth me so gret greff, So gret annoy & dysplesaunce, That I ne may me nat a-vaunce Vp-on my way nor my Iourne, Swych hevynesse encoumbreth me. ‚ÄúMyn helm hath rafft me my syyng And take a-way ek myn heryng; And most off al dyspleseth me, I se nat that I wold√´ se. And also, (yiff ye lyst to lere,) Thyng that I wolde, I may nat here; And smelle also I may no thyng That shold√´ be to my lykyng. ‚ÄúThys gorger (ek as ye may se,) Gret encoumbraunce doth to me, And strangleth me almost vp ryht, That I may nat speke a-ryht, I fele so gret a pass√Øoun: And (for short conclus√Øoun) Thys armure may me nat profyte, In wych I do me nat delyte. ‚ÄúThys glouys bynd√´ me so sore, That I may weryn hem no more, With her pynchyng to be bounde, Myn handys ben so tendre and Rounde; And al the remnaunt (I ensure) That ye gaff me, off armure, Me streyneth so on euery syde, That I may nat ther-with a-byde. ‚ÄúI ha to yow told al the caas; I am nat strengere than dauyd was, Wych hadde so mych√´ suffysaunce; But, for cause off dysusaunce In hys youthe whan he was tendre, And off makyng smal & sklendre, ‚Äú(In the byble ye may se,) Hym lyst nat Armyd for to be Whan that he (thus stood the caas,) Shold√´ fyhte with Golyas, Swych Armure he hath forsake; Off whom I wyle exaumple take, ffor my party, to go lyht, To ben ay redy to the flyht, Whan that Venus (by bataylle,) On the weye me wyl assaylle, Al thys armure I wyl leue, Be-caus√´ that they do me greue, Off purpos (lyk as ye shal se) That I may the bettre fle, Lyst I stode in Iupartye Whan Venus me dyde espye, Wych ys the peryllous hunteresse, Pylgrymes to putten in dystresse.‚Äù Grace dieu ‚ÄòYt nedeth her-on no mor to muse,‚Äî By cause thow dost thy sylff excuse,‚Äî How armure doth to th√© grevaunce; ffor he that hath no suffysaunce Wyth-Inne hym-sylff tendur√´ peyne, Off lytel thyng he wyl compleyne, And a lytel charge refuse. ‚ÄòBut shortly, yiff thow koudest vse Thys Armure, yt sholde sem√´ lyht, And nat lette th√© in thy flyht; ffor thys armure ys nat heuy To hertys stronge, that be myghty To endure, and byd√´ longe Vp-on heuy chargys stronge. ‚ÄòBut thow hast excusyd the, That thow wylt nat Armyd be, But go lyht, bothe fer & ner, And therfore thow shalt han A Somer To karyen-in thyn harneys al, Wych in soth shal be but smal, ‚ÄòTo trusse yt in, whan thow hast nede, And with th√© thow shalt yt lede,‚Äî Lyst sodeynly, in bataylle, Any man the wolde assaylle,‚Äî Lyte and lyte to vs√´ the, Euere a-mong, armyd to be. ‚ÄòAnd for thow hast made menc√Øoun, Off dauyd the noble champyoun,‚Äî That he wold noon Armys bere,‚Äî Wych slowh the Lyon & the Beere; But touchyng the sam√´ fourme Thow mayst the neuere to hym confourme, But yiff thy body thow applye ffor to fyhte a-geyn Golye With thy staff & with thy slynge; And with the also that thow brynge In thy skrypp√´ stonys fyue, With the geaunt for to stryue, As dauyd dyde, thorgh hys renoun, Whan he hym slowh & beet a-doun.‚Äô The pylgrym ‚ÄúMa dame, certys,‚Äù tho quod I, ‚ÄúThat ye me graunt so gracyously To be armyd as dauyd was Whan he fauht with Golyas, I thank√´ yow with al myn myght, And yow be-sech√´ a-noon ryht That I may be armyd so, Whan-euere that I shal haue a-do. Other Armure ne wyl I noon, On pylgrimage whan I shal gon; But that ye lyst to do your peyne A Somer, fyrst[√´] to ordeyne, And ther-wyth (as ye haue be-hyht) Stonys & slyng√´ a-noon ryht. But fyrst I shal dysArm√´ me Off thys Armure, as ye shal Se.‚Äù And so I dyde; & cast√´ doun Purpoynt, helm and haberioun, Glouys & swerd, I yow ensure, And fynally, al myn armure; Wheroff me thouhte I was wel esyd. But Grac√´ dieu was nat wel plesyd (Shortly) off my gouernaunce, But took yt parcel in greuaunce, And fro me she gan declyne, And entrede in, in hyr courtyne. And disarmyd I a-bood, And fulle nakyd so I stood, And ffel in-to A maner Rage Off dysconfort, in my corage. The lak vpon me sylff I leyde; And thus vn-to my sylff I seyde: ‚ÄúAllas!‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúwhat shal I do, Now grac√´ dieu ys go me fro? I stonde in gret dysioynt, certeyn, But vn-to me she kome a-geyn, Wych armede me ful ryally, And apparayllede Rich√´ly, Lyk taknyht that sholde assaylle Hys Enmy√´s in bataylle. But I was nat worthy ther-to, That she shold√´ ha do So, Off neclygence and ffreelte Now I haue dyspoylled me, Destytut on euery syde. ‚ÄúAnd trewly now I most a-byde, As a shepperde (who taketh kep,) With dauyd for to kep√´ shep, With staff & slyng√´, as dyde he, I trowe yt wyl noon other be. Grac√´ dieu so me be-hyhte Whan that I stood in hyr syhte, Dysarmyd my body, euerydel, Wher-off she lykede no thyng wel; But pleynly, off my gouernaunce, Me sempte she hadd√´ dysplesaunce.‚Äù And whil I stood in swych dysioynt, And was brouht vn-to the poynt Off heuynesse in my corage, Tryst & mornyng off visage, Grac√´ d√Øeu cam a-geyn And thus she gan vn-to me seyn: Grace dieu ‚ÄòThow shalt no thyng do,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòBut at thyn own√´ lyberte: Thyn armure thow hast cast a-way, And stondyst now in gret affray, Venquisshed (in conclus√Øoun), With-out√´ strook yput adoun, And fallen in gret febylnesse; Wher-for behoueth besynesse, And also ful gret dyllygence. ‚ÄòThy gret harmys to Recompense, Thow must be wasshe & bathyd offte, And couchyd in a bed ful soffte, Ther-in thy syluen to dysporte, And han a leche, the to coumforte, Thy synwes harde to mollefye With oynementys, to make hem plye. Tel on A-noon; let for no slouthe; Her-off, yiff I sey th√© the trouth.‚Äô The pylgrym ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúyt ys no les; Off my peyn√´s to haue reles, I wold√´ fayn (trusteth me) Off my disesses holpen be. The maner (yiff ye koude espye) ffor to shape a remedye; ffor, be my trouthe, I yow ensure, That I may no lenger dure To suffre mor, (taketh good hed,) But that I muste pleynly be ded: With-Inne my-sylff, many wyse, Off labour I fele so gret feyntyse.‚Äù Grace dieu Quod Grac√´ dieu a-noon to me: ‚ÄòI haue espyed wel, and Se: ‚ÄòBut I dyde my bysynesse To taken hed to thy syknesse, The to helpyn & releue Off thyng that doth thyn hert√´ greue. I wot ryht wel (yt ys no nay) Thow sholdest gon a peryllous way. ‚ÄòBut fyrst tak hed, & be wel war, The stonys wych that dauyd bar, Wyth the wych he slewe Golye, And hadd√´ off hym the mystrye, The sam√´ stonys, I ha longe Kept hem bounde wonder stronge With-Inne a purs (shortly to seye), Off entent, with hem to pleye With maydenys wych on me a-byde, Euere a-waytynge on my syde, At the martews, the gentyl play Vsyd in fraunc√´ many day: The wych stonys, the to saue, I purp√≥se that thow shalt haue, As dauyd hadde, in hys dyffence, ffor to mak√´ r√©sistence A-geyn the geaunt Golyat, Vn-to hym to seyn ‚Äòchek maat,‚Äô Whan that euere in bataylle He cast hym proudly the tassaylle.‚Äô And a-noon she dyde hyr peyne To tak√´ with hyr handys tweyne Out off a pours, stonys fyue; That neuere yet, in al my lyue, I ne sawh nat to my syht No maner ston so cler nor bryht. And in al hast, thys lady fre, Wyth hyr hond she took hem me: Wych I receyuede ful lowly, And in my skrypp√´ sykerly, I putte hem up, on by on. But she to-forn, off euerychon, Sche made a declarac√Øoun And ful cler exposic√Øoun; In whos speche ther was no lak; And euene thus to me she spak: Grace Dieu ‚ÄòThow shalt,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòyt ys no fayl, Offten entren in bataylle, With thy foomen for to stryue, And han a werr√´ al thy lyue With the Geaunt Golyas, Wych hath be-set ech maner pas Wher thow shalt passe in thy vyage, As thow gost on pylgrymage. Whos Ioy√´ ys (who kan conceyue,) All pylgrym√´s to deceyue; Vp-on the wey lyth, hem tespye, As doth the hyrayne for the fflye. ‚ÄòAnd as she hyr net kan spynne, Tyl that she the fly√´ wynne, And by hyr sleyth√´ kan hem take, Ryht so hys trappys he doth make, Alle pylgrym√´s to enbrace, Wher they walke in any place, ffalsly to take on hem vengaunce, With hys deceytys off plesaunce, And flesshly lustys off delyt fful plesaunt to the appetyt. ‚ÄòWith worldly rychesses, & veyn glorye Off goodys that ben transitorye, Off hem he maketh a sotyl net; And whan he hath yt vp ful knet, Ther-with he doth hys besy peyne, Pylgrymes to bryngen in A treyne. Hem cachchynge (or they kan espye) As the hereyne doth the fflye, By √°pparence ful √°gr√´√°ble, Thys ffals√´ geaunt d√©ceyu√°ble, ‚ÄòLyk the bacyn that ys brennynge, And sheweth ffayr as in shynynge; Yet nat for-thy, thogh yt be bryht, The Beere yt reueth off hys syht, And maketh hym blynd, he may nat se. ‚ÄòRyght so, worldly prosperyte, fflesshly lust & fals plesaunce, Causen folk, by d√©ceyvaunce, ffor to be blynd, & lese her syht. ‚ÄòWher-for with-stond with al thy myht The power of thys proud Golye. Al fflesshly lustys ek defye; And off the world ek, tak noon hede, Wych deceyueth a man at nede. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow wylt don affter me, I shal a-noon her techyn the, Lych a myghty champyoun To venquysshe al temptac√Øoun Off the world, Golye, & the fflessh. ‚ÄòLooke ffyrst that thow be fressh, Lyk to dauyd off corage, Manly off hert√´, wys & sage A-geyn thyn Enmyes for to stryue; And euere have redy, stonys ffyue, To caste hem (off entenc√Øoun) A-geyn[√´]s al Temptac√Øoun, Loke thow be redy, euere in on. ‚ÄòThe nam√´ off thy ffyrst√´ ston Ys the mynde most off vertu, Off the deth off cryst ihesu; How that he sprad on the rood, ffor mankynde, hys own√´ blood; The peple ther-with to beyn a-geyn, Wych that Golyas hadde slayn. Thys, the precyous ruby Ryche, In al thys world ther ys noon lyche; Wych receyuede hys rednesse ‚ÄòOff crystys blood, & hys rychesse. ‚ÄòDye thyn herte (as yt ys good,) In the sylu√´ sam√´ blood; Ha ther-in feyth & stedefastnesse; Than artow strong (in sothnesse) Ageyn golye & al hys myght, ffor to venquysshe hym by ffiht: Thy mynde ha ther-on, euere in oon. ‚ÄòAnd the next√´ Rych√´ Ston, In noumbre callyd the secounde, Wych wyth al grac√´ doth habounde, Off vertu hath most suffysaunce, And ys callyd Remembraunce Off that mayde & moder fre, Y-chosen off the d√´yte fful many hundryd yer to-forn, Or she was off hyr modern born). Thys, the precyouse margaryte Off hevenly dewh & dropys whyte, Sprang in a Cokyl bryht & shene, ffor tavoyden al our tene, Whos grac√´, thorgh the world doth shyne: Lat hyre thyn hert√´ enlwmyne, And a-dewhen with hyr grace; And neuere dred the (in no place) But thow shalt han the maystrye Off the devel and off golye. ‚ÄòThe thrydde ston ys ‚ÄòMemorye Off the perdurable glorye,‚Äô And off the hih√´ blysse in heuene A-boue the planetys all√´ seuene: Thys, the blyssyd saphyr trewe, Al-to-gidre off hevenly hewe, Wych recounforteth most the syht Wyth hys counfortable lyht: Kep hyt for thyn own√´ stoor, ffor yt saueth euery soor; Yt sleth bochches & ffelouns, Destroyeth venym & poyssouns; And off colour yt ys ynde: ‚ÄòLat yt neuer out off thy mynde. ‚ÄòAzure thyn hert√´ ther-wyth-al; And loue yt yn especyal, As for thy cheff pocess√Øoun; And thanke (off hih affecc√Øoun) To god only, wych off grace Hath ordeyned swych a place ffor his chos√´ chyldre dere, The wych√´, as champ√Øouns here, ffyhten wyth golye day be day, And overkome hym in ther way; Pylgrymes that passen many Rewm Toward hevenly Jerusaleem. ‚ÄòThe ffourth√´ ston ys callyd ‚ÄòMynde‚Äô: Be-war that yt be nat be-hynde. Haue yt in thy memoryal Mynde off the peynys infernal, Wych ys gretly for to drede, Wyth hys flawmy fyrys rede. Redy (ther ys noon other wente,) Thys synn√©rys to tormente Eternally, for ther penaunce, That dey√´ wyth-out r√©pentaunce; ‚ÄòBut, off that lord grettest off myght, Whos mercy euer passeth ryht, Off synnerys desyreth nat the deth; ffor he doth mercy or that he sleth; Loth, swych folkys to tormente, That off herte hem wyl repente. ‚ÄòBut yet haue alway in thy thouht, (And look that thou for-gete yt nouht,) To haue thy mynde, euere a-mong, Up-on thys mortal peynys strong. ‚ÄòAnd the name of thys dredful stone Ys ycallyd Albeston, Wych, whan yt receyueth ffyr, To hete yt hath so gret desyr, That whan wyth ffyr yt ys ymeynt, Affter, neuere yt wyl be queynt. ‚ÄòHaue on thys ston ay mencyoun, ‚ÄòAnd in eche temptacyoun, Latt love off God, and drede off peyne, Fro dedly Synn√´ the Restreyne. And yiff thow hast her-Inne mem√≥rye, Off Golye thow hast the vyct√≥rye. ‚ÄòThe ffyffth√´ ston (I the ensure) That thow shalt han, ys ‚Äòscrypture‚Äô Hooly wryt, & thus I mene, The Emerawd that ys so grene, A rych√´ ston, off gret counfort, That to the eye doth most dysport, And, thorgh hys myght & hys puissaunce, Voydeth a-way al grevaunce ffrom an ey√´ fer & ner, And maketh A manhys syht√´ cler, Clenseth a-way al ordure, The gownde, & euery thyng vnpure. ‚ÄòNow haue I told the, by & by, Off thys stonys coryously, Wych that ben in noumbre fyue: Put hem in thy skrypp√´ blyue, Caste hem ay whan thow hast nede; And specyally (as I the rede) Caste hem euere in ech sesoun A-geyns al temptacyoun, Ech affter other, in thy dyffence; And mak alway strong r√©systence, Spendynge thys stonys, on by on; And I ensur√´ the a-noon, Thow shalt nat faylle (yiff thow be wys,) Off vyctorye to gete a prys.‚Äô The pylgrym Than quod I to hyre a-geyn, ‚ÄúThys fyue stonys (in certeyn) Ben ryht good & grac√Øous, & at assay ryht vertuous; But I merueylle, syth ye be wys, Why that ye, in your a-vys, Lykne my Mouth un-to a slynge; ffor I kan nat about√´ brynge, ‚ÄúNor deuyse, how that I schal To cast√´ stonys ther-wyth-al, To helpe my sylff ageyn my ffon; ffor custoom hadde I neuere noon, God know√©th wel, nyh nor ferre, Me to gouerne in swych a werre.‚Äù Grace dieu. Quod she, ‚ÄòKanstow nat espye? Who kan wysdom, he kan folye; And who that knoweth ek goodnesse, Parcel he knoweth off shrewdnesse; ffor ryhtwysnesse, & also wrong, Entermedlen euere a-mong; And in an herte (yiff yt be souht) Ther tourneth many a dyuers thouht, Lyk a corde (yt ys no doute), Wyth-Inne yt tourneth ofte aboute; And off two cordys, they a-corde Offt√´ for to make a corde. ‚Äòffor Cordys be sayd (who kan aduerte,) Off offt√´ tournynges in an herte; And wyth twynnyng, (in certeyne,) A cord ys ymad off tweyne. ‚ÄòAnd thus thow shalt about√´ brynge, Off thy thouht to make a slynge, Ther-in to putt√´ stonys ffyue, Ageyn thyn enmyes for to stryue, To cast hem in thys mortal werre, Wer-so thow lyketh, nyh or ferre. ‚Äòffor, slynge ys noon, (thys no doute,) That may tourne so offte aboute As may thy thouht (be wel certeyn); ffor bothe on hylle, on vale & pleyn, Yt tourneth her, yt tourneth yonder, So offt√´ sythe, that yt ys wonder, ffer or ner, ryht at thy lust, On whos abood, yt ys no trust. But, yit I red√´, tak good kep (Lyk thys Erdys that kepe shep) Thy slynge and stonys to kep√´ wel, And that thow err, neueradel.‚Äù The pylgrym: ‚ÄúAllas,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúwhat may thys be, That, off my foly nycete, I am be-kome an Erd√´ man,‚Äî And noon other crafft ne kan,‚Äî A rud shepperde, thorgh my folye, And ha for-sak√´ chyualrye, Armys that longen to a knyht, Ther-off complaynynge day & nyht. And syker, so I may ryht wel, Whan I consydre euerydel Hou dauyd (who lyst taken kep) Was fyrst an Erde, & kept√´ shep; But, thorgh hys manly gouernaunce, Hym-sylff affter he dyde avaunce To be callyd a myghty kyng, Thorgh hys vertuous lyuyng, And wyth al thys, a famous knyht. Wherfor, I pray yow anoon ryht, Lyk your hest, doth your deuer To ordeyne me a somer, Myn harneys ther-in for to karye; And her-vp-on that ye nat tarye, But in al hast that ye me spede, That whan yt falleth I ha nede, Myn armure be nat fer me ffro, Whan that I ha nede ther-to.‚Äù Grace dieu: Quod grace dieu anoon to me, ‚ÄòThow hast abydynge ay wyth the A seruant and a chaumberere, Wych in soth, (as thow shalt lere,) Lesyth hyr tyme, & doth ryht nouht, A Damyselle: lat hyr be souht, To trusse thyn harneys euerydel. ffor yiff hyr lyst, she kan ryht wel (I haue off hyre no maner doute,) Trusse, and bern yt ek a-boute, And folwe the owher so thou go; ‚ÄòAnd by my counsayl, lat her so, Syth that she kan do hyr deuer, Bothe be thy seruant & somer.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù (to speke feythfully,) ‚ÄúI ha noon sywch wyth me,‚Äù quod I. Grace dieu: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthou hast swych on; I shal hyr shewe to the a-noon, Yiff in thy sylff ther be no lak: Looke be-hynden at thy bak!‚Äô The pylgrym: And so I dyd√´,‚Äîlyk as she The sam√´ tyme comaundyd me,‚Äî Be-held bakward, & saw sywch on; Wheroff astonyd I was a-noon, And fyl in-to a ful gret doute, Be-cause, whan I be-held aboute, I sawh that eyen hadde she noon, Ne mor than hath a stok or ston; Wych was to me a thyng hydous; She sempt√´, a best monstruows, Outward, by hyr contenaunce. But tho I hadde a r√©membraunce How Grac√´ dieu hadde don to me Touchynge myn eyen, wyth wych I se, Wyth them to make me se the bet, In myn erys whan they wer set, By hyr oun√´ puruyaunce; Wher-off havyng a r√©membraunce, I gan consydre & lok√´ wel Hyr shap & maner euerydel. Tyl at the laste, I dyd√´ fynde In hyr haterel, fer be-hynde, Tweyne Eyen fful cler & bryht; Wych was to me a wonder syht. And on thys thyng gretly musynge, To grace dieu my-sylff tournynge, Sodeynly I tho abrayde, And, astonyd, to hyre I sayde: The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, (‚Äúyiff ye lyst lere,) I ha founde a chaumberere, Me suyng at my bak be-hynde, Off whom I hadde to-forn no mynde Nor no maner r√©membraunce; And syker, I ha no gret plesaunce Off hyr offyce nor hyr seruise; Caus√´ why, I shal devyse: Me semeth she ys vngracyous, Counterfeet & monstruous: And as me semeth in my syht, She ne kan nat, halff a-ryht, Wyth me trussen myn armure, Nouther kepe myn harneys sure.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod Grac√´ dieu ryht tho, ‚ÄòI wot my sylff yt ys nat so: She kan hem truss√´ most trewly, And beren also sykerly. Wherfor, in thyn oppynyoun, Tyl thow haue occas√Øoun Or som cause, dyspreyse hyr nouht; ffor whan the trouthe ys clerly souht, Thow shalt know√´ wel that she Ys ful nec√©ssarye to the, Yiff thow lyst maken prouydence Off any konnyng or scyence, Yt to concevue wyth-out√´ lak, ‚ÄòBy cause hyr Eyen stonden bak, Yt ys a sygne (as thow shalt lere) That she is a tresourere Off konnyng & of sciencys, And off all Experyencys That be commyttyd to hyr garde; Yiff thow konne a-ryht rewarde, Thyngis passyd, thow shalt fynde Sche kepeth hem closyd in hyr mynde, Sor√´ shet wyth lok & keye, That they go nat lyhtly awey. ‚ÄòAl thyng√´s off antyquyte, Storyes that auctorys√®d be, And thyng√´s digne off R√©membraunce, And al the old√´ gouernaunce Wych a-for thys hath be do, She kan devys√´, no whyht so, Fresshly renewyd in hyr thouht. ‚ÄòAnd yet, to-forn, she seth ryht nouht, Nor a-parceyueth no maner thyng Off that shal folwe in hyr seyyng, Off wysdam, Armys, nor vyctorye. And hyr name ys ‚Äúmemorye‚Äù; And so thow shalt off Ryght hyr calle Her-affter-ward, what euer falle. And wherso that thou wake or slepe, Tak hyr thyn armure for to kepe; And she wyl mak√´ no daunger, But the to serue, & don hyr deuer.‚Äù The pylgrym to memoyre. Than quod I to thys chaumberere: ‚ÄúWych that han your eyen clere, Only be-hynde (yiff yt be souht) & to-forn ne se ryht nouht,‚Äî ffor off thynges that passyd be, Ys your charg√´ for to se; And I to-forn shal taken hede:‚Äî But I stonde in a maner drede, In what wyse ye shal sustene To remembre, (thus I mene,) Or so gret a charge to bere, Off thyng√´s out off mynd√´ feere, Hem to reporte, wyth-out√´ blame; But, for ye han so good a name, And, to bere, ben ek couenable, Strong also & seruysable; To yow thys armure I commytte, Out off your garde that they nat flytte.‚Äù And she tooke [hem] ful lowly In-to hyr kepyng fynally, And in hyr tresour vp hem layde. And Grac√´ dieu than to me sayde: Grace dieu: Quod she a-noon, ‚Äòtak hed her-to! Now artow redy for to go As a pylgrym on thy Iournee To Ierusaleem the cyte; Redy in al (yt ys no drede), Save off o thyng thow hast nede, Only off bred, (wyth-out√´ more,) Ther-wyth thy skrypp√´ to astore: Off wych bred I ha the told. ‚ÄòBut I the rede, be nat to bold To tak√´ noon (in no degre,) Wyth-outen lycence or conge Off the ladyes (in substaunce) Wych ha that bred in gouernaunce. And alderfyrst: thow ek observe, That thow konne yt wel dysserve, And thy sylff, aforn to make To be worthy yt to take Off the ladyes, benygne off cherys, Wych ther be set ffor awmenerys: With-oute hem, put the nat in pres.‚Äô Thanne wente I to Moyses, Hym be-souhte, to my good sped, ffor to youe me off that bred. And he me gaff yt ful goodly; And in my skrypp√´, a-noon I Putte that bred most off vertu. Thanne to me spak Grac√´ dieu: Grace dieu: Quod Grac√´ dieu to me tho blythe, ‚ÄòBy my counsayl, offt√´ sythe Lok ther-to that thow tak hede Whan thow shalt etyn off thys bred, Thy syluen gostly to dysporte, And thyn herte to r√©counforte, Therby tarme thy sylff ryht wel, Bet than in Iren or in stel; ‚ÄòTherby to han experyence ffor to mak√´ r√©sistence Ageyn al thy mortal ffon. ‚ÄòBut herkene vn-to me A-noon: Conceyu√´ (for conclus√Øoun) Yt ys a gret confus√Øoun To the (yiff thow lyst to lere,) That she wych ys thy chaumberere Sholde, affter the, thyn armys bere; And thow thy-sylff darst hem nat were, Nor wyth thy fynger touche hem nouht, Swych dred & fer ys in thy thouht, Thow braydest on a koward knyht, Resemblynge hem that dar nat ffyht: I holde hem nat goode werryours, Manly knyhtes, nor conquerours, That hange her sheldys vp on the wal, To make a mowstre in specyal, Outward by, as by apparence, ffor to shewe the excellence Off ther rychesse by fressh array; And ther bodyes, nyht nor day, Nor them sylff, dar nat a-vaunce To handle nouther swerd nor launce; But outward shewyn ffressh peyntures Off dyuers bestys and ffygures, Lyk to manly champyouns, As they wolden slen lyouns In dyffence off ther contre. And yet, par cas, yt may so be, Ther bodyes strong√´ly tassure, They stuffe her somerys wyth armure, Wych ay hem folweth at the bak, That in shewyng ther be no lak; And for al that, (who taketh hede) And yt kome vn-to the nede, (I mene, as off a mortal werre,) They wold√´ hem sylff holde afferre, To preue her manhood & hyr myght. ‚ÄòBut I holde hym a manly knyght, ‚ÄòWych off hys harneys (fer & ner) Ys hym syluen the somer, And bereth hys armure on hys bak, On hys Enmyes to tak√´ wrak; And in hys harneys, day & nyht Ys found√´ redy, lyk a knyht, Off prouydence hym sylff to kepe, And ther-in, day and nyht doth slepe, Redy to sende hym wyth hys hond, Namly, whan he ys in a lond Wher the werre ys ay mortal, ‚ÄòAnd truste wel in especyal, That the land & the contre Toward Ierusalem the cyte, Thow mayst nat passe yt, fer nor ner, Wyth-oute pereil & gret daunger. Yt ys ay ful off Ennemyes, Off brygauntys, & fals espyes, And off ffomen fful despytous. ‚ÄòAnd in thys passage perillous, Me semeth (in no maner wyse,) That yt may to the suffyse, Thy stonys platly, nor thy staff slynge, (Wych wyth the that thow dost brynge), But yiff thow do thy deuer, To haue wyth the thy Somer, To ber thy armys on thy bak, Bet than in bowgys or cloth sak. ‚ÄòYt wer a gret derys√Øoun To the, and gret confus√Øoun, Yiff thy chaumbrere sholde hem brynge, And thow, for lak off fforseyynge, Stoode thy syllff disconsolaat, Dysarmyd, nakyd, & chek-maat, Consydred that thy chaumberere Ys lasse off myght & off powere Than thow thy-sylff[√´] sholdest be, Yiff thow be gouernyd by equyte.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúCerteys ye seyn ryht wel at al. ‚ÄúBut I wolde in especyal Wyten how yt myght√´ be, Or whehr the faut√´ wer in me, The caus√´ platly of thys cas, That I so sone dysarmyd was; And why I myght√´ nat endure The hevynesse off myn armure.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòHastow,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòno R√©membraunce, How I the told√´, in substaunce, Thow wer to fat, and to lykynge, To gret and large (as by semynge,) The to putte in √°venture So hevy armure to endure?‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúI wel remembre,‚Äù so ye sayde, And thys defautys on me ye layde; And yet ye sayde to me no wrong; But now I ffele my sylff mor strong To ben armyd, off good entente, Yiff so be that ye assente.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòWostow what thow art?‚Äô quod she: ‚ÄòYiff thow be On, declare to me; Yiff thow be double outher tweyne, Tel me A-noon & nat ne feyne. Lat ther be no varyaunce Wher thow hau√´ gouernaunce Off any maner other wyht Than off thy sylff: tel on now ryht.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúyiff ye lyst se, Off thys thyng ye ax√´ me, (Yiff ye lyst pleynly to concerne,) I haue no mo for to gouerne But mysylff, nor to comaunde. I haue merveyl off your demaunde; What ye mene, off this questyoun Wyth-oute a declaracyoun.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòYiff vn-to me good audyence, And also do thy dyllygence Terkne a-noon what I shal say; And thy sylff shalt nat seyn nay; But I shal preue the contrayre, That thou hast an aduersayre, And On ek off thy most√´ foon, Whom that thow off yore agon Hast yhad in gouernaunce, And dost ful bysy √°ttendaunce ffor to cherysshe day & nyght, Wyth al thy power, and thy myght; A day√´s, for to fede hym offte, And a nyht, to leyn hym soffte; Wyth metys most delycyous, And, wyth deynt√´s outragous, Thow dost ful besy √°ttendaunce To ffostren hym to hys plesaunce. ‚ÄòWhat-euere cost ther-on be spent, Thow takest noon heed in thyn entent, But al hys lustys to obeye. ‚ÄòAnd yet I dar afferme & seye, He was ordeyned for to be Soget & seruaunt vn-to the, And tabyde in thy servyse. ‚ÄòBut now ys tournyd al that guyse, Pleynly, yiff thow lyst to se; ffor he hath now the souereynte, Lordshepe & domynac√Øoun, That ffyrst was in subiecc√Øoun. And to concluden, at O word, Thow art soget, & he ys lord; And yet he was delyvered the, Thy seruaunt euere to ha be; But he ys now thy most enmy, And doth hys power outterly, Euere in on, the to werreye, And day & nyght to dysobeye, And for thy lustys ay to varye, Vn-to the to be contr√°rye, ‚ÄòNat-wyth-stondynge the dyllygence, The costys & the gret expense That thow dost hym for to plese, And hys Gredynesse tapese: Thow beyst hym many fressh Iowel, And sparest nat off thy catel To beyn hym knyu√´s & tablettys, Rych√´ gyrdelys & corsettys, Clothes off sylk & off skarlet, Embrawdyd, & wyth perlys ffret: Al hys desyrs thow pursues, Somwhyle to lede hym to the stewes, To wasshe & bathe hym tendyrly, And to leyn hym sofftely On ffether beddys, mad ful wel, ffor to slepe hys vndermel; And afterward to kembe hys hed: Wyth wyn√´s also, whyt & red, Wyth maluesyn & ypocras, Thow dost to hym ful gret solas, And art mor bysy hym to queme Than thy-sylff, I dar wel deme. ‚ÄòAs a norysshe on hyr enfaunt, Thow art euere √°ttendaunt To ffostren hym, lyk hys delyt, And to serue hys appetyt; And shortly, whan thow hast al do, Thow hast noon so mortal ffo; ffor the, to trayshe wyth al hys myht, He lyth a waytynge day & nyht; And hys ffamylyaryte Ys ful noyous vn-to the. ffor Enmy noon ys so perillous, So dredful, nor cont√°gyous, In al the erth√´, fer nor ner, As an enmy ffamylyer, Nor so gretly to be drad Off ffolkys that be wyse & sad. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow lyst to lern off me, Tak good hed; for thys ys he ‚ÄòWych wolde nat suffre the to lere, Noon Armys nor noon harneys were, The to dyffende fro thyn enmyes, Brygauntys and other false espyes; And shortly (yiff I shal nat tarye) He ys thy gretest aduersarye That thow hast, & most to drede: Be war therfor, & tak bet hede.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúyiff ye lyst se, I merveylle what he shold√´ be, He that ye accuse and blame, And put on hym so gret dyffame, How that he shold√´, day & nyht, Be bysy (as ffer as he hath myght) To traisshe me, as a fals tractour, And to my worshype & honour Don any derogacioun By swych compassyd fals traisoun. ‚ÄúI pray yow for to tellen me What maner whyht he shold√´ be. Telleth me ek whar he was born, And warneth me off hym to-forn; Telleth hys name & hys fygure, That I may my sylff assure Ageyn hys mortal Enmyte, That I myghte avengyd be. And, by my trouthe, a-noon I shal Dysmembren hym on pecys smal, Quyk on the Erthe, what-euere he be, And ye hys nam√´ tellen me. And yet thys vengaunce, in no wyse Myght√´ nat ynowh suffyse, Thogh al quyk (to myn entente) I dysmembrede hym ther he wente.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthow seyst ryht wel: But, & thow wylt wyten euerydel, And conceyve ek in thy thouht, Ne wer thy-sylff, he wer ryht nouht, ‚ÄòNor, wyth-out√´ the, certeyn, He ne wer nat but in veyn; ffor ffolkys, nouther yong nor olde, Shold√´ nat on hym be-holde, But haue hym in despyt, certeyn, In r√©preff, & in gret desdeyn, (Ne wer thy sylff, I the ensure,) ffor but a lyknesse off ordure, And a statue off slyym vnclene, (Vnderstond wel what I mene,) Donge & putrefacc√Øoun, A Kareyn off corrupcyoun: Thow shalt yt fynde (in wordys fewe,) As openly I shal the shewe, Whan thow gynnest thy passage. And, for thyn owne √°vauntage, I wyl go wyth the off entent, And, holdyng our parlement, Thow & I, to-gydre yffere, What that he ys, I shal the lere.‚Äô y? pilgrime ‚ÄúGo we,‚Äù quod I ‚ÄúI am wel payd Off al that euere ye ha sayd; But specyaly I yow requere That ye & I may gon yfere, And depart√´ nat our way; And that ye wyl me goodly say (Lyk to your oppynyoun) The maner & condic√Øoun Off myn enmy, & off me, Whil that we to-gydre be, No whyht but ye & I yfere,‚Äî Except√´ that my chaumberere Wyth me haveth myn armure;‚Äî And my syluen mor tassure, That in hyre ther be no lak, Me folweth alway at the bak.‚Äù Grace Dieu. Quod grac√´ dieu, ‚Äòffor to declare Thyn Enmy pleynly, & nat spare, ‚ÄòHe ys foul & ek terryble Lothsom also, & Odyble, Off condycyoun ful dyuers, Right contrayr√´ & peruers; Was engendryd (I dar assure) And brouht forth, as by nature, Off woormys that in erth√´ krepe, And lyggen in the soil ful depe. He ys a worme, & shal also Be wormys mete; tak hed her-to! Off wormys (in especyal) He took hys orygynal; And in-to wormys he shal tourne, And wyth wormys ek soiourne; In the erth√´ putrefye; And wormys shal hym ek defye, Torne hym to foul corrupcyoun: Swych ys hys condyc√Øoun. ‚ÄòAnd nat for-thy (tak hed & se,) Euery nyht he lyth wyth the A-bedde; and trust√´ ek trewly, Ye part√´ neuere company. And vn-to the yt ys gret shame, And a maner off dyffame To the, & gret confus√Øoun; Affter hys replecyoun, He may nat purge hym on no syde But thow hym lede, & be hys guyde; In chaumbre, goyng to pryvee, Hys chaumberleyn thow mustest be: Wyth-out√´ the (yt stondeth so) That he sothly may no-thyng do: Thow art hys pyler & hys potent; And ellys he were Inpotent, Blynde, & lam√´ dout√´les, Deff, and also spech√´les, And √≥ff no reputac√Øoun, Ne wer thy supportac√Øoun. ‚ÄòAnd yet to speke in general, He kan to the no thank at al: ‚ÄòHys froward conuersacyoun Ys off swych condycioun.‚Äô Y? pilgrime. ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúal that ye seyn, I vnderstonde yt wel certeyn; But I merveyll√´ ful gretly That ye lyst nat to me pleynly Mak√´ ful relacyoun, And clerly demonstrac√Øoun, Wyth toknys bothen hih & lowe, Attonys that I myghte hym knowe; ffor thanne, nouther nyht nor day Ther sholde be makyd no delay, Wyth-out√´ respyt or pyte But that I sholde a-vengyd be (Wyth-out√´ s√∫pport or fav√≥ur) By cruel deth, on that traytour.‚Äù Grace Dieu. ‚ÄúNat-wyth-stondynge hys offence, To slen hym thow hast no lycence; That may be suffryd in no wyse. But thow mayst hym wel chastyse And correct√´ by due peyne, And fro vycys hym restreyne. And, whan that he doth forfete, As a mayster thow shalt hym bete, And correcte hym by travaylle,‚Äî Nat as a tyraunt by battaylle, By cruel Rygour nor vengaunce,‚Äî But reforme hym by penaunce, At-wyxe the yok off loue & drede. ffor (yiff thow lyst to taken hede,) Penaunce ys hys cheff maystresse, Hym to chastyse & to redresse: She shal, off al dyffaute & blame, Refreynen hym, & make hym tame, Off dyscrecioun wel a-vysed. And whan she hath hym wel ch stysed, She shal (as thow shalt vnderstond,) Make hym redy to thyn hond, As A seruaunt, the to serue, Lyk a sergaunt, to obserue Lowly, what thow byst hym do, And nat sey nay, nor go ther-fro, But be at thy comaund√´ment. ‚ÄòThys sholdest thow, off good entent, (Lyk vn-to an holsom leche,) Rather desyre, than any wreche. ffor (yiff thow look wyth Eyen cler,) He stondeth nat vnder daunger Off dethe to the, no maner wyse; ffor thow art bound√´ to deuyse Hys goostly elth√´ & wel-ffare; And ouer thys, nat for to spare, (Wherso that he wake or slepe) ffrom al pereyl hym to kepe, Wherso that thow be dul or ffressh; ffor thys, thy Body & thy fflessh, He that I mene, the sylu√´ same, Off hym I kan noon other name.‚Äù The Pylgryme. ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúwhat may thys be? Whether dreme I, other ellys ye? ffor (as fer as I kan espye,) I merveylle off your fantasye, Or by what weye ye wold√´ gon. Ys nat my body & I al on? I trow√´ yis; & ellys wonder, Or how myhte we be assonder? Ys he a-nother than am I? I pray yow, tel me ffeythfully, (And me declareth the sothnesse Wyth-outen any dowbylnesse,) What that ye men√´ verrayly; ffor her ys no whyht but ye & I, Except only my chaumberere, Wych that folweth us ryht here. ‚ÄúA-noon to me doth sygnefye, Wher yt be trouth or fayrye That we shold ben on or tweyne: ‚ÄúTel on a noon, & doth nat ffeyne.‚Äù Grace Dieu. Quod Grace dieu: ‚Äòout off my mouth Went√´ neuere north nor south, Est, nor west, n√≥ lesyng, Illusyoun, nor fals dremyng. But I axe a questyoun: Answere ther-to by good resoun: ‚ÄòYiff thow were now in a place fful off merthe & off solace, Wyth mete & drynke, at good ese, And wyth al thys, the to plese, Haddyst thy comaund√´mentys Off hallys, chaumbrys, & gaye Tentys, Sofft√´ beddys, dysport & play, And euery thyng vn-to thy pay, Havyng no lak vp-on no syde; Yiff thow myghtest ther abyde At thy choys ffrely alway, Woldestow gladly parte a-way, Or ellys stylle abyd√´ there? Tel on boldly, & ha no ffere.‚Äô Y? pilgrim ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúdysplese yow nouht; I sey ryht as lyth in my thouht: Myn hertys es√´ for to swe, I wolde abyde (& nat remewe,) ffor myn ese, euere in on, Rather than thenys for to gon; ffor yt ys profytable tabyde Wher that a man, on euery syde ffyndeth vn-to hys plesaunce Soiour, wyth-out√´ varyaunce.‚Äô Grace Dieu. ‚ÄòYs that verrayly,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòSoth that thow hast sayd to me? I vnderstonde, by thy language, Thow woldest leue thy pylgrymage, And platly settyn hyt a-syde, Only for reste, & ther a-byde.‚Äô The Pylgryme. ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúfor my dysport, Wher I fond es√´ & counfort, I wolde abyde a whyl√´ there, Tyl I sawh tyme & good leyser.‚Äù Grace dieu. To me she sayde a-noon ryht than: ‚ÄòO wrechche! o thow vnhappy man! Tak hed, & be mor √©ntentyff, How her√´, in thys mortal lyff, Thogh that a man renne euermore, He may neuere hast hym to sore To kome to tymely to that place. ‚ÄòI putt√´ caas, that he ha space fforth to proced√´, day be day, At good leyser vp-on hys way. Her-vp-on I ax√´ the, Yiff thow haddyst lyberte, Ioy√´, merthe, & al sol√°ce, Woldestow fro thylk√´ place, Yiff thow haddyst fre chois at wylle Remewen, or a-byd√´ stylle?‚Äô Y? pilgrime ‚ÄúAllas!‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúwhat may I seyn? I kan nat wel answere a-geyn. But o thyng I wot ryht wel; The cyrcumstancys euerydel Consydryd vp-on euery syde, Par cas, rather I sholde abyde, Than ben to hasty to procede, Tyl I sawh I must√´ nede Goon forth off necessyte: In caas than wolde I hast√´ me.‚Äù Grace Dieu: Quod Grace dieu thanne vn-to me: ‚ÄòBy thyn answere, I do wel se That thyn entencyoun ys trouble, And thy wyl ys also double; Thy inward thouht ek vary√°ble, Thy purpos dyuers & vnstable, ‚ÄòConsydryd vp-on outher syde, How som whyle thow wylt abyde, And a-nother tyme also, Thow art in wyl forth for to go; Now in travaylle, now in reste, And offte thow thynkest, for the beste, Stylle in a plac√´ to soiourne; And sodeynly thy wyl doth tourne, ffor to hold√´ thy passage; Thy purpos double off vysage, Constreyn√®d by a dyuers lawe, Now forth, & now yt doth wyth-drawe; Selde or neuere off O thouht; The toon wyle, & the tother nouht.‚Äù The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúlyk as ye seyn, fful trewe I ffele yt, in certeyn.‚Äù Grace dieu: Than quod she; ‚Äúlat nat the greue Vp-on thy wordys; thogh I preue, And thogh I make an Argument, That thow art double in thyn entent, Alway nat on, in certeyne, But partyd oft√´ in-to tweyne. ffor yt ys knowe, off yore agon, That two wyllys be nat on, Wych be seueryd in o thouht, And off entent acord√´ nouht. ffor, how myght√´ they accorde, Whan they drawe nat by o corde? Thys knoweth euery maner whyht, That hath off Resoun any syht.‚Äù The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I ‚ÄúI yow be-seche, Clerly that ye wyl me teche What that I am; wych seyn that I Am nat the same that my body. What am I thanne? thys wolde I se, Yiff ye lyst enfourmen me: Ther wer no thyng to me so leff, ‚ÄúAs knowe her-off A trew√´ preff.‚Äù Grace dieu: Quod grac√´ dieu: ‚Äòyt semeth wel, Thow hast nat lernyd euerydel Thyngys nouther hih nor lowe, Syth thy sylff thow kanst nat knowe; The wych, a-boue al other thyng Ys the best√´ knowelychyng That man may han in thys lyff here. ‚ÄòAnd, yiff thow lyst platly lere, To knowe thy sylff ys bet knowyng Than to be Emperour outher kyng, Or for to knowen al scy√©nces, Practykes, & experyences; Or to han al the rychesse Off thys world (in sothfastnesse), Or the tresour euerydel, But syth thow knowest nat ryht wel Thy sylff, as thow sholdest knowe, (Wyth cyrcumstauncys hih & lowe,) Me semeth (as in myn avys,) Taxe and lern√´, thow art wys. And I shal telle the feythfully In thys mater√´, trew√´ly, What that I fele in myn entent Shortly, as in sentement: ‚ÄòThe Body, fyrst, (be nat in doute,) Off wych I spak closyd' wyth-owte, Whan yt ys fro th√´ segregat, Dysseueryd & separat, Thanne off the, (I dar wel seyn And afferme yt in certeyn) Off god thow art the portrature, Thymage also, and ffygure; And off nouht (yiff thow kanst se) He ffourmede & he mad√´ the, (That lord ffyrst, in thy creaunce,) To hys own√´ r√©semblaunce And ymage, wych off lyknesse Most dygne, & worthy off noblesse, ‚ÄòA prent (to speke off dygnyte) He myghte nat ha set on the Mor worthy, nor mor not√°ble, Than to hym sylff r√©sembl√°ble. He gaff to the, off hys goodnesse, Cler syht off Resoun, & ffayrnesse, And off nature to be mor lyht Than any ffoul that ffleth in flyht, And neuere to deyen, ek wyth-al, ffor he made the Immortal, Permanent, & euere stable. And tadwellyd Immut√°ble, Yiff thow nat haddyst, off entent, fforfetyd hys comaund√´ment; Than haddystow, thorgh thy Renoun, Excellyd in comparysoun: Comparysoun myghte noon ha be To thy noblesse & dygnete, Off hewene nor Erth√´, in certeyn, Nor (to declare & speke in pleyn,) Bryd, nor other cr√´ature, Except off angelys the nature. ‚ÄòGod ys thy ffader, (tak hed her-to) And, thow art hys sone also, Most excellynge off kynrede That euere was (wyth-out√´ drede), Most noble, & off grettest style; ffor off Thomas de guillevyle Thow art nat sone on that party I dar afferme, & seyn trewly, Who-euere gruchche, or mak√´ stryff That he nat hadde, in al hys lyff. To seke, in al hys nacyoun, No sone off swych condycyoun, Douhter nouther (yt ys no fable,) Off kynred√´ so not√°ble. But, off Engendrure bodyly, Thow haddest off hym thy body, Wych kam off hym by nature: The wych body (I kan assure) ‚ÄòYs to the (tak hed her-to,) Thyn Enmy & thy grettest foo, ‚ÄòOn that party (yiff thow lyst se,) Roos fyrst the gret√´ Enmyte; Nature hath yt so ordeyned; But yt thorgh vertu be restreyned. For the ffrut (what-euere yt be) Bereth the tarage off the tre That yt kam fro (I dar assure); ffor yt were ageyn nature, A Thorn to bern a Fygg√´ soote; The bud hath tarage off the roote, Lyk as an appyl or a pere, Thogh yt be born, neuere so fere, Yt savoureth (whan that al ys do,) Off the Tre that yt kam fro. ‚ÄòAnd semblably haue in mynde, Manys body, as be kynde, As off hym sylff (be wel certeyn), May ber no ffrut but foul & veyn Ordure & corrupc√Øoun, Slym & putrefacc√Øoun. ‚ÄòBut yiff thy gynnyng be wel souht, Off swych fylth√´ thow kome nouht: ffor fyrst, in thy creac√Øoun Thow haddyst no producc√Øoun (Yiff I shal declaren al) Off no man that was mortal. Thy makynge may nat be amendyd, ffor off god thou art descended; And pleynly (yiff thou vnderstondys,) God made neuere wyth hys hondys Her in erthe (what sholde I feyne) Off mankynd√´ mo than tweyne; Vn-to wyche (wyth-out√´ wheer) He commyttede hys power, And gaff to hem an exaumplayre, Other, lyk hem, to mak√´ fayre, Lyk thexamples in general, To hym reseruynge in specyal ‚ÄòOff spyrytys (in conclus√Øoun) Thordynaunce & the ffasown, Off wych he wold√´ (as by skyl) Noon other medle, by hys wyl. ‚ÄòAnd her-vp-on (yiff thow lyst se,) The sam√´ lord, he mad√´ the Off hys goodnesse, for thy prowh; And in the body wher thow art now, He the putte (as I dar telle), Ther a whyl√´ for to dwelle, And ther tabyde (thys, the cheff) For tassay√´ the by preff; And by thy port also dyscerne How thow sholdest the gouerne Prudently, both fer & ner; And yiff thow dydest thy dever To dyffend√´ thy party, Yiff he wolde hold√´ chaumpartye Ageyn[y]s the in any wyse. ffor, (as I shal to the devyse,) Atwyx√´ yow (yt ys no faylle) Ther ys werre & strong bataylle, And contynuelly ther shal be, But so falle, thow yeld√´ the, And putte the in subiecc√Øoun Thorgh hys fals collus√Øoun, By hys deceyt & flaterye Evere to hau√´ the maystrye Over the (in c√≥nclus√Øoun) Whyl he hath domynac√Øoun. ‚ÄòBut yiff that thow (as yt ys ryht,) Dyscounfyte hym by verray myghte, And by forc√´ ber hym doun Lyk a myghty champyoun, Than shal-tow (both√´ fer & ner,) Over hym han ful power, That he shal neuere, for no quarelle, Ageyn[y]s the, dor rebelle, To Interupt√´ thyn entente. ‚ÄòAnd trewly, but thy sylff assente ‚ÄòHe shal neuere be so bold, The to wythstonde, as I ha told. ‚ÄòHe ys Dalyda, thow art Sampsoun; Thow art strong (as by resoun), Sturdy on thy feet to stonde: Suffre hym nat, the to wyth-stonde, Nor over the to han maystrye ffor no glosyng nor flatrye. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thou tak√´ hed ther-to, She ne kan nat ellys do; But wyth flatrye & deceyt, Nyht & day lyn in a-wayt, And swych wach on the doth make, To make thyn enmyes the to take At mescheff, whan they may the fynde. And yiff thow wylt, sche shal the bynde. Sher thyn heer whyl thow dost slepe, But thow konne thy-syluen kepe. And overmor, I the ensure, Thy counsayl al she wyl dyscure, And thy secretys euerichon, To phylystees that be thy ffoon. Other frenshepe, trust√´ me, She hath pleynly noon to the. ‚ÄòNow ches, & to my speche entende, How thow wylt thy syllf dyffende; Be nat to thy confus√Øoun Deceyued as whylom was Sampsoun.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù to grac√´ dieu quod I, ‚ÄúI merveyll√´ ful gret√´ly; ffor pleynly (as yt doth me seme) Outher I slep√´ or I dreme That ye, a-mong your wordys alle, Lyst a ‚ÄòSpyryt‚Äô me to calle, Wych wyth my body do abyde, Wher-so that I go or ryde; And seyn, I am to cler seyng; And me semeth I se no thyng. And ek I take good hed her-to, ‚ÄúHow ye afferme, & seyn also, That my body, wych seth so wel, How that he seth neueradel, But ys as blynd as ys a ston. And your wordys euerychon Ben so vnkouth & merveyllous, And to my wyt so daungerous, That they faren, whan I hem here, As a flee were in myn Ere; I am astonyd so outterly. I pray you tel me mor clerly, That I may wyt√´ (by som mene) Off al thys thyng, what that ye mene.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòTak hed,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòyiff thow konne, And se somwhyl√´ how the sonne, Wyth hys bemys bright & clere, Most ffressh in hys mydday spere, The sam√´ tyme, vnder a cloude, Offt√´ sythe he doth hym schrowude, That men may nat be-holde & se The bryht√´nesse off hys bewte. Wher-vp-on, I the comaunde To answere to thys demaunde: Whan the sonne ys closyd so That hys clernesse ys ago, Tel on, & Answere, yiff thow may, Off what thyng causyd ys the day.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúTo tell√´ shortly in a clause: Off day, ther ys noon other cause But phebus, as I kan espye. Thogh hys bemys, vnder skye Ben hyd, yet yt ys no doute, Al the lyht that sheweth oute, Ys ycausyd euerydel Off the sonne (who lok√´ wel); Thorgh a skye hys lyht doth passe, To shewe yt forth in euery place. And shortly ellys (yt ys no nay) ‚ÄúWyth-oute hys lyht, ther wer no day.‚Äù Grace dieu: Quod Grac√´ dieu: ‚Äòanswere me; How maystow parceyue or se, Or in any wyse espye Hys bryhte bemys thorgh a skye?‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúRyht so,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúas thorgh a verre, Men sen hys bemys shyne a-ferre, Or as men sen off ffyr the lyht, Thorgh a lanterne cler & bryht.‚Äù Grace dieu: Quod Grac√´ dieu a-noon to me: ‚ÄòWhat thow hast sayd, tak hed,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòAnd vnderstond ffyrst in thy syht, By the sonne that shyneth bryht, Thy soul√´ cler, in esp√©cyal, Wyth-Inne thy body wych ys mortal. Off thys mater we haue an honde, Ther-by thy soule I vnderstonde. ‚ÄòThy body (yiff thow kanst espye) Vs dyrk, as ys a clowdy skye; And lyk also (who kan dyscerne) To a smoky, blak lanterne. And nat for-thy (I dar expresse) Men may sen, thorgh the bryhtnesse Off the soule (yt ys no doute), And the clernesse, fer wyth-oute. Clerkys recorde yt in ther skolys; And other wene, that be but ffolys, In ther foltyssh fals demyng, That al the cler enlwmynyng Wher-off that por√´ sky√´ (lo,) Wher-wyth the sowle ys shrowdyd so, Eclypsyd off hys fayr bryhtnesse. And ne were the gret dyrknesse Off thys skye (who loke a-ryht), The sowle sholde han so cler a syht At o look, fro the oryent To sen in-to the occident. ‚Äòffor off the body (trust√´ me) The Eyen, no verray eyen be, But lyk to glas, (I dar wel seyn), Wher-thorgh the cler√´ soule ys seyn, And outward (wyth hys bemys bryht) Yiveth ther-to clernesse and lyht. ffor the sowle, (who taketh hede,) Off bodyly eyen hath no nede, No mor than, in semblable caas, The bryht√´ sonne hath off the glas, Nouther byforn, nouther be-hynde. ‚ÄòAnd conceyue also in thy mynde, That Eyen wych ben espyrytual, Wyth-oute spect√°cle or ffenestral, Sen off hem syllf mor parfytly, fferther perce, & mor clerly, Than whan the bodyly dyrknesse, The gostly ey√´ doth oppresse. ffor gostly Eyen sen wel the bet, Whan yt ys so they be nat let Wyth bodyly Eyen that ben outward, And han to no-thyng ther reward, But to thynges off veynglorye, That be passynge & transyt√≥rye, Dyrked wyth a worldly skye. ‚ÄòAnd whylom blynd√´ was Tobye Off bodyly eyen, as wyth-oute; But inwardly (yt ys no doute) He was nat blynded off hys syht, But hadde hys eyen cler & bryht; I mene, the Eyen off hys mynde; ffor by tho Eyen (as I ffynde) He tauhte hys sone, & clerly tolde The wey√´ that he shold√´ holde In hys passag√´, & nouht erre. Hys Eyen wer cler as any sterre, Off hys mynde, wych made hym se; And ellys yt myghte neuere ha be, Off hys inward inspeccyoun, To yove him swych instruccyoun ‚ÄòHow he shold√´ hym gouerne, Wyth-oute the siht wych ys eterne, I men√´, the siht spyrytual, Wych ys gostly & eternal. ‚ÄòThat syhte, by ag√´ wasteth nouht; And (yiff the trouth√´ be wel souht,) Thy bodyly eyen (trust√´ me,) Wyth hem thow mayst no thyng yse. The soule seth al by cler lookyng, And the body seth nothyng; Blynd wyth-Innen & wyth-oute. And ner the soule, (yt ys no doute,) Seyng cler he shold ha noon, Na mor than hath the cold√´ ston. ‚ÄòAnd as yt ys towchyng syht, Evene so (who looke a-ryht) Yt ys off al thy wyttys fyue; ffor who seyth nay, or geyn yt stryue, Euerych off hem, in sentement, Ys but a maner instrument, The wych, touchyng ther werkyng, Off th√© they receyve euery thyng; ffor, wyth-outen helpe off the, They no thyng here, they no thyng se, Nor no thyng thay may reporte. And yiff thow dyst hem nat supporte, And sustenyst wyth thy myghte, Eryng, Smellyng, Touch & Syht, Thy body wer nat euerydel But a verray foul dongel, Impotent, and feble also, Outher to mevyn or to go.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúThanne, wyth your supportac√Øoun, I axe off you thys questyoun; And ffryst off all I thus begynne: ‚ÄòHow may the sowle that ys wyth-inne, Ber the body that ys wyth-oute?‚Äô To me assoylleth fyrst thys doute; ffor yt semeth mor Reson, ‚Äú(As to my oppynyoun,) The body outward (thus I mene) Sholde the soule inward sustene. Yiff ye grante to speke at large, Thyng that conteneth, berth the charge, And bereth vp al, to myn entent: And thyng, wyth-Inne that ys content, That thyng ys born, as semeth me. And her-vp-on I wold√´ se, Syth that ye ben prudent & wys, A good answere, by your avys.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòVp-on thy questioun to conclude An answere, as by symylytude: Conceyu√´ fyrst in thyn entent, Thy clothyng & thy vestyment. Contene thy boady euerydel Wyth-Innen: yiff thow loke wel, Thy body closyd ys wyth-Inne; And but yiff thow fro resoun twynne, Thow wylt nat geyn-seyn vn-to me, Thow beryst thy clothys, & they nat the, And fully ben in thy depoos; And yet thow art wyth-Inne hem cloos; And, (yiff thow clerly kanst dyscerne,) At thy lust dost hem gouerne; And (to seyn shortly in substaunce,) Thow hast off hem the gouernaunce.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúAnd ys yt lyk, ma dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚ÄúIn al, off me & my body?‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòTo yive th√© mor cler evydence, I putte a maner dyfference; Leff the chaff, & tak the corn: The sowle bereth, & ys born. ffor, ffyrst, the sowle pryncypally Susteneth & bereth the body; And parcel-lyk (to thyn entent) The body bereth by accident ‚ÄòThe sowl√´, but her-on reporte, The myghte, the vertu, ay resorte Off the body, in certeyn, Evere vn-to the sowle ageyn. ‚ÄòAnd evydence her-on to make: Thow mayst a cler exaumple take, Yiff thow euere dydest se Any shyp a-myd the see, (Shortly declaryng, at a word,) The maryner wyth-Inne the bord Ledeth the shyp, (tak hed her-to,) And ys hym sylff ylad also. Tak here Exaumple, & be wel sad, But he yt ladde, he wer nat lad. ‚ÄòSemblably, by exaumple cler, Thy sawl√´ ys cheff maryner, Ledere & gov√©rneresse Off thy body, in sothnesse: She ledeth hym ay too & too, And ys hyr syllf ylad also. ffor, at hyr lust & hyr talent, She, by hyr own√´ fre assent, Ledeth the body, as yt ys skyl. ffor the body, but by hyr wyl, Hath no power, (yt ys no drede) No syde, the sowl√´ for to lede. ‚ÄòAnd therfor, do thy besy peyne, Havynge the body in thy demeyne, To lede hym so, & he ek the, In thys dredful worldly see, fful off wyndys & Tempest, And waw√´s boyllynge Est & west, That, by assent, here in your live, At goode hauene ye may aryve, And at good port, whan cruel deth Schal make hym yelden vp the breth.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dam√´, sothly, I do lere, By your wordys that I here, To forthre me, & nat to tarye. ‚ÄúYt wer to me ryht necessarye, That off your grace ye wold√´ blyue, Out off my shyp mak√´ maryue; I men√´ thus, ma dame, that ye Wolde in al haste dyspoyll√´ me Off my body, wych ys greuous, Hevy, gret, & ponderous, That I myghte off hym a-noon ryht Haue knowelychyng & ek a syht Mor cler, to make me vnderstonde The mater that we haue an honde, To sen hym, how he ys compassyd, Wych hath so offte to me trespassyd; And yet he wyl nat, for myn ese, Hys Rancour a-geyns me appese. ‚ÄòBut yet I pray yow feythfully, To don your deuer ffynally, That I may sen hym (& nat ellys), Wher he be swych as ye me tellys; ffor I nat vnderstond ywys, What ye ha sayd, nor what he ys.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòI may ryht wel be-leve,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòThys thyng so vnkouth & secre, That thow art dyrkyd in thy syht, Yt to consydre & sen a-ryht. And the cause why thow art let Ys, for thy body hath so shet Thy gostly Eyen (in substaunce) Wyth a clowde off ygnoraunce, And dyrked wyth a mysty skye, That thow mayst nat wel espye The secreness√´, yong nor Old. And as to-forn I ha the told, Other obst√°cle ys ther noon But thy body, blynd as a ston; He dyrketh so thyn Inward syht. But for thy sake, a-noon ryht I schal assayen & provyde, Thy body for to leyn asyde, ‚Äòffro the take yt, yiff I kan, That thow mayst conceyv√´ than Off hym hooly the gouernaunce, And what he ys, as in substaunce. But thow mustest, in certeyn, Affter, sone, resorte ageyn To thyn old√´ dwellyng place, Tyl that deth, a certeyn space, Schall the dyspoylle, and mak√´ twynne ffro the body that thow art Inne.‚Äô The Pylgryme: And Grac√´ dieu a-noon me took, (I not, wher that I slepte or wook,) & made (for short conclus√Øoun,) My body for to falle a-doun. And affter that, a-noon ryht Me sempt√´ that I took my flyht, And was ravisshed in-to the hayr, A place delytable & ffayr. And me thouht ek, in my syht, I was nat hevy, but verray lyht, And my beholdyng was so cler, That I sawh both√´ fer & ner, Hih & lowe, & oueral. And I was ryht glad wyth-al; Al was wel, to my plesaunce, Save a maner dysplesaunce I hadde off O thyng, in certeyn, That I muste go dwelle ageyn Wyth-Inne my body, wych that lay Lyk an hevy lompe off clay; Wych to me was no forthryng, But perturbaunce, & gret lettyng, Thyder to resorte off newe. Tho wyst I wel that al was trewe That grac√´ dieu hade seyd to me. And thanne I went√´ for to se Wher the body slepte or nouht. And whan I hadd√´ long√´ souht, Tastyd hys pows in certeyne, And gropyd euery nerff & veyne, And fond in hym no breth at al, But ded & cold as a ston wal. And whan I dyde al thys espye, Hys gouernaunce I gan defye. Grace dieu: Tho grac√´ dieu spak vn-to me, ‚ÄòLifft vy thyn Eyen, beholde & se, Yiff thow konn√´ now clerly; Knowe in erthe thy gret enmy, He that wolde nat suffre the bere Noon Armys, nor noon harneys were, Causynge, thow myghtest nat endure, Vp-on thy bak to bere Armure, The to dyffende fro thyn Enmyes, ffro brygauntys & false espyes, Wych the werreyen euermore. Off hym, I ha the told be fore, That yt ouhte ynowh suffise; Yet, as I shal to the devyse, Thow mayst nat chesyn, in certeyn, Wyth-Innen hym to entre Ageyn, Retrussen hym, & ek recharge (Bothe in streyth & ek in large) Bern hym wyth the in thy vyage, Whyder thow gost on pylgrymage.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dam√´, myn entenc√Øoun Was now, & my deuoc√Øoun, Off new√´ to haue Armyd me, Assayed yiff yt wolde ha be, That I myghte ha bor Armure, My sylff the bettre to assure; ffor, as now, to my semyng, They be nat hevy, no maner thyng, Nor lyk the c√≥nceyt off my thouht; They wey√´ but a thyng off nouht.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòno mor they doth; ‚ÄòAnd therfore thow seyst ful soth. But thow shalt vnderstond√´ me Yiff thow dyst now armen the, And woldest now a-noon begynne In the poynt that thou art Inne, Thy meryte to reknen al, Nor thy decert, ne wer but smal; ffor thyn Armure thow must vse, And feythfully yt nat refuse, Whan thow art entryd (thys the cheff,) Thy body that lyth now blynd & deff, Doom also, and insensyble, Wych must√´ wyth the be penyble, Sustene also, & be suffr√°ble. ffor he wyl also be part√°ble Off thy meryt√®s & guerdouns, As he was off thy pass√Øouns: Your decertys shal be al on. Wherfore, enhast√´ the a-noon, In-to hym for to retourne, Ther a whyl√´ to soiourne Wyth hym, as thow hast don toforn. And, that your tym√´ be nat lorn, Than off assent & wyl entere, Wyl he be to-gydre yffere, Enarm√´ yow, & make yow strong ffor to wythstondyn euery wrong.‚Äô And whan she hadde al to me sayd, Wher I was wel or evele a-payd, I sawh ther was noon other geyn; I was retrussyd, & a-geyn Wyth the body that I kam fro; And certeynly me thouht√´ tho, I was nakyd, and al bare Off al my Ioye & my wel-fare; ffor al was gon in O moment. And tho I hadde ageyn Talent (Me sempte yt myghte nat be forbore) To lou√´, as I dide affore; & holy vn-to hys entente, Me thouhte I gan a-noon assente, ffully tokeyen hys plesaunce. Thus aparceyvnge my woful chaunce, Clerly sawh wyth-Inn√´ me, That I sholde deceyved be, Lyk as I was off yore agon. And tho I gan to wepe a-noon, Sihe & sorwe, & seyn ‚Äúallas! What shal I don now in thys cas? Or to what party in certeyne Shal I drawen off thys tweyne?‚Äù Grace dieu: Quod grace dieu, ‚Äòwhat may thys be? Why wepystow? what eyleth the, So thy syluen to dyscounforte? ffor trewly (as I kan reporte,) Wepyng & tendre terys grene, Only to wommen appartene, Whan sodeynly they falle in rage, And nat to men off strong corage.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúCertys,‚Äù quod I ‚ÄúI may wel wepe; ffor, (yiff ye lyst to taken kepe,) My Ioye, my myrthe & my plesaunce, Myn Elthe, & al my suffysaunce, Sodeynly me han forsake. I may compleyne, & sorwe make, ffor, whylom, aboue the skye I was wont to fle ful hihe, And hadde also ful glad repayre Wyth bryddys fleyng in the hayr, In my most lusty fressh sesoun; But now I am avaylyd down, I fynde (by gret aduersyte) Al that ys contrayre vn-to me. I am venquisshed, I am bor doun, My vertu (in conclus√Øoun) Hath lost hys myht, hys excellence; ffor now, ther ys no r√©systence On my party (as yt ys founde); ‚Äúffor, off the body, wher I am bounde, Ys hool my force, & al my myght, (Wych ys ageyn al skyle & ryht,) And buryed quyk, (yt stondeth so,) I Am in erthe, wher-euere I go; (Thys verray Ernest, & no Iape,) Cheyned, ryht as ys An Ape, Vn-to a clog, & must yt swe, And fro thenys may nat remewe; ffor my body, gret & large, Ys the Clog that me doth charge, Wych letteth, wyth hys gret√´ wheyhte, That I may nat flen an hyhte; ffor euere, wyth hys mortal lawe, Doun to therthe he doth me drawe. ‚ÄúI trow√´ (shortly in sentence) The word ywrete in sapyence Was whilom seyd off me ywys, Who kan take hed; and yt ys thys: ‚ÄòA body corrupt (yt ys no nay) Greveth the soul√´ nyht & day, Kepeth hym in captyvyte; Yt may nat gon at lyberte, Nouther wakynge nor a-slepe;‚Äô ffor wych, certys, I may wel wepe, And seyn ‚Äòallas,‚Äô & sory be, Off my grete aduersyte.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòThan haue in mynde, for any slouthe, That vn-to the I told√´ trouthe.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúYour wordys alle I do aduerte, & thank√´ you wyth al myn herte. Off hem I am ryht wel apayd; ffor al that euere ye han sayd Ys verray soth, & no lesyng, ‚ÄúBut I be-seche yow off O thyng, Yiff I durste you compelle, O word that ye lyst me telle: What ys the cause (declareth why,) ‚ÄúThat he ys mor strong than I; Or why am I not (telleth me), As strong or myghty as ys he?‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòYiff the roote be wel out souht, Strengere than thow, th√°t ys he nouht. But her-vp-on now herkne me: Thow mayst nat, in no degre, Hym venquisshe (in conclus√Øoun), Oppressyn hym, & bere hym doun So myghtyly in hys contre, As thow sholdest, yiff that he Hadde hys conuersacioun Wher thow hast domynac√Øoun. ‚ÄòIn hys contre he doth now dwelle. Therfor shortly, I the telle, He hath the gretter √°vauntage; And yt ys sayd off ffolkys Sage, And a prouerbe wryte off old, How that euery whyht ys bold Vy-on hys owne (erly & late), At the dongel at hys gate; Strong to mak√´ r√©systence. & men sen by experyence, Ech man mor myghty off hys hond, Whan he ys in hys own√´ lond: Thys doth hym trusten, & be bold. ‚ÄòBut for al thys that I ha told, Tak hed in no maner wyse, Ne let nat, for no cowardyse, Hym tasaayll√´ ffer nor ner; ffor yiff thow konne, at the cheker, Thy drawhtys draw√´, & wel pleye, Make hym lowly to obeye Vp-on hys dongel, in hys estat, Ther, to hym to seyn ‚Äòchek maat;‚Äô Thys maat shal be, thorgh thy puissaunce, To holde hym vnder gouernaunce. And lyst that he do noon offence, Kepe hym lowe wyth abstynence, ‚ÄòVoyde hym fro replecyoun, And governe hym so, by Resoun, Off mete and drynk, only that he Ne do no superfluyte. Lat hym lytel Ete or drynke; Mak hym labour & ek swynke; Lytel slepe, & gret wakyng; Dyscyplynes & ek betyng, Yiff to hym in many wyse. ‚ÄòAnd thus thow shalt hym best chastyse: Devout wepyng wyth orisouns, And hooly medytacyouns, Wyth Instrumentys off penaunce, Shal off thy caus√´ do vengaunce, Best iustefy√´ thy party; And they shal make the fynally (Wyth-out√´ contradicc√Øoun) To haue hym in subiecc√Øoun; And, for thyn encres off glorye, Yiue the renoun & vytt√≥rye Whyl thow so dost, nyght & day, And he shal neuere dor seyn nay. ‚ÄòAnd to fforther thyn entent, Lat vs tweyn√´, by assent, Gon vn-to an hyl off sond, Wych stant her al-most at the hond: A soffte pas, lat vs go walke.‚Äô Verba Peregrini: And as we went√´ & gon talke, A sondy hyl she gan me shewe; And thus she sayde, on wordys fewe: [Grace Dieu]: ‚ÄòLeffte vp thyn eye a-noon,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòAnd ffyrst off al, be-holde & se How that an Ampt√´, a best smal, Wyth hert√´, body, myght & al, To nouht elles doth entende, But on thys hyll√´ vp tascende, And, in hyr paas & clymbyng soffte, She ys bor doun, & let ful offte ‚ÄòWyth powdry sondys out off noumbre, Wych hyr passag√´ so encoumbre, And hyr desyre ek restreyne, That she may nat fully atteyne The hyest party off the hyl, ffor she ys let ageyn hyr wyl. And thogh she peyne hyr nyht & day, Evere the soond lyth in hyr way, Overwhelmeth, & bereth hyr doun, Contrayre to hyr entenc√Øoun, Yt ys so sotyl, drye & smal, And wonder brotyl ek wyth-al, That, by reuoluc√Øoun, Yt rebateth & bereth doun Thys lytel beste that I off telle. ‚ÄòBut for al that, she wyl nat dwelle In the val√´ cast doun lowe, Ther tabyden any throwe; But hyre afforceth a-noon ryht To remounte wyth al hyr myght, Hyr sylff afforcynge, newe & newe, Euere hyr labour to renewe, (Lyk a myghty champyoun) Thogh she wer offte avalyd doun.‚Äô But at the laste, thorgh hyr labour, I sawh hyr, lyk a conquerour, Wyth hyr travaylle renewyd offte Gete vp on the hyl a-loffte; And ne wold√´ neuere lete Tyl yt was conqueryd in quyete; And thanne off ryht, as for hyr beste Vp-on the cop she dyd√´ reste. Grace Dieu: Quod grace dieu tho vn-to me: ‚ÄòHer, thow mayst beholde & se (Yiff thow lyst to loke a-ryht) The forcys (platly) & the myght Bothe off thy body & off the; And in a pleyn Exaumple se ‚ÄòOff thampt√´, wych ys doun [i]falle Among the brotyl sondys alle. Yiff he, at euery fallyng doun, Hadde lost hys myght & hys renoun ffor to recure the hylle a-geyn, Thanne al hys labour were in weyn; But, for on dysconfyture He wyl nat cessyn to recure That he hath lost, (as by hys wyl,) Tyl he be hihe vp on the hyl. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow clerly vnderstond, Thy body ys the hyl off sond, The wych√´, thorgh hys brotylnesse, And powdrys of vnstabylnesse, Ys redy (off entenc√Øoun,) Evere to make the fall√´ doun, And to dyrken (off entent,) The eye off thyn entend√´ment To kepe the in the val√´ lowe. ‚ÄòAnd whan he may espye or knowe That thow, in any maner wyse, Woldest on the hyl aryse, Wyth sondry reuoluc√Øouns Off dyuers temptac√Øouns He travayleth (thys, no tale) Lowe to holde the, in the vale, Wyth hys sturdy vyolence, But thow mak√´ r√©sistence Be tym√´s & at prim√´ face Whan he begynneth to manace. ‚ÄòAnd to wythstonde hys fell√´ myghte, At the gynnyng thow must be lyhte, Mawgre hym, wyth herte & wyl, ffor to gete vp on the hyl; And thy Iourne nat to tarye, Ther ys no bettre exaumplarye Than thampt√´ (yiff thow tak hede) Vp-ward the hyl thy sylff to spede.‚Äô ‚ÄòRemembre, in thyn entencyoun The precept off kyng salomoun, ‚ÄòWych, in hys book of sapyence, Comaundede (shortly in sentence) And bad men taken hed her-to, To the Ampt√´ ffor to go, Tavoyd√´ slouth√´, cheff noryce And moder vn-to euery vyce. ‚ÄòSalomoun vnderstood & ffond The pereyl off thys hyl off sond In hys tyme, & ek ther-to, The nature off the Ampte also; Ther-off, whan he wrot in hys book, & good hed also he took To thampte in sothfastnesse, Whan he bad voyde al ydelnesse. ‚ÄòBe war, therfore, off sleuthe, I rede And euere among, tak good heede Off hys sleyhty fals√´ whyles, Off hys treyn√´s & hys guyles. Voyde hym fro the by the roote; Kep hym lowehe vnder foote; Hys powdry sondys, trede hem doun, The sondys off al Temptacyoun, (Whos noumbre no man may acounte.) Wych wyl nat suffre the to mounte Vp on the hyl, to reste a-loffte, They wyl lett√´ the so offte, Or thow mayst ha ful vyctorye. ‚ÄòAnd haue alway in memorye, Thys sondy hyl ys thy body, Wych letteth the (as most Enemy,) That thow mayst nat in vertu ryse. ‚ÄòBut alderfyrst thow must despyse Slouthe, as I shal the lere; Than by ese thow shalt conquere, Wyth Thampte, (in certeyn space) To clymbe aboue the hyl by grace. ‚ÄòAnd haue alway wel in mynde, That thow shalt thyn enemy ffynde Slowh & ful off slogardye, Longe a bedd√´ for to lye, ‚ÄòSlombrynge euere, & neclygent, And contrayre to thyn entent, Ay awaytynge (lyk as espye) To bryng√´ the in Iupartye. Truste hym nat! ne, for no chaunce, Have in hym noon affyaunce ffor no ffavour nor flatrye; ffor I dar pleynly certefye, Yiff thow obeye hym nyh or ferre, Than he wyl be-gynne a werre A-geyn[y]s the, most peryllous, Most dredful & contagyous, (Be yt be nyhte, outher be day) To disturble on thy way, Wyth al hys power he wyl ffonde. And thus thow mayst wel vnderstonde, To knowe & wyt√´ fynally Who ys thy mortal ennemy. ‚ÄòNow go thy way, for yt stant so, That I mot nedys fro the go; I may no lengre, on thy weye Ledyn the, nor mor conveye. I haue abyden longe ynowh: I muste, ffro the, gon hennys nough; ffor a gret while (to thyn entent) I haue holde a parlement Wyth the, & her-to ben thy guyde. ffarwel! for I may nat abyde.‚Äô The Pylgryme. ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I a-noon right tho, ‚ÄúCertys, yiff ye go me fro, I am but lost; recure ys noon, Al so sone as ye ar gon.‚Äù Grace Dieu. Quod grac√´ Dieu, ‚ÄòI wot that wel; But I wyl that thow knowe, & ffel, What I shal seyn the in substaunce. Som folk ha feyth, & gret ffyaunce In dyuers ffrendys; & off gret trust, Sette their hope & hertys lust ‚ÄòAs they sholde hem neuer ffaylle, Wych offte ful lytel may avaylle. They wene ful offte, in ther degre, By hem for to supportyd be, Yiff they hadde, in any place, Outher offendyd or do trespace. ‚ÄòBut towchyng thys, I wyl thow se, Her-in ne trust√´ nat in me, Yiff thow offende, nor do nat wel, I wyl sustene the neueradel, Nor supporte the nat ywys, To ffyn thow sholdest don amys, Nor ber the vp agen[y]s ryht. For off thyn eye, nor off thy syht, I wyl no tyme be seyn off the, But whan yt lyketh vn-to me, And whan yt ys to my plesaunce, Vp-on thy good√´ gouernaunce, Than, whan me lyst, I kome a-noon. ‚Äòffor, I haue a certeyn ston Wherthorgh (trewe as any byble,) I kan me makyn invysible Whan that me lyst, a-noon ryht, And hyden me out off thy siht, And shrowden me, bothe Est & west, Whan thow wenyst to han me best, fful ffer ffro the, in √°venture: And therfor, thus in me assure, Whan thow dost wel, I am present; And yiff thow erre in thyn entent, ffarwel, a-noon I am ago. And now I must√´ parte also, (Wherso thow be glad or lyht,) As for a while out off thy siht.‚Äô And ryght a-noon, as she hath sayd. God wot, I was ful evele apayd Off hyr departynge; in myn herte Yt mad√´ me ful sor√´ smerte; Me lyst nat lawh√´ neueradel, ffor me lykede no thyng wel Hyr departyng nor absence; They dyde to me so gret offence. & yet for-thy, yt ys no nay, fforth I wente vp-on my way Wych that I afor be-gan. And in my mynde a-noon yt ran, To calle mem√≥yre vn-to me, That she shold√´ redy be Tawayte vn-to me, & don hyr cure To brynge myn harneys & armure; And bad she sholde for-gete hem nouht: And affter me she hath hem brouht, So as I had lyst in my way, I fylle in any sodeyn ffray; And trew[e]ly (yt ys no drede) I hadde off hem inly gret nede; ffor I fond gret Encoumbrementys; By peryllous wey√®s & by wentys I hadde had gret aduersyte, And offte also in perel be, Hadde nat myn harneys & armure Don to me ful gret socour. Yet offt√´, thorgh my slouthe, allas, I stood in many peryllous caas; But yiff I hadde wel armyd be, I hadd√´ nat (in no degre) Suffryd so myche, yt ys no nay. Yiff thow me seke ther du√´ly, Thow shalt me fynden ay redy. ‚ÄòNow, on thy Iourne, forth the spede Syth to tarye thow hast no nede.‚Äô Y? pilgrime. The pylgrym: ‚ÄúDamysele,‚Äù a-noon quod I, ‚ÄúI merveyll√´ ful gretly Off your ffethres ffressh & shene, What they tokne or what they mene; And that ye ben endowned so Vp-on your leggys both√´ two; ffor, syth tyme that I was born, I sawh√´ neuere her-to-fforn Noon yffetheryd, saufflly only ye: ffor, by lyknesse, ye may fle Whan that ye lyst, hih & lowe; And ffayn ther-fore, I wold√´ knowe, (Yiff ye lyst to specefye) What your ffetherys sygnefye; And your endownyng, vp & doun, I wolde ther-off ha som resoun; And or ye any ferther go, Your name I wold√´ wyte also.‚Äù The ffetherede: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòwhan thow dost knowe The caus√´ pleynly (hih & lowe) Wheroff I serue, sothly in dede Thow shalt off me han ful gret drede.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúYe ben trewly (as semeth me) So ffressh and vnkouth for to se, Se lusty ek off port & chere, That no man myght√´ beyn to dere, Off yow to han possess√Øoun: And me semeth off resoun, (By lyklynesse, as I kan ffel,) A man myghte nat lou√´ to wel Your persone, by lyklyhede. And as touchynge any drede That men sholde han off you, certeyn, Me semeth swych dred wer but in veyn.‚Äù The ffetherede: ‚ÄòThow seyst fful soth, & ryght trewly: Who me vseth prudently, And nat outrageth in no wyse, But hym gou√©rneth lyk the wyse, Swych, fro pereyl may wel eskape. And trust her-on, (yt ys no jape,) My gouernaunce (who kan espye), Ther-in ys found√´ no ffolye; And yet off custom, at the laste, In gret√´ pereyll, ffolk I caste, (As yt ys fful offt√´ seyn) And longe or they may ryse ageyn. ‚ÄòAnd my name ys ek fful kouthe, ffor I am ycallyd ‚Äòyouthe‚Äô; I pass√´ bothe thorgh thynne & thykke, And I kan wynse ageyn the prykke, As wyld√´ coltys in Arras, Or as bayard out off the tras, Tyl I a lassh haue off the whyppe; ffor now I renne, & now I skyppe, ‚ÄòAnd now I lep√´ Iouy pe; Now I sterte, & now I ffle. I wrastle, & I caste the ston; I brek√´ bothen hegge & wal, And clymb√´ tre√´s oueral In gardyns wher the ffrut ys good. I wyl be ffethryd, & go ffle, And among, go sport√´ me; ‚ÄòPleye at the cloos, among, I shal, And somwhyle Rennyn at the bal Wyth a Staff mad lyk an hook; And I wyl han a kampyng crook; ffor I desyre, in my depos, ffor to han noon other croos. ‚ÄòAnd among, I wyl nat spare To hunte for hert, ffor buk & hare; And though that thow be euele apayd, I shal seyn trouthe, as semeth me: Yt wer merveyl thow sholdest the So symple a crafft on the to take, To mak√´ nattys, & vnmake; The wych√´ crafft (whan al ys souht) Ys so pore, yt wynneth nouht.‚Äù The nat-makere: ‚ÄòTouchyng my crafft, wych I vse, To the I may me thus excuse: Thogh yt be symple, & pore off name, Therfor thow sholdest me nat blame: Swych as I kan, swych I acheue: Thys, no cause me to repreue, Nor to rebuke off no ffolye. ‚ÄòYiff ye aduerten prudently, Euery man hath nat a fforge, Crownys off gold, in for to forge; Nor ffolkys all√´, yong nor old, Kan nat the crafft to chaung√´ gold; Nor alle may nat be Iowelerys: Ech crafft hath hys offycerys: Nor alle ffolk may nat noblys telle; Nor alle ffolk may nat Rubyes selle; ffor konnyng thanne wer off no prys, Yiff ech man were alych√´ wys. ‚ÄòLerne ek off me, thys sentence, Ther muste be a dyfference (Pleynly yiff thow lyst to knowe,) Off Estatys hih & lowe, And off crafftys ek also. ‚ÄòAnd tak also good heed herto, Yiff all ffolk in a Regioun Hadden On occupacioun In the Rychest crafft of alle, Dem√´ thanne what shold√´ falle: Thanne al ylyche (yiff thow tok hed) The ffoot as good as ys the hed;
