And her, O thyng I axe off the: What ys the caus√´ (ffer or ner) That a swerd burnysshed cler, Somwhyle rusteth, as thow mayst se, Leseth hys bryhtnesse & bewte?‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúTouchyng thyn askyng, in certeyn, Me to answere, yt wer but weyn; Thow hast thy sylff (who kan ffel,) The cause ytold, pleynly & wel.‚Äù The Natte-makere: ‚ÄòSo as a swerd (I dar expresse,) Yffadyd ys off hys bryhtnesse, And off hys clernesse ek also, Whan men take noon hed ther-to, But rusteth & ffareth al amys, Ryght so a man that ydel ys, & kan hym sylff nat occupye, (By resemblaunce thow mayst espye,) In-to hys sowle (thus I be-gynne) The rust off vyces or off synne Doth a-way (wyth-out√´ gesse) Off all√´ vertu the clernesse; But excercys√´ (in sentence) ‚ÄòAnd contynual dyllygence, Born vp wyth vertuous labour, Ys bet than any ffoorbysshour Ageyn the rust off ydelnesse, Off vertu to gyue perfyt clernesse.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúNow, gentyl ffrend,‚Äù a-noon quod I, ‚ÄúTel me thy nam√´ trew[√´]ly, Wych art so wys off answerynge: Tel on, & mak no mor taryynge.‚Äù The Natte-makere: ‚ÄòTo telle the trouth√´ verrayly, Yt befalleth comounly (As clerkys wryt√´, that be sad,) Whan a man ys ffebly clad, And outward hath noon √°pparence, Phylysophres (in ther sentence) And Ek poetys that wer wys, They seyn swych on ys off no prys Nor off no reputac√Øoun Affter the worldys oppynyoun. And thys comounly the language That thylk√´ ffolkys be most sage, And wysest holden (in certeyn), That be ffressh, & wel beseyn, And kan make hem syluen gay Wyth ryche fforewrys & array, And devyses most vnkouth, Swych ffolk, in euery manhys mouth, Be wysest holde in thys world here. ‚ÄòAnd ouermor, as ye shal lere, Thogh a man wer neuere so wys, And hadd√´ lernyd at Parys, Thys thryrty yer at scol√´ be In that noble vnyuersyte, And hadd√´ ful experyence Off euery wysdom & scyence, & koude exponen euery doute, And wer but porely clad wyth-oute, Men wold√´ deme most comounly ‚ÄòThat hys wysdom wer ffoly, And that he wer a fool at al By oypynyoun general: So they reherse in ther sentence; ffor wysdom now, & sapyence, Practyk off phylosofye, Off arsmetryk & gemetrye, Off Astron√≥mye & musyk, And experyence off physyk, Ys ffled now fro vnyuersytes, And dwelleth in borwes & cytes Wyth folk that wel arrayed be At the eye, as men may se. ‚ÄòAnd ffarwel konnyng, now euery day, Wher ther ys no ffressh array! Wyth-oute array, konnyng, farwel! Wherfor I merveylle neueradel Thogh thow me settyst at no prys, Nor thogh thow holdest me nat wys, By cause my ray ys al to-rent. And yet, by good avys√´ment, Yiff thow lok√´ wel aboute, I am he (yt ys no doute,) Who so lyst to taken hed,) That yiue to all√´ folk ther bred, Or shortly (ellys for to seye) They sholde ellys for hunger deye, Ne wer√´ I & my werchyng; Ye, bothe adam & hys off-spryng. Hadde I nat be, (yt ys no ffaylle,) What myghte the gret shyp avaylle Off Noe (in conclus√Øoun) Nor al hys generac√Øoun? ‚ÄòAnd, ffor to speke in general, I sustene & ber vp al, & yt ys I, ech hour & space, That makth the tym√´ shortly pace Wyth-oute anoy or p√©rturbaunce; ffor I am he, by r√©membraunce, Syth adam the Appyl heet, ‚ÄòWych wyth labour & wyth swet Haue you√´ ffood√´ & pasture To euery levyng cre√§ture, Bothe to best & ek to man, Syth tym√´ that the world be-gan Wher-off I am no thyng to blame. And my verray ryht√´ name Ys (wyth-oute mor sarmon) ‚ÄúLabour & Occupacioun.‚Äù ‚ÄòI rechch√´ nat, whan al ys do, Wych thow me calle off both√´ two; And folkys alle that stonde in grace, By me vn-to the cyte pace The ryht√´ way wyth-out√´ lak. And for that ffyrst to me thow spak, The ryht√´ way, th√© to lere, Off thys two wey√´s that ben here, And I ha told the myn avys, Now ches the beste, syth thow art wys.‚Äô The pylgrym: And than a-noon, as ye shal here, Whyl we spak togydre yffere, My body (for hys gret plesaunce) Gat hym wyth youth√´ √°cqueyntaunce, & both√´, voyded off dyscord, Wher yfalle off on accord. ‚ÄúAnd Yowthe (off wych aforn I sayde) Vn-to me thus gan abrayde: ‚ÄòYt wer syttynge (as semeth me) And accordynge to thy degre, To gon and getyn √°queyntaunce, And, to haue som dalyaunce, The bet thy sylff ffor to provyde Wyth hyr that syt on the lefft syde, Thylk√´ damysele, I mene, Which ys so goodly on to sene, And to hyr doctryne yiue som feyth. And thow mayst sen how that she leyth Vnder hyr armole, hyr on hond; And (yiff thow kanst wel vnderstond) ‚ÄòIn the tother hond (parde) A Gloue she halt, as thow mayst se. Go to hyre, & do thy cure; And I trowe, off aventure, She wyl the teche, & pleynly seyn The wey√´ wych ys most certeyn, Bet than thys cherl that sytteth here, Swart and owgly off hys chere, Wych ys a verray tormentour To putt√´ ffolkys to labour, And may to the no thyng avaylle, But vexyn the wyth gret travaylle.‚Äô And by hys consayl (off entente) Vn-to hyre a-noon I wente; And ffyrst, as me thouhte yt due, I gan hyr goodly to salue. And she, devoyde off al dysdeyne, Mekly saluede me ageyn. And alderfyrst (shortly to seye) Humblely I gan hyr preye That she wolde, off coortesysye, Govorne me also, & guye, Tech√´ me, & sey nat nay, In my vy√°ge the ryht√´ way, By wych pylgrym√´s euerychon To Ierusalem wer wont to gon.‚Äù The damysele: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod she, off cher benygne, ‚ÄòI ne knowe noon other sygne Nor other tookne, in thys pass√°ge, Off ffolk that gon on pylgrymage; But I knowe (be wel certeyn) Yiff I sh√°l the trouth√´ seyn, On hors, on foote, in general, Thys the wey√´ most royal, Callyd the kyng√´s hih√´ weye. And her-wyth-al, I dar wel seye Yt ys most esy off pass√°ge To ffolkys old & yong off age, Smothe & pleyn, (yt ys no nay,) ‚ÄòAnd most yvsyd nyht & day; And by thys ylk√´ sam√´ weye, Gladly ffolkys I conveye, Swych as lou√´ paramours, To ward the voode, to gadre fflours, Soote rosys & vyolettys, Ther-off to make hem chapel ettys, And other fflourys to her plesaunce. ‚ÄòAnd in thys weye I teche hem daunce; And also, ffor ther lady sake, Endyte lettrys, & songys make Vp-on the glad√´ somerys dayes, Balladys, Roundelays, vyrelayes. I teche hem ek, (lyk ther ententys,) To pleye on sondry Instrumentys, On harpe, lut, & on gyterne, And to revelle at tav√©rne, Wyth al merthe & mellodye, On rebube and on symphonye; To spend√´ al the day in ffablys, Pleye at the ches, pley at the tablys, At treygobet & tregetrye, In karyyng & in Iogolory: And to al swych maner play, Thys the verray ryht√´ way.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúTrew[√´]ly, to my plesaunce, ffor your noble dalyaunce I wolde (off good entenc√Øoun) Know√´ your condycyoun; Youre Name also, yiff that ye Lyst goodly to telle hem me.‚Äù The damysele: ‚ÄòYiff thow wylt abyde a throwe, My name and al, thow shalt wel knowe: I am a poopet, in sothnesse, Douhter to Dame Ydelnesse, Set her, by hyr ordynaunce. And al my joye & my plesaunce Ys, by hyr wyl that her me sette, ‚ÄòMy glovys streythly on to sette: I take off no-thyng ell√´s hed, But, offte a day, kombe myn hed, Prye ech hour in a merour,‚Äî God wot, that ys most my labour,‚Äî Wake a nyhtys, slepe a day, And specyally the haly day I studye among (thys the caas) In Elenches off ffallas, Out to ffynd√´ thyng√´s newe, To mak√´ ffablys sem√´ trewe; And, above al other thynges, On romauncys ffondyd on lesynges, Ther-in ys my studye most. ‚ÄòAnd I am ek, in euery cost, Paramour to thy body, Yt to cherysshe in al ffolye. And wherso that thow slepe or wake, Labour, I mak√´ the forsake; And by my wyl (ek in certeyne) Thow shalt dure no maner peyne, But lyon, sewen, & make a-vaunt, And muryely pleyen the Galawnt. ‚ÄòI make ffolk, vp-on ther hed, To were chaplettys off whyht & red, Pyke her nayll√´s, wernays take, And al travayll√´ to forsake, Studye ffor to ffynde off newe, Devyses mad off many an hewe, ffolk to make hem ffressh & gay, And hem dysguyse in ther array: Thys myn offys, yer by yere. ‚ÄòNow ches a-noon, whyl thow art here, Wych√´ wey√´ thow wylt take; And wherso that thow slepe or wake, Thow shalt lerne a thyng off me: Thys sam√´ weye wych thow dost se, Ys large & pleyn, esy to pace; The tother, streiht, & hard to trace, And ffew√´ ffolkys go ther-by: ‚ÄòThys, mor plesaunt & redy. Now, syth thow hast dyscrec√Øoun Mak thy sylff Elleccyoun.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúTrew[√´]ly,‚Äù quod I a-noon, ‚ÄúThys two wey√´s wer but on, Ne wer only (as ye may sen) Thys ylk√´ heegg that stant betwen. Wherfor I pray that ye nat lette, To tell√´ who the heggg her sette.‚Äù Ydelnesse: ‚ÄòTouchyng thys heg that stondeth here, Yt was maad (yiff thow lyst lere,) Off a gret turmenteresse Wych doth to ffolk fful gret dystresse; And she maketh pylgrym√´s alle, Penytence, hyr sylff to calle. Who hath wyth hyre Aqueyntaunce, Muste endur√´ gret penaunce: Hatfful she ys off cher & fface To alle that by thys wey√´ pace,‚Äî I mene, the weye that I am Inne;‚Äî But who that lyst ffro me to twynne, And the tother wey√´ take, I dar pleynly vndertake, On leg, on ffoot, on too & hele, He shal fful sharp√´ thornys ffele, Gret prykyng, I the ensure, And sharp, wyth-outen al mesure, ffor they be sharpe, & no-thyng soffte. ‚ÄòAnd thys lady kometh fful offte (I mene thys lady dame Penaunce Wyth whom I ha noon √°cqueyntaunce); To thys heg she kometh al day, Maketh yerdys, & goth hyr way, Besmys also, sotyl & queynte. And day nor nyht she doth nat ffeynte To make ay newe in hyr werkynge, Instrumentys ffor ch√°stysynge Off synn√´, by gret ordynaunce, ‚ÄòThys same lady, Dame Penaunce; And in hyr occupac√Øoun ffolk haue but smal affecc√Øoun. I ha the tolde off hyre to-fforn, Off instrumentys that she hath born, Off Bysme, off hamer, off thyng√´s mo.‚Äô And thanne I thouhte I wold√´ go By the path & by the weye By wych the man gan me conveye, That made the nattys in certeyn, Vnmade & made hem effte ageyn. And, lyk as tauht√´ me my guyde, I drewh toward the ryht√´ syde And in that wey√´ lyst nat tarye; But youthe a-noon, to me contr√°rye, fful besy was me ffor ta let; Seyde the tother way was bet, Mor√´ hawntyd, the pass√°ge, Off ffolk that gon on pylgrymage. And fforth the sam√´ weye I helde, Tyl that a-fforn me I be-held, Reysed on hihte, a lytel wal, Two posternys & a gat√´ smal; And mid the gaate a lady stood, That was both√´ ffayr & good, (I pray god, ffayr√´ mot hyr ffalle! And vertu moral men hyr calle. And she A-noon, off hyr goodnesse, Off bounte and off gentyllesse, (As she that lyst to be my guyde,) Bad, I sholde on the tother syde Declyn√´ nouther to nor ffro, But by the sam√´ gat√´ go Wher as she stood√´, lyu√´ ryht, And I conceyvede in my syht, And fful clerly gan dyscerne On owther party a posterne, And sawh that they were √©ncoumbrous To pass√´ by, & daungerous: Bothe I leffte (as was my ffaate), And lyn√´ ryht vn-to the gaate The weye I held, by hyr byddynge, Wher as she stood hyr sylff lenyng. The pylgrym: And lyst she ffounde in me som lak, Vn-to hyre ryht thus I spak: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I ‚ÄúI stonde in wher Touchynge thys wey√´s that ben her; I not off hem wych I shal holde.‚Äù And she to me fful goodly tolde And specyally gan charg√´ me, The fforeyn posternys ffor to ffle; [Vertu Moral] ‚ÄòAnd do thy power and thy myght To holde the wey√´ that goth ryht, The weye (I men√´) ryht as lyne, Wher I stonde, & nat declyne On nouther party, nyht nor day, Also ffer fforth as thow may.‚Äô She sayd ek, as I vnderstood, That ‚Äòhe ys an archer good Wych ffaylleth nat hym-sylff taquyte, Alway the mark√´ ffor to smyte; And no man blamen hym ne may, Thogh he hytte yt nat alway: So he do trewly hys deuer, Wyth hys arme to smyte yt ner In al hys best√´ ffeythfful wyse, Yt doth ynowh to hym suffyse That in hys drawyng he nat ffeyne. And therfor do thy besy peyne Aforn, thy sylff so to provyde, Teschewe the weyes that gon asyde; Hold the myd, in especyal. ‚Äòffor I am callyd ‚Äòvertu moral, Polytyk, & general‚Äô; And myn offyce her-wyth-al I contene (as clerkys shewes) Al the pathys to good√´ thewes, The ryht√´ way, & ther degres; ‚ÄòAnd yet I haue extremytes (Who kan looke on ech a syde,) The wych I wolde fro me devyde, As fferfforth as I kan or may Severyn hem, and caste a-way, ffor caus√´ they be vycyous In my syht, & ryht greuous. ‚Äòffor thyse extremytees, in soth, ffarn ryht as a kanker doth, I mene the werm (who lyst se) That ffreteth the hert√´ off a tre, And, wyth hys ffret & wyth hys rage, Doth to tymber gret damage. Yiff thylk√´ werm (yt ys no nay) Be nat the rather kut away And dysseveryd ffrom hys place, The tre so sore he wyl manace Vp to the cropp√´ fro the roote, That affterward ther ys no bote, As men may sen in many tres. ‚ÄòAnd semblaly thextremytes The posternys that be fforeyne, Wych that ben in noumbre tweyne, I haue hem fro me put a-way Wyth-out√´ ffauor or delay, Off entent that, in thys place, Pylgrym√´s noon shal by hem pace, That wyl ouer the gret√´ see To Ierusalem the cyte; ffor yiff they wente by that passage, Yt wer pereyl & gret damage.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dam√´, wyth your reuerence, I wold√´ se som evydence, Yiff yt wer possyble, me to knowe By som exaumple (hih or lowe,) How thys vyces (som or alle,) Lyk to kanker, ye hem calle.‚Äù Vertu moral: ‚ÄòSemblably as dyuers tres, Kankres han in ther degres, Ryht so vertues (dout√´les) Han dyuers extremytes, Kankres at outher ende, That ffrete on hem wherso they wende. ‚ÄòLo, her, Exaumple in especyal! fforce ys a vertu Cardynal, The wych hath a kanker double, On outher party hym to trowble, To dystroye hym nyht & day Yiff they ne be nat kut a-way Wonder peryllous to deuyse; The ton ys callyd ‚ÄòCowardyse‚Äô; The tother (yiff I shal expresse) Ycallyd ys ‚ÄòFoolhardynesse,‚Äô Wych wyth fforce may nat abyde, They be so ffer set out asyde, ffer ffro fforce at two posternys. But fforce so wysly hym gouernys That he hath no thyng a-doo Wyth noon of thys wermys two; ffor in myd place (as I yow tolde) fforce, off custom doth hym holde. ‚ÄòA-nother exaumple ye may se Touchynge Lyberalyte, Wych hath also (who kan dyscerne) Set ffer ffrom hym at a posterne The ffals√´ werm off coveytyse, Wych ys ycallyd Auaryse. ‚ÄòThe tother Kanker (who lyst se) Ys callyd Prodygalyte; And a-twen thys wermys tweyne, Mydd√´ place (ffor mor certeyne) Halt hym Lyberalyte. Go, red Ethikes, wher thow shalt se (Whan-so-euere that thow ha space) Vertu set ay in myd place, Wher as they most clerly shyne, And many kankres wych on hem myne. ‚ÄòBut good√´ pylgrymes that ha grace, Alway by the myddys pace; Exaumple off whom b[y] nyht & day Hold alway the men√´ way. Lat moral vertu be thy guyde; ffle posternys that stonde a side, By whos pereyl (who taketh hede) Many a pylgrym hath be ded. ‚ÄòAnd whyl that youth√´ (herkne me,) ffressh and lusty abyt wyth the, Yiff the to vertu ech hour and space; ffor, whan youthe a-way doth pace Wyth-out√´ vertu (trust√´ me,) Yt ys ful hard (who that kan se,) Vertu to wynne, whan youthe ys gon. Who that in youthe lyst lern√´ noon, ffor custoom take in tendre age, (As seyn thys old√´ ffolkys sage,) Wyth-out√´ labour (thys no nay,) Ys ful hard to parte away.‚Äô The pylgrym. ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúso mot I the, I wend√´ sykerly ta be In the ryht√´ weye ywys; But, certys, I ha gon amys, ffor I ha chose (and thus yt stood) Two euele wey√´s ffor on good: I not what yt may sygnefye, That I thus erre thorgh my ffolye.‚Äù Vertu moral: ‚ÄòHa no merveyl in thy siht; flor ther ys wey√´ noon so ryht That yt ne fforketh out asyde By many pathys that yt devyde, Wych caus√´ ffolkys euere among, fful offt√´ syth√´s to go wrong. ‚ÄòAnd many on that thow dost sen, Ys nat ther-for A Geometryen Wyth-In a compas (ha thys in mynde) Thogh he konne out the centre fynde; ‚Äòffor verrayly (who kan devyse) Yt ys founde out but in O wyse; Yet ffolkys ffayll√´ dyuersly To ffynde yt out by geometry. An Archer eke, in thynne and thykke, Faylleth so?tyme off the prykke. Wh√´rfore, to ffynde the ryht√´ weye, Yt ys good, to god to preye. Yet in prayere, bothe day & night, The wey√´ goth nat alway ryht, ffor, bothe in psalmys & in vers Ther ben pathys fful dyuers, And also ek in Orysouns, Out forkyd by entenc√Øouns; As thus: who that kan aduerte: The mouth dyuerseth ffro the herte; But herte and mouth be bothen on: By dyuers pathys, in soth, they gon; And, (pleynly ffor to specefye,) Somme prey√´, by ypocrysye, Off the peple to be seyn, And ther prayer ys but in veyn; Somme also prey√´ ffor Rychesse, To wynn√´ worshepe & noblesse, Tave encres & in worldly glorye, And, ffor thyng√´s transytorye, Worldly honour ffor to wynne, Prayer ek mad in dedly synne, ffor cruelte or ffor vengaunce, Or, to brynge men to meschaunce: Swych prayer hath no deuocyoun; Yt ys nat worth a smal botoun, ‚ÄòAl thyse ar pathys fforkyd wrong To make pylgrym√´s eueramong To gon Amys in ther pass√°ge. ‚ÄòAnd syth thow gost on pylgrymage, Evere enquer√´, nyht and day, Tyl thow ha founde the ryht√´ way; Lat, in thyn askyng, be no slouthe Tyl thow be brouht vn-to the trouthe.‚Äô And so I gan to hyre doctryne Myn erys besyly enclyne, fful wel avysyng me ryht tho, By wych posterne I shold√´ go. And whyl I gan be-thynk√´ me, To-for my fface I dyd√´ se A body vp on a cross dystreyned, And, as me thouht√´, gretly peyned, To-fforn, a syde, and at the bak. And to the body a spyryt spak, The body crossyd lyk a roode, The spyryt in the wey√´ stood; The body ek (as thouht√´ me,) Myd the hegh, hong on a tre, Hys wyttys crossyd, as ye shal here, Mouth, handys, Eye & Ere; The nase also, for smellyng, Was crossyd ek, to my semyng. And on the spyryt my look I layde, And to hym ryht thus I sayde: The pylgrym: ‚ÄúI pray the, ffrend, tel me A-noon, Or we any ferther gon, What causeth the to stonden here: I am abaysshyd off thy chere, But thow (lyk myn affecc√Øoun) Make a declarac√Øoun,‚Äù Mortyfycacioun off the body: ‚ÄòI am a pylgrym (soth to seye,) That wolde ha take the sam√´ weye fful yore agon, ne hadd√´ be Thys lord that hangeth vp on the tre: ffro the weye on the tother syde He brouht√´ me, and was my guyde; Me made (ther ys no mor to seye,) Vn-to hys lust ffully tobeye, And Tacomplysshe hys byddyng Wyth-oute gruchchyng in euery thyng. ‚ÄòBut trowly in thys passage ‚ÄòI hadde ffound√´ gret damage, Hadde nat the grace off god ybe; And therfor, ffor taveng√´ me, I ha the maner wel devysed, Wherby that he ys her chastysed, Wyth ffauour and the gouernaunce Off a lady callyd Penaunce, Wych, wyth hyr hamer (as thow mayst se,) Smot the nayles in-to the tre, Euene as I bad hyr do. ‚ÄòAnd thanne A-noon he was ago: In-to thys heg he took the weye, And thus I made hym to obeye To my plesaunce in euery thyng, So that no mater off wynsyng Ys ffounde in hym in fflessh nor bon, (To seke hys membrys euerychon,) Gruchchyng, nor rebell√Øoun, Nor no contradicc√Øoun.‚Äô The pylgrym: Thanne in the sylu√´ sam√´ place He gan A-noon to tourne hys face, And sayde (as ye shal here and se) To the body vp on the Tre: Mortyfycacioun off the body: ‚ÄòHastow wel herd what I ha sayd? Tel on! artow nat wel apayd Me tobey√´ wylfully (As Resoun axeth skylfully) Whan so that me lyst comaunde? Answere anoon to my demaunde!‚Äô The body answereth: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod the body tho, ‚ÄòAlgat√´ now yt standeth so, I must√´, off necessyte Yow obey√´, mawgre me. But yiff I myght√´ (thys no Iape,) ffrom your boundys wel eskape, In no thyng (shortly ffor to seye,) To yow I wolde no mor obeye.‚Äô The spyryt: Than quod the spyryt, ‚Äòsyth yt ys so, I shal the telle what I wyl do: To kepe me (both√´ ffer & ner) ffrom al peryl & al daunger That thow woldest don to me: Thow shalt be stylle vp on thys Tre Tyl thow, by ffeythful obeysaunce, Be mek & humble to my plesaunce. ‚ÄòYet shaltow nat ay her abyde; ffor I shal gon, & be thy guyde; And thow shalt (wyth-out√´ lak) Wyth a croos vp-on thy bak, Wyth spyryt off humylyte, ffolwe, & bern yt affter me, Off hool entent, in al vertu, That thow mayst sw√´n cryst ihesu, Wych in hys gospel byt & seyth, (To whom men musten yiven ffeyth,) ‚ÄòHe ys nat worthy (thus seyth he) Nor hable for to ffolwe me, The wych, vp on hys shuldere, Lyst, off dysdeyn, no croos to bere.‚Äô He bar yt ffyrst hym sylff, certeyn, Wyth-out√´ gruchchyng or dysdeyn To shewe exaumple & sygne also, That affter hym we shold√´ go Crossyd off entenc√Øoun, Remembrynge on hys passioun.‚Äô The pylgrym to the spyryt: To the spyryt tho quod I: ‚ÄúTel and declar√´ ffeythfully, What nedede yt so many place To crossen hym in hed & fface? I pray the, tech√´ me A-noon, Or we any fferther gon.‚Äù Mortyfycacioun off the body: ‚ÄòYiff thow kanst vnderstond√´ wel, To me was youen a castel Whan I kam ffyrst to thys contre, ‚ÄòOff entent I shold√´ be Euere ther-in, & nat gon oute, Te kepe me sur ffro euery doute Whyl that I a pylgrym were, That enmy noon me shold√´ dere By noon assaut, vp-on no syde, Yiff I koude wysly provyde ffor my sylff on euery part ffro shot off quarel, or cast off dart, Or ffro shetyng off croos bowes, Outher at wyketys or wyndowys Ylefft Open reklesly, Off neclygence or ffooly, And be nat dyffencyd wel Wyth barrys off yren nor off stel, Nor yclosyd by good devys, Overthwertyd wyth no latys; ffor wych, myn Enmyes many tyme, (Bothe at eve and ek at prime) Whan they open haue hem ffounde, They han me hurt wyth many a wonde, The wych fful sor√´ doth me greue. ‚ÄòBut, off entent me to releue, I haue ordeyned (by gret avys) Barrys off yren & latys, The ffenestrallys to Amende In cross wyse, me to dyffende. ‚ÄòAnd ech pylgrym, in thys world here, Hadd√´ ned√´ ffor to lere The fenestrallys off hys body, ffor to crosse hem myghtyly, And hem to kepe in sur√´te. ‚ÄòAnd no dyffence so good maybe, As in croos wyse (yiff they be wys) To close ther wyndowes wyth latys, In remembraunce (ffor ther goode) Off hym that heng vp on A roode. ‚ÄòAnd, to dyffende vs ffro daunger Lat vs maken a baner Off the croos, ffor our dyffence ‚ÄòAgeyn the dredful vyolence And assaut off our enmyes. ‚ÄòAnd at ech wyket, ffor Espyes At ffenestrallys & at cornerys, Lat be hangen out banerys Off the croos, and put hem oute, Our Enmyes to sette in doute; ffor yt ys a kouth√´ thyng, Men drede the baner off a kyng; As yt ys ffyguryd wonder wel In the book off Ezechyel, The .ix. capytle (who taketh hede), Wher openly ye may rede That, by the tookne off Tav, The sygne was off so gret vertu, That they that hadde yt (yt ys no drede) Wel enprented in ther fforhed, By the vertu (yt ys no jape) ffro the deth they dyde Eskape: They wer dyffencyd by thylke sygne, That no whyht myghte ageyn hem malygne. ‚ÄòAnd, ffor to kep√´ thys castel, I forget√´ neueradel To be mor myghty by vertu, To marke my wyndow√´s wyth Tav, The wyndowes off my wyttys ffyue, Ageyn my ffoomen ffor to stryue, That my ffoomen spyrytual Entre nat by no ffenestrall. ‚ÄòNow, as thow lyst me to comaunde, I haue answeryd to thy demaunde; And my name (in conclus√Øoun) Ys callyd Mortificacioun Off the fflessh, or ch√°stysyng, Oppression, or ellys dawntyng. ‚ÄòChes now, off thys namys alle, By wych th√°t thow wylt me calle; And god I praye, wyth al myn herte, To graunt√´ me I may aduerte, ffor wysdom or ffor ffolye, Euere that I may yt mortefye.‚Äô Thanne he made no mor delay, But went√´ fforth vp-on hys way; The body affter hym gan gon, And bar hys croos alway in on, And was with hym ay Crucyffyed. And whan I hadde al thys espyed, In myn herte I was full wo, That I myght√´ nat do so As off hem I do reporte; And gretly gan me dyscomforte; The pylgrym dysconfortyd. And, ffor thys vnkouth woful caas, fful offt√´ sythe I seyde ‚Äòallas‚Äô Vn-to my sylff, in c√≥mpleynynge, Wepte, and gan myn hondys wrynge; And, in my dedly mortal wo, Vn-to my sylff I seyd√´ tho: ‚ÄúAl that thow wendyst ha be toward, Ys but a passage that goth bakward. Thow gost nat as thow sholdest do.‚Äù And to my body I seyde also: ‚ÄúAllas! why naddestow ybe Crucefyed vp on a tre? Crossyd thy-syllf also be-tymes, To ha go fforth wyth pylgrymes On pylgrymage? allas the whyle! Thy gret√´ slouthe wyl me be-guyle, And don to me fful gret offence Thorgh thy gret√´ neclygence, Wych, yiff I hadde aforn espyed, Thow sholdest ha be crucefyed (Wyth-out√´ mercy or pyte) Vn-to the deth vp-on A tre, And born a croos vp-on thy bak.‚Äù And whyl that I thus to hym spak, Constreyned wyth fful gret dystresse, Myd off al myn hevynesse, Sodeynly (as ye shal here) I sawh Grac√´ dieu appere, The wych, in ful goodly wyse Bad me that I sholde aryse; Sayd√´ to me, off hyr grace, ‚ÄòHer ys noon abydyng place ffor to soiourne (yt ys no drede); And also (yiff thow lyst take hede,) Thow hast clerly had a syht That thys pylgrym goth most right, And most√´ dydd hym-sylff avaunce Thet on hys fflessh√´ tooke vengaunce, I mene hym (yiff thow ha mynde) The wych vp-on hys bak behynde Bar hys croos, to do penaunce. But thow, in al thy gouernaunce, Art verray slowh, as I wel knowe, That syttest at the erth√´ lowe, And lyst no fferther fforth to gon.‚Äô To whom I answerd√´ a-noon, Sayde, in al myn hevynesse, That yt was ffor ffebylnesse, ‚ÄúI was nat off my wyl at large, Nor strong to ber so gret a charge As the pylgrym off whom we spak, Wych bar hys croos vp-on hys bak.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòLefft vp thyn eye, & look√´ wel! Sestow nat,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòa whel Large and round, & off gret myght?‚Äô And I a-noon lefft vp my syht, And sawh a whel (yt ys no doute) By vyolenc√´ tourne aboute Contynuelly to-ffor my fface, Myd the weye I shold√´ pace. The pylgrym: And I answerde, touchyng thys whel, ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚ÄúI se yt wel.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòWel,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthan tak good hed ‚ÄòIn fforthryng off thyn own√´ spede. Thys whel ys (I the ensure) A lyknesse and A ffygure, And pleynly (yiff I shal nat tarye) Vn-to the an exaumplarye, The to gouerne in thy vy√°ge, Yiff thow wylt in thy pylgrymage Be wel exspleyted (in certeyn), And ellys thy labour ys in veyn, Lesynge thy travayll euerydel. ‚ÄòTak hed,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòhow in thys whel Ther ys wyth-inne (yiff thow kanst se) A-nother off lasse quantyte, Tornynge contrayre (by hys syyt) To-ward the party opposyyt; And off tymber, wrouht fful clene, Hath .iiij. spookys yt to sustene, Set vp-on an Extre large, Off the sweygh to bere the charge.‚Äô And sothly (as I koude espye) Hadd√´ nat ben A Boterflye Ther-on tournyng round aboute, I wolde ha dempte (wyth-out√´ doute) Tournyng ech wyth-Innen other, That yt hadd√´ be noon other But the sam√´ sylu√´ whel Wych whylom Ezechyel Sawh in hys avys√Øoun, As hooly wryt maketh mencioun. The pylgrym: And off thys whel (pleynly to lere), Off Grace dieu I gan enquere, That she wolde (in conclus√Øoun,) Make a declarac√Øoun. Grace dieu: Quod grac√´ dieu to me Anoon, ‚ÄòYiff thow remembre, nat yore agon, How thow off god (I the ensure) Art thymage and creature.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúCertys,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúin substaunce, I ha thys wel in r√©membraunce.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòConceyue,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòthan, in thy syht, Yt muste ffolue, off verray ryht, Syth thow haddest, in all√´ thyng, Off hym orygynal begynnyng, And were off hym (yiff yt be souht) In euery party maad & wrouht, To hym, off verray ryht certeyn, Thow must resorte & tourne ageyn, As by mevyng natural, Ageyn to thyn orygynal. ‚ÄòTak exaumple pleyn & cler: As by mevyng circuler In hys tournyng by compasse Ageyn resorteth to hys place That he kam ffro whan he be-gan, How ffer aboute that he ran; And Trewly, in no mocyoun Ys noon so gret perfecc√Øoun As off a spyryt hym to releue, Ageyn the body ffor to meue; The wych (who lok√´ verrayly) Ys to the spyryt most enmy; Wych euere ys bysy, day be day, To taryen hym vp-on hys way, And (I dar wel afferme thys) Meketh hym offte to gon amys. And thogh thow go nat alway wel Yet dyscounforte the neueradel; Tak euere hed, yong and old, Off thexaumple I ha the told; Vp-on wych, yiff thow wylt dwelle, Mor clerly I shal the telle. ‚ÄòThys sayde whel (who kan espye) That I off spak, doth sygnefye Lust off the body, in hys mevyng, Wych clerkys calle (in ther wrytyng And name yt) Sensualyte; ‚ÄòThe wych wyl nat brydled be, But ffroward euere in hys entent, Mevyng toward the occydent, Evere in on, bothe day & nyht, Wyth swych a swegh & swych a myght That, wher the spyryt gruchche or mourne, He maketh hym offt√´ to retourne Wyth hym ageyn by vyolence, Mawgre al hys r√©systence, Al-thogh the spyryt (in hys entent) Meueth toward the oryent, Wych thenys kam. & yiff he sholde Thyder ageyn, fful ffayn he wolde: Toward the Est, in all√´ thyng, He travaylleth in hys mevyng Wych (be my red) shal neuere tarye, But labour, & be contrarye To the mevyng off the body, And contynue vertuously Bexaumple (as I dyde specefye To the,) off the boterflye, Wych ay ffro the occident Tourneth toward the orient, In hys labour hym to quyte, Tyl he by vertu, lyte and lyte, So longe ageyn the whel doth go, Tyl the marke that he kam ffro, Wyth gret labour he may atteyne. ‚ÄòAnd evene lych (in certeyne) The plan√©tys all√´ seuene Holde her cours in the heuene, Wych trewly, in ther mevynges, Han fful many gret lettynges By sondry retardac√Øouns, And be contrayre mocyouns, Or they may (yt ys no doute) Ther cyrcuyt go round aboute; And yet ther wyl and ther entent Ys ay to-ward the oryent ffro when they kam, (yt ys no fable); ‚ÄòAnd thyderward they be meveable, To thylk√´ poynt to kome ageyn, ffro wych they meuede ffyrst certeyn. Off ther cours, thys thentent; But the heuene and the ffyrmament Wych clerkys calle (yiff ye lyst se) In latyn Celum mobile, Contrayre ffro the Oryent, Draweth hem to the occident Wyth hys sweygh (yt ys no nay,) And taryeth hem mor in A day Than they be mevyng cyrculer May recuryn in A yer Toward the Est in ther mevyng. ‚ÄòAnd yet they haue mor lettyng, (Who the verray trouth√´ wyste,) ffor, whan they travaylle to resyste To the heuene callyd ‚Äòmobyle‚Äô In the Epicicles whan they be, They make hem retrogradyent, And cause hem in the ffyrmament Ther tabyd√´ stacionarye, Out off ther cours ordynarye, And sette hem in the excentrykes, Wher thay be callyd Erratykes. Retournyng nat (shortly to ryme,) But by processe off long tyme. ‚ÄòAnd sythe, thys bodyes celestyal, In ther mevyng natural, Ben let thus in ther mocyouns, And han swych retardacyouns To ben hyndred in ther labour, Or they may han ful recour To the place they kam ffyrst fro; Merveylle nat thogh yt be so That thow be let in thy vyage, And Encoumbryd, in thy passage, Off Retardac√Øouns that falle, Syth ‚ÄòMycrocosme,‚Äô men the calle; And microcosme ys a word Wych clerkys calle ‚Äòthe lass√´ world.‚Äô And in thy way, haue in mynde; Epicicles thow shalt ffynde, ‚ÄòOff Infortunyes fful dyuers, Off sodeyn caas, fful peruers; ffor thy lyff (yt ys no doute,) Ys lyk a cercle that goth aboute, Round and swyfft as any thouht, Wych in hys course ne cesset nouht Yiff he go ryht, and wel compace Tyl he kome to hys restyng place, Wych ys in god, yiff he wel go Hys own√´ place wych he kam ffro. But yet, in al hys mocyoun, He hath noon Exempc√Øoun; ffor Epicicles (who hath reward) Make the offt√´ go bakward In thy cours, th√® to tarye, And to make th√® stacyonarye, Excentryked, day be day, To make th√® gon out off the way Westward, vn-to the occident; Whan thow sholdest gon to thoryent, fful offt√´ sythe thow gost abak. ‚ÄòAnd the planetys that I off spak, Also ek the Boterflye, Vn-to th√® Exemplefye To don thy labour, and nat ffeyne, And myghtyly thy sylff to peyne In thy mevyng, that thow nat be Ylet by sensualyte, Wych on thy way doth gret greuaunce, But yiff thow haue pers√©ueraunce. ‚ÄòYet in thy cours be alway strong: By processe off tym√´ long, Thow shalt retourne ageyn by grace Vn-to thyn own√´ du√´ place, Reste in god, and ther abyde. ‚ÄòThogh that thow be set asyde, Thyder to atteyn√´ soone, ‚ÄòTak exaumple by the moone, How he ys let ek in hys way, Somtyme the spac√´ off A day; But by hys labour (in certeyn) He recureth yt ageyn, Sothly with-Inne A moneth space To resort√´ to hys place. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow lyst tak hed her-to, The sonne recureth ek also, By his mevyng cyrculer, Loos off a day with-Inne A yer. ‚ÄòSatourne, that syt so hyh and ffer, And the planete Iubyter, They tak√´ pacyenly alway; Thogh they be let som tyme a day, They dysconforte hem neueradel, ffor they recure ageyn fful wel (By pacy√©nce and √°bydyng) Al that they suffre in ther mevyng; Ther naturel cours (I yow ensure) Pacyently they muste endure; Yt nolde avaylle hem to be wroth; ffor Satourn, aboute hys cours he goth In Thrytty yer, and lass√´ nouht; And Iubiter (yiff yt be souht), By hys mevyng cyrculer, Hys cours parformeth in xij yer; They muste ha ther-to so gret space Or they resort√´ to ther place.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame, with your grace and pes, To me yt semeth dout√´les, My labour may me nat avaylle; I do but les√´ my travaylle: Los off a day, lyk as ye seen, I may nat recure ageyn; I vnderstond√´, ffer nor ner, Almost the space off thrytty yer. Allas! I am to ffer be-hynde: What conforte thann√´ sholde I ffynde, ‚ÄúSo gret labour to endure, My place ageyn ffor to recure. Thogh day be day (in certeyne) I dyd√´ dyllygence and peyne ffor to resorte, yt wyl nat be; The cours off sensualyte, To my desyr ys so ffroward, To mak√´ me to go bakward, That by reuoluc√Øoun My tyme I lese, and my sesoun; ffor, the mor I me constreyne To do my labour and my peyne, The mor to me she ys contrayre, In my Iourne me to tarye; And trewly I kan nat espye What al thys doth sygnefye.‚Äù Grace dieu: Quod grac√´ dieu fful sobyrly, ‚ÄòI speke nat off a day only, But in an hour (yiff thow kanst se) Yt may happ√´ so to be, How that A man in A moment May slen hym sylff, off entent Or casuely, on se or lond, Lese a membre, ffoot or hond, Wych he shal, peraventure, In thrytty yer, nat recure Ageyn, so myght√´ ben the cas, To refourme yt as yt was. ‚ÄòAnd semblably to be-guynne, Yiff thow ha don a dedly synne. Wheroff the strook the soul√´ sleyth, And offte ys cause off cruel deth; ffor swerd ys noon, nor sper√´, founde, So peryllous to mayme and wonde As dedly synne, (to reknen al,) The wych ycallyd ys ‚Äòmortal‚Äô, Be-cause hys hurtys ffynally Ben in effect verray dedly. ‚ÄòAnd yiff thow sle thy-syluen so ‚ÄòWith dedly synne, as somm√´ do, And myghtest nat in Thrytty yer Ben hool and sownd, but stonde in wher Touchyng thy sauac√Øoun, Yet, as to myn oppynyoun, Thow sholdest nat thy sylff dyspeyre, Thy mortal syknesse to apeyre, Nor thy syluen dysconforte, But inwardly th√® Reconforte, And specialy in O thyng Thanke ihesu, that blyssyd kyng Lyst suffre deth√´ ffor thy sake, Thy deedly wondys, hool to make; With-oute whos deth√´, I ensure, Thow myghtest nat to lyff recure, Nor, thy gret√´ loos (certeyn), With-oute hys deth√´ wynne ageyn; ffor hys hooly pass√Øoun Ys salue and fful sauac√Øoun To ffolk that haven in constaunce Off her synn√´s r√©pentaunce; ffor penaunce ys so vertuous And acceptable to cryst ihesus, That who that doth yt hertyly, Off hys synnes hath remedy.‚Äô The pylgrym: To grac√´ dieu quod I ryht tho, ‚ÄúMa dame, in soth yt stondeth so, Your exaumples by rehersaylle May to me fful lyte avaylle, ffor they be nat (who look√´ wel) Vn-to purpos neueradel. ‚Äúffor the planetys hih in heuene, In ther mevyng, all√´ seuene, How so they in her cours be let, Yet ther Termys ben yset, And ther boundys, (in certeyn,) What tyme they shal resorte ageyn, By terme and lymytac√Øoun, With-oute any transgress√Øoun; ‚ÄúOff ther tyme they may nat erre, As yt ys set, nyh nor fferre, But that they shal, at certeyn space, Retourn√´ to her du√´ place, At ther tyme, whan-euere yt be. ‚ÄúBut yt stant nat so with me, No thyng at al, off my retour; And caus√´ why, ffor myn Errour Hath no lymytac√Øouns; ffor I, thorgh my transgress√Øouns, So long tyme ther-in soiourne, That I shal neuere ageyn Retourne To entre the place that I kam ffro. ‚ÄúTouchynge the boterflye also, Therby, to myn oppynyoun, I ha noon informac√Øoun As off hys mevyng on the whel; ffor, at hys lust, (who lok√´ wel) He may go slowh, he may go lyht, He hath .iiij. wyng√´s ffor the fflyht; And whan he seth yt may avaylle, He may chese, in hys travaylle, At hys lust, abyde and reste By good leyser, ffor the beste: Al thys consydred prudently, I dar wel seyn, so may nat I.‚Äù Grace dieu: ‚ÄòMyn exaumples, trewly,‚Äô quod she, ‚ÄòMay to purpos taken be, Yiff thow aduert√´ wel ther-to; ffor, set thys cas,‚Äîthat yt be so That thys planetys, in her mevyng, May nat erre no maner thyng, Nouther ffaylle, but in certeyn To ther places retourne ageyn ffro whenys they kam, On and alle; Yet somme off hem, I sey, may ffalle As yt be-ffyl, the trouth√´ wyst, Whan seyn Iohan the ewangelyst Sawh, among the sterrys alle, ‚ÄòHow On ffrom heuene dyd√´ ffalle‚Äî Lyk a brond off ffyr with levene‚Äî Doun to the Erthe ffro the heuene; The wych√´ sterre, I dar wel seyn, Retournede neuere yet ageyn Thyder ffro whens he dyd√´ ffalle; And ‚ÄòAbsinthium‚Äô men hym calle, Be caus√´ he doth sygnefye, Thorgh hys pryde and ffals envye, The bryhte aungel that ffel so ffer,‚Äî I mene the Aungel Lucyfer‚Äî ffro the heuene in-to dyrknesse; And he hath ek mor bytternesse Than any woormood growyng here. And, Trewly, yiff thow lyst lere, That he whylom (thus stood the caas,) Bryhter than any sterr√´ was: Truste me wel, and be certeyn That he shal neuere Retourne ageyn To the place that he kam ffro. ‚ÄòBut off th√®, yt stant nat so; And ffyrst, by thys exaumple layd To conferme that I ha sayd: Thogh thow a-mong, in thyn entent, ffalle doun ffro the ffyrmament Off verray ffeyth, doun ffro so fer With the Angel lucyfer, And thy ffal and thy soiourn Were with-out√´ mor retourn, That thow sholdest ay and euere In thyn errour so pers√©uere, And woldest nat thy sylff avaunce, Th√® tamende by r√©pentaunce, Than, thorgh thyn erroure and ffolye, Thow stoode in gret Iupartye To kome ageyn to thyn degre. ‚ÄòBut yiff thow woldest amende the, And off herte and hool entente Resorte ageyn, and th√® repente Off al that euere thow hast mysdo, ‚ÄòThow sholdest neuere haue erryd so, But that thow sholdest (trust√´ me) fful wel ageyn receyved be; And with al thys, only by grace, Restoryd to thy ffyrst√´ place: Ther-to thow sholdest ha no let, Thy terme, thy boundys, ben so set, And markys ffor thy savacyoun Only by crystys pass√Øoun: Truste me wel, and thus yt ys, They wyl nat suffre the gon Amys, Whyl thow th√® holdest by resoun Wyth-Inne thy lymytac√Øoun, Nat to Erryn, nyh nor ffer; But so ne may nat lucyfer, ffor he muste abyde and dwelle With-oute Retourn√´, styll in helle; He may haue noon other graunt. And thys Exaumple ys suffysaunt Off the planetys told off me, In thy pass√°ge tenformen the. ‚ÄòAnd fferther-mor√´, the to guye Touchynge also the boterflye, Off wych Exaumple, in thyn Avys, Thow settyst ther-off but lytel prys; But yiff thy wyt, off Resoun seth, The .iiij. wynges with wych he ffleth, And hys ffeet ek (tak hed ther-to) Make hym on the whel to go At leyser, hym sylff to spede. By wych exaumple (as I rede) Thow shalt hym folwe in sondry wyse; And ffyrst off all√´, the avyse How thys whel hath (yt ys no doute,) .iiij. spokys strechchyd oute, Vp-on wych, ffor thy beste, Thow mayst wel thyn syluen reste, And by es√´, soffte and soffte Clymben tyl thow kome aloffte. ‚ÄòThys spokys .iiij. off most vertu ‚ÄòBen in the croos off cryst ihesu, The wych√´ ben yset fful wel With-Inne in the myddel whel, Off wych√´, with hys eyen bryhte, Ezechiel hadde a syhte: Hys prophesy√´ doth vs lere, To hym a whel ther dyde appere, Wych hym thouhte (in sondry placys) By semyng hadd√´ .iiij. ffacys, ffor to shewyn in ffygure Auctorysed by scrypture (Yiff thow lyst to haue in mynde) .iiij. helpys thow mayst fynde In crystys cros, (yiff thow take hede,) In thy Iourn√® th√® to spede; Wych .iiij. shal th√® solace, Make th√® to thy ffyrst√´ place ffor to retourne the wey√´-ryht. ‚ÄòAs longe as thow hast a syht To .iiij. partyes off crystis cros, Ne drede the neuere off no los, Nor off hyndryng in thy vyage. And looke, in thy pylgrymage, Wher-so-euere thow repayre, Ther-off to take thyn exaumplayre, ffor thow mayst no bettre do.‚Äô And whan she hadd√´ sayd me so, Thys Grac√´ dieu, affter a-noon, ffarwel, fro me, she was a-gon Al sodeynly out off my syht. But thanne, off cher fful glad and lyht, Youthe And with hyr ffressh√´ ffethrys ffayre, Youth√´ gan to me repayre, And to me sayde in hyr manere: ‚ÄòThow art a ffool! what dostow here? Tak good hed to my sentence! Thow art mad, to yive credence, To leue and herknen euerytale Or syngyng off the nyhtyngale; ‚ÄòTher-in ys no melody, Whos song ys euere ‚ÄòOccy, occy,‚Äô Wych ys to seyne, whan she hath do, ‚ÄúGo sle thy sylff!‚Äù she meneth so. Leff al thys thyng, and go with me; ffor, thys weye wych thow dost se, Ys penyble and √©ncombrous, Dredful also, and envyous; Thy myght, thy power, ben ago; Thy body ys wery ek also; The weye wyl mak√´ the to tarye, ffor yt ys ffroward and contr√°rye, And ffer also ffro thyn entente; And I ther-to wyl nat assente. ‚ÄòAnd in fforthryng ek off the I wyl nat go, but I wyl ffle; ffor thow and I shal han repayr, Nat on the ground, But in the hayr, Wher thow shalt fynde no maner lak; ffor I wyl trusse th√® on my bak, Ber th√® fforth (yt shal nat ffaylle) That thow shalt fel√´ no trawaylle In thy vyag√´, but ful soffte I shal ber th√® hih a-loffte, That thow mayst sen about√´ Round, The se, the heyr, and al the ground; And al that euere ffolkys do, Thow shalt be-holde and sen also.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúYst in thy power, answere me, Thus to ber me, and to ffle?‚Äù Youthe: ‚ÄòTher-to I hau√´ suffysaunce, So yt be to thy plesaunce; And that thow shalt knowe agon, Skyp on my bak, and lat vs gon, And in effect thow shalt wel se How that I shal helpyn the.‚Äô And I, with-out√´ mor abood, Clamb on hyr bak wher-as she stood. To hyre yt was no grevaunce; ffor, as lyhtly (in substaunce) I was take vp in-to lyte, As a chykne off a kyte, Al sodeynly, or I was war; And on hyr bak, fforth she me bar Vn-to the hegh, and was my guyde Stretth vn-to the tother syde. And to that weye she hath me born Wych that I hadde lefft to-forn, And held to me ful wel forward; But gret encombraunce affterward Ther-off ys ffallen vn-to me, And fful gret aduersyte, Wych I shal tellyn in substaunce, As they kome to r√©membraunce. Whan I was passyd the hegh allas, ffynally thys was the caas: Yowthe me brouht (and thus yt stood,) In-to a wey√´ large and brood, And sayde she wolde, off al that day, No ferther ber me on my way. And so, wher yt were sour or soote, She trew me doun. I wente on foote Ay be that hegh, doun costeyynge. ‚ÄúAnd, with-out√´ long taryynge, In the weye that she me sette, An Old√´ wekke a-noon I mette, Hydous and owgly off hyr look; And off hyr shap, good hed I took; Hyr Eyen royllynge in hyr hed, Hyr fface colouryd was lyk led, Hyr noos√´ heng doun to hyr chyn, Hyr mouth fful large, and ek ther-in With hyr teth (as I beheld,) A fful large sak she held; Ther-in a tonge she held also, And Rampawntly she gan to go Vn-to me-ward, off cruelte, Lych as she wolde ha stranglyd me; Gan hyr handys to me strecche, And felly sayde ‚ÄòArrew, thow wrechche! Thow skapyst nat:‚Äô she swor, seyn george, She wolde me stranglyn by the Gorge: Thus yt sempte, as by hyr cher; And I hadde-on no gorger In my dyffence, but drowh abak, And vn-to hyre ryht thus I spak: The pylgrym: ‚ÄúWhat artow,‚Äù a-noon quod I, ‚ÄúThat komyst so dyspytously, Thow Old√´ wekk√´, with meschaunce, ffroward off look and contynaunce; and al that euere I se on the, fful gretly dyspleseth me.‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòI am,‚Äô quod she, ‚Äòas thow shalt lere, Off Epicuris chyldre dere, Verray moder and maystresse, And off that sorte gou√©rneresse: I gouerne hem, (thus stant the cas,) Who that euere her ffader was.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚Äúfful ffayn,‚Äù quod I ‚ÄúI wold√´ se What Epicuriens shold√´ be.‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòThey be (ffor short conclusioun) A sect off thys condic√Øoun, Wych holde, and lern√´ thys off me, That perfyt ffelycyte Ys, that a man lyk hys delyt, ffolwe alway hys appetyt; Ther Sak, ther wombe, (I vndertake,) Off hem ther goddys they do make; Ther Ioye and al ther bysynesse Ys only set in lykerousnesse; ffor, thys Sect alway most thynkes On dyuers metys and on drynkes: ‚ÄòTo thys Sect yt ys endwed, With rost somwhyle, and with stewyd, To be seruyd, and metys bake, Now to ffrye, now steyk√´s make, And many other soteltes. And dyuers ffoundyn out deyntes; ffor al thys sect, I the ensure, Be nat c√≥ntent that nature Yservyd be with suffysaunce; But ther Ioye and ther plesaunce Stant in superfluyte; And hooly ther ffelycyte (Affter ther oppynyoun) Ys in delectacyoun.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúWhat ys thy name? tel on,‚Äù quod I. Glotonye: And she Answerd redyly, ‚ÄòTo sey trouthe, and nat to lye, My name in soth ys ‚ÄòGlotonye.‚Äô My sak, I ffelle vp to the brynke, And neuere I spar√´ ffor to drynke, fful offt√´ whan I ha no nede; And I allone (yt ys no drede) fful offt√´ sythe, off lykerousnesse, ffylle my paunche, off gredynesse, With as mych√´ (trew(√´)ly) As .iij. men myght√´ lyu√´ by, Swyche as hauen indygence; ffor, in Ryot and dyspence, In wast, in reuel and outr√°ges, Spent in gelees and pot√°ges, And dyuers drynk√´s ffor solas, Romney, clarre, ypocras, In malvesyn, and in Osey, The long√´ nyht I daunce and pley, And cess√´ nat to drynke alway; Go to bedde whan yt ys day; And somm√´ clerkys a-mong alle, ‚ÄòCastrimargia‚Äô me calle.‚Äô The Pylgrym: ‚ÄúDeclar√´ me, and nat ne ffeyne, What ‚Äòcastrimargia‚Äô ys to seyne.‚Äù Glotonye: ‚Äò‚ÄúCastrimargia,‚Äù ys ploungyn doun Off mussellys by submercioun; Wyth-out√´ chawyng, doun they launche, Devouryd hool in-to the pawnche; And ther they be so depe ydreynt, In the mawe to-gydre meynt, That my sak, by submercioun, Ys offt√´ tournyd vp so doun. Whan yt ys fful and overleyn, Yt goth out by the gorge ageyn; Over bord, al goth to wrak; And thus I voyde among my sak; The Tempest draweth doun the sayl. ‚ÄòI make tracys, as doth a snayl, With drawlyng on my mokadour, And efft ageyn do my labour (As an vngry wolff, certeyn,) ffor to ffylle my pook ageyn. ‚ÄòI may resemble wel to Bel, Off whom that speketh Danyel, The ydole that devourede al: My bely round, and no thyng smal, And with my nos√´ long and round, I trace affter, as doth an hound, To ffynde the ffwet wher mete ys good; And, by the goolet off myn hood The best√´ goth; yiff that I may, Thys lyff I let√´ nyht and day.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúYet off a thyng I pray the, That thow woldest tellyn me: Yiff thow th√® ffyllest (in thyn avys) Off metys that ben off lytel prys, As off benys or brown√´ bred, (Kome ther any in thyn hed,) Thyn appetyt for to staunche, ‚ÄúSwych hard√´ metys in thy pawnche?‚Äù Glotonye: Quod she, ‚Äòthow shalt ful wel espye, The custom ys off glotonye, As wel (yiff I shal expresse,) In gret√´ metys to don excesse, (Who the trouth√´ wel espyes,) As wel as in del√Ωcacyes; ffor men as wel may doun outr√°ges With ben√´ bred and swyd pot√°ge, Excesse and superfluyte, Als wel as in curyouste: The mete nat causeth the excesse, But the ffretyng gredynesse, They maketh only the Glotoun, And nat the mete in no sesoun: Tast, that ys the pryncypal, And lust ther-off, that causeth al.‚Äô The pylgrm: Than quod I ‚ÄúI pray the, What thyng ys ‚ÄòTast‚Äô? declar√´ me.‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòYiff I to the declar√´ shal, Therby inward passeth al; And ther-in ek myn appetyt Hath specially al hys delyt; Yt ys the mouth off my sachel, Wh√©rby passeth euerydel; By that golet, large and strong, Off mesour nat .iij. Ench√´ long; I wolde, ffor delectac√Øoun, That yt were (off hys ffacoun,) Long as ys a kranys nekke; Thanne I nolde off nothyng wrekke, But only (yiff I shal telle) With fatt√´ mussellys yt to ffelle, With lard, and collopys wel yfryed; How hard they were to be defyed, I wold√´ ther wer ffounde no lak In the stuffyng off my sak, ‚ÄòWych that hath a double mouth, To receyu√´ north and sowth, Al deyntes that may be founde; ffatt√´ mussellys large and Rounde, I threste hem in fful lykerously. ‚ÄòAnd yet myn Eyen be mor gredy, Mor desyrous to do gret wast Than ys my sak outher my tast: To ther desyre, in no wyse Nothyng may ynowh suffyse; Myn Eyen, thorgh none suffysaunce, Don to my stomak gret grevaunce, Mor peryllous than swyrd or knyff, ffor to shorte a manhys lyff; And ffynally, (who that kan se,) Excesse and superfluyte Slen mo men, nyh and ffere, Than outher swerd, dagger or spere.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúSyth excesse and swych outr√°ge Don to the so gret dam√°ge, Off mussellys smale and grete, Why lystow with hem surfeete, Syth thow concludest (in sentence) In surfet ys gret pestylence?‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòWith-Inne my mouth (as thow shalt lere,) I bere A touch, (yiff thow wylt here,) A Touch off gret infecc√Øoun The wych√´, by corrupc√Øoun, Wher that euere he haue repeyr, He infecteth al the heyr, And sleth mo ffolk by vyolence Than any other pestylence. ‚ÄòThat touch, by touchyng redyly, Ys mad so sharpe and so gredy By touch off metys delycat, Thanne he to Resoun obstynat, Mut, with hys touch, touchyn som whyht, Or ellys wolde he, a-noon ryht, ‚ÄòWexyn wod, or by outrage Sodeynly ffalle in-to a rage, Th√® to touche, as yt ys due; The tother touch ay doth hym sue; And semblably, (who lyst to se,) Ryht thus ffareth tast by me, Wych lytel rechchet off my profyt, So that he haue hys owne delyt.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúMa dame,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúwhat euere ffalle, What shal I thys Touch ycalle?‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòThow shalt calle hym, ffer and ner, The ffleynge massager, Off wyng√´s swyft, wych wyl nat dwelle, Euery thyng out for to telle: Al that euere ys in the herte, Ther shal no thyng besyde asterte; And most, a-mong thys ffolkys alle, A shrewd√´ neihbour, men hym calle; Or a clyket fful mortal, Wych opneth and vncloseth al. ‚ÄòAnd hys condicioun ek ys thys, Gladly euere to seyn Amys; And most he doth hym sylff applye ffor to spek√´ vyllenye, And ther-vp-on tabyd√´ longe. Whan he hath dronk√´ wyn√´s stronge, And with deyntes ffeld hys sak, Thann√´ al thyng goth to wrak, What he touchet, I ensure, So ffer he goth out off mesure.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúWhat ar they, off her tongys large, That with wyn hem overcharge?‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòTher-in ys most hys appetyt, And ther-in he hath most delyt. By hym I am out off mesure Brouht, that I may nat endure; ‚ÄòOfft by hym I ffalle in blame, In gret dyshonour and dyffame; ffor he me gaff (who lok√´ wel) Thys sak also, and thys phonel Wyth wych my wyn√´s I vp tonne. And whan that I haue onys gonne To tonnen vp, (as thow mayst se,) I take ther-off so gret plente, Swych h√°boundaunce and swych foysoun, That I lese wyt and resoun, Dyscrec√Øoun, wysdam and mynde, That I kan no wey√´ ffynde To gon vn-to myn own√´ hous, Mad and dronke, as ys A mous. ‚ÄòThan spek I nat but Ribaudye, Outrage and gret vyllenye; I haue noon other Elloquence; ffor than I do no reuerence, Nouther to god, (in no manere,) Nor to hys own√´ moder dere; ffor yiff I shal the trouthe expresse, Whan I am ffalle in dronkenesse, My tong√´ than I gynne to broche, That, yiff Resoun wolde aproche, I bydde hym shortly (thys no nay,) To take hys leue, and gon hys way. And also in my dronkenesse I sey the same to Ryhtwysnesse; ffor thogh prudence and equyte, Sapyence And veryte, Hadden with me tho to done, They sholde be put abak fful sone. ‚ÄòWith sobyrnesse, nor √°ttempraunce, I wyl haue noon √°cqueyntaunce: They be no thyng off myn allye; I haue off hem but moquerye; ffor, wher dronkenesse ys guyde, Ech vertu ys set asyde; And whan with wyn ful ys myn horn, I am ffers as an vnycorn; ‚Äòffor, than bothe, in wrong and ryht, I wyl stryue with euery whyht, Tak vp quarellys, and dyffame, Sette on euery whyht a blame, And, lyk a bole, (yt ys no dred,) Myn Eyen Rollyn in myn hed; Lyk a botore, I haue also Two wombys whan I haue A-do.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúExpown√´ me, √°nd nat ffeyne, Hastow verrayly wombys tweyne?‚Äù Glotonye: ‚ÄòTrewly,‚Äô quod glotonye to me, ‚ÄòI haue tweyne, as thow mayst se, Wych ben ful nyh (who kan espye,) Off the kynrede and allye Off Venus; ffor lykerousnesse Off welfare, and gret excesse, Engendre and cause naturelly fflesshly lust and lechery. ‚ÄòAnd the ffyrst off thys kynrede Ys callyd (who that taketh hede) Off som ffolkys ‚ÄòDronkenesse,‚Äô And the tother ‚ÄòGredynesse‚Äô Off sondry metys and deyntes; And both√´ two, in ther degres, Wyl ther placys occupye, Drynke and et√´ by envye. Evere ther glotons appetyt Ys so ful off ffals delyt, So gredy and so vnstaunchable, Ther Etyk ys so importable; Now I ete, and now I drynke; Tyl I be ful vp to the brynke, I do alway my besy peyne. And trew(e)ly thys wombys tweyne, Wych al devoure, and neuere slake, Mak√´ Venus to a-wake Out off hyr slep, (lyk as I sayde,) And causeth hyre fful offte abrayde. ‚ÄòAnd for that I am glotonye, I dar trewly specefye How Venus (yt ys no ffayl) Euere me sueth at the tayl; We depart√´ seld or neuere, ffor we be to-gydre euere; She wyl nat part√´, yiff she may. ‚ÄòAnd whom that I, be nyht or day, Areste, or mak√´ to abyde, Wher-so that he go or ryde, I brynge hym off entenc√Øoun To ben vnder subiect√Øoun Off Venus; for she and I Confedryd ben so trew[e]ly, That ffolkys vnder my demeyne,‚Äî Swych as be lacyd in my cheyne, Or sesyd, (ther ys no mor to seye,)‚Äî Vn-to hyre they muste obeye.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúI praye, declare a-noon to me, What thyng thys Venus shold√´ be.‚Äù Glotonye: Quod glotonye, ‚Äòwith-out√´ glose, Thow shalt off hyr√´ (I suppose) Hyryn tydynges A-noon ryht, Off hyr power and off hyr myght; And thann√´, yiff thow wylt enquere, What she ys, she wyl the lere.‚Äô And, whyl I stood musynge thus, I sawh a-noon wher that Venus Kam rydynge on a swyn sav√°ge, And in hyr hand, a ffals vys√°ge I sawh hyr bern, fful brood and large, To-fforn hyr Eyen, lyk A targe. Myn Elm was lefft behynde, allas! My ffac√´ bare (thys was the cas); Ageyn Venus vyolence, I hadde as tho no bet dyffence. The pylgrym: ‚ÄúO, thow Olde! what hastow do, Vnwarly me to smyt√´ so?‚Äù Olde venus: ‚ÄòReporte off me, and sey ryht thus, That I am callyd Dame venus. My dwellyng and my manc√Øoun (To me Ordeyn√®d off Resoun) Ys in the Reynys most certeyn,‚Äî Ther wyl no clerk ageyns thys seyn;‚Äî I chace a-way al chastyte, And, werray vyrgynyte: Vyrgynyte, whylom off ryht, To the Aungellys cler and bryht Was suster, and ther nexte allye; But now (yiff I shal nat lye Touchyng parfyt vyrgynyte,) Wher that euere she may me se, She halt hyr nose, and wol be go, Vp-on hyre I stynk√´ so; To hyre I am so gret Enmy, That, but she hadd√´ ffynally ffled ffor hyr savacyoun Whylom in-to Relig√Øoun,‚Äî She hadde (with-out√´ mor refut,) ‚ÄòBe slayn, and dede by my pursuit‚Äî Wher the castel ys so strong, That I may do to hyre no wronge, Nor the fforteress√´ wynne, As longe as she halt hyr with-Inne; But yiff so be (yt ys no doute) That she go a-brood with-oute At large, and haue hyr lyberte,‚Äî As Dina went√´ for to se Wommen off that reg√Øoun, (As holy wryt maketh mencioun) Iacobys douhter (thys the cas) And she a-noon dyffoulyd was, And the slaundre gret arose, Be-cause she kepte hyr sylff nat cloos. ‚ÄòEk I ne haue noon √°vauntage ffor to harme nor do damage‚Äî Nat the valu off An Oystre‚Äî Whyl chastyte kepeth hys cloystre, And goth nat out in no maner, Than ffarvel al my power.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúTel on a-noon, and nat ne ffeyne, What ys thoffenc√´ off thys tweyne, Off maydenhed or chastyte? What wrong han they don to the, That thow hem hatest in thy thouht? And caus√´ why that I do thus Geyn chastyte fful vertuous, Ys ffynally (yiff thow lyst se), She wyl no queyntaunce han with me.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúWherfor seystow in any wyse, And wrongfully lyst to devyse Mong thyn Errours, on and alle, Thys Romaunc√´ thyn to calle? Thy part ther-off ys neueradel; ffor I knowe that man fful wel ‚ÄúWith euery maner cyrcumstaunce, Wych that mad√´ that Romaunce.‚Äù Venus: ‚ÄòThys Romaunce (in c√≥nclusioun), I may calle yt off Resoun Myn own√´ book, (whan al ys do,) And I my sylff made yt also; And yiff that thow consydre wel, Gynnynge, ende, and euerydel, He speketh ther (yiff thow kanst se) Off nat ellys but off me, Except only (yt ys no doute) My clerk, my skryveyn, racede oute Off strang√´ ffeldys as I be-held, And sewh yt in A-nother ffeld, ffolkys wenynge (yt ys no dred) That he hadde sowhe the sam√´ sed Vp-on hys own√´ lond certeyn. ‚ÄòBut to declare the trouth√´ pleyn, He dyde nat so, no thyng at al, In straung√´ feldys, for he yt stal, (Al be yt so by fful gret lak,) He put al in hys own√´ sak Be-caus√´ only (who kan ffele) He caste the trouth√´ to concele; Off surquedye, (yt ys no nay,) Wolde ha born yt with hym away, Al be, sothly, (who haue a syht) He hadde ther-to no maner ryht; ‚ÄòBut affterward he was ascryed By a normaund, and espyed, Wych loude cryede, and made A soun, Yt was no ryht nor no Resoun Off other ffolkys gadryng To make hys berthene by stelyng. But for al that, forth he wente, Nouht abaysshed in hys entente, But bold√´ly, or I was war, fforth with hym hys stelthe he bar, Ympyd yt in in my romaunce, ‚ÄòWych was to me gret dysplesaunce; ffor my wyl was, that he no thyng Sholde ha set in hys wrytyng, No thyng (as to myn entent,) But yt wer to me pertynent, Or accordynge to my matere, Or at the leste (as ye shal here), That he hadde set in no mor But that was off hys own√´ stor: He was askryed off hys ffolye Off On yborn in Normaundye; ffor wych, neuer affter (by couenaunt) He louede neuere no Normaund: The Romaunce kan yt wel declare, In wych he wrot (and lyst nat spare,) That Male-bouche (yt ys no lye) ffledde ffyrst out off Normaundye; Wher-off he made a strong lesyng, Lyede also in hys wrytyng, Off relygious, euele to speke, And vp-on hem to ben a-wreke, To my ffauour (as ye may se) Be-cause I p√∫rsue chastyte.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúThan may I ryht wel certeyn Afferme, that thow and thy skryveyn Ben replevysshed (who kan se) Off malys and inyquyte; ffor who-so, thogh he wer my brother, Wyl gladly seyn evel off A-nother I may off hym seyn (Est and south,) That he haueth no good mouth; ffor with hys tonge (who that touche,) He may be callyd ‚ÄòMal√´ bouche.‚Äô Wherfor trewly thy skryveyn Hihte ‚ÄòMal√´ bouche,‚Äô I dar wel seyn, Whan he (voyde off al ffavour) Gan appell√´ hys neyhbour, Only for he dyde hym ascrye, To seyn the trouthe, and lyst nat lye. ‚ÄúAnd thow (who taketh hed ther-to) Hast a wykked mouth also, Wych, off thyn Inyquyte, Hast lyed vp-on Chastyte, To mak√´ good√´ ffolk hyr haate, And ageyn hyr to debate.‚Äù Venus: ‚ÄòThow seyst soth, (yt ys no drede,) But thow shalt wyte (in verray dede) My condicioun ys to lye; And pleynly, (yiff thow konne espye) Be ryht wel war alway off me; With lyyng I shal deceyu√´ the.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúTel on to me the caus√´ why; Why hastow smet me vnwarly?‚Äù Venus: ‚ÄòWhat trowestow for to go ffre Whyl that I am so nyh by the? Nay, nay! that may nat be-falle. Thow knowest nat thassautys alle Off my werk, nor the manere, But by processe thow shalt lere; Wherso-euere that I assaylle, Off my pray I wyl nat ffaylle; And wher I hurt√´ with my darte, Yt ys ful hard ffor to departe With-outen harm ffro my daunger, Whom-euere I mark√´, ffer or ner, I dar yt swern (in verray sothe) By myn hed ykempt so smothe.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúSyth thow art kempt so sotylly And arrayed so ffressh√´ly, As thow sayst in thyn language, Why hydestow thy vysage That I may nat clerly yt se? ffor som deceyt I trowe yt be.‚Äù Venus: ‚ÄòWher-euere that I repayr, ‚ÄòTrust√´ wel, I am nat ffayr; And yiff I hadd√´ gret fayrnesse, I wolde nat hyde yt in dyrknesse. And thogh that I be kempt ryht wel, Yt ne sueth neueradel That I am ffayr, for in array, Thogh that I be queynte and gay, I am ryht foul for to beholde; My chekys Rympled and ryht Olde, And ful hydous, (yt ys no nay) And mor horryble than I dar say. ‚ÄòAnd ther-for be ryht wel certeyn, I hyde me that I be nat seyn, And holde me euere in placys dyrke, Go by cornerys that be myrke; And I ne haue no maner syth At mydday whan the sonne ys bryht In hys spere ful hih aloffte; And I me putte in pereil offte, Yiff thow knew√´ my pass√°ges, Placys off my gret outr√°ges Wych I vs√´, trust√´ me, Ther-off thow woldest astonyd be: ‚ÄòI Ryde vp-on A cursyd hors, I trow√´ nowher be no wors; ffor placys that be most peryllous, Most horryble and hydous, Most dredful and most vnsure, Ther I logg√´, off nature: Thys my custom, day be day, As a sowhe, in donge and clay, Ther ys my lust most to dwelle; I am mor ffoul than I kan telle: Ryht foul I am in abstracto: But yet mor ffoul in Concreto I am holde, a thowsand ffold; And, therfor, as I ha told, I ber thys wonderful peynture, Thys ffalse vysag√´, thys ffigure, Off entent, in euery place, ‚Äòffor to shrowde ther-with my fface, And my ffeturys ffor to hyde, That men espyen in no syde My scornyng nor my mokerye,‚Äî In ffrench ycallyd ‚ÄòFarderye‚Äô And in ynglyssh, off old wrytyng, Ys ynamyd ek ‚Äòpoppyng‚Äô‚Äî Wych, whan ffolkys ffall in age, Maketh Ryvelys in the vysage, And large ffrowncys I ensure. ‚ÄòAnd, also, ageyn nature, I mak√´ ffolkys ffor to deme By crafft outward, my sylff to seme ffayrere than euere that I was, To looke in merour or in glas. ‚ÄòAlso my condic√Øoun Ys to walkyn vp and doun, Now in towne, now in the ffeld; In O place I abyd√´ seld, But yt be by swych a fortune Wher my lust I may parfourme; I men√´, placys off dyffame, Wych, to r√©herse, ys gret shame; Wher-off my clerk, off whom I tolde, Hath yseyd lyk as he wolde, Spekynge ful outragously, And gaff Exaumple ffynally ffor to speke off dyshoneste, Off entent (as thow mayst se) Out off my slep me to awake, In a-wayt, I shold√´ take Pylgrymes that walk√´ by the way, Hem tareste, and make affray, Off fforc√´ doun hem bowe hyr chyne, And tobey√´ my doctryne. ‚ÄòHe wend√´ I hadde ben a-slepe; But the wey√´s I do kepe Nyht and day, (yt ys no les;) And I am nat rekk√´les, But hem areste in euery place, ‚ÄòWher-so-euere that they pace; Ther skapeth noon, day nor nyht, But yiff yt be only by fflyht; I may nat ffayll√´, ffer nor ner, Yiff myn offycerys done ther dever.‚Äô The pylgrym: Thanne quod I ‚ÄúI pray the Lat me sen hem, what they be; But I leue, in myn entent, That they be nat her present.‚Äù Venus: ‚Äòffor sothe, I haue hem her with me, But I wil nat shewe hem the; Yet neuertheles, yiff thow wylt dwelle, The namys off hem I shal telle: The ffyrst√´ callyd ys ‚Äòraptus,‚Äô The tother ‚Äòstuprum,‚Äô And next, ‚ÄòIncestus,‚Äô The ffourth√´, ‚ÄòAdulterium,‚Äô The ffyffth√´, ‚ÄòFornicacioun.‚Äô ‚ÄòRaptus ffor-soth (by d√©scryvyng,) Ys ycallyd ‚ÄòRavysshyng Off wommen‚Äô (who so taketh hede), A Synne gretly for to drede. ‚ÄòAnd stuprum (with-out√´ wene,) Ys off maydenys that be clene. ‚ÄúIncestus‚Äô ys a synne in dede, A man to taken hys kynrede. ‚ÄòThe ffourth√´ ys ‚Äòavout[e]rye‚Äô With wyv√´s by ffoul lecherye. ‚ÄòAnother ther ys, wych for me Shal nat here rehersyd be, Nor told, in no maner wyse, Wych houeth ynowh to suffyse; And yt shal nat ffor me be wyst, Vnderstond yt as ye lyst. ‚ÄòEch by hym sylff ys vycyous, And to vse, fful perillous; I wyl nat telle hem out at al. But to swych (in especyal) As dwell√´ with me, yong and old, ‚ÄòAnd be with-holde in myn houshold; Yet I dar make descripc√Øoun; They be ffoul off condic√Øoun, Off shap, off ffourme, I the ensure, And ryht lothsom off ffygure. ‚ÄòWith hem I mark√´ many On, Pylgrymes that by the wey√´ gon; Th√® may skapen on no syde. ‚ÄòAnd be ek war, yiff thow abyde, A-mong other, I shal th√® smyte, In abydyng yiff thow delyte; Or thow must be in thy ffleyng, Swyfft as A tygre in rennyng, But, ffor √°l that, I dar say, I shal nat fayllen off my pray, ffor al thy fflyht. whyl glotonye Hath power th√® ffor to guye, Al kommeth to my subiecc√Øoun, Wher she hath domynac√Øoun.‚Äô The pylgrym: ‚ÄúI may yive credence wel her-to, ffor glotonye me told√´ so, That thow or she, selde or neuere, Lyst a-sonder to dysseuere. But, as ffer as I kan lere, Ye ben to-gydre ay yffere: She causeth ffyrst, in substaunce, That I off th√® haue √°cqueyntaunce.‚Äù Thanne glotonye fful redyly Answerd√´, that was fast√´ by, Glotonye: ‚ÄòYiff thow me call√´, in sothnesse, Lyk as I am, A Bocheresse, Or in ffrench (who lok√´ wel) I am callyd a ‚ÄòMakerel,‚Äô Whos offyce (to specefye,) Ys in ynglysshe ‚Äòbauderye;‚Äô And lern√´, (ffor conclus√Øoun,) That ys verrayly my surnoun; ffor, (the soth yiff I shal telle,) ‚ÄòQuyk flessh I vs√´ for to selle; And yet (who vnderstondeth me) I ha lernyd wel to sle Mo bestys (in conclus√Øoun) Than .iij. Bocherys in som toun. But what fflessh euere that I selle, Mor money at the stalle I telle,‚Äî Double (yiff I shal sey soth,)‚Äî Than any other bocher doth; ffor wych, my nam√´ t[o] expresse Thow mayst me calle a ‚Äòbocheresse‚Äô Or a bawde, and no thyng lye, That selleth fflessh by bauderye. ‚ÄòI am no ffyssh (who lok√´ wel) Thogh I be callyd A ‚Äòmakerel,‚Äô Wych in ffraunc√´ ys a name Off gret sclaundre and diffame; And I shal lerne th√®, parcel Off my crafft to knowe somdel: I haue abyde in soth to longe, Thogh my powerys be wonder stronge.‚Äô Venus: ‚ÄòSothly,‚Äô quod Venus, ‚Äòthow seyst wel; But ne dred th√® neueradel, ffor, by the wordys that thow hast told, W√© han √≥n hym fful good hold, Wych shal tourn√´ to no Iape; ffor he may nat our handys skape, Nor, out off our daunger gon.‚Äô The Pilgrim: And by the throt√´ thanne anoon Glotonye held me so ffaste, To grounde almost that she me caste. And Venus gan to neyen ner, And, fful dredful off hyr cher, Gan ley to hand, me to confounde. And they han me so sore bounde, Hand and ffoot, and leggys to, I myghte nat meu√´, to nor ffro; That I dar afferme (and seyn, Who hadde al the maner seyn,) I was lyk (he myghte ha told) Tacalff wych shold√´ ha be sold In som market ffast√´ by, On stallys in the bochery. In swych dysioynt they ladd√´ me, Myn Eyen cloos, I myghte nat se; And for they wolde nat off me ffayl, They bond me to a swyn√´s tayl, I mene, the swyn off dame Venus, fful dredfful and fful contagyous, The wych√´ (by fful mortal lawe) At hys tayl gan me to drawe, And to brynge me vp on the wrak, Thys ylk√´ two that I off spak, Venus, and ek Glotonye, To shewe on me ther tyrantrye, Gan bete on me, and bonch√´ sore. And affter thys, they dyd√´ more; They Robbede me off my treasour; And ffor that I ffond no socour A-geyn ther myght, (as I ha told,) Bothe my syluer and my gold; And nakyd they wolde ha spoyled me, Nadd√´ sothly O thyng be: They sawh on komen ffast√´ by, Vnwar, with a gret company; And pleynly (as I koud√´ deme,) A pylgrym he dyd√´ seme, And a gret lord (yt ys no nay) By lyklyhed off hys array. Venus: Quod Venus thann√´, ‚Äòby my wylle, Lat hym lyn a whyl√´ stylle, Tyl we may, ffrom al daunger, Spoyllen hym at bet leyser. ‚ÄòHer kometh on, me semeth now, Wych ys mor lykly ffor our prow, Wham we tweyn√´ wyl nat ffaylle ‚Äòffor to spoyllen and assaylle; We wyl vs both√´ putte in pres.‚Äô [The Pilgrim:] And whyl they leffte me thus in pes, I koud√´ mak√´ no declyn; So euere in On the cruel swyn Me drowh out off the hih√´ way Among the donge, among the clay, At hys tayl, me to confounde, To wych I was so sor√´ bounde. And whil I lay thus in dystresse, A-noon I gan myn Eyen dresse To be-holde how thylk√´ tweyne Wer dyllygent, and dyde her peyne, The lord tassaylle, that I off spak; And made hym fyrst, fro hors√´ bak, Maugre hys myght, to lyht√´ doun; ffor, mercy nor remyssyoun Ther was noon, on no party; They hym beete fful cruelly; And by the throt√´ they hym took, And pullyd hym so that he shook, Leyde hym low√´ doun to grounde; And hys Eyen so they bounde, That he lost√´ look and syht, Hys force, hys power, and hys myght. And affter that, thogh he wer strong, They gan strechche hym forth along, On a barhyde off A Somer, Lyk a beste off A bocher, Voyde off pyte and off shame. And for he was a man off name (Semynge, by hys contenaunce,) Therfor they took√´ mor vengaunce Vp-on hym, and bounde hym sore; And Venus swyn, with brustlys hoore, Drowh hym forth On the bar hyde End√´long and ek a-syde, By brookys and by sloos fowle, A-mong the clay they hym dyffoule; On hym they wer√´ so cruel, The bar hyde halp neu√©radel; ffor thys old√´ wekkys tweyne Gan hym cerche, and ek constreyne; In euery place they han hym souht; They took hys good, they leffte hym nouht, And to hym dyd√´ gret disesse. And to me yt was noon ese To beholdyn and to se Ther tyranye, ther cruelte; And trew(√´)ly yt sat me sore, That the folk I spak off yore Halp nat hyr lord, but hym forsook, And, noon hed off hym they took, But in hys mescheff lefft hym sool; And lyk as he hadde ben a ffool, They scorned hym, and hadd√´ game, And gan lawhen at hys shame; They halp hym nouht, but leet hym be In hys grete aduersyte, Markede hym in hys mescheff, Ther he lay bounden as a theff, Scornynge at hys bak behynde. And swych folkys men may fynde In many place (yiff yt be souht); Whan a man ys to mescheff brouht, And falle in-to aduersyte, fful few√´ frendys than hath he; At mescheff, they hym for-sake, And but a Iape off hym they make, Al be yt so, that they beforn Wer supported and vp born By hys lordshepe, in ther degre. Whan he stood in prosperyte, Than they wold√´ make hem strong, To stonde with hym in ryht and wrong, With false behestys (as I ha told,) In al hys werkys make hym bold, That they wolde with hym abyde ffor lyff or deth, on euery syde; But fynally, whan al ys do, I ha wyst lordys deceyved so In dyvers contres, mo than on, Whan ther ffrenshepys wer agon. Lat no man trusten on ffortune, Wych selde, in on, lyst to contune. And thus thys man, brouht to the poynt, Stood allone in swych dysioynt, And in gret mescheff, as dyde I; ffor, Venus and Glotony In swych mescheff hadde hym brouht, That off hys lyff he rouht√´ nouht, ffor hys grete aduersyte. But than I gan remembre me As I lay bounden in the place, I wolde assayen ffor to pace The hegh, that was so thykke and strong, Off wych I tolde, nat go fful long; And for mor ese and sofft√´nesse, I thouhte I wolde my syluen dresse To the path on the tother syde; ffor, wher as tho I dyde abyde, Me sempte the plac√´ peryllous, Both√´ dredful and dotous. I gan a-noon to neyhen ner To-ward the hegh, and her and ther I gan consydren in my mynde, Yiff I myghte an hool√´ ffynde To pac√´ by, that wer nat thykke fful off thornys me to prykke. Al thys I gan consydre and se, Swych routhe I hadd√´, and pyte, A-mong the sharp√´ busshys alle, That my body shold√´ falle In any daunger or dam√°ge, Yiff I passed√´ that pass√°ge; Prayd√´ god, for hys pyte, ffrom swych harm to saven me; ffor I stood in fful gret dred, Lyk a bryd that kan no Red, Wych, in hyr gret mortal ffer, Loketh her, and loketh ther, And for dred begynneth quake, Whan she ys in the panter take, Or engluyd with bryd-lym, Al hyr ffethrys fful off slym, Or vnwarly, in heth or holt, Ys y-slayn with arwe or bolt, Whil she ys besy to escape, The ffoulere kan hyr so be-Iape. Ryght so fferd I, al out off Ioynt, Brouht vn-to the sam√´ poynt; But ‚Äòwho that wyl nat whan he may, He ys a fool, (yt ys no nay,) And he ne shal nat whan he wolde.‚Äô ffor whyl I stood and gan be-holde Now her now ther, and for ffer shake, Vnwarly, by the ffeet ytake, I was bounden, and forth lad, That for fer I was nyh mad, And knew nat what was best to do; But, amyd off al my wo, I sawh a wekke, Old and hydous, Off look and cher ryht monstrous, Pyled and seynt as any kaat, And moosy-heryd as a raat. And thys wekke (as I was war) Vnder hyr Arm, an Ax she bar, Lych a bocher that wyl slen Grete bestys, and affter ffleen, And sythen put hem to larder. Lyk swych a womman was hyr cher; ffor bestys at ther ffeet be-hynde, With a corde she dyd√´ bynde, And cordys ek (as I was war) Gret plente, on hyr Arm she bar, And affter, with hyr own√´ hond, Strongly by the ffeet me bond; In the knotte ther was no lak; And thann√´ thus to hyr I spak: Pilgrym ‚ÄúO, thow Old√´ Ryvelede whyht! ffoul and owgly off thy syht! Why artow, off thy cruelte, Kome vnwarly thus on me, ffals, and a traytour in werkyng, And spak no word in thy komyng? I wot, by tooknes off thy fface, Thow kam neuere out off no good place, Nor, thogh thow haddest the Reuers sworn, I wot that thow wer neuer born Off no good moder, out off drede. And as touchynge thy kynrede, Be thyn array (yt semeth wel) I shold yt preysen neueradel. ffle fforth thy way, and cast the bondys That thow beryst, out off thyn hondys.‚Äù [Sloth]: Quod she, (as in conclus√Øoun) ‚ÄòI am no Gerfawk nor fawcoun, Nouther sparhawk nor Emerlyoun, Nor lyk to thyn oppynyoun; Ches nor bellys, nyh nor ffere, To be bounde I wyl nat bere; ffor, al ffre, with-out√´ charge, My lust ys for to gon at large. Slouthe. ‚ÄòTrust me wel, bothe hih and lowe, By ffeyth that I my ffader howe, Thow shalt nat (whan al ys do,) ffro my daunger escap√´ so; But thow shalt, for al thy pryde, Ben arestyd, and abyde, Be caus√´ thow hast ben so bold To call√´ me ‚Äòstynkynge and old;‚Äô And caus√´les thus blamyd me, Wych haue in many a plac√´ be, ‚ÄòIn somer and in wynter shours, In chaumbrys off thys Emperours, Off kynges, dukys, (who lyst sek,) And off gret√´ bysshopys ek, Off abbotys, pryours, and prelatys, And many other grete estatys, Wych neuer was (to ther semynge) Callyd Old√´ nor stynkynge, Wher-off I wyl aveng√´ me; But yiff thow the strenger be, Aud mor off power, than am I. I shal the venquysshe cruelly.‚Äô The Pylgrym: Than off hyre I gan enquere, That she wolde me pleynly lere, and declare, by short avys, Bothe hyr name and hyr offys. Slouthe: ‚ÄòThe trouth√´,‚Äô yiff I shal the telle, ‚ÄòWith a mayster I do dwelle. ffel and vnkouth off hys cher, And ys off hell√´ cheff Boocher; And with thys corde (yt ys no drede) Al pylgrymes to hym I lede, As thys Bocherys don a beste. ffor I am she (my name ys spronge) That lye a bedde with ffolkys yonge, And make hem tourn√´ to and ffro; I close her Eyen both√´ two, I make hem slep√´, dreme and slombre, Yong√´ folkys out off noumbre; ‚ÄòI make the Maryner fful ffast Lyn and slepe vnder the mast, Tyl hys vessel, by som cost, Be ydrownyd and ylost; I brek√´ al hys gouernaylle, By costys, wher as he doth saylle; And myd off many straung√´ se, The wrak ys maad only by me. ffor lak, in soth, off governaunce, I cause that al goth to meschaunce, Ther loodmanage, ther sttuff, ther wynes. ‚ÄòI cause also that, in gardynys, (Who so lyst to looke aboute,) That bremblys, netlys, fful gret route, Wexe and encresse round a rowe, And many weedys that be nat sowe; And for tamende hem, day be day, I putte yt euere in-to delay; ffor I lernede, syth go fful long, The maner off the Rauenys song, Wych by delay (thys the cas) Ys wont to syng√´ ay ‚Äòcraas, craas;‚Äô That song I kepe wel in my thouht, Thys lessoun, I forgete yt nouht; ffor I am slowh and √©ncombrows, Haltynge also, and Gotows, Off my lym√´s crampysshynge, Maymed ek in my goynge, Coorbyd, lyk ffolkys that ben Old, And afowndryd ay with cold; On ech whedyr, I putt√´ blame, And, ther-f√≥re, Slouthe ys my name, Off custom callyd ‚ÄòYdelnesse.‚Äô ‚ÄòThow mayst me calle ek ‚Äòhevynesse,‚Äô ‚Äòffor what thyng euer that I se, Shortly yt dyspleseth me, And, ther-off no tale I telle, ffor, I am the sam√´ Melle That tourneth ay and grynt ryht nouht, Save waste vp-on myn own√´ thouht; ffor they be dowmb in ther spekyng, As an ymage wrouht off Tre or ston; Ouht to seyn, power ha they noon; They may here, but no thyng declare; ffor wych, folk shold√´ no-thyng spare To tellyn out ther synnes and offence To ther curatys wyth humble reuerence, And gaste hem nouht by noon oppynyoun ‚ÄòTo shewyn pleynly ther confess√Øoun; ffor goode prestys (who so taketh hed) In ther kepyng haven greyn and bred, Bred off lyff, sed ek off scyence, And goostly ffoode ek off elloquence, Hys sogetys fructuously to ffeede With doctrine whan that they ha nede. ‚ÄòThe thrydde Corde ys ycallyd ‚ÄòShame,‚Äô Causynge A man, he dar nat attame To tellyn out hys ffautys, nor expresse, Only for dred and ffor shamfastnesse. ‚ÄòThe ffourthe corde callyd ‚ÄòPapyllardie,‚Äô Wych ys a maner off ypocrysie;
