Wych corde ys ffer ffrom all vertu, Off vyces werst (shortly for to telle); ffor he that ys hangeman off helle, With the corde off desperacioun Hangeth all (in conclusioun) ffolk endurat in ther entente, That dysespeyre, and wyl nat repente, Neuer in thys world whyl they ben alyve. ‚ÄòAnd with thys cordys, that be in noumbre ffyve, I shal don al my besy peyne, Yiff that I may, thy throte to restreyne, Hale the fforth, and no lenger dwelle By the way wych ledeth vn-to helle.‚Äô [The Pilgrim]: And affter thys, by hyr grete sleyhte, And hyr Ax that was so gret off wheyhte, Lyk a theff And A ffals ffeloun, She smot ?e so that I fyl a-doun; ffor I ne hadde power nouther myght, On my ffeet for to stonde vp ryht. And affter that, ful sore she me bond With the cordys that were in hyr hond: Over myn throte, ffyrst she gan hem caste, And knette hem affter wonder streight and ffaste; And ffro the hegh, by hyr mortal lawe, Cruelly she gan me for to drawe, Wher-off I felte gret anoy and greff, Lyk taffalle in-to gret mescheff And gret dystresse, only nadde be A whyht dowhe, wych that I sawh fle To-ward hegh, wych my cordys brak, And Ellys hadde I sothly go to wrak; But she was sent vn-to me by grace, Me to socoure in the sam√´ place. And whan I sawh that I was vnbounde, The cordys brak, that wer gret and rounde, Vp on my ffeet I gan me for to dresse; And as I myghte (for verray werynesse), To-ward the hegh I wende ha gon ful ryht; But ther I sawh, fful owgly off ther syht, Two that wern to me ful contrayre, And to my purpos gretly aduersayre, At the pendant off an hyl doun lowe; And on off hem (as I koude knowe) In my beholdyng (lyk as I was war) Vp-on hyr nekke, she the tother bar; And she that was vp-on the bak yborn, Was gretly bolle and yswolle aforn, And in hyr hand she bar a staff fful round, Wych whilom Grew on A werray ground. And off hyr look (in myn inspeccyoun) She was lyk to a ffers lyoun, And hornyd ek as an vnycorn; And in hyr hand also she bar an horn, And lyk a skryppe (ek afferme I dar) A peyre belwys aboute hyr nekke she bar; And she hadde On (as was hyr delyt) On hyr shuldres, A mantel large off whyt, A peyre off spores poynted (soth to say) Lyk the bek off a somer Iay, Shewyng out that she was maystresse Vn-to hyre that was hyr porteresse, I mene, tholde that bar hyre on hyr bak, Whos clothyng was shapyn lyk a sak. But she that rood, off whom I tolde, Maade the tother lede hyr wher she wolde; And she that bar, (ye shal vnderstonde,) Held a large merour in hyr hond, Hyr owgly ffeturys to beholde and se. And than I gan a-noon to remembre me, Seyde, ‚Äúallas! what hap haue I, or grace! All they that I mete in thys place, Ben olde, echon, to-forn and ek be-hynde; I am gretly astonyd in my mynde; They wyl me slen, thorgh som dysaventure, Or me Outrage, I shal yt nat recure;‚Äù ffor she that rood vp-on the olde a-forn, I herde a-ffer, how she blew hyr horn, And ffaste gan affter me to ryde, To me sayde, as I stood a syde, The Olde Pride: ‚ÄòYeld the!‚Äô quod she in al hast to me, Or thow shalt deye; yt wyl noon other be.‚Äù The Pylgrym: ‚ÄúWhat artow,‚Äù quod I to that olde; ‚ÄúWenystow I so sone sholde Yelde me, and know√´ nat thy name, With-out√´ mor? in soth I wer to blame; Thyn offyce ek, and also thy power, Or that I me yelde prysowner.‚Äù Pride: ‚ÄòVnderstond wel ffyrst, and se, ‚ÄòAnd wyte yt wel, that I am she Off all Olde sothly the Eldest: Whylom, in hevene I hadde a nest; And ther I was Eyred and yleyd, And engendryd ek (as yt ys seyd), Thogh yt be hih, and hennys ffer. ‚ÄòMy ffader was ynamyd Lucyfer; Off bryd ther was neuer (in-to thys day) In bussh nor braunche leyd swych an Ey; ffor affter tyme that I Eyred was, Wyth thys belwys (trewly thys the caas) I blewe ther so horryble a blast, That my ffader was a-noon doun cast ffrom that hih hevenly mansioun, In-to helle cast fful low√´ doun: To-fforn he was a bryd ful cler and bryht, And passyngly ffayr vnto the syght, Noble, gentyl, and also ek mor cler Than Phebus ys in hys mydday sper; But now he ys blak, and mor horryble Than any deth, also mor terryble. ‚ÄòAnd shortly ek (in conclusioun) With my ffader I was also cast doun, In-to thys Erth√´ doun ful lowe; And ther I sawh and dyd√´ knowe On ymad ful fressh off fface, ffor to restore a-geyn my place; The wych, whan I dyde espye, At hym I hadd√´ gret envye, And cast√´ that I wolde assay ffor to lette hym off hys way. And with-Inne a lytel throwe, I took my belwys, and gan blowe, And made on hym so fel a suit, I made hym Etyn off the frut Wych was dyffendyd hym (certeyn) Off hys lord, cheff and souereyn; Wher-for he was (after my devys,) Affter chacyd out off paradys; Ther he loste hys avauntage. ‚ÄòThus wrouht I ffyrst in my yong age: And day be day I ne cessede nouht Tyl I hadde gret harmys wrouht; ffor yt am I, both nyh and ferre, That make A-mong gret lordys, werre; I cause al dissenc√Øouns, Dyscord and indygnac√Øouns, And make hem, by ful gret envye, Everych other to dyffye; ffor I am leder and maystresse, Cheventayne and guyderesse, Bothe off werre and off bataylle. I make off plat√´ and of maylle Many devyses, mo than on; And to rekne hem euerychon, Yt wold√´ doun but lytel good. ‚ÄòI causede ffyrst, shedyng off blood; I ffond vp fyrst, devyses newe, Ray√´s off many sondry hewe; Off short, off long, I ffond the guyse; Now streight, now large, I kan devyse, That men sholde, for syngulerte, Beholde and lokyn vp-on me. I wolde be holden ay sanz per, And by my syluen synguler; I wolde also that, off degre, Ther wer noon other lyk to me; Yiff any dyd√´ me resemble, Myn hert√´ wolde for Ire tremble, Ryve atwo almost for tene. ‚ÄòWhat euere I sey, I wyl sustene, Be yt wrong or be yt ryht; And I wyl ek, off verray myght, Be cheff mayster aboue echon: Other doctryne kepe I noon. ‚ÄòI hate also, in myn entent, Good consayl and avys√´ment, And overmor, thus ys yt, I preyse noon other manhys wyt, But myn owne, what so be-falle, ‚Äòffor that I hold√´ best off alle; And me semeth that I kan Mor than any other man; Ther-with I am ek best apayd, No thyng ys wel doun nor wel sayd, By noon off hih nor lowh degre, But yiff yt be only by me Gouernyd al, to my delyt; And ek I wolde ha gret despyt, ffor bothe in hopen and in cloos I wolde be preysed, and ha the loos; ffor I wolde no man wer preysed, Worshepyd, nor hys honour reysed, But I allon√´, mor ne lasse; ffor I holde ech man an Asse Saue I, wych, a-boue ech on, Am worthy to haue the prys allone. ‚ÄòAnd sothly yet, whan men me preyse, Or with laude myn honour reyse, Outward I do yt al denye, And sey ‚Äòyt ys but mokerye That they so lyst my prys avaunce; I sey I ha no suffysaunce Lyk to her oppynyoun, To haue swych commendac√Øoun:‚Äô And al thys thyng√´s I expresse, To shewe a maner of meknesse Outward, as by √°pparence, Thogh ther be noon in √©xistence. I with-seye hem, and swere soore, Off entent that, mor and more They sholde myn honour magnefye To-for the peple by flaterye, Taferme off me, bothe fer and ner, That my wyt ys synguler. ‚ÄòAnd whan I her√´ ther flatrynges, Ther gret√´ bost, ther whystlynges, ffor verray Ioy I hoppe and daunce, I ha ther-in so gret plesaunce, That, lyk a bladder, in ech cost ‚ÄòI wex swoll√´ with ther bost, And thynke my place and my degre Muste gretly enhaunsyd be, And thynke yt sytteth wel to me Tave a cheyre off dygnyte, Lyk as I were a gret pryncesse, A lady, or A gret duchesse, Worthy for to were A Crowne. ‚ÄòAnd whan I se Round envyroune, ffolk me Obeye on euery part, I resemble a ffers lyppart; Off port, off cher, I-rous and ffel, And off my lookys ryht cruel I be-holde on hem so rowe, And gynne to lefften vp the browe Off verray Indygnac√Øoun, Off contenaunce lyk a lyoun, As thogh I myghte the sky√´s bynd: Al ys but smoke, al ys but wynd, Lyk a bladdere that ys blowe, Wych, with-Inne a lytel throwe, Pryke yt with a poynt, a-noon, And ffarwel, al the wynd ys gon, That men ther-off may no thyng se. ‚ÄòAnd lyk as foom amyd the se Ys reysed hih√´ with a wawe, And sodeynly ys efft with-drawe, Th√°t men sen ther-off ryht nowht, Ryght so the waw√´s off my thouht, By pryd√´ reysed hih a-loffte, With vnwar wynd be chaungyd offte. ‚ÄòEch manhys ffawtys besyd√´ me, Saue myn owne, I kan wel se; But I parceyu√´ neueradel Off no thyng that they do wel. ‚ÄòTo all√´ scornerys, in sothnesse, I am lady and maystresse; And off the castel off landown, That off scornyng hath cheff renoun, By Old√´ tyme (as men may sen) ‚ÄòI was som tyme crownyd quen. But the prophete ysaye, Whan he dyd√´ me espye, He cursyde (off ful yore ago,) Bothe my crowne and me also. ‚ÄòMy name ys, ‚Äòthat wyl feynte Euere to be nyce and queynte‚Äô; And I am she (yt ys no dred) That ber an horn in my forhed, Wych ys ycallyd ‚ÄòCruelte,‚Äô To hurt√´ folk about√´ me: Off verray surquedy and pryde, I smyte and wynse on euery syde; Prest nor clerk, I wyl noon spare; And wyth my syluen thus I ffare, Mor cruel, in my ffell√´ rage, Than a Boole wylde and savage, Wych rent a-doun bothe roote and rynd. ‚ÄòI ber thys belwes fful off wynd, I ber thys sporys, I ber thys staff, Wych that my ffader to me gaff; I bere thys horn (who look√´ wel), I were also a whyt mantel, To close ther vnder (vp and doun) Al my guyle and my tresoun. ‚Äòffro tym√´ long, out off memoyre, Thys belwes callyd ben ‚Äòveyngloyre,‚Äô Ther-with to quyke the ffyr ageyn, To mak√´ ffoolys in certeyn, Thogh they be blak as cole or get, Off me whan they ha kauht an het, To semyn in ther own√´ syht That they in vertu shynen bryht, Bryhter than Any other man That was syth the world be-gan, Or any that they alyv√´ knowe. ‚ÄòThys Belwes I made whilom Blowe In the fforge, with gret bostyng, Off Nabugodonosor the kyng, That bostede in hys regioun ‚ÄòThat the cyte off Babiloun Wyth al hys gret√´ Ryalte, Wyth al hys fforce and hys bewte, Was bylt and mad by hym only: Thys was hys bost; and ffynally With thys belwes I made a levene, The fflawme touchyde nyh the heuene, But affterward yt gan abate, Yt lasteth nat by no long date. ‚ÄòAnd as gret wynd (who lyst to se) Smyt al the ffrut doun off A tre, Brawnche and bowh, and levys fayre, And ther bewte doth apayre, Ryght so the wynd off veyn glorye‚Äî Be yt off conquest or vyct√≥rye, Or off what vertu that yt be‚Äî Yt bloweth yt doun (as men may se), Worshep, honour, R√©noun, ffame‚Äî Ther ys in bostyng so gret blame. ffor bryddes that flen in the hayr, And hyest mak√´ ther repayr, Thys wynd kan maken hem avale, Talyht√´ lowe doun in the vale. ‚ÄòHastow, a-for-tyme, nat herd sayd, How for an Exaumple ys layd, That a Reuene, Or north or souht, Bar a chese with-Inne hyr mouht As she fley ouer a ffeld; The wych√´, whan the ffox beheld, Thoght√´ that he wolde yt haue; Sayde, ‚ÄòRavene, god yow saue, And kep√´ yow fro al meschaunce! Prayynge yow, for my plesaunce, That ye lyst, at my prayere, Wyth your notys fressh and clere Syngen som song off gentyllesse, And your goodly throte vp dresse, Wych ys so fful off melodye And off hevenly Armonye; for trewly, as I kan dyscerne, Ther ys harp√´ nor gyterne, Symphony√´, nouther crowde, Whan ye lyst to syng√´ lowde, Ys to me so gracyous, So swete, nor melodius As ys your song with notys clere; And I am komen ffor to here, Off entent, in-to thys place, A lytel motet with your grace.‚Äô ‚ÄòAnd whan the Ravene hadde herknyd wel The ffoxys spech√´ euerydel,‚Äî As she that koud√´ nat espye Hys tresoun nor hys fflaterye,‚Äî ffor to synge she dyde hyr peyne, And gan hyr throt√´ for to streyne, And ther-with maade an owgly soun, Ther whyles the ches√´ fyl a-doun, And the ffox, lyk hys entente, Took the chese, and forth he wente. ‚ÄòAnd thys deceyt (yiff yt be souht,) Was only by my bylwes wrouht, With fals√´ wynd off trecherye, Thorgh the blast off fflaterye, The wych, with hys sugryd galle, Euery vertu doth appalle And bet yt doun on every syde. ‚ÄòTher-for lat no man abyde The wyndes, that ben so peryllous, Off thys belwys contagyous; Lat ech man, (in especyal,) Consydren that he ys mortal, And thynk√´ that swych wynd in-dede Bloweth But on asshes dede, That wyl with lytel blast a-ryse, And dysparpyle in many wyse; And affter swych dyspers√Øoun Al goth in-to perdic√Øoun. ‚ÄòThys belwes ek (yt ys no drede) Causeth (who-so taketh hede) Bombardys and cornemusys, ‚ÄòThys ffloutys ek, with sotyl musys, And thys shallys loud√´ crye, And al swych other menstralcye, With ther blastys off bobbaunce, Don offt√´ tym√´ gret grevaunce; ffor, wyth ther wynd√´s off gret myght, They quenche, off vertu al the lyht; They blowe many a blast in veyn, They seuere the chaff fer fro the greyn. ‚ÄòThys wynd also, (as ye shal lere,) Whan yt taboureth in myn Ere, And with hys blast hath ther repayr, Bereth me An hand that I am ffayr, Noble also, and ryht myghty, Curteys, wys, and ful worthy, With swych√´ wynd√´s cryyng lowd. A-noon I gynn√´ wexen proud; But whan ther wynd ys ouergon, ffrut ther-off ne kometh noon; Al ys but wynd (yt ys no doute,) Turnynge as offt√´ sythe aboute As phan√´ doth, or wheder-cok. ‚ÄòAnd my Tayl, lych a pocok, Offt√´ sythe on heihte I reyse, With swych wynd, whan men me preyse. And whan I ha swych prys ywonne, I swoll√´, gret as any tonne, Lyk to brestyn for swollyng; Ne wer I hadde som √°ventyng To mak√´ the wynd fro me twynne, Wych ys closyd me with-Inne, Me semeth ellys al wer lorn. ‚ÄòAnd, therfore I bere thys horn, Wych that callyd ys ‚Äòbostyng,‚Äô Or voyd√´ pownche, by som lesyng. And trewly, with myn hydous blast, All the bestys I make a-gast, Off my contre, for verray drede, Make hem to lefft vp hyr hed. ‚ÄòAnd offt√´ tyme I boste also ‚ÄòOff thyng wher neuer I hadde a-do, My sylff avaunce, off thys and that, Off thynges wych I neuer kam at. ‚ÄòI boste also off my lynage, That I am kome off hih parage, Born in An hous off gret renoun; That I ha gret pocess√Øoun, And that I kan ful many a thyng, And am aqueynted with the kyng. ‚ÄòI booste and blow√´ offte A day, Whan that I ha take my pray, Or whan that I, (lyk myn awys,) Ha done a thyng off any prys, Achevyd, by my gret labour, Thyng resownynge to honour; Consayl ther-off I kan noon make; Vp with my tayl, my ffethrys shake, As, whan an henne hath layd an Ay, Kakleth affter, al the day; Whan I do wel any thyng, I cesse neuere off kakelyng, But telle yt forth in euery cost; I blowe myn horn, and mak√´ bost; I sey ‚ÄòTru tru,‚Äô and blowe my ffame, As hontys whan they fynd√´ game. Ryht so, whan that I do wel, Avauntyng I tell yt euerydel, And axe also off surquedy, ‚ÄòHath any man do so, but I, Outher off hih or lowh degre?‚Äô ‚ÄòAnd, but ech man herkne me, (Wher yt to hem be leff or loth,) With hem in soth I am ryht wroth, Be yt wrong, or be yt ryght. And I wyl here noon other whyht, But so be I be herd to-forn, Whan that euere I blowe myn horn. ‚ÄòAnd thus thow mayst wel knowen how I resemble the Cookkoow, Wych vp-on o lay halt so long, ‚ÄòAnd kan synge noon other song. ‚ÄòAnd avawntyng (who taketh hed) Ys sayd off wynd (yt ys no dred) Wych ys voyde off al prudence In shewyng out off hys sentence; And on ech thyng (in hys entent) He wyl make an Argument, Sustene hys part and make yt strong, Wher that yt be ryht or wrong, Sette a prys and sette A lak, And preue also that whyht ys blak; And who-euere ageyn hym stryue, He wyl ffyht√´ with hym blyue, And, holdyng hys oppynyoun, Make a noyse and a gret soun ffor to supporten hys entent, Lyk as yt wer a thonder dent. ‚ÄòSomtyme he wyl, off surquedye, ffastyng, gretly magnefye, And prechyn ek (by gret bobbaunce) Off abstynence and off penaunce; And yiff hys pawnch√´ be nat fful, Wynd and wordys rud and dul Yssen out fful gret plente, To make al folkys that hym se, Vp-on hym to stare and muse And to here hys Cornemose: Swych hornys (who that vnderstoode) Ar wont to make noon huntys goode; Hys hornys he bloweth al the day, And Iangleth euere lyk a Iay, A bryd that callyd ys ‚ÄòAgaas,‚Äô Wych wyl suffren in no caas No bryd aboute hyr nest to make, With noyse she doth hym so a-wake. ‚ÄòThus all√´ ffolk that here hys bost Wyl eschewe (in euery cost) Off swych a bostour that kan lye, The dalyaunce and the companye. ‚ÄòAnd off my spores, to specefye ‚ÄòWhat they tookne or signefye, Thow shalt wyte (and thow abyde) That offte I shap√´ for to ryde, And am ful loth, in cold or heet, ffor to gon vp-on my ffeet, Yiff that myn hors be fast√´ by, And al myn harneys be redy. ‚ÄòOn off my spor√´s (in sentence) Ys callyd ‚ÄòInobedyence;‚Äô The tother (in conclus√Øoun) Callyd ys ‚ÄòRebell√Øoun.‚Äô ‚ÄòThe ffyrst√´ mad√´, (by my sut,) Adam to Etyn off the ffrut That was forboode to hym afforn; But thys spore, sharpere than thorn, Maade hym stedefastly beleue The counsayl and the reed of Eue, Aforn ytake out off hys syde; But to the frut she was hys guyde. ‚ÄòThe tother spor√´, hadde also Vp-on hys Ele, kyng Pharao,‚Äî Whylom a kyng off gret renoun, And hadde in hys subiecc√Øoun (As the byble kan wel tel) Al the peple off Israel, And in thraldam and seruage,‚Äî In hys woodnesse and hys rage Wolde nat graunte hem lyberte To gon out off hys contre (In hooly wryt, as yt ys ryff); And, for thys Pharao held stryff Ageyn mor myghty than he was, ffynally (thus stood the caas,) By the spore off Rebellyoun He was brouht to confusioun. ‚ÄòHard ys to sporne ageyn an hal, Or a crokke a-geyn a wal; Swych wynsyng, thorgh hys foly, Ageyn the lord most myghty, Made hym, that he was atteynt, ‚ÄòAnd myddes off the see ydreynt. ‚ÄòHe was a ffool, (yt ys no faylle,) The grete mayster for tassaylle, That ys lord most souerayne; But pryde that tym√´ held hys reyne, Off malys and off surquedye, ffor to trusten and affye In thys spore that I off spak, Tyl he fyl vp-on the wrak. ‚ÄòNow wyl I speken off the staff Wych that pryd√´ to me gaff, And I, to my protecc√Øoun, Bar yt in-stede off a bordoun, And ther-vp-on (for my beste) Off custoom I lene and reste; And who that wolde yt take a-way, With hym I wold√´ mak√´ ffray; I wyl leue yt for no techyng ffor no counsayl nor no prechyng, But, obstynat in myn entent, I voyde resoun and argument; ffor with thys staff (who kan entende) Myn offencys I dyffende. ‚Äòffor thys staff, (in sentement,) Whylom Rud entendement, The cherl, held by rebellioun, Whan he dysputede with Resoun, And callyd ys ‚ÄòObstynacye‚Äô, On wyche (the byble wyl nat lye) Lenede whilom kyng Saul, Whan he (off Resoun rud and dul,) Was reprevyd off Samuel, A prophete in Ysrael, ffor the grete vnleful pray That he took vp-on a day In Amalech, most Rych√´ thynges, As, in the ffyrste book off kynges, Makyd ys cler mencyoun. ‚ÄòAnd I, for my rebell√Øoun, Hatyd am in many wyse, ‚ÄòOff all√´ folkys that be wyse; And ek, thorgh myn Inquyte, I am cheff cause, and mak√´ ffle Grac√´ dieu; to-for my fface She may byden in no place:‚Äî Wher-as I am, she duelleth nouht. ‚ÄòAnd ek also (yiff yt be souht) I caus√´ paynymes, euerychon, ffrom ther Errour they may nat gon, Ydolatry√´ to for-sake, And the ffeyth of cryst to take, ffrom ther errour hem with-drawe, And to kome to crystys lawe; They be blynded so by me, And Indurat, they may nat se To c√≥nuerte as they shold√´ do. ‚ÄòAnd the Iew√´s ek also I nyl stynte, nor cess√´ nouht, Tyl off entent I haue hem brouht To ther ffynal perdyc√Øoun And to ther dampnac√Øoun: I debarre hem from al grace, That the hegh they may nat pace; The hegh, I men√´, off penaunce, Ther-by to kome to r√©pentaunce: I sterte aforn hem (in certeyn) And make hem for to tourne ageyn, ffor to wynse and dysobeye, And to tourne A-nother weye. ‚ÄòEk to the, I wyl nat spare, Off my Mantel to declare, Wych ys fayr by √°pparence, And haueth ek gret excellence, Both off shap and off bewte Owtward (who that lyst to se), ffor couere (yt ys no doute) Al the fowle that ys wyth-oute, As Snowh (who that lok√´ wel) Maketh whyht a ffoul dongel; And lyk also as fressh peynture ‚ÄòMaketh fayr a sepulture On euery party, syde and brynke, With-Inn√´ thogh yt ffoul√´ stynke Off karyen and off root√´ boonys; So thys mantel (for the noonys) Maketh me (in my repayr) Outward for to semyn ffayr, Parfyt, and off gret holynesse. ‚ÄòBut, yiff Outward my foulnesse Wer open shewed to the syht, I sholde be ffoul, and no thyng bryht: My mantel overspredeth al; But who that (in especyal) Inwardly knew√´ herte and thouht, Blowh, and he shal fynd√´ nouht; Wherfor, by descripc√Øoun, I bere the sygnyficac√Øoun In r√©semblanc√´, and am lych Taffoul callyd an Ostrych, Off whom the nature euerydel Ys vnderstonde by my mantel. ‚ÄòThys ffoul hath fethres fressh to se, ffayr√´ wynges, and may nat ffle, Nor fro the erthe (in hys repayr) He may nat soore in-to the heyr; Yet men wolde demyn, off resoun, And wene in ther oppynyoun, By √°pparenc√´, to ther syht, That he wer hable to the fflyht; But he ffleth nat, whan al ys do. ‚ÄòAnd by myn habyt ek also Men myght√´ deme ther-by in al That I were celestyal, Goostly and contemplatyff, Parfyt, and hooly off my lyff, Hable to fflen vp to heuene, ffer aboue the sterrys seuene; And how my conuersac√Øoun Wer nat in erth√´ low√´ doun; But who the trouth√´ kan wel se, ‚ÄòI nouther kan, nor may nat fle; I ber thys mantel but for ffraude, Off ffolk outward to haue A laude; And the name to specefye, Callyd ys ‚Äòypocrysye,‚Äô Therby outward a prys to wynne. ‚ÄòAnd the forour wych ys with-Inne, Off fox skynn√´s euerydel; Al be that, outward, my mantel Ys ywoven (by gret delyt) Off shepys woll√´, soffte and whyt, I were yt on (soth to seye) By fawssemblaunt whan I preye; And who lyst know√´ verrayly, Many men vse yt mo than I, Wrappe hem ther-in, in ther nede, In hope the bettre for to spede. ‚ÄòI covere slouthe vnder meknesse, And gret√´ ffelthe vnder fayrnesse; Sey (whan rathest I wyl greue) Sanctificetur in my be-leve; ‚ÄòAnd as the ffox (yt ys no dred) Maade hym oonys as he wer ded, And off fals fraude, (yt ys no nay,) Mydd√´s off the way he lay, Ded only by r√©semblaunce Outward, by cher and contenaunce; Thus he feynede ful falsly, Seynge a cart√´ pass√´ by fful off haryng (ther yt wente); And the cartere vp hym hente; In-to the carte a-non hym threwh, ffor he in soth noon other knewh. And whyl the carter forth hym ledde, On the haryng the fox hym fedde; He heet hys felle, and wente hys way. ‚ÄòAnd euene lyk, fro day to day, Vnder thys mantel I me wrye, Wych callyd ys ‚Äòypocrysye,‚Äô By wych (erly, and ek ful laat,) ‚ÄòI ha be brouht to hih estaat fful offt√´ sythe, (as men may se) And reysed vn-to hih degre. ‚ÄòBut yiff thys mantel wer asyde, Vnder wych I do me hyde, Off ffolk (that vnderstond√´ wel) I shold be preysed neueradel; For ffolkys wolden at me chace, Hunte at me in euery place, Sette on me ful many a lak. ‚ÄòAnd she that bereth me on hyr bak, I shal the maner off hyr telle, Yiff thow wylt a whyl√´ dwelle.‚Äô The Pylgrym asketh: Thanne quod I, or she was war, Vn-to the old√´ that hyr bar: ‚ÄúCertys, in myn oppynyoun, Off lytel reputac√Øoun, Nor off no prys, thow sholdest be, Be thyn offyce, (as semeth me,) To bern A best so cruel, Vp-on thy bak, Irous and fel.‚Äù The Olde Answerde: ‚ÄòI am she that ful wel kan Scorne and mokk√´ many A man; And to myn offyce, yt ys due, ffolkys lowly to salue. ‚ÄòLordys that ben off gret estaat, On hem I wayte, Erly and late; In wrong and ryght, I kan hem plese, And pleynly to ther hertys ese, fful gret plesaunce I kan do; My song to hem ys ‚Äòplacebo,‚Äô And they ful wel vp-on me leve, I sey√´ nat that sholde hem greue; And thogh they kan me nat espye, Vn-to hem I kan wel lye. ‚ÄòAnd my crafft I thus devyse: I sey to ffoolys, they be wyse, And to folk that ben hasty, ‚ÄòI afferm√´ bold√´ly They be mes√∫rable and ffre, And off ther port fful √°ttempre. ‚ÄòI sey also (off ffals entent,) To ffolkys that be neclygent, That they in vertu be besy; And to tyrauntys, ful bold√´ly I afferme, and sey hem thus, That they off hert√´ be pytous; I swere yt, for to make hem sure. ‚ÄòAnd placys ful off old ordure, I kan strowhe with Rosshys grene, That ther ys no ffelth√´ sene. And I kan sette (or folk take hed) A Coyffe vp-on a skallyd heed: Thys myn offyce, and noon other; ‚ÄòAnd at the kyng√´s hous, my brother, I am welkomyd off euery man, So wel to hem I ples√´ kan, ffor in that court ys no gestour, I yow ensure, nor tregetour, That doth to hem so gret plesaunce As I do with my dallyaunce, They han in me so gret delyt. ‚ÄòYet for al that, myn appetyt Ys to deceyue hem, grene and rype; So swetly with my ffloute I pype, My song ys swettere, hem tagree, Than off meremaydenys in the se, Wych, with ther notys that they sowne, Caus√´ folkys for to drowne With ther soot√´ mellodye. ‚ÄòMy ryht√´ nam√´ ys ‚ÄòFlatrye,‚Äô Callyd ‚Äòcosyn to Tresoun,‚Äô And by dyssent off lyn√´ doun Eldest douhter off Falsnesse, Cheff noryce off Wykkednesse; And all thys old√´ ffolk (certeyn) Her-to-fforn that thow hast seyn, I excepte off hem neuere on, ‚ÄòI haue hem fostryd euerychon With my mylk, on and alle, In tast lyk sugre; but the galle Ys hyd, they may yt nat espye. ‚ÄòAnd, with my mylk off fflaterye I was noryce, and ek guyde, In especyal vn-to Pryde, Vn-to whom, in sothfastnesse, I am verray porteresse. And, that in me ther be no lak, I bere hyre euere vp-on my bak, And ellys she, in sowre and soote, She sholde shortly gon on fote.‚Äô The Pylgrym: Thanne quod I, ‚Äúanswere to me; Thylke merour wych I se, Wych thow beryst, ther-in to prye, Tel on, what yt doth sygnefye!‚Äù Flatrye: ‚ÄòHerdestow neuere her-to-forn Tellyn, how the vnycorn, Off hys nature, how that he fforgeteth al hys cruelte, And no maner harm ne doth, Whan that he be-halt (in soth) Hys own√´ hed, and hath a syht Ther-off, with-Inne a merour bryht?‚Äô The Pylgrym: ‚ÄúI haue herd sayd,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äúryht wel Ther-off the maner euerydel.‚Äù Flatrye: Than quod she, ‚ÄòI wyl nat spare, Off Resoun, Pryd√´ to compare To the vnycorn (off ryht), The wych, whan he hath a syht Off hym sylff in A merour, And beholdeth the rygour Off hys port, he bereth hym ffayre, And gynneth wexyn debonayre. And thys merour (in substaunce) ‚ÄòYs ycallyd ‚ÄòAccordaunce,‚Äô Resownyng ay (be wel certeyn) To al that pryd√´ lyst to seyn, To holde wyth hym in ech degre, With-outen al contraryouste; ffor whyl that folk hys wordys preyse, And on heyhte hys honour reyse, Al that whyle (in sykernesse) Pryd√´ leueth hys ffersnesse, And ellys, lyk an vnycorn, He wolde hurtle with his horn, That no thyng, on se nor londe, Sholde hys cruelte with-stonde. ‚ÄòAnd for thys cause, to my socour, I ber with me thys merour, ffro hys saw√´s nat dyscorde; What-euere he seyth, I accorde And assente ay wel ther-to. ‚ÄòWho vnderstant, I am Echcho Among the rokkys wylde and rage, Wych answere to euery age: To yong and old, what so they seyn, I answere the same ageyn, In ryght and wrong, to ther menyng, And contrarye hem in no thyng.‚Äô [The Pilgrim:] And whyl that I held companye And dalyaunce with fflatrye, Heryng the maner and the guyse Off hyr deceyt in many wyse, I sawh an old on, ful hydous, Off look and cher ryht outragous, Off whom ful sore I dradd√´ me; And in hyr Eyen I dyde se Tweyn√´ sperys sharp and kene; And she glood vp-on the grene, (Me sempte, by good avys√´ment) On all√´ foure, lyk a serpent, Megre and lene, off chere and look; And for verray Ire she shook, Dreye as a bast, voyde off blood, Hyr fflessh wastyd, (and thus yt stood,) Men myght√´ sen bothe nerffe and bon, And hyr Ioynt√´s euerychon. Other tweyne (I was wel war,) I sawh, that on hyr bak she bar, Wonder dredful and horryble, And to behold√´ ful terryble: On off hem (by gret outrage) Veylled was in hyr vysage, That men ne sholde hyr fac√´ se, Nor hyr port in no degre; Hyr lokkys wern ryht Rud and badde; In hyr ryht hand A knyff she hadde, And in hyr lyfft (as sempt√´ me) A boyst with oynementys had she; But hyr knyff, stel sharp and kene, Was hyd, that no man myghte yt sen, Be-hynde hyr bak ful couertly. The tother vekke, that rood on hih, Hadde in hyr hand a swerd also, And (as I took good hed ther-to) End√´long yt was yset, fful off Eerys, and y-ffret Off swych folkys as wer wood. The toon Ende, (thus yt stood,) She yt held with-Inne hyr mouth, Wych was a thyng ful vnkouth. And ther-with-al, she, euere in on, ffast√´ gnew vp-on a bon; And (bettre hede ek as I took,) She hadde also a long flessh-hook, Double-fforkyd at the ende, Sharp and krokyd for to rende. The Pylgrym: Thys thyng√´s whan I gan beholde, Off the wych aforn I tolde, I abrayd with al my peyne; And off hyre that bar the tweyne Vp-on hyr bak I gan enquere, That she lyst me for to lere, And declaren vn-to me Wheroff they seruede all√´ thre, And off that owgly companye They wolde her namys specefye. Envye Answerde: ‚ÄòI merveylle nat,‚Äô ywys, quod she, ‚ÄòThogh [that] thow abaysshed be; ffor the trouthe, yiff I shal seye, We wold√´ mak√´ the to deye Or thow sholdest yt espye. ‚Äòffor I am callyd ‚ÄòFals Envye,‚Äô Douhter to Pryde: whylom I was Conceyved whan that Sathanas By hys cursyd moder lay, Syth√´ go fful many a day; And trustly, thogh I be nat ffayr, I am hys douhter and hys hayr, Who so lyst seke out the lyne. ‚ÄòAnd shortly to determyne, Who so that consydre wel, Ther ys strength√´ nor castel, Nouther cyte, borgh nor toun, But that I, by fals tresoun, Haue hem tournyd vp so doun By slauhtre and gret occis√Øoun. And haue her-off the lass√´ wonder, Whan I devydede hem assonder. ‚ÄòI am that beste (who taketh kep) That devowrede whilom Ioseph, ffor whom Iacob, in gret peyne, Gan to sorwen and compleyne, Sayd√´, in hys mortal rage, How a best√´ most savage Hadde hys chyld falsly devowryd, Wher-off he myghte nat be soc√≥uryd; He ffelte yt at hys hert√´ roote. ‚ÄòAnd vn-to me ys nothyng soote (The trouth√´ yiff I shal expresse,) ‚ÄòBut other folkys bytternesse; And whan I se ffolk lene and bare, That ys my norysshyng and welffare; And thus with me the gam√´ goth: Gladdest I am, whan folk ar wroth; Th√©r mesch√©ff (I yow ensure) Ys my fedyng and pasture; The mylk off other menhys greff, Off my fostryng ys most cheff; And yiff I hadde ther-off plente, I sholde be faat in my degre, And for I ha nat myn Entent Off plente, therfor, I am shent; I wex√´ megre, pale and lene, Dyscolouryd, off verray tene, As I sholde yelde vp the breth; And no thyng so sone me sleth At all√´ tymes, as whan I se Other folk in prosperyte; And ther habundaunce in good, That dryeth and sowketh vp my blood. (The trouth√´, yIff I shal yow teche) Evene lyk an hors√´ leche. ‚ÄòAnd I dar seyn, (in myn avys,) Yiff that I were in paradys, I shold√´ deye, and nat abyde, To beholde, on euery syde, The Ioye and the ffelycyte Off hem that ben in that contre; To me yt sholde be gret√´ wrong, ffor to duellyn hem among; Yt wolde myn herte assonder rende; And platly, to the worldys ende, I dar wel conferme and seye, I, envye, shal neuere deye, Nor in no cas yelde vp the breth; ffor he that ys ycallyd ‚Äòdeth,‚Äô Thorgh-out the world√´, fynally, Shal be ded as sone as I. ‚ÄòI am that beste serpentyne, ‚ÄòWych, off entent, my sylff enclyne, With all√´ folkys to debaate; And all√´ ffolkys ek I haate; I loue no thyng (thys the cas) Hih nor lowe, hault nor baas, In hevene, erthe, nor in the se; I ha despyt off charyte, And ek also, in every cost, I werreye the holy gost; And with thys sperys (in certeyne) Set with-Inne myn Eyen tweyne, I werreye euery maner whyht; I taake noon heed off wrong nor ryht, Reward off no man alyue. ‚ÄòAnd the namys to descryue, Off thys sperys that I tolde, Wych that thow dost [in me] beholde: The Ton ys namyd (Trust√´ me) ‚ÄòWraththe off the prosperyte Off other ffolkys me besyde, Wher that euer I go or ryde;‚Äô The tother callyd ys off me, ‚ÄòIoye off ffolkys aduersyte:‚Äô Yt maketh me glad, and nothyng dul; And with the ffyrst√´ spere, kyng Saul, He afforcede hym-sylff ther-with, ffor taslayn kyng Davyd; Hanger fret on hym so sore, Whan he herde the prys was more Off Davyd than off hym-sylff, allas! Off envye (and thus yt was) He hadde so inly gret dysdeyn, So gret despyt (ek in certeyn) That he ne myght√´ (I ensure) In hys herte the wo endure. ‚ÄòThe tother spere off wych I spak Ther-with was taken fful gret wrak, ffor ther-with, (who that lyst aduerte,) Cryst was percyd to the herte By the hand off Longius ‚Äò(As the gospel telleth vs) Affter hys grevous passioun. ‚ÄòAnd yet (as in conclusioun) Whan he drank Eysel and galle, Scornyng off the Iew√´s alle, Ther mowyng and derys√Øoun Was to hym gretter pass√Øoun In hys suffryng, or he was ded, Than was the sharp√´ sperys hed, Wych, A-mong hys peynes smerte, Rooff that lord vn-to the herte. ‚ÄòAnd thys sperys both√´ two, Yplauntyd ben (tak hed her-to) Myd off myn herte and off my thouhte, And fro me depart√´ nouht; And fro myn eyen (yt ys no doute) Thys two sperys kam fyrst oute; And ther (yiff I shal nat feyne) They be set lyk horn√´s tweyne, And Round abouten envyroun They envenyme as poysoun. ‚ÄòMyn eyen ben off kynd√´ lyk The Eyen off a basylyk, Wych, with a sodeyn look, men sleyth, And maketh hem yeldyn vp the breth; And who that dwelleth nyh by me, He deyeth A-noon as I hym se; Ther may no man hym-sylff for-bere, But my two douhtres that I bere. ‚ÄòYiff thow lyst a whyl√´ dwelle, At bet leyser they may the telle Than may I, (on euery syde) Be caus√´ only that they ryde Vp-on my bak, at ese and reste; flor they ha leyser at the beste, (Who taketh hed) mor than haue I; Therfore oppose hem by and by, What I am, bothe fer and ner, And they wyl telle the my maner.‚Äô The Pylgrym: And fyrst off all√´, tho I spak To hyre that sat vp-on the bak Off Envye, formest off alle, Bytter off look as any galle, As she hadd√´ ben in rage, Shrowdyd to-forn al hyr vysage, Requerynge hyre nat to spare, What she was, for to declare. Tresoun Answerde: Quod she, for short conclusioun, ‚ÄòYiff thow lyst knowe, I am Tresoun; And yiff that ffolkys knewen me, My fellashepe they wold√´ ffle, Eschewe yt, but he wer a ffool, Lete me abyde allone, al sool, Off me, so peryllous ys the suit. ‚Äòffor thorgh me ys execut, Off my moder callyd Envye, Al the malys (who kan espye), Hyr wyl, hyr lust, and hyr lykyng, And hyr venym in euery thyng. And, for hyr-sylff may nat fulfylle Al hyr malys at hyr wylle, Ther-for, off gret Inyquyte, ffyrst to scole she sett√´ me, Bad, I sholde myn hert√´ caste To practyse and lern√´ faste, ffynde a way, by somm√´ vyce T√°compl√Ωsshen hyr malyce, Hyr cursyd fals affecc√Øoun To putte in execuc√Øoun. ‚ÄòAnd I wyl tellyn (off entente) ffyrst wher I to scol√´ wente; Off wych√´ scol√´ (thys the caas), Myn own√´ ffader mayster was; Wych tauhte my suster fyrst to frete, And the fflessh off men to ete, As yt wer√´, for the noonys, Gnawe and Ronnge hem to the boonys. ‚ÄòWhan he me sawh the sam√´ whyle, ‚ÄúKome ner,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòfor vn-to gnyle I se (by cler inspecc√Øoun) Ys hool thy dysposic√Øoun; To lerne and practyse in malyce And in every other vyce, Thow art off wyt and konnyng hable To be fals and d√©ceyv√°ble. Be fals inward, and outward sad, And ther-off I wyl be glad Wherso-euere that we gon.‚Äô ‚ÄòAnd with that word he took A-noon Vn-to me, by gret corage, Out off a Boyst, a fals vysage, Took yt me ful couertly. Vnder couert, to gynne a stryff, I ha the taken a sharp knyff, And also, for mor √°vauntage, In-to thy hand a fals vysage; And with thys .iiij. (who rekn√´ kan) Ther hath perysshed many A man; ffor in Regum, ye may se That Ioab (thorgh hys cruelte, As yt ys kouthe, ageyn al ryht) Slowh Amasa, A worthy knyht. ‚ÄòEk whilom in the sam√´ caas Stood the traytour callyd Iudas, Whan he traysshed cryst ihesu (That blyssyd lord, off most vertu) To the Iewes fful yore agon. And thow mayst Redyn, off tryphon The ffals tresoun, many weyes, In the book off Machabeyes. ‚ÄòAnd al thys tresouns wrouht off Old, Vn-to the I haue hem told, To thyn offyce, as yt ys due, Off entent that thow hem sue; And that thow mayst hem wel reporte, Thyn own√´ moder to counforte, ffor to helpyn hyr ffulfylle The surplus off hyr own√´ wylle, And lat thy couert venym byte. ‚ÄòSpar√´ nat also to smyte Wyth thys knyff, cloos and secre, ‚ÄòWhan thow hast opportunyte; And loke that thow be dyllygent, Wyth thy plesaunt vnyment Tenoynt√´-wyth thy vysage, That men sen nat thyn outrage; Be war that yt be nat apert; Kep al thy venym in covert, Ellys thow dost nat worth a lek. ‚ÄòShew the outward, ay humble and mek, Contrayre to that thow art with-Inne, Whan any tresoun thow wylt gynne; And looke thow tak√´ hed ful offte, With thy wordys smothe and soffte, And with thy speche off fflaterye, To bler√´ many a lordys Eye; ffor, with enoyntyng off swych thynges, Lordys, prynces, and ek kynges, Other many dyuers estatys, Both√´ bysshopys and prelatys, Ha ben ther-with deceyved offte. ‚ÄòBut, for the oynement ys soffte, They han echon (in ther entent,) Savour in that oyn√´ment; They desyre, for ther plesaunce, That ffolkys in ther dallyaunce Sey no thyng that hem dysplese, But al that may be to hem ese, Wher-so that yt be ryht or wrong. ‚ÄòTher-for, my douhter, euer among, Spar√´ nat Ay to be bold; But that thow (as I ha told) In thy speche and thy language, With a fflatryng ffals vysage, Enoynt hem with thys Oyn√´ment. Hih vp on my moder bak, As thow sest, ther-on to Ryde, And she ageyn to be my guyde. ‚ÄòAnd trewly, yiff I shal expresse, I am bekome A gret maystresse ffro poynt to poynt, as thow mayst se, Off that my ffader tauht√´ me, Bothe off spech√´ and language, And to shewe a fals vysage Whan that me lyst in myn entent; And also with the oyn√´ment Off wych I tolde nat longe ago, And with the knyff yhyd also Vnder my cloke: off fals tresoun I ha lernyd my lessoun, And reporte yt in my mynde. ‚ÄòI kan byte also be-hynde With my sharp√´ toth fful wel, And yet ne berk√´ neueradel. Whan she hath any malladye, I make hyr sowpe yt vp a-noon, Whan I ha grounde both flessh and bon. ‚ÄòShe me made gou√©rneresse Off hyr kychene, and maysteresse: Ther kometh no mete in hyr syhte But yiff that I to-forn yt dyhte; And hyr thank for to dysserue, Off straung√´ mes I kan hyr serue, With ffarsyd Erys fful off poysoun Put on A spyt√´ by traysoun. ‚ÄòSwettere than samoun outher karp, My tong√´ ys, that spyt√´ sharp Wych hath the offyce and the charge ffor to make a wound√´ large; Yt kerueth sharp√´, and mor narwe Than any quarel or hookyd arwe, Thogh the bowe be strong√´ bent ffro the place that yt ys sent: Wyth wych fful many a man ys kut. ‚ÄòAnd on thys spyte, the Erys be put, Off folk that yiven audyence, ffor to heryn the sentence And thabomynable sown Off sklaundre and off detraccioun, ffor to lestene hem fer or ner. Myn Awnte (I wot ryht wel also) Wold√´ nat accorde ther-to.‚Äô The Pylgrym: ‚ÄúI wold√´ wyte what thow dost than, Whan thow hast Robbyd thus A man Off hys honour and good√´ ffame: What dostow thann√´ with hys name?‚Äù Detraccioun: ‚ÄòI wyl answere to thy demaunde: I maake a maner off vyaunde Off that nam√´ dout√´les; And next, affter the fyrst√´ mes, Wyth swych A Coolys I hyr serue, Ellys she sholde for hunger sterue: ‚ÄòThys secounde cours (yt ys no dred,) Doth gret good vn-to hyr hed; Whan she hath sowpyd that potage, Off verray custoom and vsage; ffor wych I am mad ‚Äòcusyner,‚Äô And for hyr mouth, ‚Äòcheff potager.‚Äù The Pylgryme: ‚Äúffor auht that I espy√´ kan Sythe tym√´ that the world began, I sawh neuer, nor fond or now, A wers√´ best than art thow.‚Äù Detraccioun: ‚ÄòAl ys trewe that thow dost telle, ffor I am wers than any helle; ffor trewly hell√´ hath no myght To don harm to Any whyht But to the ffolk that he hath bounde. ‚ÄòBut I kan hurte, and make a wounde, Nat only to folk present, But vn-to hem that ben absent. thow callyst thy tonge ‚Äòforswerynge,‚Äô and thyn haunche also ‚Äòlyenge,‚Äô whiche is so halt and corbyd doun); tell me here-on some reson.‚Äù Avarice: quod avaric√´, ‚Äòlay to ere, and anon thow shalt well here, how that I this othar day mett with truthe vp-on the way; withe her was also equite, and both√´ tweyn, I dyd se. of them, as I tok√´ hede, how they begged bothe ther bred; they were so poor√´ both√´ two, for theyr frynd[√´]s wer all go. and yf I shall the truth√´ showe, ‚Äòthis day they ha but frynd[√´]s fewe, ne non) ne shal, yf that I may. ‚Äòand when I met them on the way, I gan to turne the bake full sone; with them I had no thynge to done; for me sempte, to my plesaunce, they myght me no thynge avaunce, nor no profit done to me. therfore from them I gan to fle over the feld[√´]s as they lay, and I ne cept none hygh√´ way, but forthe, lyke myn opin√Øon. as I rann, I fell doune; and with that fall ther was no gayne, but that I cawht a great spavayne vpon my lege, whiche mad√´ me for to halt, as thow mayst se; and sothly yet, (who lok√´ well,) to halt, I hate it nevar a dell. for when with haltynge I am dull, it makythe my sake to be more full; haltynge dothe me more avaunce; therby I mak√´ chevysaunce, for in haltynge is no synne; who dothe vpryght, may nothynge wynn; haltynge me wynnythe many a grote, it maketh me hatter than my cote, that I must my tunge in sothe cast out as a dogg√´ dothe. ‚Äòand than full offe it falleth so, that to the kyng[√´]s court I goo, and am ther, of no man afferyd. and whan I have the law√´s leryd, and am come to hyghe estat, than I become an advocat, and mak√´ folk[√´]s to me drawe, swyche as hav to don with lawe. ‚Äòbut first I swere, with-out[en] doute, my tunge I shall nat puten oute, for ryght ne wronge, ne for no thynge, ‚Äòbut wher I se ryght gret wynnynge. ‚Äòon that party evar I hold, lyche a balaunce of whiche y told, whose tung√´ draweth to that cost, wher the weyht gothe doun√´ most: to that party he wyll nat fyne the balaunc√´ to enclyne. and so fare I when I begyne, to holden ther I may most wyne. ‚Äòwhan folke me pray with all ther myght for to help them in theyr ryght, wher the cawse be grene or rype, a-non as I the money grype, than I dare swaryn, by bone & blood, that theyr cawse is trwe and good, thoughe I know the contrary. and than anon I wyll not tary, for gold and sylvar evar amonge, to mak√´ ryght, thowghe it be wronge; for I can make, vnto hir syght, ryght of wronge, and wrong of ryght; tourne the matere vp se doune, and preue it out by good reson, that in the case there is no lake: and all I do, to fyll my sake withe gold and othar men[n√´]s good, how evar aforne the cas√´ stode. ‚Äòthus haue I told the by resonne, and mad a demonstrac√Øon, why that my tonge (by dyscryvynge) is [y]callyd ‚Äòforswerynge.‚Äô and withe lesyngs, (who lyst know,) vp and downe it is y-sowe; to falshed I do most avauntage, and to truth√´ gretyst damage. and in this plyht, as I the told, ever my purpos I shall hold, that yf the lawe ne chaung√´ nought, I will be fals of word and thought, in every place, wher evar I be, ‚Äòthat no man shall lev√´ me: now I ha told the of my sake. ‚Äòtouchinge the bonche vpon my bake, I wyll to the now specifye what thynge it dothe signefye. this is the boch gret and hydous, with whiche this folke relyg√Øous bene ybonchyd, full many on;‚Äî som, I say, nat everychon, suche as by transgressyon kepe not theyr professyon, as they be bound by theyr degre. ‚Äòand by example, (as thow mayst se,) so as a boche or a fellon ar cawsyd of corrupt√Øon of wyckyd humours & corrupt blood, of colore adust, fervent and wood, and othar suparfluyte; ryght so, ryches and gret plente ar caws√´ that a rych√´ man, as the gospell rehers[√´] can, May in-to heven have none entre, But euen lyke as ye may se, A camell may hym-silffe applye To passen thorugh a nedelyes eye, Whiche is a thyng not credible, But a maner impossible, Thys beste is so encomerous, Off bak corbyd and tortuous, And so to pass√´, no thyng able. ‚ÄòAnd euene lyk in caas sembl√°ble, ffolkis off relygyoun, Bounde by ther professyoun ffor to lyue in pouerte Off ther own√´ volunte, And to pouert hem silffe proffesse, ?eue they be bocchyd with richesse, To gadre vp good in ther bandoun, Tresoure, and greet pocescyoun; ‚Äòffor hard it is ffor hem to trace, Or by so smal an hoole to passe Vp to that heuenly mansyoun, To cleyme there habytacyoun. This lytle hool√´ (who kan se,) Bytokeneth willefful pouerte, Receyued with-outen eny stryffe; ffor, pore we kam in-to this lyffe, And nakyd, (who taketh heede ther-to,) Out off this lyffe we schal eke go. ‚ÄòWherffore late ffolkis good heede take, (Swyche as han this world fforsake,) Hem to preserue by holynesse ffrom the bocche off ffalse richesse, Whiche is a thyng (who kan discerne) That wyl clos√´ the posterne Of Paradys and the entre, And stope the hole off pouerte, Whiche is, to parffyte ffolke, the gate To lete hem in, erly and late, Alle that ben ffounden vertuous In ffolkis eke relygyous. Properte. ‚ÄòThis bocche is callyd ‚ÄòProperte,‚Äô Whiche is afferd off Pouerte; ffor pouerte (as clerkys teche) Is both√´ medicyne and leche To launche the bocche off Properte, And voyde alle superfluyte, And the bollynge in ech√´ syde. ‚ÄòBut Properte dar not Abyde To suffre Pouerte hym to kerue, Leste off the wounde he schuly√´ sterue Leuere he hathe, in peyne tendure, Than pouerte schulde his bocche recure; ffor he is dredefful, and eke arwh, To passe an hole that is so narwh As hym semyth in his devys, Outher to heven or paradys: His herte is no thyng ther-on set. ‚ÄòNow wole I speke off my mawmet. The Mawmet: ‚ÄòAnd off myn ydol that is so oold, Made off siluer and off gold, In the whiche (I the ensure) Is the ymage and the ffygure And the prynte (as thou mayste see) Off the lord off the contre. This is the god whiche, by depos, Loueth to be schutte in hucches clos. Somwhyle, that men may hym not knowe, He wole hym hyde in erth√´ lowe. ‚ÄòThis god kan mak√´ ffolkys blynde, That to his √≥bseruaunce hem bynde; And causith hem, ageyn resoun, To caste her lok√´s low√´ down In-to the erthe, ageyne nature, Hem-silffe so mykel they assure In eerthely tresoure, whiche at o day Schal vnwarely passe away; ffor lawe in erthe, on euery syde, Lyche a moll√´ they abyde; In erthe is hoolly ther labour; In erthe ys also ther tresour; Erthe is ther Ioye and ther plesaunce; No thyng but erthe may hem avaunce; Gold and seluer makyth hem nygh wood; Gold is ther god, gold is ther good; I worschipe gold and my tresour As ffor my god and savyour; Saue gold, noon other god I haue. ‚ÄòI thenke not how I schal be grave In eerth√´ lowe, ther to be ffreete, Corupcyoun and worm√´s mete, Hydous, stynkynge, and horryble, And to loke vp-on, odyble: What may my gold thanne me avayle, Whanne wormes han with me batayle? But here, while I haue lyberte, ‚ÄòThis thyng to-fforne I kan no se, ffor in no thyng I kan affye, But gold and good to multeplye. Gold is my god and my Mawmet; And al on gold myne herte is sette; ffor golde, I dyde fful greet offence, In colys to rost√´ seynt Laurence. For he, off pite (thus it stood) ?aue the tresoure and the good Off holy church√´ ffor almesse, To pore ffolkis he ffonde in distresse. ‚ÄòBut I, in myne oppynyoun, am not off that condicioun: To get√´ good is my laboure, And to awment√´ my tresoure, And (as it is to ffolke fful kouthe,) More in ag√´ thanne in ?outhe, Som tyme with lesynges and with ffablys, Som tyme at chesse, som tyme at tablys, At merels and the botevaunt, At hasard and at [the] devaunt, And at these pley√´s euerychon, My mawmet I worschipe euere in oon. ffor, wher-so it be vyce or synne, I do no thyng but ffor to wynne; To good is al-way my repayre. ‚ÄòAnd, ffor my Mawmet is so ffayre, And ffulffylled off alle plesaunce, Do ther-to som √≥bseruaunce, And knele anoon vpon thy kne, Lowely to his d√´yte. ffor, but thow do with-out[√´] more, Thow schalt abyggen it fful sore; And I schal ellys verrey the; Thow geteste no lenger trewys off me.‚Äô The Pylgryme: And whil√´ sche gan me assayle fful cruelly, as by batayle, Alle sodeynely I dyd√´ sen, How that ?outh√´ wente atwen, Bytwyxen Avarise and me, Cryed trewys, and bad let be. Than ?outhe spak: ‚ÄòDo to hym no vyolence, ffor I am komen in his diffence, Ageynse the to make hym stronge. Thow schalt to hym do now no wronge, (Thow thow be cruel off entent,) While that I am here present.‚Äô Auaryce: ‚Äò?eue thow ne were not ffast√´ by, Thow myghtteste trust√´ ffynaly, That I ffor no thyng wold√´ lette, But that I schulde vp-on hym sette. Thy komynge is not to my pay; Thow haste me lettyd off my pray; ffor the whiche, I am fful wo; But now to hym I may nat do, ffor to ffulffill√´ my talent, While thow art with hym present. But go thi way, and late hym be, And anoon thow schalt wel se, I schal hem cacchen in a trappe, And aresten by the lappe, That he schal not skape away ffro my daungere, ?eue I may.‚Äô The Pylgryme: And whanne that I was at my large, And thought I wold√´ me discharge, ffrom all√´ daunger to go ffre, ffrom Auaryce at lyberte, Thorough helpe and ffavour (in this cas) Off ?outh√´ that my guyd√´ was, I wolde, as tho, no lenger byde, But in-tawod√´ there bysyde I entryd, whiche stood ffast√´ by. And as I wente, alle sodeynely I herde oon wonder lowd√´ crye, And afftir me gan ffaste hym hye, As he h√°dde ben in a rage. And so straunge was his langage, That I ne vnderstood hym nought; ffor I conceyued in my thought, How he that affter me gan gon: ffrenche nor Latyn he spak noon. And in his hand (I was wel war,) A nakyd swerde how that he bar, fful scharp√´ grownd√´ ffor to byte, And redy as he wold√´ smyte, And bade, I schulde me ffast√´ dresse, Kome to speke with his Maystresse. Amydde the way, vpon a lond, With-in a cercle I hym ffond, With-in whiche (so god me save,) I sawgh fful many a ffygure grave, fful meruelous, as in workynge; And he bare armys off A kynge, A Box√´, lyche a Messangere. And trewely, as I neyghed nere, By sygn√´s that I dyd√´ se, I wend√´ so that he hadde be, Hopynge the bette, at lyberte, ffrom al daunger to skap√´ ffre: To whom I spake fful bold√´ly, And seyde, ‚ÄúI merveyl ryght greetly That thow byddeste me ffaste dresse ffor to kome to thi maystresse; And by no tokene that I kan se, I wote not what sche schuld√´ be; ffor whiche, I preye the not to spare, Off hir the maner to declare.‚Äù And he to me in word√´s ffewe, With his ffynger gan me schewe fful ffast√´ by, a mansyoun), Ryght vp, lyche a p√°vyloun; And on the pomel (who lyste knowe) Wonder hygh ther sate a krowe, His whynges splayynge to and ffro; And with the noyse he mad√´ tho, The messangere gan newe abreyde, And vn-to me ryght thus he seyde: The Messangere: ‚ÄòByhoolde ?one habytacyoun And the hygh√´ p√°vylloun: In that place (I dar expresse) There abydith my maystresse, Whiche cessith, nowther nyght nor day, To teche hir scolers what sche may, fful many wonderfful lessouns, And many dyuerse c√≥nclusyouns. ‚ÄòAnd, therffore, I callyd the, That thow scholdeste the maner se Off hir scole, and knowe it offte. And ffor this skele, the crowe aloffte Is sette, (?eue thow kanste espye,) Afftir hir scolerys ffor to crye; That fforby passe, bothe este and west; Thereffore sche hath made there hir nest.‚Äô The pylgryme: ‚ÄúCertis me semyth it were ffolye To kom√´ there, or go fforby, But ?eue I knew√´ (in sentence) What doctryne or what science, To hir scolers sche dothe teche. Thereffore, opunly in thy speche, Declar√´ what it schuld√´ be, Or ellys I wole not go with the.‚Äù The Messangere: ‚ÄòA yer√´,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòand no mo, ther I had to scol√´ go; Couetys√´, off entente, To that scol√´ sche me sente; And sothely, as it semyth me, So I trowe sche dyd√´ the.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúCerteynely that is not so; Though sche and I (both√´ two) ‚ÄúHadde I-ffere longe dalyaunce, Sche made no maner off r√©membraunce Off this scole, in no degre, Off whiche thow spekist off to me.‚Äù The messangere: ‚ÄòThan I dar seyn (as thow schalt ffynde) That it was, out off hyre mynde; ffor at this scole ther comyth no wyght ffor to leern√´, day nor nyght, But ?eue that he, ffirste, (off entent,) Be ffro covetyse I-sent. ‚Äò?it off this scole, (?eue thow wylte dwelle,) The maner, I schal the telle: ffirste, whanne I was heder sent, I wolde, by som experiment, Or by som schorte conclusyoun, Haue preued out my lessoun; ffor speculatyff and the practyk Off this scol√´ be not lyk; ffor specul√°tyff (in sentence) With-outen good experience, Avaylith lytle or ellis nought, How longe euere that it be sought. Now take heede, and thow schalt se I wolde hau√´ dygnyte, Or som other greet tresour, And ther-on sett√´ my labour; And wold√´ knowe, to this estat Wher I schal be ffortunat. ffirste, with my swerd, vp-on the ground I make a cercle large and round, With karectis and with ffygures, And know√´ not the √°ventures, Nor the dirkenesse hydde with-Inne, Off the karectis, whanne I gynne To emprynte: al they be sene, I wot√´ neuere what they mene; Saue I conyecte yt may so be, That spiritis scholde obeye to me, ‚ÄòBy my invocacyouns To answere to my questyouns, Swyche sperytis as I kalle; And ?it I knowe noon off hem alle, Saue off entente, as thow mayste se, That they schuld√´ graunt√´ me Som maner gyffte, or som gerdoun, Concernynge myn oppynyoun, By vertu off the cercle round, And Carectis graven in the ground, By schewynge or by √°pparence, Affter that I ?eue credence.‚Äô The pylgryme: ‚ÄúAlle that thow doste specyffye, Is but ffalsehed and ffantesye And cursyd ymagynacyoun, Brouth in ffirste by Illus√Øoun. ‚ÄúThis scole is nought, in sotheffastenesse, Whos doctryne is but cursydnesse. The scolers there-off, I holde hem wood; Swyche spiritis may don to the no good; And ?eue thow koudeste the trouthe entende, Harme they may, but not amende: They wole wyrke in thi dam√°ge, But no thyng to thyne √°vauntage, Who that kan lok√´ wel aboute. ‚ÄúAlso thi siluen stante in doute Where-off thi cercle schold√´ serue; And thyng√´s that thow doste obserue, Alle is but ffoly and mysbyleve, Towchynge the spiritis, thow mayste wel leve; ffor the they wyl no thynge do wel, ffor they the louen neuere a del.‚Äù The Messangere: ‚ÄòI Dar afferme (with-out√´ slouthe) In party that thow haste seyde trouthe, Excepte oonly (it is no nay) In many thynges they help√´ may, A man greetly to magnyffye, Encresse also, and multeplye, Whanne they be c√≥nstreyned to do so, And haue no power to go ther-ffro, Comaunded to swyche √≥bseruaunce By hym that hathe the gouernaunce I mene the kyng, to whom, eche weye, Mawgre ther myght, they muste obeye.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúI conceyue, and se wel here, Thow art the kyng√´s messangere, By the armes that thow dost were, And by the sygnes I se the bere; But mak√´ demonstracyoun To me off thi comyssyoun, By what power or by what peyne Th√°t thow mayste hem so constreyne.‚Äù The Messangere: ‚ÄòCommyssyoun I haue neuere on; And trewely I dar ax√´ non; And though I dyde (as thow schalt se) He wold√´ graunt√´ noon to me.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúThanne wote I wel, (?eue it be sought,) ffor the, that they wole do ryght nought.‚Äù The Messangere: ‚ÄòHere vp-on, what so ?e seye, Wot√´ wel they wole obeye Pleynely vnto my byddynge; ffor they wene that, off the kynge I hadd√´ fful auctorite, Commyssyoun and fful pouste, To maken them, lyche myn entent, To √≥beye my comaund√´ment By vertu off myn orysoun, Karectys and coniurysoun; ffor drede off whiche, (be wel certeyn,) I knowe they dar me not with-seyn.‚Äô The Pilgryme: ‚ÄúWher thow be wel or yuel apayd, Take good heed what thow haste sayd: Thow haste ben ffalse in thi workyng, ‚ÄúAnd wrongely don vn-to thi kyng; Wher-ffore thow shalt I-ponysshed be ffor thi greet Inequyte, To make spiritys the to obeye, And swych√´ charges on hem leye By disseyte and ffalse tresoun, And, haste no commyss√Øoun ffor the to schewe on see nor lond, And haste I-made eke, with thyn hand, Karectis and cercle round, And compassid it vp-on the ground; And art so blynd, thow kanste not seen, On no party, what they mene. ‚ÄúAnd swyche karectis (I dar wel telle) Be markis off the deuel off helle, ffirste ordeyned (who kan conceyue) Innocentis to disceyue. And thow mayste also (trust√´ me) There-with thow schalt dysseyued be; ffor this selis, thow schalt ffynde, Constreyn√´ the, and sor√´ bynde By a maner √°llyaunce To do the deuel swyche √≥bseruaunce Made to thi conffus√Øoun, As bonde or oblygacyoun; By whiche he wole (off verrey myght) Cleym√´ the his man off ryght; By swyche a tytle, make hym stronge. ‚ÄúAnd to spiritis thow doste greet wronge, Hem to constreyne in thi workynge To brynge th√© other menn√´s thynge, (Be it by day, be it by nyght,) Vn-to whiche thow haste no ryght; Where-in thow art greetly to blame, To bydde hem in the kyng√´s name Or constreyne hem, ageyne resoun, By karecte or by comyssyoun, To robbe or steele, to thi ffavour, Off other ffolk√´s ther tresour, By verrey fforce, ageyn√´ ryght. ‚ÄúAnd ?eue thow loke about√´ ryght, To the kyng, vsynge this vice, Thow doste fful greet preivdice Ageyne his lawefful ordynaunce, Where it is boden (in substaunce) And dyffendid, (who kan espye,) Alle maner theffte and robrye, In peyne off deth: take heede her-to, And with-drawe thyne hand ther-ffro With al thi myght and al thy peyne. Thow standeste in daunger atwene tweyne; Outher off God or off Sathan Thow art off the leeg√´ man; And therffore, ffor to lyue in reste, Leeue the worste, and cheese the beste; ffor (schortly I schal devyse,) Thow schalt be quytte lyke thi servyse, In hell√´ with dampnacyoun, Or heuene, to thi savac√Øoun.‚Äù The Messangere: ‚ÄòOf thy word√´s I take hede, They putt√´ me in fful greet drede: But, o thyng comfforteth me, Whanne that I considere and se There is so greet a companye, Me to susteyne in my ffolye, Off ffolkis that to-fforne haue be Off wonder greet autoryte, As whylom was kyng Salamoun, And Virgyle, off greet renoun, Cypryan and Albalart, And many an-other in this art, Maystres by experyence, And hadde also ther-to lycence (With-outen eny noyse or stryffe,) ffor to vse it al her lyffe. ‚ÄòAnd this ilk√´ craffte also (Who that takyth heed ther-to,) Is not in rewarde so perillous, Dredefful, nor superstyc√Øous, ‚ÄòAs som crafftis that haue be do With sacriffyce, and eke also With √≥bseru√°unces, vpon mownteynes, In des√©rte, and eke in pleynes, And in placis fful savage, Solytarye, and fful off rage, That, alle the maner ffor to noumbre, It wolde a man greetly encombre, As thow schalt se and knowe anon ?eue thow lyste with me to gon; And ffynally, thi pas to dresse To hir that is the cheff maystresse Off alle this thyng that I haue tolde, That, ?eue thow be hardy and bolde ffor to proche to hir presence, Thow schalt haue fful experyence.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúThat euere I schuld√´ this thyng se, God, off his grace, dyffend√´ me; And he be my proteccyoun Fro thylk√´ habytacyoun! ffor, by opene evidence, And by recorde off thi sentence, Thilk√´ place, with-out√´ wene, To good it doth no-thyng partene; ffor, by the crowe that sytte aloffte, Makyth noyse and cryeth offte, It schewith wel how thylk√´ place Is devoyde, and ffer ffro grace, And longeth (as I rehers√´ kan) To the Deuel and to Sathan; ffor, save the Deuel, noon other wyght Hathe power there, off verray ryght. Therffore I wole me holden heere, And to that plac√´ kome noon nere; And trew√´ly, (to my devys,) Thi-silff also (?eue thow be wys,) Thow schalt wysely with-draw√´ the, And abyd√´ here with me ffor thyne own√´ √°vauntage, ‚ÄúLeste it turne to thi damage; ffor, who gothe to that mancyoun, Gothe streytte to his destruccyoun, As ther haue do fful many oon, Whiche here-to-fforne haue theder gon, Resemblynge (as I kan devyse) To hym that was the Duke of Fryse, Whiche, whanne he shuld ha be baptisyd, (In storye as it ys devysed, And as bok√´s kan wel telle,) His o ffoot was putte in the welle, To haue receyved cristis lawe, But he in haste gan it with-drawe; For hym thought he herde a cry, That affermed certeynely, ffor synne and ffor Inyquyte, How mo ffolke schuld√´ dampned be At the day off Iug√´ment, Gon to helle, there to be brent, ?e mo (as in comparisoun) Thanne ffolk ffor ther savacyoun Scholde that day receyued be, To dwelle in heuene, that ffayre cyte. But this duke, hym-silff to encombre, Seyde with the gretteste nowmbre, And wold√´ go, thorough his ffolye, And with hem hold√´ companye, There-with affermynge, in his thought, That, off baptysme, he sette nought. ffor whiche, me semeth it were ffolye, The to halden companye With swyche ffolke in thyn entent, Off whiche affter thow schalt repente. ‚Äúffor I suppose that Salamoun (Off whom thow madest mencyoun) Wher in-ffectte, or hadde his parte, In his day√´s, off swyche arte, As som ffolk seyne, (who kan entende,) That hym-silffe he dyde amende ‚ÄúOff that and many another thyng, To-ffore the hour off his deiyng, And resceyued was to grace, And hath in heuene a dwellynge place. And semblabely, the tother man, The gret√´ clerke callyd Cypryan, To-fforne his deth, lyste to fforsake This craffte, and ffor Crystis sake, Suffred (as made is mencyoun) Martirdam and passyoun, And is in heuene stelleffyed, And with seyntis gloreffyed. Take heede to hem, by reed off me, And not to hem that dampned be. Thenke on hem that ben in blysse; And where as thow haste don amysse, With-drawe thy ffoot, and do penaunce, And haue in hert√´ r√©pentaunce.‚Äù The Messangere: ‚ÄòCertys,‚Äô quod he (‚Äò?eue thow lyste se,) That thow seyste, ne may not be. And therffore I abasched was, And sawe no bette reffute to me, But ffro that plac√´ ffor to ffle; ffor he (schortely, in sentence) To whome I neuere dyde offence, Me to bryngen in-to distresse, Gan to callen his maystresse To kome vpon me in greet rape, That I schulde hir not escape. And sche, off ffalse entencyoun, Kam out off hir p√°villoun Affter me, that I wente abak, Hydous off look, oolde and blak, Off whom I greetly was afferd. In the mydde off a book, sche heelde a swerd; Other scawberk hadde sche noon; And, as I byhelde anoon, Sche hadde (in sothe, as thought√´ me) Larg√´ whyng√´s ffor to ffle. And, by a maner ffelonye, Sche gan loud√´ ffor to crye; And, me manasynge off pryde, Bad me that I schulde abyde; And ellis, mawgrey al my myght, I schulde not skape out off hir syght Til I hadd√´ in partye Somwhat seyne off hir maystrye. And towarde me hir look sche caste, And gan to come vp-on fful ffaste; But as sche kam, it sempt√´ me, That sche sate hygh vp-on a tre, And pleynely gan to speceffye, Hir nam√´ was ‚ÄòNygr√≥mauncye,‚Äô Whiche, by my craffte (in substaunce) Kan ffolke encresse, and wel avaunce, That ben in my subieccyoun And lyste to leern√´ my lessoun. This ilk√´ book that thou wolte se, Is I-callyd Mors Anime, Whiche is in englysche (ffor to seyn,) ‚ÄòDethe off the sowl√´,‚Äô in certeyn. And this nakyd swerd whiche I hoolde, (As thow mayste thi silffe byholde,) There-with (ffor schorte conclusyoun,) Whanne thow haste herd√´ my lessoun, There-with thow schalt yslayn√´ be. And thus sche gan manass√´ me, Where-off I stood in fful greet drede; But off grace, (as I toke hede) A whit√´ dowu√´ I dyde se ffleen sodeynely toward√´s me; But with me, where as I stood, Sche ne made no lenger abood. And I ne made no greet delay, But went√´ fforthe vp-on my way; And I mette (or I was war) An oolde oon, whiche that ffagot bar Vpon hir bak, and eke therto, In hir hand sche heelde also A peyr√´ cysours scharpe I-grownde. And, to me-ward as sche was bounde, Sche bad (ffor schorte conclusyoun) ffor to leye my skryppe adoun; And gan vp-on me ffor to ffrowne, Lowd√´ cryed, hir lyste not rowne: Heresye: ‚ÄòFor but thow ley√´ here adoun, I schal, to thi conffusyoun, Schape thi skryppe off newe array, ffor it is not to my pay; ‚ÄòI schal it kutte in other wyse, Lyche as my-syluen lyste devyse.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúThow oold√´ vekke, as semeth me, That thow mayste not clerely se; Wherffore me lyste, by thi byddynge, ffor to do no maner thyng, But ?eue to-fforne I knowe and se Thy powere and thyn autorite; Thy worke also, and thyne office, I wole ffirste knowe in myn avyce.‚Äù Heresie: ‚ÄòFor pleyn√´ly, off lasse and more, Evene afftir my ffadris lore, I wole (off both√´ ffalse and trewe,) The skripp√´s kutte and schap√´ newe, Off pylgrym√´s greet and smale, Kutte hem alle on pecys smale; ffor it was I, my-silffe allon, That schope the skrypp√´s ?ore agon; ffirste, off this Pellagyens, And also off these Arryens, And off other sectys newe, ffound√´ ffals√´, and vntrewe, As oold√´ bok√´s speciffye; ffor I am callyd ‚ÄòHeresye,‚Äô The whiche do alwey my labour To bryng√´ ffolke in greet errour, That ffolwe my condissiouns; Only by ffalse oppynyouns, Make her hertis to declyne ffro the trouthe off Iuste doctryne, And cause hem ffor to don ther cure, And amys to expowne hooly scripture. ‚ÄòAnd, trew√´ly, nadd√´ bene The greet√´ counceyle at Nycene, Ordeyned by greet Constantyn, And nadde ben also Augustyn ‚ÄòAnd many other greet doctours ffor to anull√´ myn errours, The skryppes off holy churche echon, I hadde ffor-don (fful ?ore agoon,) Off pylgrymes that passe by the way, Sythen goon fful many a day. ‚ÄòAnd ?it I schal, what so byffalle, Assayl√´ th√© amonge hem alle, And myn oold√´ purpos holde, In ffyre, though that I brenn√´ schulde, I wole my wytt√´s alle applye, Hardyd with obst√Ωnacye, Contynue til the ffyre be hoot; Therffore I ber√´ this ffagot. ‚ÄòAnd ffirste, thow schalt me not escape, But newe I wole thy skrypp√´s schape, Or ellis I dar vndirtake Th√°t thow schalt it here fforsake, And leve it with me vtterly: My ffader is here ffast√´ by, Whiche hathe power (as thow mayste se) And both√´ vp-on londe and see, Thow schalt not skape hym (in certeyne,) But with daunger and greet peyne.‚Äô The Pylgryme: Myne eyen tho I gan vnffolde, And anoon I gan byholde In the wey√´ me byfforne, An hunt√´ stood√´ with his horne, Off chere and look√´ ryght pervers. And the passage, in travers, With cordes he gan it ouere-leyne, ffrette with nettys alle the pleyne. And he brought in his companye The ffals√´ vekk√´ Heresye. And, that men schulde hym wel knowe, His horne he gan fful lowd√´ blowe; As it were to catche his pray, Ryght so he blew√´ on the way, Bad his doughter Heresye, The passage so to kepe and guye, That I scholde not, in no syde, ffrom ther damage my sylffe provyde. And trew√´ly (as I haue sayd) The nettys were so narewe layd, On lond, on water, and in the hayr, That I myght haue no repayr To pass√´ ffreely that pass√°ge. It was so fful off mortal rage, Off daunger and adversite, That, but yiff I amydde the see Durst√´ swymme, ther was no way ffor me to pass√´, nyght nor day. And there he dyde also malygne To leyne out nettys, and assigne, There to stoppen my pass√°ge; So that I ffonde noon √°vauntage, ffrom his dawngere to declyne; ffor many an hook and many a lyne Were caste in-to that peryllous se, Off entente to letten me; That, mawgre alle my fforce and myght, But ?eue I kowd√´ swymme aryght Amonge the wawys ffeerse and ffelle, I muste vndir his dawnger dwelle. But ffirste, while he his trappys leyde, Vnto the hunt√´ thus I sayde: The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúHvnt√´,‚Äù quod I, ‚Äútelle me now, What maner officere arthow, Whiche [thus] lyggeste on the way, Vnlaweffully to cacch√´ pray, Thus to mak√´ thyne arestis, Namely on the kyng√´s beestis? I trowe thow haueste no lycence ffor to don so greet offence; I dar afferme (eerly and late), Swyche hunters, the kyng doth hate; ‚ÄúAnd it semyth, by thi manere, Off his, thow art noon officere.‚Äù The hunte: Qvod he, ‚Äòwhat makystetow swyche stryff? Thow art wonder Inquysytyff, Besy also, by argument, To hoolde with me a parlement, By lang√°ge, and longe pletyng; ffor, though I longe not to the kyng, (And thow conceyue aryght I-wys,) Som tyme I was oon off his; And though I hau√´ no cong√© Off hym, to hunte in this contr√©, He suffryth me here, in this place, At his beestis ffor to chace, And assaute on hem to make. And whanne that I by fforce hem take, Be it by day, be it by nyght, I cleyme hem to ben myn off ryght.‚Äô The Pylgryme: And while I herde alle his resouns And ffrowarde oppynyouns, Myne herte abaschyd, gan to colde, Namely whanne I gan byholde Pylgrymes, by greet aduersite, fful many oon swymme in the see; And they were clothyd euerychon. And som off hem, I sawe anoon, Ther ffeet reversed vp so doun; And som (in myn inspeccyoun) Swomm√´ fforth fful euene and ryght; And som hadde whyng√´s ffor the fflyght, That afforcyd hem silff fful offte For to fflowe fful hygh alloffte. And though ther purpos was so sette, The see hath hem fful offt√´ lette; Somme, by the ffeet were bound√´ stronge With knottys, off herbis longe; And somme, with waw√´s wood and rage, Were ysmytt in ther vysage, That they losten look and syght, And ffeble were off fforce and myght: And, by dyuerse √°pparaylle, The rag√´ so gan hem assayle, In many another dyuerse wyse, Mo than I may as now devyse. The Hunte: ‚ÄòI do fful wel,‚Äô quod he, ‚Äòespye Where-on thow castyste so thyne eye. ffor alle thy wyl√´s and thi Iape, Thow schalt not so ffro me eskape; I schal the cacch√´ by som crook; I haue leyde ffor the, las and hook, As thow mayste thy-syluen se: Thow schalt not skapen by this see.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúTelle me anoon, and ly√´ nought, As it lythe, ryght in thy thought, These pylgrymes all√´ that I se, Who hathe thus putte hem in thys see?‚Äù The hunte: ‚ÄòIs not this,‚Äô quod he anoon, ‚ÄòAn hygh√´ way ffor ffolke to goon Therby, alle day in ther vyage, Swyche as goon on pilgrymage? I hadde not ellis (as I haue seyde) Myne hookys and my nettys leyde, To cacchen all√´ in this place ffolke that fforby here do pace; ffor this greet√´ larg√´ see Which√´ that thow here doste se, It is the world, ay fful off trowble, fful off many wawys dowble, And fful off woo and greet torment, In whiche fful many a man is schent, With bellewys blowe on euery syde, Which that myne own√´ douhter, Pryde, Is wont√´, with hir ffor to bere, Good pylgrym√´s ffor to dere. ‚ÄòAnd many a pylgryme thow mayste se Swymme in this per√©lous see: S√≥mme off hem, (whiche is not ffeyre,) Ther ffeet han vpwarde in the ayre; And all√´ swyche (?eue thow lyste se) Ben thylk√´ ffolke that charged be With the sak off couetyse, And ouere-lade in many wyse, That they, to swymm√´ be not able, Ther burthen is so Import√°ble; Whiche, by ffalse affeccyoun, Ploungith her heed√´s low a-down Vnder the wawys off this world here, That they may not (in no manere) Swymm√´, ffor the hevynesse That they bere, off greet rychesse. Other ther ben that swymmen ryght, And haue eke wyng√´s ffor the fflyght; And tho ben ffolkis whiche, in this lyffe, In hert√´ ben contemplatyffe, In wordely thyng haue no plesaunce, Save in ther bar√´ sustenaunce: In this world, ther Ioye is nought; ffor alle ther herte and alle ther thought, And ffynal truste off ther workynge, Is sette vp-on the heuenly kynge. ‚ÄòBut ffor alle that, (I the assure,) In this see they muste endure Bodily, by greet penaunce, In hevene hem sylff√´ to avaunce. And, ffor the love off crist ihesu, They make hem whyng√´s off vertu, To ffleen (by clene affeccyoun) To the heuenly mansyoun; Whiche greetly displesith me, Theder whanne I se hem ffle. Swych√´ ffolke resemblen alle Vn-to a bryd that clerkes calle Ortigometra in ther bokys; And this bryd caste his lokys ‚ÄòTo-fforne hym prudently, to se Whanne he schal swymm√´ in the see: This ffoul hath whyng√´s ffor the fflyght, Be he anoon off kyndely ryght. Whanne he is wery off travayle, And that his ffederes do hym ffayle, Anoon (off his condiscyoun) In-to the water he fallith doun, And thanne to swymm√´ wole not ffayle: Off his o whynge, he makith a ssayle, Amonge the sturdy wawys alle To kepe hym silffe, that he not ffalle, Til he resume ageyne his myght, Off acustom, to take his fflyght. Thus stound√´mel ?e may hym se, Som tym√´ swymme, som tym√´ fflee, In bokys as it is I-ffounde. ‚ÄòBut they that hau√´ ffeet I-bounde With herb√´s and with wed√´s greene, That they may not aryght sustene, Nowther to swymm√´ nor to fflee, They be so bounden in the see Off wordely delectacyoun In ther inwarde affeccyoun; ffor alle ther hool ffelicyte Is sette in veyne prosperite Off the world, and in rychesse, fful off chaunge and dowblenesse, With whiche they be so sor√´ bounde, That her soulis yt wole conffounde; ffor they haue power none, nor myght, Nowther to swymme nor ffleen aryght; So sore the world doth hem constreyne, That it were to hem greet peyne, Her hertis ffro the world to vnbynde. ‚ÄòAnd som also be makyd blynde, Ther eyen cloos, they may not se, ffor to considere the vanyte Off this worldis ffalse veyneglorye, Euere vnsure and transitorye, ‚ÄòAnd fful off mvtabylyte, Whiche schewith to hem fful greet bewete By a maner off √°pparence, But it is ffalse in √©xistence; That is fful ffoule, dothe schew√´ ffayre, Lyche a ffloure that dothe vnapayre Whanne it is plukkyd and leyde lowe, Or with som sodeyne wynde I-blowe. Whiche bewete (as wryte Salamoun) Is but a ffalse decepcyoun; And ffolkis that beth there-with blente, Or they be war, beth offt√´ schente, ffor lak ther eyen be not clere. ‚ÄòEke som ther swymmes (as ?e may leere) With hand and armys strecchyd out; Swyche as parte her good aboute To por√´ ffolkis that haue neede; And swyche vnbynde her ffeet, in deede, ffrom wordely delectacyoun, And off devoute entencyoun, By councel off her c√≥nffessour, Vnbynde her ffeet, by greet labour, ffor to goon in there vy√°ges, Barffote, to sek√´ pilgrym√°ges; Off ther synn√´s to haue pardoun, ffor?euenesse and remyssyoun, Whanne ther menynge trew√´ly Is voyde ffrom al ypocrysy. And thus as now (without√´ slouthe) To the I hau√´ tolde the trouthe. ‚ÄòAnd trewely ?it, ouere alle thyng, I hat√´ trowthe in my workyng; And off malys, bothe day and nyght, Werrey trouthe with al my myght. ‚ÄòBy nam√´, callyd I am Sathan; The whiche, as ffer as euere I kan, I worke, in myne entencyoun, ffor to cacche, in my bandoun, Alle pylgrymes (as thow mayst se,) That swymmen in the wawy see ‚ÄòOff this world, fful off disseyte. ‚ÄòAnd euere I lye in greet awayte, And no moment I ne ffyne ffor to leyne out hook and lyne. ‚ÄòMy lyne (by demonstracyoun) I-callyd is Temptacyoun; And whanne that ffolke (in ther entente) Off herte and wylle ther-to concente, Thanne on myn hook (by ffalse awayte,) They ben I-cacchyd with the bayte; And thann√´, by fful mortal lawe, T√≥ my bandoun, I hem drawe. ‚ÄòI leye out nett√´s nyght and day, In water and lond, to cacche my pray. ‚ÄòWith nettys, I haue eke my repayre ffor bryddes that ffleen eke in the hayre, ffor to make hem ffalle adown ffrom ther contemplacyown. And, thus ffolkys to bygyle, I am a ffoulere eke som whyle; ffor alle that hygh or low√´ goon, I mak√´ nettis ffor euerychoon, (In myne entente, it is no drede), To cacche hem, outher by ffoot or hede, As an vreyne wewyth a calle, To mak√´ fflyes there-in to ffalle. ‚ÄòBut I ne may not do no wronge To ffolke that ben in vertu stronge. I venquysche (nouther nygh nor fferre) No man that halte ageyne me werre; And ffeble is my vyolence, Whanne ther is manly r√©systence. And ?it I haue a thowsande treynes, And as many laas and cheynes, With whiche I compasse, day by day, To lett√´ pylgrymes on ther way; ffor I, by ffalse illusyoun And by dyssumylacyoun, Kan me transfform√´ (anoon ryght,) To lykenesse off an aungel bryght; ‚ÄòTake off hym the r√©semblaunce, The vesage and the contenaunce, So to disseyuen, in couert; And to an heremyte in desert; I dyde oon√´s so appere, fful off ffetheres bryght and clere, And toke on me the message Off an aungel, by my vysage, And bad vn-to that hooly man To kepe hym warly ffrom Sathan, ffor he was schapen, by batayle, The nexte morewe, hym to assayle; And tolde hym also, (ffynally, ffor to disceyve hym sotylly,) He wold√´ tak√´, (in sothenesse,) Off hys ffader the lyknesse, Bothe vesage and contenaunce, The maner and the r√©semblaunce. ‚ÄòAnd bad the heremyte anoon ryght To fforce hym, at the ffirst√´ syght, To smyte hym ffirste, with knyffe or swerde, And no thyng to ben afferde With al his myghtty vyolence, Whanne he cam ffirste to his presence. And so, vpon the next√´ morewe, ffor to encresse his dool and sorewe, I made his ffader hym vesyte; And anoon, this seyde heremyte, This Innocent, thys cely man, Wenynge hit hadd√´ be Sathan, Vp sterte anoon, and toke a knyff, And raffte his ffader off his lyff, That he to ground√´ ffel downe deed. ‚ÄòAnd thus I kan (who takyth heed) A thousande wey√´s, ffolke dysceyue, Or they my treyn√´s kan conceyue. And therffore, be wel war off me, ffor I caste eke dysseyu√´ the; ?eue I at larg√´ may the ffynde, ‚ÄòIn my laas I schal the bynde; ffor, as seynt Petre lyste endyte, And in his pystelys ffor to wryte, I go and serch√´, day and nyght, With alle my fforce, with al my myght, Lyche a ravenous lyoun, ffor to devoure, vp and doun, All√´ ffolkys, ?onge and oolde, That lambre be off cristis ffoolde. I haue off hem, fful ?ore agoon, Off hem devoured many oon; Strangelyd mo than I kan telle; And that were to longe to dwelle, ffor to rekene hem alle in nowmbre, Thousandis mo than I kan nowmbre; And trewely, in two hundred ?er, I koude not tell√´ the maner Off alle my treyn√´s by and by. ‚ÄòAnd I warne the outerly, Thow schalt not lyghttely (?eue I may,) ffro my daunger skape away.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúWher thow be wel or yuel apayd In the wordes that thow haste sayd, I haue ffounden a greet dyffence, To make ageyne th√©, r√©sistence, And conceyued it in my thought. Blowe thyne horne, and spar√´ nought, ffor thow schalt ffayle (?eue that I may) To make off me schortely thi pray.‚Äù And to be more stronge in vertu, With the crosse off crist ihesu, And off his grac√´ moste benygne, I gan me crossen, and eke sygne, ffor to assur√´ my passage Ageyne his laas so fful off rage. And by my crossynge, I anoon Gan to passe hem euerichoon; They hadde no power ffor to laste; ffor, by the vertu, they to-braste; And I anoon gan ffast√´ fflee, And wolde haue taken anoon the see; But, longe or I entter myght, Whan Sathan off me hadde a syght, He gan to crye (so stood the cas) ‚ÄòOut and harow! allas, allas!‚Äô Sathan the hunte weymentith And tormentyth with hym silffe. ‚ÄòVnhappy, and fful off meschaunce I was, whanne I dyde me avaunce In any wys√´ ffor to teche Vertu, or trowth√´ ffor to preche; ffor, it longeth not to me To tech√´ trouthe in no degre; But, off ffortune it happ√´ so, That I be c√≥nstreyn√´d ther-to, By vertu off som orysoun Or by som conyurisoun, That greet√´ clerk√´s me compelle, The verrey trowth√´ ffor to telle, Mawgrey my wylle, off many a thyng, By vertu off the greet√´ kyng. ffor ellys (who that kan espye) My purpos is, euere ffor to lye, And haue disseyued fful many a man, Ryght as dyd√´ Iulyan. ‚ÄòThough I were by hym constreyned, And by his charm√´s greetly peyned, ?it at the laste, whanne I abrayde, I ly√´d, alle that euere I sayde. And now I oughte a-cursyd be, Whanne that I gan medle me To seyne a trouthe agayn√´s kynde, Sethen men, in me may noon ffynde; There-off I r√©pente me fful sore, With trowth√´, medle I wole no more.‚Äô The Pylgryme answerth to Satan: ‚ÄúO Sathan, thi displesaunce Was to me fful greet plesaunce, ‚ÄúReleuynge me off my distresse.‚Äù I took there-off greet hardynesse, Made as tho no lenger lette, I spared nowther hook nor nette, But, trustynge (in conclusyoun) Vp-on my skrippe and my burdoun, And there-vp-on I bylened me Whanne I entryd in-to the see; And, in swymmynge to be more stable, Me thought my skrypp√´ proffitable To kepe me sure in herte and thought, In my way, that I err√´d nought. Trewely, in this dredefful see, Is greet myscheeff and aduersyte: Many a perel (I ?ou ensure,) And many a straung√´ √°venture I ffelt√´ tho in my passage, Off wawys and off rokkis rage, And many a tempeste (in certeyn) Off thondrynge, lyghtnynge, and off reyn, And other perels that be-ffelle, That, ?eue I schulde hem all√´ telle, Or the mysch√©v√´s alle endyte, They were to long√´ for to wryte. But while that I, in my pass√°ge, Byheelde the see, sterne and sav√°ge, Me thought I sawe bysyd√´ me, That there stood a green√´ tre; And I was glad alle thilk√´ while, Wenynge there hadde ben an yle, In hop√´ that I schuld√´ londe, Hastely, vp at som stronde, Whiche was to me fful greet plesaunce.
