I dyde my labour and my cure, In hope my syluen to assure, Yiff I myhte, by hap or grace, To draw√´ to som other place. And whyl I lay thus in A trance, In gret Anoy and p√©rturbaunce, I herde a voys mellodyus, Wonder soote and gracyous, Wych was to me ful gret plesaunce; ffor I forgat al my grevaunce, My dool and al my pass√Øoun, Wyth mellodye off thylk√´ soun. But as I stood thus in a wher, And drowh√´ me toward the ryver, A Tour I sawh, wylde and savage, And squar abouten, off passage, Wych hadd√´ Round√´ ffenestrallys, Percyd thorgh, vp-on the wallys; At wyche hoolys, (out off doute,) Smoke and flawm√´ passede oute; And yet thys tour (who lok√´ wel,) Tournede abouten as a whel Vp-on the fflodys Envyroun, Wyth the waw√´s vp and doun. And in thys whyle, euer Among, I herd√´ a melodyous song, Off On (as I koude vnderstond,) That ber a phetele in hys hond; And thys menstral (soth to seyne) Was departyd evene a tweyne: ffrom the myddel vp, A man, Donward (as I rehers√´ kan) A bryd wynged merveyllously, Wyth pawnys streynynge mortally. And thys best√´ ful savage, Lyk a man off hys vysage, Spak to me fful curteysly; And thus he sayd√´ muryely; Gladnesse off the World: ‚ÄòTel on to me (and sey nat nay,) What maner solace, or what play Lovest thow best: tel on, lat se, And I shal pleyn to-for√´ the; ffor I kan (lych to thyn entent) Pleye on euery instrument; And, for to mak√´ lordys cher, Bothe at ches and the cheker, The drawhtes ther-off, ful wel I kan, Ye bet than any other man. And whan that ylk√´ play ys do, ffor shepperdys I kan also, At the merellys, best off alle, Whan so that they lyst me calle, Pype and taboure in the strete, Wyth lusty folkys whan I mete. ‚ÄòAt weddynges, to do plesaunce, I kan karole wel, and daunce; In euery play I do excelle. And wyth that ffyr despytous, He maketh folkys amerous; And with the flawme he kan enbrace, ffolkys hertys to han solace In worldly Ioy√´ (at A word) Mor than in ther sovereyn lord. ‚ÄòThe folkys wych, in ther desyr, That nyht and day brenne in thys ffyr, Ar thylk√´ ffolkys (fynally) Wych that brenne so fervently, Worldly goodys, whan they be-gynne, To encressyn and to wynne, Gret tresour to multeplye; In the wych they mor affye Inwardly, in ther entent, Than in the lord, that al hath sent. fflowynge and ebbynge in thys se, Som tyme with gret prosperyte, Somwhyle, whan the tourn doth varye, The world they fynde to hem contr√°rye; Al goth to wrak; they may nat chese; And thogh so fall√´ that they lese, And fynde ffortune in nowncerteyn, Yet they wylle hem awntre ageyn To sayllen in thys perillous see, So ful off mutabylyte; ffor the hoot√´ smoky ffyr Neuere quencheth, in her desyr. And by his sleyhtys, thus Sathan, He hath deceyvyd many A man. Let now se, and make no Iape, ‚ÄòWher thow hys treyn√´s kanst eskape.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúWyth-Out√´ long processe to make, Hys tour and hym, her I forsake; And, (short√´ly to specefye,) Swych√´ pley√´s I defye, Wych bryng a man in sorwe and shame. And doun I sat, ffor werynesse, And gan compleyne in gret dystresse: ‚ÄúAllas,‚Äù quod I, (myd off my wo,) ‚ÄúAllas, allas! what shal I do? How shal I, wrechche, eskape a-way Out off thys yl√´? weyllavay! ffor, by .v. And now I stonde in so gret drede, Helpe me in thys gret√´ nede!‚Äù And whyl I gan me thus compleyne, Evene A-myd off al my peyne, I sawh, A-myddys off the se, A shyp√´ saylle towardys me; And evene above, vp on the mast (Wherfor I was the lasse A-gast,) I sawh a croos stonde, (and nat flytte,) And ther-vp-on, A dow√´ sytte, Whyt as any mylk or snowh, Wheroff I hadd√´ Ioye ynowh. [Grace Dieu]: ‚ÄòWhat ys al thys?‚Äô A-noon quod she; ‚ÄòWhens komestow? wher hastow be? fful longe (as thow shalt vnderstond) I ha th√® souht, On se and lond, God woot, in ful good entent; And yt wer mor convenyent That thow sholdest, affter me Ha souht, wher that I hadd√´ be. Breke the smal√´ here and ?onder, And the greete muste goon assonder. Thus the schippe off religyoun Gothe offte to distruccyoun. So, wold√´ god, ther lyvynge Were lyk√´ now ther gynnynge, The schipp√´ scholde the better preve, Ageyne al tempeste hym-silffe releve: It were almesse, by the roode. ‚Äò?it I hoop√´ som are gode, Swyche as to holynesse entende; And who doth not, god hym amende! The pylgryme: ‚ÄúPorter,‚Äù quod I, in haste, ‚ÄúI preye the, At this castel graunte me entre, ffor Grace dieu hathe me hyder brought, Off the entre that I ffayle not.‚Äù The Porter answerith: Qvod the porter anoon to me, ‚Äò?eue I knew√´, and dyde se That the kyng wolde it avowe, Thyne entre I scholde alowe; But the wyll√´ off the kyng There-off I knowe no maner thyng.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúTelle me thanne, lyke myne entent, Is the kyng hym-silffe present?‚Äù The porter answerith: ‚ÄòTrust√´ wel, as thow schalt leere, I wolde not ellis sytten heere: It is a sygne (eerly and late,) Whanne thow seeste me at the gate, To telle (by good avys√´ment,) The kyng hym-silffe ys here present.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúTelle me thy name, off gentillesse, With-outen eny straung√´nesse.‚Äù The Porter answerith: ‚ÄòAnd I schal telle the with-out schame: Drede off god, that is my name; Whiche is ground (with-out offence) Off wysdam and Sapyence. I voyd√´ synne, and vyces chace, That noon may entren in this place; ‚ÄòNowther oolde nor ?onge off age Schal have heere noon herbergage; ffor this staffe (?eue thow take heede) With the greet parlom of leed, Is I-callyd (in substaunce) ‚ÄòOff god almyghtty, the vengaunce;‚Äô And there-with-al, in cruel wyse, All√´ synners I chastyse. ‚ÄòAnd with this ylk√´ sturdy Maas, I putte hem out a fful greet paas; ffor noon swyche (?eue thow lyst√´ lere,) Ben hardy to entre here.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúSyre, I praye the, oonly off grace, I may entren in this place; ffor myne entente and my menynge Is to do servyse to the kyng.‚Äù The Porter answerith: ‚Äò?eue I knewe that it were so, With-outen many word√´s mo Thow scholdeste hau√´ graunte off me, To entren at good lyberte.‚Äô The Pylgryme: ‚ÄúIn other wys√´ neuere a del Wole I not entren in this castel, But ffor to do the kyng servyse.‚Äù And thann√´, in fful goodly wyse, I was leten in off the porter: Hym lyste to mak√´ no daunger. Aboute I went√´, byholdynge Vp-on many a rych√´ thynge; I sawe A cloystre and A dortour, A chapytlehous and A ffreytour; And there-with-al, a ffayre Hostrye, And a larg√´ ffermerye; And, off God, thanke to dysserve, ffayr√´ meyn√´ I sawgh there serve. And, I suppos√´ ffor my beste, There to herborewe and to reste, On ther cam, and preyed me, And hir name was Charite. To pylgrymes, in goodly wyse, Sche dyde moste trewely the servyse. The Pylgryme: And as I lokyd heere and ther, I stood in a maner wher, What tok√©n√´s it myght be, The thyng√´s that I dyd√´ se; Prayed hir in goodly wyse, That sche wolde anoon devyse There-off by exposicyoun, A cleer sygnyffy cacyoun. My ffoode is soote and cherischynge, And ryght hoolsom in tastynge; Whiche ffoode is delyuered me By on whom that thow schalt se; ffor sche is bothe A Mercer Off this place, and cheeff Cloystrer.‚Äô The Pylgryme: Lyke the desyre whiche that I hadde, To that lady sche me ladde; Whiche (schortely to speceffye) Plente hadde off Mercerye, And moste delytable off syght, Sche hadd√´ Merours ffeyre and bryght. Agyographe: ‚ÄòHyt were good to hye and lowe, That all√´ ffolk√´s schold√´ knowe, And there-off hadde a trew√´ syght, Iustely what this merour hyght, That ffolk√´s (ffor greet lak off lyght) Were not deceyued in her syght.
